CHAPTER 1

mnga' sde chen po og la ho ma zhes bya ba'i yul 'di'i dmar mdangs chags pa'i yul ljongs hril po dang / skya mdangs babs pa'i yul ljongs kyi cha shas 'ga' rer/ ches mjug mtha'i char pa thengs 'ga' zhi 'jam gyis babs byung la/ char pa 'bab thengs de dag gis ser gas gang ba'i sa gzhi 'di gtol ma thub/ sa zhing steng gi chu phran rgyug shul rnams rmos gshol gyis phar gshags tshur gshags yang yang byas yod/ mjug mtha'i char pa 'bab thengs de dag gis ma rmos lo tog mgyogs por skye ru bcug song la/ gzhung lam 'gram gnyis su ldum bu dang rtswa sngon gyis khyab par byas song / de bas/ da ni dmar mdangs chags pa'i yul ljongs dang skya mdangs babs pa'i yul ljongs gnyis ka khebs g.yogs ljang khu zhig gi 'og nas rang rang gi kha dog mi mngon par 'gyur bzhin gda'/ spyi zla lnga pa'i zla smad tsam du/ nam mkha' thal mdog tu 'gyur mgo brtsams song la/ dpyid dus nam mkha'i mthongs su rgyun du dpyangs pa'i sprin tshom rnams kyang yun gyis thor song / dgung gi nyi zer de yar skye bzhin pa'i ma rmos lo tog gi steng du nyin 'phror nyin mthud de 'phros pas/ ljang mdog gi lo ma re re'i mtha' mtshams su rim bzhin smug mdog gi mtha' thig re babs song / sprin tshom 'ga' re yud tsam la mngon rjes/ yang bskyar med par 'gyur 'gro la/ yud tsam gyi rjes nas sprin pa de tsho yang bskyar mkha' dbyings su phyir slebs e thub ma bltas/ sa gzhi'i ngos su sa shun chags song la/ sa shun de dag ni srab cing mkhregs por gyur/ nam mkha' thal mdog tu gyur pa dang chabs cig tu/ sa gzhi'ang thal mdog tu gyur song / yul ljongs dmar po de zing skya ru gyur song la/ yul ljongs skya bo de dkar po ru gyur song /

TO THE RED COUNTRY and part of the gray country of Oklahoma, the last rains came gently, and they did not cut the scarred earth. The plows crossed and recrossed the rivulet marks. The last rains lifted the corn quickly and scattered weed colonies and grass along the sides of the roads so that the gray country and the dark red country began to disappear under a green cover. In the last part of May the sky grew pale and the clouds that had hung in high puffs for so long in the spring were dissipated. The sun flared down on the growing corn day after day until a line of brown spread along the edge of each green bayonet. The clouds appeared, and went away, and in a while they did not try any more. The weeds grew darker green to protect themselves, and they did not spread any more. The surface of the earth crusted, a thin hard crust, and as the sky became pale, so the earth became pale, pink in the red country and white in the gray country.

rgyug chus gshags pa'i grog shur dag tu/ thal rdul gyis tshos pa'i chu phran skam la ma skam pa tsam re yod/ a bra dang seng ge grog ma tshos sa 'bur chung chung re 'phen mgo brtsams/ tsha shugs can gyi nyi zer de nyin 'phror nyin mthud de 'phros pa'i rkyen gyis/ ma rmos lo tog gi lo ma rnams sngar ltar mkhregs po dang drang mor gnas ma thub/ lo ma de dag la thog mar ltebs gnyer shor song la/ de nas rim bzhin dbus kyi rtsib ma'i 'dzin shugs je zhan du gyur nas/ lo ma re re bzhin mgo bo thur du 'khyogs/

In the water-cut gullies the earth dusted down in dry little streams. Gophers and ant lions started small avalanches. And as the sharp sun struck day after day, the leaves of the young corn became less stiff and erect; they bent in a curve at first, and then, as the central ribs of strength grew weak, each leaf tilted downward.

de ltar spyi zla drug par bslebs song la/ nyi 'od sngar las kyang tsha/ ldum bu rnams rnyid ral du gyur nas rim bzhin so so'i rtsad pa ru phyir 'khums song / rlung bu ldang ba nyung la/ nam mkha' sngar las kyang skya mdog red/ sa gzhi ni nyin re nas nyin rer je skya red/

Then it was June, and the sun shone more fiercely. The brown lines on the corn leaves widened and moved in on the central ribs. The weeds frayed and edged back toward their roots. The air was thin and the sky more pale; and every day the earth paled.

rmon dor rnams yang yang du song myong zhing / 'khor lo'i rigs kyis sa ngos bcag bcag tu btang myong la/ rta pho'i rmig pas kyang sa ngos su thag thag tu rdung myong sa'i gzhung lam ngos kyi sa shun rnams la da lta gas kha brgyugs pas/ rim bzhin rdul phung du gyur/ dngos po 'gul skyod re res thal rdul de rnams bar snang du 'gyogs/ rkang thang pa zhig song tshe/ khos rang nyid kyi sked mtshams la slebs pa'i thal rdul zhig slong la/ shing rta zhig song tshe/ des ra ba'i rtse la slebs pa'i thal rdul zhig slong / rlangs 'khor zhig song tshe/ des rang nyid kyi rgyab phyogs su thal rdul gyi sprin phung zhig 'khrigs su 'jug la/ de nas dus yun ring po zhig gi rjes su thal rdul rnams yang bskyar sa la phyir 'bab yong /

In the roads where the teams moved, where the wheels milled the ground and the hooves of the horses beat the ground, the dirt crust broke and the dust formed. Every moving thing lifted the dust into the air: a walking man lifted a thin layer as high as his waist, and a wagon lifted the dust as high as the fence tops, and an automobile boiled a cloud behind it. The dust was long in settling back again.

spyi zla drug pa'i zla phyed rdzogs song la/ sprin phung chen po rnams Theg sa si mnga' sde dang mtsho khug sa khul nas phyir bud/ de bas/ da lta char chu'i khur po 'khur ba'i sprin phung rnams shin tu lci/ zhing nang gi mi rnams kyis gnam gyi sprin par yar la lta bzhin sprin phung la sna snyer byed la/ mchil mas brlan pa'i mdzub mo gnam la ker te rlung bu'i rgyu phyogs 'tshol/ sprin pa mgo thog tu slebs tshe/ rta pho rnams kyang brel 'tshub langs/ char sprin gyis thol char re phab rjes brel 'tshub ngang lung pa gzhan pa'i phyogs su bzhud/ sprin tshogs rnams bzhud rjes nam mkha' yang bskyar skya bor gyur la/ nyi 'od kyang yang bskyar 'phros byung / thal rdul khrod na char thigs lhung shul gyi kong bu chung chung re yod cing / ma rmos lo tog gi steng du chu zegs gtsang ma re 'khyil yod/ thol char gyi byas rjes de tsam las ma 'das/

When June was half gone, the big clouds moved up out of Texas and the Gulf, high heavy clouds, rainheads. The men in the fields looked up at the clouds and sniffed at them and held wet fingers up to sense the wind. And the horses were nervous while the clouds were up. The rainheads dropped a little spattering and hurried on to some other country. Behind them the sky was pale again and the sun flared. In the dust there were drop craters where the rain had fallen, and there were clean splashes on the corn, and that was all.

'jam rlung zhig gis char sprin gyi rjes ded nas yong la/ des sprin pa rnams byang phyogs su bdas/ 'jam rlung 'dis skam bzhin pa'i ma rmos lo tog rnams yang mor sgul/ nyi ma gcig phyin song la / rlung bu yang je cher song zhing / rlung rgyun gyi 'gul tshad snyoms la rlung kha brtan/ gzhung lam steng gi thal rdul rnams rlung bus sprugs nas bar snang la spur zhing / rim bzhin thal rdul rnams zhing 'gram gyi ldum bu'i steng dang / phar phyogs kyi zhing kha sogs su babs/ da lta rlung shugs je che dang je rtsub tu song yod pas/ des ma rmos lo tog zhing nang gi char rjes kyi sa shun la brnyas gtser byed bzhin gda'/ thal rdul 'dres mas rim bzhin nam mkha' nag thing nger bsgyur song / rlung bus sa gzhi'i ngos su byil byil byas te thal ba rnams sob sob tu bsgyur song la/ sob sob tu gyur pa'i thal rdul rnams rlung rgyun dang bsdongs te bar snang la 'phur/ rlung shugs de bas kyang je cher gyur pas/ char rjes kyi sa shun gog nas zhing nang du rdul 'tshub langs/

A gentle wind followed the rain clouds, driving them on northward, a wind that softly clashed the drying corn. A day went by and the wind increased, steady, unbroken by gusts. The dust from the roads fluffed up and spread out and fell on the weeds beside the fields, and fell into the fields a little way. Now the wind grew strong and hard and it worked at the rain crust in the corn fields. Little by little the sky was darkened by the mixing dust, and the wind felt over the earth, loosened the dust, and carried it away. The wind grew stronger.

rdul 'tshub kyis bya sgro skya bo de dag bar snang du sgyid lug che ba'i dud sprin bzhin du ded/ ma rmos lo tog rnams rlung bu la brdar ba las skam sag sag gi sgra grag thal rdul ches 'jam shos rnams da lta sa gzhi'i steng du phyir ma babs par/ nag thing nger 'gyur bzhin pa'i nam mkha'i dbyings su yal/

The rain crust broke and the dust lifted up out of the fields and drove gray plumes into the air like sluggish smoke. The corn threshed the wind and made a dry, rushing sound. The finest dust did not settle back to earth now, but disappeared into the darkening sky.

rlung shugs de bas kyang je cher gyur pas/ rdo gseb nas shug sgra sgrog la/ lo ma rnying pa dang rtswa sog rnams kyang rlung bus 'khyer 'gro/ tha na spo tho chung chung yang ded nas 'gro bas/ zhing nang du rlung bu rgyu shul zhig gsal por mngon/ mkha' dbugs dang nam mkha' mthing nag tu gyur pas/ de dag gi khrod nas dgung gi nyi ma dmar lham mer gyur/ mkha' dbugs kyi khrod du'ang sna la gzan pa'i rdzas sna zhig slebs/ mtshan mo'i dus su/ sa ngos su rlung bu ldang ba de bas kyang mgyogs shing / rlung bu de dag gis ma rmos lo tog gi rtsa ba rnams g.yo sgyu tsha pos slog thabs byas/ ma rmos lo tog gis rang nyid kyi gnyom chung ba'i lo 'dab rnams spyad de rlung bu la kha gtad 'jal thabs byas mod/ 'on kyang / g.yo sgyu can gyi rlung bus ma rmos lo tog gi rtsad pa bkog pas/ da ni lo tog re re'i gzhung rta rlung bu rgyu phyogs su phyogs nas/ sa ngos su nyam thag pa'i ngang nas 'gyel song /

The wind grew stronger, whisked under stones, carried up straws and old leaves, and even little clods, marking its course as it sailed across the fields. The air and the sky darkened and through them the sun shone redly, and there was a raw sting in the air. During a night the wind raced faster over the land, dug cunningly among the rootlets of the corn, and the corn fought the wind with its weakened leaves until the roots were freed by the prying wind and then each stalk settled wearily sideways toward the earth and pointed the direction of the wind.

skya rengs shar byung mod/ zhogs pa'i snang ba dkar po mig lam du mngon rgyu ma byung / skya mdog gi nam mkha' ru nyi ma dmar po zhig mngon byung la/ gsal la mi gsal ba'i gor thig dmar po 'dis sa srod kyi snang ba dang 'dra ba'i 'od phran zhig spros/ nam langs pa dang chabs cig tu/ sa srod kyi snang ba de mun pa'i klong du phyir bros song / rlung bus sa la 'gyel yod pa'i ma rmos lo tog gi steng du mya ngan gyi smre sngags 'don/

The dawn came, but no day. In the gray sky a red sun appeared, a dim red circle that gave a little light, like dusk; and as that day advanced, the dusk slipped back toward darkness, and the wind cried and whimpered over the fallen corn.

skyes pa dang bud med tshang ma khang pa'i nang du sdeb 'tshang rgyag gi 'dug la/ kho tsho phyi logs su 'gro dus lag ras kyis kha sna btums shing / mig zung srung skyob ched du bye 'gog mig shel gon yod/
Men and women huddled in their houses, and they tied handkerchiefs over their noses when they went out, and wore goggles to protect their eyes.

yang bskyar mtshan mor bslebs song / skar tshogs kyis thal rdul gyi seng ras brtol ma thub la/ sge'u khung gi dkar 'od rnams kyang so so'i sgo ra'i phan la 'phro mi thub pas/ mtshan mo 'dir mun pa ha cang nag da lta thal rdul rnams mkha' dbugs dang cha snyoms su 'dres pas/ mkha' dbugs dang thal rdul gyi rdzas sbyor gsar pa zhig grub/ khang pa'i sgo rnams dam por brgyab yod la/ sgo dang sge'u khung gi mtha' ru ras lhan btsangs yod/ 'on kyang / thal rdul rnams mig gis kyang zin mi thub pa'i rdul phung phra mo phra mo byas te nang du 'dzul yong nas/ rkub stegs dang sgrog tse/ sder ma bcas kyi steng du ze'u 'bru'i rdul bzhin du babs/ mi tshos thal rdul de dag phrag kha nas sprug sprug byed/ da lta sgo them gyi steng du'ang thal rdul rim pa re chags yod/

When the night came again it was black night, for the stars could not pierce the dust to get down, and the window lights could not even spread beyond their own yards. Now the dust was evenly mixed with the air, an emulsion of dust and air. Houses were shut tight, and cloth wedged around doors and windows, but the dust came in so thinly that it could not be seen in the air, and it settled like pollen on the chairs and tables, on the dishes. The people brushed it from their shoulders. Little lines of dust lay at the door sills.

mtshan mo de'i nam gung tsam la rlung bu 'jags song la/ sa gzhi hril po khu sim por gyur/ smug pa dang bsdur na/ thal rdul dang 'dres pa'i mkha' dbugs kyis sgra mgo lhag tu gnon thub/ nyal sa'i nang du nyal yod pa'i mi rnams kyis rlung bu 'jags pa thos la/ mgyogs rlung gi ldang mtshams chad pa na kho tsho gnyid las sad/ kho tsho mu mthud du nyal bzhin/ khu sim sim gyi khor yug la rna rtsa grung pos nyan/ tho rengs bya phos bya skad bsgrags byung la/ de tsho'i skad kyang nam rgyun las kyang dma' bar snang / mi rnams so so'i nyal sa'i nang nas 'gre log phar rgyag tshur rgyag byed bzhin nam langs par sgug mkha' dbugs khrod kyi thal rdul rnams yongs su 'jags par dus yun ring po zhig dgos pa kho tshos shes kyi yod/ zhogs par slebs dus thal rdul rnams smug pa bzhin 'thibs 'dug la/ dgung gi nyi ma de khrag gsar bzhin dmar po dmar rkyang red/ nyin de'i nyin gang por thal rdul rnams nam mkha' nas babs byung la/ de'i phyi nyin yang thal rdul mu mthud du babs/ de bas/ da lta sa gzhi 'di ni ngos snyoms pa'i khebs ma zhig gis yongs su g.yogs zin/ thal rdul rnams ma rmos lo tog gi steng du babs 'dug la/ ra ba'i ka rtse dang dang lcags skud kyi steng du spungs/ thal rdul rnams khang klad du babs 'dug la/ ldum bu dang ljon shing rnams kyang thal rdul gyis yongs su bkab zin/

In the middle of that night the wind passed on and left the land quiet. The dust-filled air muffled sound more completely than fog does. The people, lying in their beds, heard the wind stop. They awakened when the rushing wind was gone. They lay quietly and listened deep into the stillness. Then the roosters crowed, and their voices were muffled, and the people stirred restlessly in their beds and wanted the morning. They knew it would take a long time for the dust to settle out of the air. In the morning the dust hung like fog, and the sun was as red as ripe new blood. All day the dust sifted down from the sky, and the next day it sifted down. An even blanket covered the earth. It settled on the corn, piled up on the tops of the fence posts, piled up on the wires; it settled on roofs, blanketed the weeds and trees.

mi rnams rang nyid kyi khang pa'i nang nas phyi la bud ma thag tu/ sna la gzan pa'i mkha' rlung dron po zhig gi dri ma tshor la/ de ma thag tu so so'i kha sna yongs su btum/ byis pa tsho khang pa'i nang nas phyi la bud/ nam rgyun char rjes kyi zhogs par/ byis pa tshos yar rgyug mar lding gis ku co sgrog mod/ de ring kho tsho 'jam cag ge red/ skyes pa rnams ra ba'i 'gram du langs nas yongs su bcom tshar ba'i ma rmos lo tog la bltas nas bsdad/ ma rmos lo tog rnams da lta mgyogs por skam bzhin yod pas/ thal rdul gyi mig dar khrod nas ljang mdog phran bu tsam ma gtogs mthong rgyu med/

The people came out of their houses and smelled the hot stinging air and covered their noses from it. And the children came out of the houses, but they did not run or shout as they would have done after a rain. Men stood by their fences and looked at the ruined corn, drying fast now, only a little green showing through the film of dust.

skyes pa tsho khu sim po red la/ 'gul skyod kyang de 'dra med/ bud med tsho khang pa las phyir bud nas so so'i skyes pa'i 'gram du langs te/ da thengs rang nyid kyi skyes pa tsho re thag chad rgyu yin min tshod bgam byed/ bud med tshos lkog nas so so'i skyes pa tsho'i gdong mdangs la lta bzhin 'dug ste/ kho mo tsho'i sems su/ da dung shul du brten rung ba zhig lus yod tshe/ ma rmos lo tog med par gyur rung mi skyon snyam gyi yod/ byis pa tsho kho tsho dang thag mi ring ba'i sa ru langs nas yod cing / kho tshos mdun gyi thal ba'i nang du rkang mdzub kyis ri mo 'bri zhor/ da thengs skyes pa dang bud med tsho re thag chad rgyu yin min rtog zhib byed bzhin yod/ byis pa tshos skyes pa dang bud med tsho'i gdong par lkog lta re byas rjes/ mdun gyi thal ba'i nang du rkang mdzub kyis thig ris zhib mo re bris/

The men were silent and they did not move often. And the women came out of the houses to stand beside their men- to feel whether this time the men would break. The women studied the men's faces secretly, for the corn could go, as long as something else remained. The children stood near by, drawing figures in the dust with bare toes, and the children sent exploring senses out to see whether men and women would break. The children peeked at the faces of the men and women, and then drew careful lines in the dust with their toes.

rta bo rnams chu bres kha ru chu 'thung du yong zhing / kho tshos sna sbrid brgyab ste chu ngos kyi thal rdul rnams bsal/ yud tsam gyi rjes su/ rgyang so byed bzhin pa'i skyes pa tsho'i gdong gi rmongs 'thom gyi glen mdangs sel bas/ da lta ngo gdong gnag cing khong khro zos nas sdod mi tshugs par gyur/ de dus bud med tshos kho tsho bde 'jags yin zhing da dung re thag chad med pa tshor/ de nas kho mo tshos/ da nga tshos ci byed dam/ zhes dris par/ skyes pa tshos/ ngas mi shes/ zhes lan btab/ 'on kyang skyon med/ bud med tshos skyon med pa shes la/ tshur bltas nas yod pa'i byis pa tshos kyang skyon med pa shes kyi yod/ bud med dang byis pa tsho'i sems kyi gting rim nas/ rang re'i skyes pa tsho sra thag thag yin dus/ rkyen ngan ci zhig byung rung gdong len byed mi thub pa med pa shes kyi yod/ bud med tsho so so'i khang pa'i nang du phyir khyim las la phyin song la/ byis pa tshos rtsed mo rtse mgo brtsams/ 'on kyang / kho tshos thog mar cung gzab gzab ngang brtses/ nyin mo'i dus skabs yud tsam song tshe/ dgung gi nyi ma'ang de 'dra dmar po min par gyur cing / nyi zer rnams thal rdul gyis bkab pa'i sa gzhi'i steng du 'phros/ skyes pa tsho so so'i khang pa'i sgo lam bar du tsog pur bsdad cing / kho tsho'i lag zung shing thur dang rdo hrug steng du brel/ skyes pa tsho g.yo 'gul med par tsog pur bsdad nas/ bsam blo gtong bzhin zhib 'dang rgyag gi yod/

Horses came to the watering troughs and nuzzled the water to clear the surface dust. After a while the faces of the watching men lost their bemused perplexity and became hard and angry and resistant. Then the women knew that they were safe and that there was no break. Then they asked, What'll we do? And the men replied, I don't know. But it was all right. The women knew it was all right, and the watching children knew it was all right. Women and children knew deep in themselves that no misfortune was too great to bear if their men were whole. The women went into the houses to their work, and the children began to play, but cautiously at first. As the day went forward the sun became less red. It flared down on the dust-blanketed land. The men sat in the doorways of their houses; their hands were busy with sticks and little rocks. The men sat still- thinking- figuring.
le'u gnyis pa/

dos skyel rlangs 'khor dmar po chen po zhig lam 'gram gyi za khang chung chung zhig gi mdun du bsdad 'dug rlangs 'khor de'i gyen du bsgar ba'i dud khung las shub sgra 'jam po zhig grag gi 'dug la/ mthong la mi mthong ba'i lcags mdog gi dud sngon zhig dud khung gi sne ru lding skor rgyag de ni dmar mdangs 'phro ba'i rlangs 'khor gsar pa zhig red la/ de'i 'gram ngos gnyis su [“]og la ho ma grong khyer skyel 'dren spyi gnyer khang /[”] zhes pa'i dbyin tshun bcu gnyis can gyi yig phreng zhig bris 'dug rlangs 'khor de'i 'gyig 'khor nyis brtsegs ma rnams gsar pa red la/ rgyab sgo chen po'i ngos kyi lcags lung las ra gan gyi sgo zwa zhig dpyangs 'dug

A HUGE RED TRANSPORT truck stood in front of the little roadside restaurant. The vertical exhaust pipe muttered softly, and an almost invisible haze of steel-blue smoke hovered over its end. It was a new truck, shining red, and in twelve-inch letters on its sides-OKLAHOMA CITY TRANSPORT COMPANY. Its double tires were new, and a brass padlock stood straight out from the hasp on the big black doors.

drwa tshags sgo mo [2]brgyab pa'i za khang gi nang du rlung 'phrin zhig btang 'dug la/ nyan mkhan med skabs kyi 'gro stangs ltar/ zhabs bro'i rol dbyangs kyi sgra je dma' ru btang yod/ mdun sgo'i thad kyi kha phyi la bskor ba'i rlung 'khor de ni rang nyid kyi 'khor gdan gor gor gyi steng du khu sim pos 'khor gyi 'dug la/ sbrang 'bu rnams kyis sgo dang sge'u khung mtha' ru spro snang dang bcas zir sgra sgrog bzhin drwa tshags sgo mo la gdong thug rgyag par byed/ za khang gi nang du/ rlangs 'khor gyi kha lo ba de rgyab snyes med pa'i rkub stegs shig gi steng du bsdad 'dug la/ gru mo gnyis ka tshong sgrom steng du bzhag nas/ 'tshig ja 'thung zhor du phar phyogs kyi sha rid cing kher rkyang gi rnam pa dod pa'i zhabs zhu ma der bltas/ de nas khos lam 'gram gyi skad cha rgya yan pa de kho mor bshad [“]ngas kho zla ba gsum gyi sngon du mthong byung / kho la gshag bcos byas 'dug la/ kho'i lus nas gcig bcad pa red zer/ ci zhig bcad pa da lta dran gyi mi 'dug[”] de nas kho mos [“]gza' 'khor gcig tsam gyi sngon du ngas kho mthong byung / de dus kho la gnad don 'dra yod pa mthong ma byung / kho chang rkyal zhig min rgyu na mi bzang po 'dra yin/[”] zhes bshad/ mtshams dang mtshams su sbrang 'bu tshos sgo mo'i ngos su zir sgra re sgrog bzhin gda'/ 'tshig ja'i 'phrul chas las rlangs pa thol thol du 'phyur byung la/ zhabs zhu mas mig gis lta tsam yang mi byed par/ lag pa rgyab phyogs su bsrings nas 'phrul chas kyi glog sgo brgyab/

Inside the screened restaurant a radio played, quiet dance music turned low the way it is when no one is listening. A small outlet fan turned silently in its circular hole over the entrance, and flies buzzed excitedly about the doors and windows, butting the screens. Inside, one man, the truck driver, sat on a stool and rested his elbows on the counter and looked over his coffee at the lean and lonely waitress. He talked the smart listless language of the roadsides to her. “I seen him about three months ago. He had a operation. Cut somepin out. I forget what.” And she- “Doesn't seem no longer than a week I seen him myself. Looked fine then. He's a nice sort of a guy when he ain't stinko.” Now and then the flies roared softly at the screen door. The coffee machine spurted steam, and the waitress, without looking, reached behind her and shut it off.

Outside, a man walking along the edge of the highway crossed over and approached the truck. He walked slowly to the front of it, put his hand on the shiny fender, and looked at the No Riders sticker on the windshield. For a moment he was about to walk on down the road, but instead he sat on the running board on the side away from the restaurant. He was not over thirty. His eyes were very dark brown and there was a hint of brown pigment in his eyeballs. His cheek bones were high and wide, and strong deep lines cut down his cheeks, in curves beside his mouth. His upper lip was long, and since his teeth protruded, the lips stretched to cover them, for this man kept his lips closed. His hands were hard, with broad fingers and nails as thick and ridged as little clam shells. The space between thumb and forefinger and the hams of his hands were shiny with callus.

The man's clothes were new- all of them, cheap and new. His gray cap was so new that the visor was still stiff and the button still on, not shapeless and bulged as it would be when it had served for a while all the various purposes of a cap- carrying sack, towel, handkerchief. His suit was of cheap gray hardcloth and so new that there were creases in the trousers. His blue chambray shirt was stiff and smooth with filler. The coat was too big, the trousers too short, for he was a tall man. The coat shoulder peaks hung down on his arms, and even then the sleeves were too short and the front of the coat flapped loosely over his stomach. He wore a pair of new tan shoes of the kind called “army last,” hob-nailed and with half-circles like horseshoes to protect the edges of the heels from wear. This man sat on the running board and took off his cap and mopped his face with it. Then he put on the cap, and by pulling started the future ruin of the visor. His feet caught his attention. He leaned down and loosened the shoelaces, and did not tie the ends again. Over his head the exhaust of the Diesel engine whispered in quick puffs of blue smoke.

The music stopped in the restaurant and a man's voice spoke from the loudspeaker, but the waitress did not turn him off, for she didn't know the music had stopped. Her exploring fingers had found a lump under her ear. She was trying to see it in a mirror behind the counter without letting the truck driver know, and so she pretended to push a bit of hair to neatness. The truck driver said, “They was a big dance in Shawnee. I heard somebody got killed or somepin. You hear anything?” “No,” said the waitress, and she lovingly fingered the lump under her ear.

The driver, getting slowly into the truck, considered the parts of this answer. If he refused now, not only was he not a good guy, but he was forced to carry a sticker, was not allowed to have company. The hitch-hiker flopped down out of sight and clung to the door handle. The motor roared up for a moment, the gears clicked in, and the great truck moved away, first gear, second gear, third gear, and then a high whining pick-up and fourth gear. Under the clinging man the highway blurred dizzily by. It was a mile to the first turn in the road, then the truck slowed down. The hitch-hiker stood up, eased the door open, and slipped into the seat. The driver looked over at him, slitting his eyes, and he chewed as though thoughts and impressions were being sorted and arranged by his jaws before they were finally filed away in his brain. His eyes began at the new cap, moved down the new clothes to the new shoes. The hitch-hiker squirmed his back against the seat in comfort, took off his cap, and swabbed his sweating forehead and chin with it. “Thanks, buddy,” he said. “My dogs was pooped out.”

THE CONCRETE HIGHWAY was edged with a mat of tangled, broken, dry grass, and the grass heads were heavy with oat beards to catch on a dog's coat, and foxtails to tangle in a horse's fetlocks, and clover burrs to fasten in sheep's wool; sleeping life waiting to be spread and dispersed, every seed armed with an appliance of dispersal, twisting darts and parachutes for the wind, little spears and balls of tiny thorns, and all waiting for animals and for the wind, for a man's trouser cuff or the hem of a woman's skirt, all passive but armed with appliances of activity, still, but each possessed of the anlage of movement.

The sun lay on the grass and warmed it, and in the shade under the grass the insects moved, ants and ant lions to set traps for them, grasshoppers to jump into the air and flick their yellow wings for a second, sow bugs like little armadillos, plodding restlessly on many tender feet. And over the grass at the roadside a land turtle crawled, turning aside for nothing, dragging his high-domed shell over the grass: His hard legs and yellow-nailed feet threshed slowly through the grass, not really walking, but boosting and dragging his shell along. The barley beards slid off his shell, and the clover burrs fell on him and rolled to the ground. His horny beak was partly open, and his fierce, humorous eyes, under brows like fingernails, stared straight ahead. He came over the grass leaving a beaten trail behind him, and the hill, which was the highway embankment, reared up ahead of him. For a moment he stopped, his head held high. He blinked and looked up and down. At last he started to climb the embankment.

Front clawed feet reached forward but did not touch. The hind feet kicked his shell along, and it scraped on the grass, and on the gravel. As the embankment grew steeper and steeper, the more frantic were the efforts of the land turtle. Pushing hind legs strained and slipped, boosting the shell along, and the horny head protruded as far as the neck could stretch. Little by little the shell slid up the embankment until at last a parapet cut straight across its line of march, the shoulder of the road, a concrete wall four inches high.

As though they worked independently the hind legs pushed the shell against the wall. The head upraised and peered over the wall to the broad smooth plain of cement. Now the hands, braced on top of the wall, strained and lifted, and the shell came slowly up and rested its front end on the wall. For a moment the turtle rested. A red ant ran into the shell, into the soft skin inside the shell, and suddenly head and legs snapped in, and the armored tail clamped in sideways. The red ant was crushed between body and legs. And one head of wild oats was clamped into the shell by a front leg. For a long moment the turtle lay still, and then the neck crept out and the old humorous frowning eyes looked about and the legs and tail came out. The back legs went to work, straining like elephant legs, and the shell tipped to an angle so that the front legs could not reach the level cement plain.

Now the going was easy, and all the legs worked, and the shell boosted along, waggling from side to side. A sedan driven by a forty-year-old woman approached. She saw the turtle and swung to the right, off the highway, the wheels screamed and a cloud of dust boiled up. Two wheels lifted for a moment and then settled. The car skidded back onto the road, and went on, but more slowly. The turtle had jerked into its shell, but now it hurried on, for the highway was burning hot.

And now a light truck approached, and as it came near, the driver saw the turtle and swerved to hit it. His front wheel struck the edge of the shell, flipped the turtle like a tiddly-wink, spun it like a coin, and rolled it off the highway. The truck went back to its course along the right side. Lying on its back, the turtle was tight in its shell for a long time. But at last its legs waved in the air, reaching for something to pull it over. Its front foot caught a piece of quartz and little by little the shell pulled over and flopped upright. The wild oat head fell out and three of the spearhead seeds stuck in the ground. And as the turtle crawled on down the embankment, its shell dragged dirt over the seeds. The turtle entered a dust road and jerked itself along, drawing a wavy shallow trench in the dust with its shell. The old humorous eyes looked ahead, and the horny beak opened a little. His yellow toe nails slipped a fraction in the dust.

WHEN JOAD HEARD THE truck get under way, gear climbing up to gear and the ground throbbing under the rubber beating of the tires, he stopped and turned about and watched it until it disappeared. When it was out of sight he still watched the distance and the blue air-shimmer. Thoughtfully he took the pint from his pocket, unscrewed the metal cap, and sipped the whisky delicately, running his tongue inside the bottle neck, and then around his lips, to gather in any flavor that might have escaped him. He said experimentally, “There we spied a nigger-” and that was all he could remember. At last he turned about and faced the dusty side road that cut off at right angles through the fields. The sun was hot, and no wind stirred the sifted dust. The road was cut with furrows where dust had slid and settled back into the wheel tracks. Joad took a few steps, and the flourlike dust spurted up in front of his new yellow shoes, and the yellowness was disappearing under gray dust.

Joad plodded along, dragging his cloud of dust behind him. A little bit ahead he saw the high-domed shell of a land turtle, crawling slowly along through the dust, its legs working stiffly and jerkily. Joad stopped to watch it, and his shadow fell on the turtle. Instantly head and legs were withdrawn and the short thick tail clamped sideways into the shell. Joad picked it up and turned it over. The back was brown-gray, like the dust, but the underside of the shell was creamy yellow, clean and smooth. Joad shifted his bundle high under his arm and stroked the smooth undershell with his finger, and he pressed it. It was softer than the back. The hard old head came out and tried to look at the pressing finger, and the legs waved wildly. The turtle wetted on Joad's hand and struggled uselessly in the air. Joad turned it back upright and rolled it up in his coat with his shoes. He could feel it pressing and struggling and fussing under his arm. He moved ahead more quickly now, dragged his heels a little in the fine dust.

Ahead of him, beside the road, a scrawny, dusty willow tree cast a speckled shade. Joad could see it ahead of him, its poor branches curving over the way, its load of leaves tattered and scraggly as a molting chicken. Joad was sweating now. His blue shirt darkened down his back and under his arms. He pulled at the visor of his cap and creased it in the middle, breaking its cardboard lining so completely that it could never look new again. And his steps took on new speed and intent toward the shade of the distant willow tree. At the willow he knew there would be shade, at least one hard bar of absolute shade thrown by the trunk, since the sun had passed its zenith. The sun whipped the back of his neck now and made a little humming in his head. He could not see the base of the tree, for it grew out of a little swale that held water longer than the level places. Joad speeded his pace against the sun, and he started down the declivity. He slowed cautiously, for the bar of absolute shade was taken. A man sat on the ground, leaning against the trunk of the tree.

kho'i rkang pa gnyis ka mdun du bsnol nas/ rkang pa rjen pa gcig kho'i mgo'i mtho tshad dang mnyam pa'i bar snang la btegs/ mi des [“]red lags/ sku zhabs/ de ni nga yi snying gi nor bu yin/[”] zhes pa'i dbyangs 'gros shig blo rig bsgrims nas shu glu ru len bzhin yod pas/ khos jo Di rang nyid dang thag nye ru yong gi yod pa yang ma tshor/ kho'i yar btegs yod pa'i rkang pa de dbyangs 'gros dang bstun nas yar g.yo mar g.yo byed/ dbyangs 'gros de zhabs bro'i dbyangs 'gros shig ma red/ khos shu 'debs mtshams bzhag nas pho skad 'jam zhing phra ba zhig gis glu chung blangs/

His legs were crossed and one bare foot extended nearly as high as his head. He did not hear Joad approaching, for he was whistling solemnly the tune of “Yes, Sir, That's My Baby.” His extended foot swung slowly up and down in the tempo. It was not dance tempo. He stopped whistling and sang in an easy thin tenor:

[“]red lags/ sku zhabs/ de ni nga yi skyabs mgon yin/ ston pa ye shu nga yi skyabs mgon yin/ ston pa ye shu da lta nga yi skyabs mgon yin/ snying gtam drang mor bshad pa/ bdud kyi cho 'phrul ma yin/ ston pa ye shu nga yi skyabs mgon yin/[”]
“Yes, sir, that's my Saviour, Je-sus is my Saviour, Je-sus is my Saviour now. On the level 'S not the devil, Jesus is my Saviour now.”

mi des jo Di yong bzhin pa ma tshor gong du/ jo Di ni rtsab ral lo 'dab kyis spros pa'i grib ma thar thor gyi 'og tu yongs su 'dzul zin/ mi des glu dbyangs len mtshams bzhag nas kha phyir 'khor/ kho'i skam zhing skyi lpags kyis dam por btum pa'i mgo bo nar mo de lca tshal gyi gzhung rta zhig dang 'dra bar/ sha gnad kyis gang ba'i mjing pa phra mo zhig gi steng nas yar 'grengs yod/ kho'i mig 'bras che zhing 'bur tshugs su yod cing / dmar zhing rjen pa'i mig lpags des mig 'bras 'gebs pa'i ched du bsnar nas 'dug kho'i mkhur tshos gnyis ka smug cing skam la gdong spu bral zhing / kho'i bag phebs dang tshor ba skyen pa'i smra sgo de dung sos gang / kho'i bya mchu bzhin rno zhing mkhregs pa'i sna yi steng du skyi lpags rnams 'then drags pa'i rkyen gyis sna phrum dkar por snang / kho'i gdong la rngul chu gcig kyang med la/ tha na ring zhing skya ba'i dpral ba na'ang rngul chu mthong rgyu med/ kho'i dpral ba 'di dmigs bsal gyis mtho la/ mur gong gi steng du sngo shur shur gyi khrag rtsa phra mo gral du bsgrigs/ kho'i ngo gdong gi phyed hril po mig gi yan chod du yod cing / skya mdog babs pa'i skra lo rengs po rnams mdzub mos rgyab phyogs su shad pa ltar dpral mtshams nas ltag rgyab phyogs su gzengs/ khos las dor dang nang stod sngon po gyon 'dug la/ ra gan gyi sgrog bu ldan pa'i De nim ras kyi phyi stod cig gyon yod/ sha bag leb ltar ltebs gnyer shor ba'i zhwa mo thig khra can zhig kho'i 'gram gyi sa steng du bzhag 'dug la/ thal rdul gyis skya bor bsgyur pa'i ras lham cha gcig po de dang thog ji ltar phud pa de ltar lus 'dug

Joad had moved into the imperfect shade of the molting leaves before the man heard him coming, stopped his song, and turned his head. It was a long head, bony; tight of skin, and set on a neck as stringy and muscular as a celery stalk. His eyeballs were heavy and protruding; the lids stretched to cover them, and the lids were raw and red. His cheeks were brown and shiny and hairless and his mouth full-humorous or sensual. The nose, beaked and hard, stretched the skin so tightly that the bridge showed white. There was no perspiration on the face, not even on the tall pale forehead. It was an abnormally high forehead, lined with delicate blue veins at the temples. Fully half of the face was above the eyes. His stiff gray hair was mussed back from his brow as though he had combed it back with his fingers. For clothes he wore overalls and a blue shirt. A denim coat with brass buttons and a spotted brown hat creased like a pork pie lay on the ground beside him. Canvas sneakers, gray with dust, lay near by where they had fallen when they were kicked off.

mi des jo Di la yun ring la bltas/ nyi ma'i 'od zer kho'i mig nang du 'dzul nas mig gi 'ja' skyi'i gting rum nas gser mdog gi thig le 'ga' re phyir 'dren bzhin pa dang 'dra la/ kho'i ske yi sha thang chad pa'i sha gnad kyi tshom bu rnams phyi phyogs su 'bur nas yod/
The man looked long at Joad. The light seemed to go far into his brown eyes, and it picked out little golden specks deep in the irises. The strained bundle of neck muscles stood out.

Joad stood still in the speckled shade. He took off his cap and mopped his wet face with it and dropped it and his rolled coat on the ground. The man in the absolute shade uncrossed his legs and dug with his toes at the earth.
jo Di yis [“]gzhung lam thog 'di tsha dmyal las kyang tsha/[”] zhes bshad/
Joad said, “Hi. It's hotter'n hell on the road.”

jo Di yis [“]yin ya/ yin/ pha yul du phyir log bzhin yod/[”] ces bshad/

mi des [“]ngas bltas na khyod kyis nga su yin dran rgyu ma red/[”] ces zer bzhin gdong la 'dzum zhig langs pas/ kho'i mchu to mthug po des rta so dang 'dra ba'i so chen rnams phyi ru ngom/ [“]ci la dran nam/ khyod kyis nga yid la dran rgyu ma red/ ngas khyod la dam pa'i rnam shes sprod skabs/ khyod rang rtag par bu mo tsho'i ral ba 'then rgyur ma khom nas yod cing / khyod kyis kho mo tsho'i lan bu'i rtsa ba nas bzung ste gtong gi ma red/ khyod kyi yid la mi dran yang srid/ nyin zhig bu mo zhig gi ral ba 'then pa'i gnad don gyi dbang gis khyod gnyis ka nga'i sar khrid yong la/ ngas khyod gnyis kar zhing chu'i chu dong nang nas chos zhugs khrus dbang bskur ba yin/ de dus khyod gnyis kas ri skyes byi la bzhin du dmar 'dzing byed kyi yod/[”]

“You wouldn't remember me, I guess,” the man said. He smiled and his full lips revealed great horse teeth. “Oh, no, you wouldn't remember. You was always too busy pullin' little girls' pigtails when I give you the Holy Sperit. You was all wropped up in yankin' that pigtail out by the roots. You maybe don't recollect, but I do. The two of you come to Jesus at once 'cause of the pigtail yankin'. Baptized both of you in the irrigation ditch at once. Fightin' an' yellin' like a couple of cats.”

jo Di yis mig thur du phab nas kho la yud tsam bltas rjes gad mo bgad/ [“]o/ red/ khyod chos dpon de red a/ red/ khyod chos dpon de red/ chu tshod gcig ma zin tsam gyi sngon la ngas khyod kyi skor gyi phyir dran zhig mi zhig la bshad pa yin/[”]

mi des nan tan gyi sgo nas [“]nga sngon chad chos dpon zhig yin/ sngon chad yin na dam pa jim kha se ste/ dad pa dang dam tshig can po de red/ ston pa ye shu'i mtshan nas gzi brjid dang bcas bzung nas cho nge bton myong / zhing chu'i chu dong kha ru phreng bstar gyis mgo bo dgye ba'i sdig bshags mkhan gyi sdig can gyis gang myong yod la/ de las phyed tsam gyis rang nyid chu nang du byings nas 'chi 'dod yod pa red/ 'on kyang / da ni de 'dra byed kyi med/[”] ces bshad cing / de nas khos shu ring zhig 'then/ [“]da lta yin na jim kha se kho na yin/ sngon gyi las 'gan de da lta dang du len gyi med/ da lta ha cang sdig pa'i bsam blo mang po 'khor gyi 'dug la/ de dag la'ang gnas lugs nges can yod par snang /[”]

“I was a preacher,” said the man seriously. “Reverend Jim Casy-was a Burning Busher. Used to howl out the name of Jesus to glory. jo Di yis [“]bsam blo gtong rgyu mang na sems la bsam tshul 'dra min slebs yong gi red/ red/ ngas khyod los dran/ khyod kyis chos tshogs yag po re bsdus myong la/ thengs shig la khyod kyis bka' chos hril po zhig gi ring la rang nyid kyi lag pa gnyis ka thang la btsugs nas song zhing / mgo bo g.yug bzhin skad cor bton/ a ma chos dpon gzhan pa su las kyang khyod la dga' la/ a phyi yis khyod rang dam pa'i rnam shes lus la zhugs bsdad pa zhig tu brtsis yod/[”] ces bshad rjes/ khos rang nyid kyi phyi stod kyi thum sgril de bshigs nas/ de'i glo khug btsal te chang dam phyir blangs/ rus sbal gyis sug pa 'gul thabs byas mod/ khos thum sgril yang bskyar phyir dam por bsdams/ khos chang dam gyi kha gcod phyes rjes/ dam be phar la sring zhor du [“]hub cig 'thung gi yin nam/[”] zhes dris/

“Lead 'em around and around,” said Joad. “Sling 'em in the irrigation ditch. Tell 'em they'll burn in hell if they don't think like you. What the hell you want to lead 'em someplace for? Jus' lead 'em.” The straight trunk shade had stretched out along the ground. A thick-furred yellow shepherd dog came trotting down the road, head low, tongue lolling and dripping. Its tail hung limply curled, and it panted loudly. Joad whistled at it, but it only dropped its head an inch and trotted fast toward some definite destination. “Goin' someplace,” Joad explained, a little piqued. “Goin' for home maybe.”

The preacher could not be thrown from his subject. “Goin' someplace,” he repeated. “That's right, he's goin' someplace. Me- I don't know where I'm goin'. Tell you what- I used ta get the people jumpin' an' talkin' in tongues and glory-shoutin' till they just fell down an' passed out. An' some I'd baptize to bring 'em to. An' then- you know what I'd do? I'd take one of them girls out in the grass, an' I'd lay with her. Done it ever' time. Then I'd feel bad, an' I'd pray an' pray, but it didn't do no good. Come the next time, them an' me was full of the sperit, I'd do it again. I figgered there just wasn't no hope for me, an' I was a damned ol' hypocrite. But I didn't mean to be.”

jo Di yi gdong la 'dzum zhig langs pas/ kho'i zheng che ba'i ya so ma so gnyis ka so sor gyes/ khos mchu to lce ldag byed bzhin [“]kho mo tshor ngar slong byed du chos tshogs 'khrug po las lhag pa zhig gang na yod/ nga rang nyid kyis kyang de 'dra byas pa yin/[”] zhes bshad/
Joad smiled and his long teeth parted and he licked his lips. “There ain't nothing like a good hot meetin' for pushin' 'em over,” he said. “I done that myself.”

kha se yis spro sems 'khol ba'i ngang nas mdun phyogs su dgye ste [“]ltos dang / ngas kyang de 'dra zhig red bsam song / de bas nga la bsam blo 'di 'khor mgo brtsams/[”] zhes bshad cing / kho'i skam rid kyi lag pas yar mar la rdeb rdeb byed pa'i tshul bstan/ [“]nga la bsam blo 'di 'dra zhig 'khor gyi 'dug ste/ ngas 'di nas chos shig 'chad dus/ mi dmangs la byin rlabs zhugs drags nas gnam lding sa lding byed la/ ngag nas ki co 'don/ de nas kho tshos zer na/ bu mo tshor nyal 'dun skye ba ni kho tsho'i khog gi bdud gyi cho 'phrul las byung ba yin zer/ 'on kyang / bu mo tshor byin rlabs ga tshad zhugs na rtswa gseng du 'gro 'dod de tshod che/ de bas nga'i sems la dri ba 'di 'dra zhig slebs kyi yod/ bu mo zhig gi lus yongs dam pa'i rnam shes kyis bzung nas/ byin rlabs kha sna las kyang phyir 'phyo yong ba'i tshad la slebs yod dus/ kho mo'i khog tu bdud cig ci 'dra byas te zhugs pa yin nam snyam gyi yod/ nga tshos bltas na gnas skabs de ni bdud la rgyal kha 'thob pa'i go skabs sen mgo tsam yang med skabs 'dra snang mod/ 'on kyang / mjug mthar bdud rgyal 'gro yi yod/[”] kho'i mig zung dkrog snang gis khengs shing / rang nyid kyi mkhur mgo 'phur 'phur zhig byas rjes thal nang du mchil ma zhig 'phangs/ mchil ma ril mo de mar 'gril zhing / 'gril bzhin 'gril bzhin steng du thal rdul 'gos nas mtha' mar rde'u ril skam po lta bu zhig tu gyur/ chos dpon gyis lag gnyis mdun du bsrings nas/ rang nyid kyi lag ngos su dpe deb cig klog bzhin pa ltar bltas nas/ skad mgo dma' mos [“]'di nga red/ mi tshang ma'i rnam shes lag tu bzung nas 'gro mkhan 'di nga red/ kho tsho'i bu mo re rer nyal thengs re la/ nga'i phrag steng du 'gan khur yod la sems gting du 'gan sems yod/[”] ces bshad/ de nas khos jo Di la bltas shing gdong par ci bya gtol med kyi rnam pa zhig shar/ kho'i gdong mdangs las kho la sems gso zhig mkho ba rtogs nus/

Casy leaned forward excitedly. “You see,” he cried, “I seen it was that way, an' I started thinkin'.” He waved his bony big-knuckled hand up and down in a patting gesture. “I got to thinkin' like this- 'Here's me preachin' grace. An' here's them people gettin' grace so hard they're jumpin' an' shoutin'. Now they say layin' up with a girl comes from the devil. But the more grace a girl got in her, the quicker she wants to go out in the grass.' An' I got to thinkin' how in hell, s'cuse me, how can the devil get in when a girl is so full of the Holy Sperit that it's spoutin' out of her nose an' ears. You'd think that'd be one time when the devil didn't stand a snowball's chance in hell. But there it was.” His eyes were shining with excitement. He worked his cheeks for a moment and then spat into the dust, and the gob of spit rolled over and over, picking up dust until it looked like a round dry little pellet. The preacher spread out his hand and looked at his palm as though he were reading a book. “An' there's me,” he went on softly. “There's me with all them people's souls in my han'- responsible an' feelin' my responsibility- an' ever time, I lay with one of them girls.” He looked over at Joad and his face looked helpless. His expression asked for help.

jo Di yis mdun gyi thal nang du sems zhib mos bud med cig gi skya ris shig bris shing / skya ris steng gi bud med de'i nu 'bur dang 'phongs tshos/ dpyi mgo bcas kyi rnam pa gsal por mngon/ de nas khos [“]nga nam yang chos dpon zhig byas myong med la/ nam yang nga'i lag tu gcig thon dus sus kyang de la bar chad byed du mi 'jug nga'i lag tu gcig thon dus sems pa dga' spros gang nas 'dug pa las gzhan pa gang la'ang bsam blo btang ma myong /[”] zhes bshad/

Joad carefully drew the torso of a woman in the dirt, breasts, hips, pelvis. “I wasn't never a preacher,” he said. “I never let nothin' go by when I could catch it. An' I never had no idears about it except that I was goddamn glad when I got one.”

kha se yis [“]'on kyang khyod chos dpon ma red/ khyod la mtshon na bu mo ni bu mo tsam red/ gzhan pa'i nang don ci yang yod pa ma red/ 'on kyang / nga la mtshon na kho tsho tshang ma ni rin chen bum bzang red/ ngas kho tsho'i rnam shes skyob dgos kyi yod/ nga'i phrag steng du 'gan khur 'di 'dra yod bzhin du/ ngas kho tsho'i lus la dam pa'i rnam shes zhugs su bcug rjes/ kho tsho re re bzhin rtswa gseng du khrid kyi yod pa red/[”] ces bshad/

“But you wasn't a preacher,” Casy insisted. “A girl was just a girl to you. They wasn't nothin' to you. But to me they was holy vessels. I was savin' their souls. An' here with all that responsibility on me I'd just get 'em frothin' with the Holy Sperit, an' then I'd take 'em out in the grass.”

jo Di yis [“]gcig byas na nga chos dpon byas na 'grig sa red/[”] ces zer bzhin rdo tha dang shog bu blangs nas tha mag bsgril/ khos tha mag la me bsgron zhing / tha mag gi dud pa'i khrod nas mig phyes ma btsum gyis chos dpon la lta bzhin [“]nga bu mo zhig la ma thug par yun ring po zhig 'gor song / de'i ring gi gyong gun tshang ma gsab par dus tshod nges can zhig dgos rgyu red/[”] ces bshad/

“Maybe I should of been a preacher,” said Joad. He brought out his tobacco and papers and rolled a cigarette. He lighted it and squinted through the smoke at the preacher. “I been a long time without a girl,” he said. “It's gonna take some catchin' up.”

kha se yis mu mthud du [“]'dis nga sems khur la gtad nas rim bzhin gnyid kyang khug gi mi 'dug nga chos tshogs su 'gro ba'i skabs su/ ngas rang nyid la/ [‘]dkon mchog dpang du btsugs nas/ da thengs ngas bya ngan 'di bsgrub rgyu min/[’] zhes bshad kyi red la/ de shod pa'i skabs su/ nga'i sems su ngas mu mthud du 'di ltar bsgrub rgyu yin pa'ang shes kyi yod/[”] ces bshad/
Casy continued, “It worried me till I couldn't get no sleep. Here I'd go to preachin' and I'd say, 'By God, this time I ain't gonna do it.' And right while I said it, I knowed I was.”

jo Di yis [“]khyod kyis chung ma blangs na 'grig yod rgyu red/ sngon chad cig la chos dpon zhig dang khong gi chung ma nged tshang la bsdad myong / kho tsho ye ho grub mtha'i [4]rjes 'jug pa red/ kho tsho nged tshang gi thog khang du nyal gyi yod la/ kho tshos zhal 'don de nged tshang gi g.yul kha nas 'tshogs kyi yod/ skabs der byis pa tshos rna nyan byed kyi yod/ dgong mo re re'i zhal 'don dgong tshogs grol rjes su/ chos dpon gyi lcam mos gsig rdeb chen po re byed kyi yod/[”] ces bshad/

“You should a got a wife,” said Joad. “Preacher an' his wife stayed at our place one time. Jehovites they was. Slep' upstairs. Held meetin's in our barnyard. Us kids would listen. That preacher's missus took a god-awful poundin' after ever' night meetin'.”

kha se yis [“]'di nga la bshad par thugs rje che/ ngas nga rang gcig po yin rgyu red bsam myong / gang ltar/ mjug mthar ngas chos 'chad kyi las ka mtshams bzhag nas/ de'i thad la bsam blo zhib mo zhig btang ba yin/[”] zhes bshad/ khos rkang pa gnyis ka yar bkyags nas skam sob sob kyi rkang mdzub bar 'phrugs/ [“]ngas rang nyid la 'di ltar klan ka btsal myong / [‘]ci zhig gis khyod la mnar gcod gtong gi 'dug de ni khyod kyi spyod ngan gyi dbang gis red dam/[’] zhes rang nyid la dris rjes/ [‘]ma red/ sdig sgrib kyi dbang gis red/[’] ces lan btab pa yin/ de nas rang nyid la/ [‘]sdig pa'i bsam blos mi tshugs shing / snying khong du ston pa ye shu sku dngos su bzhugs dgos pa'i skabs su/ tag tag skabs der/ mi nga lta bus rang nyid kyi dor ma'i kha sgrog bdag mi thub pa 'di ci'i phyir yin/[’] zhes dris pa yin/[”]

“I'm glad you tol' me,” said Casy. “I used to think it was jus' me. Finally it give me such pain I quit an went off by myself an' give her a damn good thinkin' about.” He doubled up his legs and scratched between his dry dusty toes. “I says to myself, 'What's gnawin' you? Is it the screwin'?' An' I says, 'No, it's the sin.' An' I says, 'Why is it that when a fella ought to be just about mule-ass proof against sin, an' full up of Jesus, why is it that's the time a fella gets fingerin' his pants buttons?'”

[4] ye ho grub mtha'/ [Jehovite] ste/ drag shugs che ba'i zhal 'don 'du 'dzoms dang cho nge 'don pa/ 'khun sgra 'byin pa/ dbyangs rta gyer ba bcas khyad chos gtso bor byas pa'i ye shu'i chos lugs kyi grub mtha' zhig

khos tshig re re phan tshun legs par gshib nas 'jog pa ltar/ mdzub mo gnyis lag mthil du tshig 'gros dang bcas 'jog [“]ngas rang nyid la/ [‘]gcig byas na 'di sdig sgrib kyi dbang gis yin rgyu ma red/ gcig byas na de ni mi'i lhan skyes yin rgyu red/ gcig byas na nga tshos rang sdug rang gis nyo bzhin yod rgyu red/[’] ces bshad pa yin/ de nas ngas jo mo tshos dbyin khre gsum can gyi gze ma ra mgo'i lcag tshan gyis rang nyid kyi lus la 'brab pa de dag la bsam blo btang ba yin/ gcig byas na kho mo tshos rang nyid la mnar gcod gtong 'dod pa tsam yin nges red/ gcig byas na ngas kyang rang nyid la mnar gcod gtong 'dod pa tsam yin nges/ red/ nga sdong po zhig gi 'og tu gan rkyal du log nas yod skabs shig la nga la rtogs pa de sad byung / de nas nga rang gnyid du song ba yin/ nga la mtshan mo zhig la rtogs pa sad byung la/ rtogs pa de sad dus mun pa yongs su rub 'dug skabs der thag nye zhig na spyang khyi zhig gis zug rngu 'don bzhin 'dug la/ nga rang nyid kyis kyang ma tshor gong rang nyid kyis skad gsang mthon pos/ [‘]skyag pa zo/ 'jig rten 'dir sdig pa zer rgyu med la/ dge ba zer rgyu'ang med/ yod pa tshang ma mi rnams kyis sgrub dgos pa'i bya ba tsam red/ 'di tshang ma ngo bo gcig gi cha shas mi 'dra ba tsam red/ mi rnams kyis sgrub pa'i bya ba 'ga' re bzang po red la 'ga' re ngan pa red/ 'on kyang / mi zhig la 'di yan gyi 'grel bshad rgyag pa'i thob thang med/[’] ces sgrog bzhin 'dug[”] khos bshad mtshams bzhag nas/ tshig 'bru rnams bsgrigs yod pa'i lag mthil las mgo bo phyir yar dkyags/

He laid two fingers down in his palm in rhythm, as though he gently placed each word there side by side. “I says, 'Maybe it ain't a sin. Maybe it's just the way folks is. Maybe we been whippin' the hell out of ourselves for nothin'.' An' I thought how some sisters took to beatin' theirselves with a three-foot shag of bobwire. An' I thought how maybe they liked to hurt themselves, an' maybe I liked to hurt myself. Well, I was layin' under a tree when I figured that out, and I went to sleep. And it come night, an' it was dark when I come to. They was a coyote squawkin' near by. Before I knowed it, I was sayin' out loud, 'The hell with it! There ain't no sin and there ain't no virtue. There's just stuff people do. It's all part of the same thing. And some of the things folks do is nice, and some ain't nice, but that's as far as any man got a right to say.'” He paused and looked up from the palm of his hand, where he had laid down the words.

jo Di yis kho la khrel dgod kyi rnam pas bltas 'dug mod/ 'on kyang / kho'i mig nang du do snang yod pa'i nyams shig mngon nas [“]khyod kyis de thog la bsam blo btang nas/ mjug mthar rtogs pa yang sad 'dug a/[”] zhes bshad/
Joad was grinning at him, but Joad's eyes were sharp and interested, too. “You give her a goin'-over,” he said. “You figured her out.”

kha se yis yang bskyar skad cha bshad byung la/ kho'i skad la na zug dang rmongs 'thoms kyi gdangs shig babs te [“]de nas ngas rang nyid la/ [‘]'gan khur 'di ci zhig red/ rnam shes 'di ci zhig red/[’] ces dris rjes/ rang nyid la/ [‘]de ni brtse dung red/ ngas mi dmangs la bcangs pa'i brtse dung shugs drag nas/ mtshams mtshams su 'dug bzod mi bde/[’] zhes lan btab pa yin/ de nas rang nyid la/ [‘]'o na khyod ston pa ye shu la brtse dung med dam/[’] zhes dris shing / dris lan la yun ring zhig la bsam blo btang rjes/ [‘]med/ ngas ston pa ye shu zer ba'i ming zhig go ba ma gtogs kho ngo mi shes/ ngas kho'i mdzad rnam mang po go myong yang / nga mi dmangs kho na la dungs/ mtshams la lar kho tsho la bcangs pa'i brtse dung gi dbang gis rang sems la na zug skye la/ ngas kho tsho tshang ma dga' dga' spro spro byung na 'dod/ ngas kho tsho dga' ru 'jug e thub bsam nas kho tshor 'chad khrid byas pa yin/[’] zhes bshad pa yin/ de dus ngas skad cha mang po bshad pa yin/ khyod kyis bsam na ngas skad cha 'di 'dra ma rung ba bshad dgos don gang yin nam snyam yang srid/ 'on kyang / skad cha de dag nga la mtshon na btsog pa ma red/ skad cha de dag ni mi dmangs kyis spyod pa'i skad cha red la/ kho tshos skad cha de 'dra bshad dus dmigs yul btsog pa ci yang med/ gang ltar/ ngas khyod la yang bskyar don dag gzhan pa zhig bshad/ 'di ni chos dpon zhig la mtshon nas bshad na ha cang chos dang mi mthun pa'i bsam tshul red/ 'on kyang / ngas 'di dag la bsam blo btang ba ma zad yid ches kyang byed kyi yod pas/ da nga chos dpon zhig byed thabs bral/[”]

Casy spoke again, and his voice rang with pain and confusion. “I says, 'What's this call, this sperit?' An' I says, 'It's love. I love people so much I'm fit to bust, sometimes.' An' I says, 'Don't you love Jesus?' Well, I thought an' thought, an' finally I says, 'No, I don't know nobody name' Jesus. I know a bunch of stories, but I only love people. An' sometimes I love 'em fit to bust, an' I want to make 'em happy, so I been preachin' somepin I thought would make 'em happy.' An' then- I been talkin' a hell of a lot. Maybe you wonder about me using bad words. Well, they ain't bad to me no more. They're jus' words folks use, an' they don't mean nothing bad with 'em. Anyways, I'll tell you one more thing I thought out; an' from a preacher it's the most unreligious thing, and I can't be a preacher no more because I thought it an' I believe it.”
jo Di yis [“]de ci zhig red/[”] ces dris/
“What's that?” Joad asked.
kha se yis kho la cung dogs mi bde ba'i sgo nas bltas/ [“]gal srid bsam tshul 'dis khyod la phog thug 'dra btang na/ khyod rang khong khro za mi yong ngam/[”]
Casy looked shyly at him. “If it hits you wrong, don't take no offense at it, will you?”
jo Di yis [“]gcig gis nga'i sna gdong la gzhus bzhag na red ma gtogs/ de min nga la phog thug yong gi ma red/ ya/ khyod kyis gnad don ci zhig rtogs byung /[”] zhes bshad/
“I don't take no offense 'cept a bust in the nose,” said Joad. “What did you figger?”

[“]ngas dam pa'i rnam shes dang ston pa ye shu'i lam rtogs byung / ngas 'di ltar bsam byung / [‘]nga tsho dkon mchog dang ye shu la brten 'dug dgos don ci yin nam/ gcig byas na de ni nga tsho dga' sa dung sa'i skyes pa dang bud med tsho yin srid/ gcig byas na dam pa'i rnam shes dang mi'i rnam shes sogs yod tshad tshang ma gzhi gcig yin srid/ gcig byas na mi tshang mar thun mong gi rnam shes chen po zhig yod cing / mi re re ni de'i cha shas yin srid/[’] ngas de ltar bsam blo gtong bzhin pa'i skabs su/ glo bur du nga'i sems pa'i zab sa nas don dngos ni de 'dra zhig yin pa rtogs byung / de ni bden pa yin pa nga'i snying khung rus pa'i gting nas shes byung la/ da lta yang de ltar 'dod kyi yod/[”]

“I figgered about the Holy Sperit and the Jesus road. I figgered, 'Why do we got to hang it on God or Jesus? Maybe,' I figgered, 'maybe it's all men an' all women we love; maybe that's the Holy Sperit- the human sperit- the whole shebang. Maybe all men got one big soul ever'body's a part of.' Now I sat there thinkin' it, an' all of a suddent- I knew it. I knew it so deep down that it was true, and I still know it.”

jo Di yis chos dpon gyi mig kong las gsal ba'i drang gtam dmar rjen ma 'dir thad kar blta mi bzod pa ltar/ mig gnyis thang la 'phangs nas [“]khyod kyis lta ba de 'dra 'khur nas chos tshogs 'tshog thabs med/ lta ba de 'dra 'khur na mi dmangs kyis khyod rang lung pa 'di nas rgyang phud gtong gi red la/ de las ldog ste/ mchong lding byed cing ku co bton na/ mi dmangs rnams da gzod dga' yi red/ de ltar byas na kho tshor stobs shugs slebs pa'i snang ba skye yi yod/ thengs shig la nga'i a phyi la rnam shes babs pas sus kyang kho mo bkyig mi thub la/ kho mo'i khu tshur gyis mchod g.yog rgya stag 'dra po de'ang thang la bsgyel song /[”] zhes bshad/

Joad's eyes dropped to the ground as though he could not meet the naked honesty in the preacher's eyes. “You can't hold no church with idears like that,” he said. “People would drive you out of the country with idears like that. Jumpin' an' yellin'. That's what folks like. Makes 'em feel swell. When Granma got to talkin' in tongues, you couldn't tie her down. She could knock over a full-growed deacon with her fist.”

kha se yis kho la bsam gzhig gi rnam pas bltas nas [“]ngas khyod la don dag cig 'dri rgyu 'dug 'di khyod la 'dri bsam nas yun ring zhig 'gor song /[”] zhes bshad/ [“]shod dang / nga yang mtshams la lar skad cha bshad rgyur dga' mkhan zhig yin/[”]
Casy regarded him broodingly. “Somepin I like to ast you,” he said. “Somepin that been eatin' on me.” “Go ahead. I'll talk, sometimes.”

chos dpon gyis sos dal mo'i sgo nas [“]red ya/ ngas khyod la chos zhugs khrus dbang bskur ba'i nyin der nga'i snang ba ban bun yin la/ kha nang nas ye shu'i bka' chos chu bzhur bzhur byed bzhin pa'i skabs red/ khyod kyis ga la dran te/ de dus khyod kyis bu mo de'i ral ba 'then nas ma khom par yod pa'i skabs red/[”] ces bshad/

“Well”- the preacher said slowly- “here's you that I baptized right when I was in the glory roof-tree. Got little hunks of Jesus jumpin' outa my mouth that day. You won't remember 'cause you was busy pullin' that pigtail.”
jo Di yis [“]de ngas dran gyi 'dug kho mo su ze chung ba red/ lo gcig gi rjes su kho mos nga'i mdzub mo gcig bcag song /[”] zhes bshad/
“I remember,” said Joad. “That was Susy Little. She bust my finger a year later.”
[“]ya/ des na khyod la khrus dbang bskur ba des phan 'thogs song ngam/ khyod la khrus dbang bskur stangs de bzang ngam/[”]
“Well- did you take any good outa that baptizin'? Was your ways better?”
jo Di yis bsam blo cung tsam btang / [“]phan ma thogs/ dmigs bsal gyi tshor ba ci yang ma byung /[”]
Joad thought about it. “No-o-o, can't say as I felt anything.”
[“]'o na/ des khyod la gnod 'dra bskyal e song / bsam blo zhib mo thongs/[”]
“Well- did you take any bad from it? Think hard.”
jo Di yis chang dam lag tu blangs nas hub gang btung / [“]des phan gnod ci yang ma byung / gang ltar nga rang nyin der skyid po byung song /[”] khos chang dam de chos dpon la phar bsrings/
Joad picked up the bottle and took a swig. “They wasn't nothing in it, good or bad. I just had fun.” He handed the flask to the preacher.

khos shu ring zhig 'then zhor hub gang btung zhing / de nas dam be'i dma' sar slebs bzhin pa'i chang dkar la gcig bltas rjes yang bskyar hub chung chung zhig btung zhing / de nas [“]des na bzang 'dug ngas smyo rtags gza' rtags bstan nas/ gcig la gnod bskyal e yod dam bsam nas sems khur byung song /[”] zhes bshad/
He sighed and drank and looked at the low level of the whisky and took another tiny drink. “That's good,” he said. “I got to worryin' about whether in messin' around maybe I done somebody a hurt.”

jo Di yis rang nyid kyi phyi stod kyi phyogs su gcig bltas dus/ rus sbal de gyon gos las thar nas thog mar jo Di yis kho rnyed sa'i sa phyogs su mgyogs por phyir gog bzhin pa mthong / jo Di yis gog bzhin pa'i rus sbal la yud tsam bltas rjes/ dal mor yar langs te rus sbal de phyir bzung yong nas phyi stod kyi nang du phyir gcud rjes [“]ngas byis pa tshor legs skyes ci yang 'khyer med/ rus sbal 'di ma gtogs ci yang med/[”] ces bshad/

Joad looked over toward his coat and saw the turtle, free of the cloth and hurrying away in the direction he had been following when Joad found him. Joad watched him for a moment and then got slowly to his feet and retrieved him and wrapped him in the coat again. “I ain't got no present for the kids,” he said. “Nothin' but this ol' turtle.”

chos dpon gyis [“]khyad mtshar zhig la/ da snga khyod 'dir yong ba'i skabs su/ tag tag ngas Thom rgan pa'i skor la bsam blo gtong bzhin pa'i sgang yin/ nga kho dang thug 'phrad cig byed dgos pa min nam bsam nas yod/ ngas kho chos dad med mkhan zhig red bsam myong / Thom lags da lta ga 'dra 'dug[”] zhes bshad/
“It's a funny thing,” the preacher said. “I was thinkin' about ol' Tom Joad when you come along. Thinkin' I'd call in on him. I used to think he was a godless man. How is Tom?”
[“]kho ga 'dra yin pa ngas kyang mi shes/ nga khyim du ma log par lo ngo bzhi 'gor song /[”]
“I don't know how he is. I ain't been home in four years.”
[“]khos khyod la 'phrin yig ma bris sam/[”]
“Didn't he write to you?”

jo Di ngo nongs byung / [“]red ya/ nga'i a phas yi ge yag po 'bri mi shes la 'phrin yig kyang mi 'bri/ khos kyang gzhan dang 'dra bar/ rang nyid kyi ming rtags yag po 'god shes la smyug kha lce ldag kyang byed shes/ khos rgyun par/ ngag thog nas skad cha bshad mi thub sa'i mi zhig la yig thog nas bshad rin yod pa ma red zer gyi yod/[”]

Joad was embarrassed. “Well, Pa wasn't no hand to write for pretty, or to write for writin'. He'd sign up his name as nice as anybody, an' lick his pencil. But Pa never did write no letters. He always says what he couldn' tell a fella with his mouth wasn't worth leanin' on no pencil about.”
kha se yis [“]yar mar la 'grul brgyab nas bsdad pa yin nam/[”] zhes dris/
“Been out travelin' around?” Casy asked.
jo Di yis kho la cung yid mi ches pa'i rnam pas bltas [“]khyod kyis nga'i skor go ma byung ngam/ tshags par tshang ma'i steng du nga'i skor bkod byung a/[”]
Joad regarded him suspiciously. “Didn't you hear about me? I was in all the papers.”

[“]go ma byung / rtsa ba nas go ma byung / ci red/[”] khos rkang pa gcig rkang pa gzhan pa'i steng du bsnol nas/ sgal ba cung dma' sar phab ste mu mthud du lcang sdong la khen/ nyin gung mgyogs por yol bzhin 'dug la/ dgung nyi ma'i kha dog je dmar du 'gyur bzhin gda'/
“No- I never. What?” He jerked one leg over the other and settled lower against the tree. The afternoon was advancing rapidly, and a richer tone was growing on the sun.

jo Di yis spro sems 'khol bos [“]da lta khyod la bshad nas kha khog med pa byas na 'grig rgyu red/ 'on kyang / khyod kyis da dung yang chos 'chad kyi yod na ngas khyod la bshad rgyu ma red de/ gal sril bshad na khyod kyis nga'i thog la chos bshad rgyag par dogs/[”] zhes zer bzhin/ khos chang dam nang gi thigs pa ches mtha' ma'ang 'jib rjes chang dam de phar g.yugs pas/ dam be smug po leb leb de thal rdul gyi steng nas 'jam pos shud/ [“]nga mag le si Thir btson khang du lo ngo bzhi la bsdad pa yin/[”]

Joad said pleasantly, “Might's well tell you now an' get it over with. But if you was still preachin' I wouldn't tell, fear you get prayin' over me.” He drained the last of the pint and flung it from him, and the flat brown bottle skidded lightly over the dust. “I been in McAlester them four years.”

kha se glo bur du kho'i phyogs su 'khor zhing / kho'i smin ma je dma' ru btang bas kho'i dpral ba sngar bas kyang ring bar snang / [“]khyod kyis de'i skor bshad mi 'dod dam/ ngas khyod la dri ba ci yang mi 'dri/ gal srid khyod kyis don ngan zhig bsgrubs pa yin na [...][”]
Casy swung around to him, and his brows lowered so that his tall forehead seemed even taller. “Ain't wantin' to talk about it, huh? I won't ask you no questions, if you done something bad…”

jo Di yis [“]gnad don de 'drar yang bskyar thug rung ngas de ga rang byed rgyu yin/ ngas 'khrug 'dzing khrod nas mi zhig bsad pa yin/ skabs der nga tsho tshang ma bzi yod/ khos nga la gris bsnun byung bas ngas thang du yod pa'i sbyag ma zhig gis kho rang bsad pa yin/ kho'i mgo bo ril mo de nyag nyag tu btang ba yin/[”] zhes bshad/

“I'd do what I done- again,” said Joad. “I killed a guy in a fight. We was drunk at a dance. He got a knife in me, an' I killed him with a shovel that was layin' there. Knocked his head plumb to squash.”
kha se yi smin ma rang gnas su phyir slebs/ [“]khyod rang gi byas nyes thad la nongs 'gyod e skye/[”]
Casy's eyebrows resumed their normal level. “You ain't ashamed of nothin' then?”

jo Di yis [“]mi skye/ nongs 'gyod mi skye/ khos nga la gri yis bsnun par gzhigs nas khrims khang gis nga la khrims thag lo bdun ma gtogs ma bcad/ lo ngo bzhi la nang du bcug rjes bzang btson gyi mna' gan 'og glod byung /[”] zhes bshad/
“No,” said Joad, “I ain't. I got seven years, account of he had a knife in me. Got out in four- parole.”
[“]des na khyod kyis lo ngo bzhi'i ring khyim mi'i skor ci yang go yod rgyu ma red/[”]
“Then you ain't heard nothin' about your folks for four years?”

[“]de yang ma red/ lo ngo gnyis kyi sngon la a mas nga la shog byang zhig bskur byung la/ lo sngon ma'i ye shu'i 'khrungs skar dus chen skabs su a phyis kyang nga la shog byang zhig bskur byung / ston pa ye shu/ de dus btson grogs tsho gad mo dir dir shor song / shog byang gi ngos su shing sdong zhig dang / kha ba dang 'dra ba'i bkrag mdangs can gyi tshon shog sbyar 'dug la/ shog byang steng du 'di 'dra bris 'dug
“Oh, I heard. Ma sent me a card two years ago, an' las' Christmas Granma sent a card. Jesus, the guys in the cell block laughed! Had a tree an' shiny stuff looks like snow. It says in po'try:

[“][‘]ye shu'i 'khrungs skar la rten 'brel zhu/ snying du sdug pa'i byis pa/ ye shu gnyom chung yin la/ ye shu zhi dul yin/ ye shu'i 'khrungs skar sdong po'i 'og tu/ nga yis khyed la bzhag pa'i legs skyes yod/[’]
“'Merry Christmas, purty child, Jesus meek an' Jesus mild, Underneath the Christmas tree There's a gif' for you from me.'

ngas bltas na/ a phyi yis steng gi yi ge gtan nas bklags yod sa ma red/ kho mos skor skyod tshong pa zhig gi lag nas nyos pa yin nges shing / ches bkrag mdangs can po de bdams pa yin rgyu red/ nga'i btson shag nang gi btson grogs tsho gad mo shor nas shi grabs byas shing / kho tshos de nas bzung nga'i ming la ye shu gnyom chung zer gyi yod/ a phyi yis de ni de 'dra'i dgod bro ba zhig yin pa shes yod rgyu ma red/ kho mos de bkrag mdangs can zhig yin pa mthong bas steng gi yi ge la kha ya tsam yang byas yod rgyu ma red/ nga btson la bcug pa'i lo der kho mo'i mig shel bor song la/ gcig byas na de nas bzung phyir rnyed yod rgyu ma red/[”]

I guess Granma never read it. Prob'ly got it from a drummer an' picked out the one with the mos' shiny stuff on it. The guys in my cell block goddamn near died laughin'. Jesus Meek they called me after that. Granma never meant it funny; she jus' figgered it was so purty she wouldn' bother to read it. She lost her glasses the year I went up. Maybe she never did find 'em.”
kha se yis [“]mag le si Thir btson khang nas khyod tshor lta skyong ga 'dra byed kyi 'dug[”] ces dris/
“How they treat you in McAlester?” Casy asked.

[“]'grig 'dug dus ltar za ma bza' rgyu yod la/ gyon gos gtsang ma yod pa dang khrus rgyag sa'ang yod/ phyogs gzhan zhig nas bltas na yag po 'dra yod pa red/ bud med med pas dka' ngal cung 'phrad kyi yod/[”] ces bshad cing / de nas kho glo bur du gad mo shor [“]sngon ma bzang btson la glod pa'i btson pa gcig yod pa red/ 'on kyang / kho rang bzang btson la glod nas zla ba gcig ma 'gor bar bzang btson gyi dam bcar 'gal nas phyir btson du slebs/ gcig gis kho la ci'i phyir bzang btson gyi dam bcar 'gal ba yin nam zhes dris par/ de'i lan du khos/ [‘]o/ nga'i pha rgan gyi khyim la cha rkyen ha cang zhan pas/ glog sgron med la chu stor khrus khang yang med/ dpe deb klog rgyu med la za ma yang ngan ngon red/[’] ces bshad cing / khos btson khang du cha rkyen gang 'tshams yod cing / za ma'ang dus ltar bza' rgyu yod pas phyir btson du yong ba yin zer la/ phyi rol 'jig rten du yod dus/ rgyun du las ka ci zhig las par bsam blo gtong dgos pas kher rkyang gi snang ba skye bas/ khos rlangs 'khor zhig brkus nas phyir btson khang la 'dzul thabs byas pa yin zer/[”]

“Oh, awright. You eat regular, an' get clean clothes, and there's places to take a bath. It's pretty nice some ways. Makes it hard not havin' no women.” Suddenly he laughed. “They was a guy paroled,” he said. “'Bout a month he's back for breakin' parole. A guy ast him why he bust his parole. 'Well, hell,' he says. 'They got no conveniences at my old man's place. Got no 'lectric lights, got no shower baths. There ain't no books, an' the food's lousy.' Says he come back where they got a few conveniences an' he eats regular. He says it makes him feel lonesome out there in the open havin' to think what to do next. So he stole a car an' come back.”

jo Di yis rdo thal phyi la blangs nas/ thum bu bral ba'i shog bu smug po der phu zhig btab rjes tha mag sgril bzhin [“]mi des bshad pa'ang mi bden rgyu med/ mdang nub ngas rang nyid gang du nyal dgos par bsam blo gtong dgos byung la/ sems la zhed snang skyes/ ngas nga'i nyal khri brtsegs ma sems la 'khor byung la/ nga'i shag grogs btson pa des ci zhig byed kyi yod dam snyam nas bsdad pa yin/ nga dang btson grogs skor gcig gis rol dbyangs ru khag cig btsugs yod la/ gcig gis nga tshos rlung 'phrin steng du glu dbyangs len dgos zer gyi yod/ da nangs zhogs pa slebs dus/ ngas rang nyid ga dus mal las langs dgos pa'ang ma shes par/ nyal sa'i nang du cong brda grag par sgug nas bsdad pa yin/[”] zhes bshad/

Joad got out his tobacco and blew a brown paper free of the pack and rolled a cigarette. “The guy's right, too,” he said. “Las' night, thinkin' where I'm gonna sleep, I got scared. An' I got thinkin' about my bunk, an' I wonder what the stir-bug I got for a cell mate is doin'. Me an' some guys had a strang band goin'. Good one. Guy said we ought to go on the radio. An' this mornin' I didn't know what time to get up. Jus' laid there waitin' for the bell to go off.”
kha se yis khrel dgod cig byas [“]goms song na shing gshag sog le'i sgra yang dran rabs yod/[”]
Casy chuckled. “Fella can get so he misses the noise of a saw mill.”

ser zhing thal mdog babs pa'i phyi dro'i nyi 'od kyis sa gzhi la gser mdog phab cing / ma rmos lo tog gi gzhung rta la'ang gser mdog babs/ khug rta khyu zhig kho tsho'i mgo thog nas phar phyogs kyi rdzing bu'i phyogs su 'phur/ jo Di yi phyi stod nang gi rus sbal gyis bros byol gyi las 'gul gsar pa zhig gi mgo brtsams/ jo Di yis rang nyid kyi zhwa mo'i thod lce ltebs rtseg brgyab pas/ da ni kho'i zhwa mo la bya yi mchu to dang mtshungs pa'i rtse mo gug ring ma de mngon yong gi 'dug jo Di yis [“]da nga 'gro ran yod sa red/ nyi ma'i tsha drod nang du 'gro rgyur mi dga' mod/ 'on kyang / da lta tsha ba de 'dra mi che ba 'dra/[”] zhes bshad/

The yellowing, dusty, afternoon light put a golden color on the land. The cornstalks looked golden. A flight of swallows swooped overhead toward some waterhole. The turtle in Joad's coat began a new campaign of escape. Joad creased the visor of his cap. It was getting the long protruding curve of a crow's beak now. “Guess I'll mosey along,” he said. “I hate to hit the sun, but it ain't so bad now.”

kha se yis snang ba phyir bsdus nas [“]nga Thom rgan pa lags dang ma thug par yun ring zhig 'gor song la/ gang ltar nga kho dang thug par 'gro ba'i 'char gzhi'ang yod/ ngas khyod tsho'i yul mi la dus yun de 'dra'i ring po'i ring la ye shu'i dgongs pa mtshams sbyor byas mod/ ngas khyod tsho'i lag nas za ma re zos pa ma gtogs 'bul ba sogs ci yang bsdus myong med/[”] ces bshad/

Casy pulled himself together. “I ain't seen ol' Tom in a bug's age,” he said. “I was gonna look in on him anyways. I brang Jesus to your folks for a long time, an' I never took up a collection nor nothin' but a bite to eat.”

jo Di yis [“]des na mnyam du 'gro/ nga'i pha rgan gyis khyod rang mthong na dga' nges yin/ khos rgyun par/ khyod la chos dpon zhig la mi 'tshams pa'i mchu to rnon po zhig yod zer/[”] zhes bshad cing / de nas khos rang nyid kyi lham dang rus sbal gcud pa'i phyi stod kyi thum sgril de je dam du bsdams/
“Come along,” said Joad. “Pa'll be glad to see you. He always said you got too long a pecker for a preacher.” He picked up his coat roll and tightened it snugly about his shoes and turtle.

kha se yis rang nyid kyi ras lham de tshur drud yong nas/ rkang pa rjen pa lham nang du btsangs rjes [“]nga la khyod lta bu'i spobs pa med/ ngas nam rgyun thal rdul gyi nang du lcags skud dang shel chag yod rgyu red bsam nas zhed kyi yod/ rkang mdzub la rma bzo bar skrag skrag cig gzhan pa ci la'ang mi skrag[”] ces bshad/

Casy gathered in his canvas sneakers and shoved his bare feet into them. “I ain't got your confidence,” he said. “I'm always scared there's wire or glass under the dust. I don't know nothin' I hate so much as a cut toe.”

kho tshos grib bsil gyi sne nas tsham tshom zhig byas rjes/ chu'i pha rol tu 'bud par brel ba'i chu rkyal mkhan gnyis dang 'dra bar/ nyi 'od ser po'i nang du lding nas song / kho gnyis kyis gom stabs mgyogs po 'ga' re spos rjes gom kha je dal du btang nas rgyun ldan gyi mgyogs tshad kyis phyin/ ma rmos lo tog gi gzhung rtas skya mdog gi grib ma rnams 'gram gyi sa ngos su spros 'dug la/ mkha' rlung khrod du thal rdul tsha po'i dri ma zhig gis khyab/ ma rmos lo tog gi zhing kha'i mjug la bud rjes/ de'i 'phror yod pa ni ljang nag gi sring bal zhing kha red/ thal rdul gyi seng ras khrod du ljang nag gi sring bal gyi lo 'dab mthong thub la/ gsar du skye bzhin pa'i sring bal the'u yang mthong thub/ zhing kha 'dir sring bal skye ba srab mthug mi snyoms te/ smad kyi gzha' brlan che ba'i zhing kha ru sring bal mthug po skyes 'dug la/ stod kyi skam sa'i zhing kha rnams sa rjen red/ sring sdong rnams kyis dgung gi nyi mar kha gtad 'jal bzhin yod/ thag ring gi gnam sa 'dres mtshams phyogs kyi yul gru rnams ni ser smug nas rim bzhin mi snang bar gyur/ thal rdul gyis gang ba'i gzhung lam de kho gnyis kyi mdun phyogs su re mtho re dma'i tshul gyis g.yo zhing 'gul/ chu phran 'gram gyi lcang sdong rnams nub ngos su 'phred du bstar nas skyes 'dug la/ nub byang ngos kyi sa rgod du bskyur pa'i zhing kha de rim bzhin rtswa ldum thar thor skyes pa'i spang rgod la phyir 'gyur bzhin 'dug de lta na'ang / nyi 'od kyis tshig pa'i thal dri de da dung yang mkha' dbugs khrod du khyab cing / mkha' dbugs skam drags pa'i rkyen gyis/ sna khung nang gi be snabs kyang skam nas sob sob tu 'gyur gyi 'dug la/ mchi mas mig zung brlan nas tsha drod kyis mig 'bras mi skam pa'i thabs byed kyi yod/

They hesitated on the edge of the shade and then they plunged into the yellow sunlight like two swimmers hastening to get to shore. After a few fast steps they slowed to a gentle, thoughtful pace. The cornstalks threw gray shadows sideways now, and the raw smell of hot dust was in the air. The corn field ended and dark green cotton took its place, dark green leaves through a film of dust, and the bolls forming. It was spotty cotton, thick in the low places where water had stood, and bare on the high places. The plants strove against the sun. And distance, toward the horizon, was tan to invisibility. The dust road stretched out ahead of them, waving up and down. The willows of a stream lined across the west, and to the northwest a fallow section was going back to sparse brush. But the smell of burned dust was in the air, and the air was dry, so that mucus in the nose dried to a crust, and the eyes watered to keep the eyeballs from drying out.
kha se yis [“]ltos dang / thal rdul ma slebs gong du ma rmos lo tog rnams ga 'dra yag po skye yi 'dug ang / lo tog nang gi yang rtse red ya/[”] zhes bshad/
Casy said, “See how good the corn come along until the dust got up. Been a dinger of a crop.”

jo Di yis [“]nga'i yid la dran pa ni/ lo legs ni lo re rer yong mod/ 'on kyang / nam yang lo legs kyi 'bras bzang btu rgyu 'byung gi med/ a mes kyis zer na/ sa zhing rmo thengs thog ma lnga'i ring la lo tog ha cang yag byung la/ skabs de dus zhing nang du da dung rtswa ldum yod skabs red zer/[”] zhes bshad/ gzhung lam de de'u 'bur zhig las mar babs rjes/ yang bskyar dkris log thebs pa'i de'u 'bur zhig gi ngos su 'gos/

“Ever' year,” said Joad. “Ever' year I can remember, we had a good crop comin' an' it never come. Grampa says she was good the first five plowin's, while the wild grass was still in her.” The road dropped down a little hill and climbed up another rolling hill.
kha se yis [“]da 'di nas Thom rgan po'i khang pa'i bar du le dbar gcig tsam ma gtogs yod rgyu ma red/ de'u 'bur gsum pa de'i phag tu yod pa e red/[”] ces dris/
Casy said, “Ol' Tom's house can't be more'n a mile from here. Ain't she over that third rise?”
jo Di yis [“]red/ nga'i pha rgan gyis khang pa de tshur brkus yong ba bzhin/ gcig gis de phar brkus song med na de gar yod pa red/[”] ces bshad/
“Sure,” said Joad. “'Less somebody stole it, like Pa stole it.”
[“]de khyod kyi pha rgan gyis brkus yong ba red dam/[”]
“Your pa stole it?”

[“]red/ nga tshos khang rgan de 'di nas le dbar phyed tsam sa nas rnyed byung zhing / de nas khyim du drud nas yong ba yin/ khang rgan de'i nang du sngon chad khyim tshang zhig bsdad yod kyang / rjes sor gnas spar song ba red/ nga'i a mes dang a pha/ nga'i gcen po no ya bcas kyis khang pa de hril po 'khur rtsis yin mod/ 'on kyang / de ltar 'khur yong ma thub/ de bas kho tshor khang pa de'i phyed ka ma gtogs ma thob pa red/ nged tshang gi khang pa'i sne gcig ni de 'dra'i khyad mtshar zhig yin dgos don yang de'i rkyen gyis red/ kho tshos khang pa de dum bu gnyis su gshag rjes rta bcu gnyis dang drel gnyis la brten nas drud yong ba red/

“Sure, got it a mile an' a half east of here an' drug it. Was a family livin' there, an' they moved away. Grampa an' Pa an' my brother Noah like to took the whole house, but she wouldn't come.
