They only got part of her. That's why she looks so funny on one end. They cut her in two an' drug her over with twelve head of horses and two mules.

kho tsho'i 'char gzhi yin na/ sngon la phyed ka de tshur drud yong rjes lhag 'phros kyi phyed ka de yang bskyar len du 'gro rgyu de red/ 'on kyang / kho tsho phyir ma slebs gong du win khi man le yis kho tshang gi byis pa tshang ma khrid nas yong ste lhag ma phyed ka de brkus song ba red/ a pha dang a mes gnyis ka de dus khong khro ha cang zos yod la/ de'i rjes shig la kho tsho dang win khi mnyam por chang gis bzi nas/ don dag de'i skor bshad nas grod khog na ba'i bar du gad mo bgad pa red/ win khi yis zer na/ kho tshang gi khang pa de rta rgyud spel sa ru yod cing / gal srid nged tshang gi khang pa khrid yong nas kho tshang gi khang pa dang mnyam du bsdeb rgyu na/ khang phrug mang po zhig mi btsa' ba'i nges pa med zer/ win khi ni bzi yod dus mi ha cang bzang po zhig yin/ de nas bzung kho dang nga'i a pha/ a mes bcas grogs por gyur pa red la/ kho tshos go skabs nam byung la mnyam du chang 'thung gi yod/[”]

They was goin' back for the other half an' stick her together again, but before they got there Wink Manley come with his boys and stole the other half. Pa an' Grampa was pretty sore, but a little later them an' Wink got drunk together an' laughed their heads off about it. Wink, he says his house is at stud, an' if we'll bring our'n over an' breed 'em we'll maybe get a litter of crap houses. Wink was a great ol' fella when he was drunk. After that him an' Pa an' Grampa was friends. Got drunk together ever' chance they got.”

kha se yis [“]Thom khong mi yag po yod pa red/[”] ces mos mthun byas/ kho tshos gom pa ljid tig tig gis spos nas rdul 'tshub dang bcas ri mthil du babs shing / yang bskyar la ngor 'gos/ kha se yis rang nyid kyi thod pa phu thung gis phyis rjes zhwa mo klad leb de phyir gon/ de nas khos bskyar zlos kyis [“]red ya/ Thom khong mi yag po zhig yod pa red/ chos dad med mkhan zhig gi nang nas mi bzang shos de yin/ kho'i lus la dam pa'i rnam shes phran tsam zhugs yod pa'i skabs su chos tshogs la mtshams rer yong gi red la/ kho gom pa bcu grangs la mchong bzhin 'gro ba'ang mthong myong /

“Tom's a great one,” Casy agreed. They plodded dustily on down to the bottom of the draw, and then slowed their steps for the rise. Casy wiped his forehead with his sleeve and put on his flat-topped hat again. “Yes,” he repeated, “Tom was a great one. For a godless man he was a great one. I seen him in meetin' sometimes when the sperit got into him just a little, an' I seen him take ten-twelve foot jumps.

Thom rgan pa la dam pa'i rnam shes zhugs yod dus tshang mas gzab gzab byed dgos pa red ma gtogs khos rdog brdzis byed kyi red/ kho ni rta khang la bcug pa'i gseb rgan zhig dang 'dra bar gnam mchong sa mchong byed kyi red/[”] ces bshad/ kho gnyis ka la mo rjes ma'i rtser bud pa na gzhung lam gyi sne mo grog shur zhig gi nang du mar 'then yod/ grog shur nang gi lam phran de'i ngos rtsub cing kha mi snyoms la/ chu log brgyugs shul gyis 'gram ngogs gnyis ka rtsab hrul du btang yod/ grog shur gyi pha rol tu 'bud sa der 'bab stegs kyi rdo ba re 'ga' bsgrigs yod/ jo Di rkang rjen ngang nas khyar khyor gyis pha rol tu bud rjes [“]khyod kyis nga'i a pha'i skor mang po bshad song / 'on kyang / khyod kyis sku zhabs phol khi tshang gi gzhis ka nas nged tshang gi a khu jon chos zhugs khrus dbang la zhugs pa de mthong yod rgyu ma red/ skabs der kho yar rgyug ma rgyug byas shing / gnam lding sa lding yang byas/ kho rno sbreng gi mtho tshad yod pa'i shing phran gyi steng nas lding thub la/ mtshan mo'i zla 'od 'og gi spyang khyi zhig dang 'dra bar cho nge 'don bzhin shing phran gyi steng nas phar lding tshur lding byas/ a phas kho mchong ba mthong ba dang / nam rgyun kho'i sems su rang nyid ni 'di phyogs kyi ye shu mchong mkhan ang dang po de yin 'dod kyi yod pas/ khos a khu jon mchong sa'i shing phran de'i ldab gcig gis mtho ba'i shing phran zhig bdams nas/ kha nang nas phag ma zhig gis shel chag gi steng du brdzis pa lta bu'i gtser skad cig 'don bzhin shing phran gyi phyogs su brgyugs nas mchongs pas/ stabs ma legs par kho'i rkang pa g.yas pa bcag pa red/ des a pha'i lus nas rnam shes de mthar bskrad pa 'dra/ chos dpon gyis cho ga bton nas kho'i rkang pa gso thabs byed ces bshad mod/ nga'i a phas da lta kho la sman pa las gzhan pa ci yang mi dgos zer/ 'on kyang / skabs der tshad ldan gyi sman pa zhig ma rnyed/ stabs 'grig nas skor skyod so sman pa zhig gis kho'i rkang par sman bcos byas pa red/ chos dpon gyis kho'i 'dod blo la ma ltos par gang ltar chos shig bton song /[”] zhes bshad/

I tell you when ol' Tom got a dose of the Holy Sperit you got to move fast to keep from gettin' run down an' tromped. Jumpy as a stud horse in a box stall.” They topped the next rise and the road dropped into an old water-cut, ugly and raw, a ragged course, and freshet scars cutting into it from both sides. A few stones were in the crossing. Joad minced across in his bare feet. “You talk about Pa,” he said. “Maybe you never seen Uncle John the time they baptized him over to Polk's place. Why, he got to plungin' an' jumpin'. Jumped over a feeny bush as big as a piana. Over he'd jump, an' back he'd jump, howlin' like a dog-wolf in moon time. Well, Pa seen him, an' Pa, he figgers he's the bes' Jesus-jumper in these parts. So Pa picks out a feeny bush 'bout twicet as big as Uncle John's feeny bush, and Pa lets out a squawk like a sow litterin' broken bottles, an' he takes a run at that feeny bush an' clears her an' bust his right leg. That took the sperit out of Pa. Preacher wants to pray it set, but Pa says, no, by God, he'd got his heart full of havin' a doctor. Well, they wasn't a doctor, but they was a travelin' dentist, an' he set her. Preacher give her a prayin' over anyways.”

kho tsho grog shur phar phyogs kyi la ngos su gom kha ljid mos 'gos/ da ni nyi ma nub grabs yod pas tsha drod sngar ltar mi che/ mkha' dbugs da dung dron po yin na'ang sa la zags pa'i nyi zer je zhan red/ kho tsho'i g.yas phyogs su sring bal zhing kha'i khrod du lcags tsher ra ba'i bstar ba zhig 'phred rgyug gis bslas 'dug la/ thal mdog babs pa'i sring sdong ljang khu de ra ba'i phar tshur gnyis kar gcig mtshungs kyis thal mdog babs shing / skam nas ljang nag tu 'gyur bzhin 'dug

They plodded up the little rise on the other side of the water-cut. Now that the sun was on the wane some of its impact was gone, and while the air was hot, the hammering rays were weaker. The strung wire on crooked poles still edged the road. On the right-hand side a line of wire fence strung out across the cotton field, and the dusty green cotton was the same on both sides, dusty and dry and dark green.

jo Di yis zhing tshigs ra ba'i phyogs su mdzub ston byas te [“]de nga tsho'i zhing tshigs red/ dngos gnas bshad na nga tshor lcags ra zhig dgos don med mod/ 'on kyang / nga tsho la lcags skud yod cing / a pha yang lcags ra la dga' ba 'dra/ khos zer na 'dis kho la 'thab rags lta bu'i bde 'jags kyi tshor ba ster zer/ a khu jon lags kyis dgong mo zhig la kho'i shing rta'i thog nas lcags skud gru gu drug 'khur mi yong rgyu na/ deng sang lcags ra 'di yod rgyu ma red/ khos gru gu drug po phag phrug gcig la brjes song zhing / lcags skud de rnams gang zhig nas 'khyer yong ba khos ma bshad/[”] kho tsho la ngor dal mos 'go bzhin yod cing / rkang pa thal rdul gyi khrod nas yang mos 'gul bzhin thal rdul gyi reg bya rkang pas myangs/ jo Di yi mig mdangs nang du bkug nas phyir dran gyi klong du tshud/ kho'i sems su gad mo dgod bzhin pa dang 'dra bar [“]a khu jon kho smyon pa ltas ngan zhig yin/ dper na/ khos phag phrug de la ci byas lta bu red/[”] ces bshad cing / de nas kho gad mo dgod bzhin mdun du bskyod/

Joad pointed to the boundary fence. “That there's our line. We didn't really need no fence there, but we had the wire, an' Pa kinda liked her there. Said it give him a feelin' that forty was forty. Wouldn't of had the fence if Uncle John didn't come drivin' in one night with six spools of wire in his wagon. He give 'em to Pa for a shoat. We never did know where he got that wire.” They slowed for the rise, moving their feet in the deep soft dust, feeling the earth with their feet. Joad's eyes were inward on his memory. He seemed to be laughing inside himself. “Uncle John was a crazy bastard,” he said. “Like what he done with that shoat.” He chuckled and walked on.

kha se yis 'tshab snang dang bcas mu mthud du sgug mod/ 'on kyang / jo Di yis sgrung gi mjug ma bskyangs/ kha se yis dus yun gang 'tshams la sgug rjes kho'i sems la za 'phrug langs pa ltar [“]ya/ khos phag gsar la ci zhig byas song ngam/[”] zhes dris/
Jim Casy waited impatiently. The story did not continue. Casy gave it a good long time to come out. “Well, what'd he do with that shoat?” he demanded at last, with some irritation.

[“]a/ o/ khos de ma thag tu phag gsar de bshas song / khos a ma la thab kar me 'bud du bcug rjes phag pa'i 'gram pa gtubs nas tshal slang nang du 'phangs byung la/ rtsib bu dang rkang pa gcig lcags thab kyi sreg sgam du bcug pa red/ khos rtsib bu rnams tshos pa'i bar du phag 'gram zos song la/ rkang pa rnams tshos pa'i bar du rtsib bu rnams zos song / de nas kho rkang sha'i steng du mchongs nas rkang pa'i steng nas sha rdog chen po zhig bcad nas kha nang du btsangs/ byis pa tsho kho'i mtha' ru 'dus nas kho la g.yog las byas shing / khos byis pa tsho la sha rdog re byin/ 'on kyang / khos a pha la sha rdog gcig kyang ma sprad/ de ltar rim pa rim pa bzhin zos drags pa'i rkyen gyis/ kho rang skyug song la skyug tshar rjes nyal du phyin song / kho gnyid yod pa'i go skabs dang bstun nas nga'i a pha dang byis pa tshos phag rkang gi lhag ma de gtsang mar zos pa red/ de'i phyi nyin/ a khu jon lags mal las langs ma thag tu phag rkang gzhan pa de sreg sgam du bcug skabs der a phas/ [‘]a rog jon/ khyod kyis phag pa cha tshang ba zhig de 'dra byas nas zos tshar rgyu yin nam/[’] zhes dris par/ a khu jon gyis/ [‘]Thom/ de 'dra byed rgyu'i 'char gzhi yod/ ngas phag sha dran nas shi grabs byas song / 'on kyang / phag sha 'di tshang ma zos ma tshar gong du 'ga' re rul mi 'gro'am snyam nas sems khur skye/ 'o na 'di 'dra byas na ga 'dra 'dug khyod kyis nga la lcags skud gru gu 'ga' re phyir slogs dang / de nas khyod kyis sder ma 'khyer yong nas 'ga' re zos chog[’]ces bshad par/ a pha glen pa min pas/ khos jon la phag shas na tsha slong ba'i bar du zos shog ces bshad/ a khu jon lags 'gro ran dus phag sha'i phyed tsam ma gtogs bza' thub mi 'dug pas/ a phas kho la/ [‘]tshwa snyal byas te mi 'khyer ram/[’] zhes bshad mod/ 'on kyang / de ni a khu jon gyi gshis ka ma yin te/ khos phag sha dran dus phag pa cha tshang zhig bza' 'dod la/ zos nas yid tshims song na de nas phag cig gi nye sar yang mi btud/ de bas/ kho song rjes a phas phag sha lhag ma rnams tshwa snyal byas song /[”]

“Huh? Oh! Well, he killed that shoat right there, an' he got Ma to light up the stove. He cut out pork chops an' put 'em in the pan, an' he put ribs an' a leg in the oven. He et chops till the ribs was done, an' he et ribs till the leg was done. An' then he tore into that leg. Cut off big hunks of her an' shoved 'em in his mouth. Us kids hung around slaverin', an' he give us some, but he wouldn't give Pa none. By an' by he et so much he throwed up an' went to sleep. While he's asleep us kids an' Pa finished off the leg. Well, when Uncle John woke up in the mornin' he slaps another leg in the oven. Pa says, 'John, you gonna eat that whole damn pig?' An' he says, 'I aim to, Tom, but I'm scairt some of her'll spoil 'fore I get her et, hungry as I am for pork. Maybe you better get a plate an' gimme back a couple rolls of wire.' Well, sir, Pa wasn't no fool. He jus' let Uncle John go on an' eat himself sick of pig, an' when he drove off he hadn't et much more'n half. Pa says, 'Whyn't you salt her down?' But not Uncle John; when he wants pig he wants a whole pig, an' when he's through, he don't want no pig hangin' around. So off he goes, and Pa salts down what's left.”

kha se yis [“]gal srid ngas da dung yang chos 'chad kyi yod rgyu na/ ngas de'i steng nas bslab bya zhig bzos nas khyod la 'chad khrid cig byed rgyu red mod/ 'on kyang / ngas deng sang de rigs byed kyi med/ khyod kyis bltas na khos de 'dra ci'i phyir byas pa yin nam/[”] zhes bshad/
Casy said, “While I was still in the preachin' sperit I'd a made a lesson of that an' spoke it to you, but I don't do that no more. What you s'pose he done a thing like that for?”

jo Di yis [“]ngas mi shes/ kho rang gis phag sha dran drags pa red/ gnas tshul de dran na grod khog ltogs yong gi 'dug a/ lo ngo bzhi'i ring la ngas phag sha bsregs ma leb mo bzhi ma gtogs bza' rgyu ma byung / bzhi po de yang lo re'i ye shu'i 'khrungs skar skabs su thengs re sprod pa de red/[”] ces bshad/
“I dunno,” said Joad. “He jus' got hungry for pork. Makes me hungry jus' to think of it. I had jus' four slices of roastin' pork in four years- one slice ever' Christmus.”

kha se yis rang nyid kyi bsam tshul brjod pa'i tshul gyis [“]gcig byas na dam pa'i gsung rab nang gi bag med zas ston ltar/ Thom gyis ba mo tshon por gsos rjes da gzod bsha' bsam pa yin rgyu red/[”] ces bshad/
Casy suggested elaborately, “Maybe Tom'll kill the fatted calf like for the prodigal in Scripture.”

jo Di yi gdong la cung khyad gsod kyi rnam pa zhig shar/ [“]khyod kyis nga'i a pha ni mi ci 'dra yin min shes mi 'dug gal srid khos khyim bya zhig gsod rgyu na/ gtser skad sgrog mkhan che shos de kho yin pa las khyim bya yin rgyu ma red/ kho la bslab bya zhig 'thob rgyu med/ khos rgyun par ye shu'i 'khrungs skar dus ston la dmigs nas phag pa zhig gso yi red mod/ 'on kyang / phag pa de zla ba dgu pa'i nang du lto ba sbos pa'am/ yang na ci zhig byung nas shi 'gro bas phag sha bza' rgyu med par 'gyur 'gro yi red/ a khu jon gyis phag sha za 'dod dus bza' ba red la/ bza' rgyu'ang yod pa red/[”]

Joad laughed scornfully. “You don't know Pa. If he kills a chicken most of the squawkin' will come from Pa, not the chicken. He don't never learn. He's always savin' a pig for Christmus and then it dies in September of bloat or somepin so you can't eat it. When Uncle John wanted pork he et pork. He had her.”

kho tsho de'u 'bur gyi rtse mo'i khugs so der slebs pa na/ gsham du jo Di tshang gi khyim gzhis gsal por mthong thub/ jo Di yis glo bur du 'gro mtshams bzhag nas [“]'di sngon dang mi 'dra/ khang pa la gcig ltos dang / don dag cig byung ba 'dra/ mi gcig kyang mthong rgyu mi 'dug[”] ces bshad cing / kho gnyis ka de gar 'greng nas gsham gyi khang tshom chung chung khag la bltas nas bsdad/

They moved over the curving top of the hill and saw the Joad place below them. And Joad stopped. “It ain't the same,” he said. “Looka that house. Somepin's happened. They ain't nobody there.” The two stood and stared at the little cluster of buildings.
le'u lnga pa/
CHAPTER 5

sa bdag rnams sa gzhis kyi steng du yong gi yod la/ mang che bar kho tsho'i mgrin tshab pa yong gi yod/ kho tsho rlangs 'khor chung ba khebs ldan ma'i nang du bsdad nas yong gi yod/ kho tshos sa skam mdzub bar du 'phur nas tshod lta byed la/ mtshams la lar kho tshos sa ngos su gsor 'big chen po bskor nas sa bcud brtag dpyad byed/ bogs len zhing pa rnams kyis rang nyid kyi nyi mas tshos pa'i sgo ra'i nang nas/ zhing kha brgyud nas yong ba'i khebs ldan rlangs 'khor chung ba la dogs mi bde ba'i rnam pas lta/ mjug mthar sa bdag gi rlangs 'khor chung ba sgo ra'i nang du bskor nas yong zhing / rlangs 'khor gyi sge'u khung nas ske bsrings nas skad cha bshad/ bogs len zhing pa rlangs 'khor gyi 'gram du 'greng nas yud tsam la bsdad rjes/ rang nyid kyi sgyid khug gi steng du tsog pur bsdad nas/ sa nas shing thur zhig btsal nas sa la ri mo 'bri/

THE OWNERS OF THE land came onto the land, or more often a spokesman for the owners came. They came in closed cars, and they felt the dry earth with their fingers, and sometimes they drove big earth augers into the ground for soil tests. The tenants, from their sun-beaten dooryards, watched uneasily when the closed cars drove along the fields. And at last the owner men drove into the dooryards and sat in their cars to talk out of the windows. The tenant men stood beside the cars for a while, and then squatted on their hams and found sticks with which to mark the dust.

yangs por phyes yod pa'i sgo mo khag gi nang nas/ bud med tshos phyi logs su bltas nas 'greng yod la/ kho mo tsho'i rgyab phyogs nas skra lo ma rmos lo tog dang 'dra ba'i byis pa tshos mig gnyis yangs por bgrad cing / rkang pa rjen pa gnyis ka gcig thog gcig brtsegs byas nas rkang mdzub rnams 'gul bzhin sdod/ bud med dang byis pa tshos rang re'i skyes pa tshos sa bdag la skad cha bshad par ltad mo bltas/ kho tsho khu sim po red/

In the open doors the women stood looking out, and behind them the children- corn-headed children, with wide eyes, one bare foot on top of the other bare foot, and the toes working. The women and the children watched their men talking to the owner men. They were silent.

sa bdag 'ga' re rang nyid kyis ci zhig byed dgos pa la mi dga' bas snying rje dang ldan/ sa bdag 'ga' re rtsub spyod la mi dga' bas sems nas khong khro zos/ sa bdag 'ga' res snying rje med pa ma byas na sa bdag byed mi thub pa snga sa nas rtogs yod pas snying rje blo yis btang / kho tsho tshang ma rang nyid las kyang che ba'i rgya rnyi zhig gi nang du tshud yod/ kho tsho las 'ga' shas shig rang nyid bran du bkol ba'i rtsis rig 'di la sdang sems yod la/ 'ga' re de la 'jigs skrag skye zhing / yang 'ga' res 'di la dad pa byed kyi yod de/ rgyu mtshan ni/ 'dis rang nyid bsam gzhig dang tshor ba las skyob kyi yod pas so// dngul khang de'am yang na spyi gnyer khang 'di la de dgos kyi 'dug 'di 'dod kyi 'dug de nges par du bsgrub dgos kyi 'dug 'di nges par du yod dgos kyi 'dug sogs zer nas/ phal cher dngul khang 'di'am spyi gnyer khang de ni bsam gzhig dang tshor ba med pa'i srin po lta bu zhig yin par smra la/ 'dis kho tsho rnyi la bzung yod pa lta bur smra/ kho tsho ni mi tsam dang bran g.yog tsam yin pa'i rkyen gyis/ kho tshos 'phrul chas dang bdag po gnyis ka dus mnyam du yin pa'i dngul khang dang spyi gnyer khang gi thad la 'gan 'khur gyi med/ sa bdag 'ga' re 'di lta bu'i snying rje bral zhing dbang shugs che ba'i bdag po zhig gi bran g.yog tu gyur par spobs pa skye bzhin yod/ sa bdag tsho rlangs 'khor gyi nang nas bsdad de 'grel bshad byed/ sa 'di sa rgyu zhan pa khyod tshos shes gsal red/ khyod tshos sa 'di la sder shad ga tshod cig brgyab pa dkon mchog gis mkhyen/

Some of the owner men were kind because they hated what they had to do, and some of them were angry because they hated to be cruel, and some of them were cold because they had long ago found that one could not be an owner unless one were cold. And all of them were caught in something larger than themselves. Some of them hated the mathematics that drove them, and some were afraid, and some worshiped the mathematics because it provided a refuge from thought and from feeling. If a bank or a finance company owned the land, the owner man said, The Bank- or the Company- needs- wants- insists-must have- as though the Bank or the Company were a monster, with thought and feeling, which had ensnared them. These last would take no responsibility for the banks or the companies because they were men and slaves, while the banks were machines and masters all at the same time. Some of the owner men were a little proud to be slaves to such cold and powerful masters. The owner men sat in the cars and explained. You know the land is poor. You've scrabbled at it long enough, God knows.

tsog pur bsdad pa'i bogs len zhing pa tshos mgo bo ldem tsam byed cing / kho tshos bsam blo gtong bzhin thal rdul khrod du ri mo 'bri/ red ya/ kho tshos shes yod/ dkon mchog gis mkhyen yod/ gal srid thal rdul gnam la mi 'phur rgyu na/ gal srid sa shun rnams sa ngos nas sdod du 'jug rgyu na/ gnas tshul 'di 'dra'i sdug po zhig yin mi srid/

The squatting tenant men nodded and wondered and drew figures in the dust, and yes, they knew, God knows. If the dust only wouldn't fly. If the top would only stay on the soil, it might not be so bad.

sa bdag tsho don gyi mdo rtsa la babs/ sa 'di'i sa rgyu je zhan nas je zhan red/ sring bal gyis sa zhing la shugs rkyen ci zhig thebs pa khyod tshos shes gsal red/ des sa rgyu brlags nas sa zhing gi zungs khrag tshang ma 'jib nas 'gro yi yod pa red/
The owner men went on leading to their point: You know the land's getting poorer. You know what cotton does to the land; robs it, sucks all the blood out of it.

tsog pur sdod mkhan tshos mgo bo ldem/ kho tshos shes la dkon mchog gis kyang mkhyen/ gal srid kho tshos lo tog gi rigs mi 'dra ba khag res mos kyis btab pa yin na sa zhing gi zungs khrag phyir gso thub kyang srid/
The squatters nodded- they knew, God knew. If they could only rotate the crops they might pump blood back into the land.

red ya/ da 'gor drags pa red/ sa bdag tshos rang nyid las kyang dbang shugs che ba'i srin po de'i spyod stangs dang bsam blo la 'grel bshad byed/ zhing pa su zhig yin rung / rang kha sos pa'i steng du dpya khral sprod thub pa yin na khos sa zhing mu mthud du btab na chog
Well, it's too late. And the owner men explained the workings and the thinkings of the monster that was stronger than they were. A man can hold land if he can just eat and pay taxes; he can do that.
red/ de chog gi red/ nyin zhig ston thog la lo nyes byung ste dngul khang nas sgor mo bskyi dgos pa'i bar du chog gi red/
Yes, he can do that until his crops fail one day and he has to borrow money from the bank.

'on kyang / ltos dang / dngul khang dang spyi gnyer khang gis de ltar byed rgyu ma red/ gcan gzan 'di tshos mkha' dbugs rngub mi dgos la phag sha tsam yang bza' mi dgos/ kho tshos rngub pa'i dbugs ni khe spogs yin la/ kho tshos bza' ba'i kha zas ni sgor mo'i steng gi skyed ka yin/ gal srid kho tshor 'di dag ma yod na/ kho tsho yang khyod la mkha' dbugs dang phag sha med na mug shi thebs pa ltar mug shi thebs kyi red/ 'di ni yid skyo ba zhig red mod/ 'on kyang / don dngos ni de ltar red/ de ltar red/

But- you see, a bank or a company can't do that, because those creatures don't breathe air, don't eat side-meat. They breathe profits; they eat the interest on money. If they don't get it, they die the way you die without air, without side-meat. It is a sad thing, but it is so. It is just so.

tsog pur 'dug mkhan tshos ha go song ba'i brda yis yar la bltas/ nga tsho gnas skabs ring 'di ltar bsdad na 'grig gi ma red dam/ gcig byas na lo rjes mar lo legs 'byung yang srid/ lo rjes mar sring bal ga tshod cig yod srid pa sus shes/ deng sang ga sa gang du dmag 'khrug rgyag gi yod pas sring bal gyi rin gong ga tshod 'phar srid pa sus shes/ kho tshos sring bal spyad de 'gad rdzas bzo bzhin yod pa ma red dam/ dmag gos kyang sring bal gyis bzos pa ma red dam/ dmag 'khrug yud tsam la brgyab na sring bal gyi rin gong gnam la 'gro nges red/ gcig byas na lo rjes mar de 'dra yin rgyu red/ kho tsho'i gdong la dri ba'i mdangs shig babs nas yar bltas/

The squatting men raised their eyes to understand. Can't we just hang on? Maybe the next year will be a good year. God knows how much cotton next year. And with all the wars- God knows what price cotton will bring. Don't they make explosives out of cotton? And uniforms? Get enough wars and cotton'll hit the ceiling. Next year, maybe. They looked up questioningly.

nga tshos de la yid bcol mi thub/ dngul khang srin po des dus rtag par khe spogs len dgos la/ des sgug nas mi sdod/ de ltar bsdad na de shi yi red/ ma red/ de ltar bsdad na dpya khral je mtho ru 'gro yi red/ srin po de skyed mtshams chad na de shi yi red/ kho nam yang gzugs stobs che chung gcig gi steng nas sdod mi thub/
We can't depend on it. The bank- the monster has to have profits all the time. It can't wait. It'll die. No, taxes go on. When the monster stops growing, it dies. It can't stay one size.

mdzub mo snyi mo tshos rlangs 'khor gyi sge'u khung gi them pa'i steng du rdeb tsam rdeb tsam byed la/ mdzub mo mkhregs po tshos shing thur bzung nas sa ngos su ri mo bar med du 'bri/ bogs len zhing pa tshang gi nyi mas tshos pa'i sgo lam bar du bud med tshos dbugs ring 'then bzhin rkang pa'i steng 'og brjes pas/ da sngon steng du yod pa'i rkang pa de da lta 'og tu 'khel nas rkang mdzub rnams 'gul 'gul byed/ sgo khyi rnams sa bdag gi rlangs 'khor gyi 'khris su brgyugs nas rlangs 'khor gyi 'khor lo bzhi po re re'i steng du gcin pa btang / khyim bya rnams nyi 'od nang gi thal rdul khrod du nyal nas gshog rdeb byas te/ thal ba rnams rang nyid kyi spu gseng brgyud nas pags pa bar du 'thim par byas/ phag tshang chung chung nang gi phag pa tshos lto gzhong nang gi phag lto lhag ma de brtsad nas tsi shur 'debs/

Soft fingers began to tap the sill of the car window, and hard fingers tightened on the restless drawing sticks. In the doorways of the sun-beaten tenant houses, women sighed and then shifted feet so that the one that had been down was now on top, and the toes working. Dogs came sniffing near the owner cars and wetted on all four tires one after another. And chickens lay in the sunny dust and fluffed their feathers to get the cleansing dust down to the skin. In the little sties the pigs grunted inquiringly over the muddy remnants of the slops.

tsog pur 'dug mkhan tshos mgo bo yang bskyar sgur/ khyod kyis ci zhig byed du 'jug 'dod dam/ nga tsho'i 'bru rigs thob skal je nyung du gtong mi rung / da yod kyi thob skal gyis kyang kha mi sos pa'i tshod red/ byis pa tsho rtag par grod khog ltogs nas yod/ nga tshor gyon gos med la yod pa tshang ma thed po dang rnying hrul red/ gal srid khyim mtshes tshang ma nga tsho dang gcig mtshungs min rgyu na/ de nas chos tshogs la 'gro rgyu yang ngo tsha dgos pa'i tshod red/

The squatting men looked down again. What do you want us to do? We can't take less share of the crop- we're half starved now. The kids are hungry all the time. We got no clothes, torn an' ragged. If all the neighbors weren't the same, we'd be ashamed to go to meeting.

mjug mthar sa bdag tshos skad cha'i mdo rtsa bshad/ bogs gtong lam lugs de da lta yongs su 'gro thabs med/ mi gcig dang 'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor gcig gis khyim tshang bcu gnyis sam bcu bzhi yi las ka las thub cing / kho la gla cha zhig sprad na khos lo tog hril po brngas tshar gyi yod/ nga tshos kyang 'di ltar byed mi 'dod kyang / 'di ltar mi byed thabs med red/ 'on kyang / srin po der na tsha zhig phog yod la/ srin po de la gnad don zhig byung yod/

And at last the owner men came to the point. The tenant system won't work any more. One man on a tractor can take the place of twelve or fourteen families. Pay him a wage and take all the crop. We have to do it. We don't like to do it. But the monster's sick. Something's happened to the monster.
'on kyang / khyod kyis sring bal btab na sa zhing 'di gsod nges red/
But you'll kill the land with cotton.

de nga tshos shes/ sa zhing 'di ma shi sngon du nga tshos sring bal mgyogs por len dgos/ de nas nga tshos sa zhing 'di btsong rgyu yin/ shar phyogs kyi khyim tshang mang po zhig rang nyid la bdag pa'i sa zhing re yod par dga'/
We know. We've got to take cotton quick before the land dies. Then we'll sell the land. Lots of families in the East would like to own a piece of land.
bogs len zhing pa tsho'i gdong la sems 'tshab kyi nyams shig shar/ 'o na nga tshos ci byed/ nga tshos ci zhig gis rang kha gso/
The tenant men looked up alarmed. But what'll happen to us? How'll we eat?
khyod tsho sa gzhis 'di dang kha 'bral dgos/ rmos gshol rnams khyod tsho'i sgo ra brgyud nas 'gro yi red/
You'll have to get off the land. The plows'll go through the dooryard.

da lta tsog pur 'dug mkhan tsho khong khro dang bcas yar langs/ nga'i a mes kyis sa gzhis 'di blangs pa red/ khos sa gzhis 'di tshur len pa'i ched du in Di'i mi tsho gsod pa dang kho tsho mtha' skrod gtong dgos byung ba red/ nga'i a pha sa gzhis 'di'i steng du skyes pa red la/ khos sa gzhis 'di'i steng gi rtswa ldum bal zhing dug sbrul bsad yod/ de nas nam zla ngan pa zhig slebs pas khos sgor mo nyung tsam bskyi dgos byung ba red/ de nas nga tsho skyes pa red/ pha gi'i khang pa de'i nang nas nga tsho'i phru gu tsho btsas pa red/ de nas a phas sgor mo bskyi dgos byung / de ltar sa gzhis 'di rim bzhin dngul khang la bdag pa red/ 'on kyang / de lta na'ang/ nga tsho rang nyid kyis bskyangs pa'i lo tog las nga tsho la cung zad 'thob kyi yod/

And now the squatting men stood up angrily. Grampa took up the land, and he had to kill the Indians and drive them away. And Pa was born here, and he killed weeds and snakes. Then a bad year came and he had to borrow a little money. An' we was born here. There in the door-our children born here. And Pa had to borrow money. The bank owned the land then, but we stayed and we got a little bit of what we raised.

de nga tshos shes/ de tsho tshang ma shes/ 'di dag byed mkhan nga tsho ma red/ dngul khang red/ dngul khang zer ba ni mi zhig dang mi 'dra/ kho ni sa zhing dbyin mu'u stong phrag lnga bcu bdag la bzung ba'i sa bdag cig red la/ sa bdag 'di mi zhig dang mi 'dra/ de ni srin po zhig red/
We know that- all that. It's not us, it's the bank. A bank isn't like a man. Or an owner with fifty thousand acres, he isn't like a man either. That's the monster.

bogs len zhing pa tshos skad ngan shor/ de red/ 'on kyang / 'di nga tsho'i sa gzhis red a/ 'di nga tshos tshad la 'jal nas sger la bgos pa red la/ nga tsho 'di'i steng du skyes pa red/ 'di'i steng du nga tsho bsad pa yod la shi ba'ang yod/ sa 'di bzang rgyu med rung / 'on kyang / 'di nga tsho rang nyid kyi yin/ nga tsho sa 'di'i steng du skyes nas/ sa 'di'i steng du las ka las shing / sa 'di'i steng nas shi yi yod/ 'dis sa 'di nga tsho'i yin pa byas yod/ des nga tsho sa 'di'i sa bdag yin pa ra sprod byas yod pa las/ shog bu'i steng gi ang grangs 'ga' res go ci zhig chod/

Sure, cried the tenant men, but it's our land. We measured it and broke it up. We were born on it, and we got killed on it, died on it. Even if it's no good, it's still ours. That's what makes it ours- being born on it, working it, dying on it. That makes ownership, not a paper with numbers on it.
dgongs dag 'on kyang / 'di dag byed mkhan nga tsho ma red/ srin po de red/ dngul khang zer ba de mi dang mi 'dra/
We're sorry. It's not us. It's the monster. The bank isn't like a man.
red/ 'on kyang / dngul khang de mis btsugs shing mis skyong gi yod pa ma red dam/
Yes, but the bank is only made of men.

ma red/ khyod rang nor 'dug rbad de nor 'dug dngul khang ni mi las gzhan pa zhig red/ dngul khang nang gi mi re res dngul khang gis ci byed bzhin par zhe mer langs mod/ dngul khang gis de ltar mu mthud du byas nas 'gro yi yod/ ngas khyod la bshad ya/ dngul khang ni mi las brgal ba'i dngos po zhig red/ de ni srin po zhig red/ mis de bskrun pa red mod/ 'on kyang / mis de stangs 'dzin byed thub kyi med/

No, you're wrong there- quite wrong there. The bank is something else than men. It happens that every man in a bank hates what the bank does, and yet the bank does it. The bank is something more than men, I tell you. It's the monster. Men made it, but they can't control it.

bogs len zhing pa tshos skad ngan bton/ nga'i a mes kyis sa 'di'i ched du in Di'i mi rigs bsad pa red la/ nga'i a phas sa 'di'i ched du dug sbrul bsad pa red/ gcig byas na nga tshos dngul khang bsad na 'grig rgyu red/ dngul khang 'di in Di'i mi rigs dang dug sbrul las kyang gdug rtsub che/ gcig byas na nga'i a mes dang a pha'i byed stangs ltar/ nga tshos sa 'di'i ched du 'thab 'dzing byed dgos rgyu red/

The tenants cried, Grampa killed Indians, Pa killed snakes for the land. Maybe we can kill banks- they're worse than Indians and snakes. Maybe we got to fight to keep our land, like Pa and Grampa did.
da ni sa bdag khong khro zos song / khyod tsho sa gzhis 'di dang kha 'bral dgos/
And now the owner men grew angry. You'll have to go.
bogs len zhing pa tshos sdug skad bton/ 'on kyang / de nga tsho'i red a/ nga tshos [...] /
But it's ours, the tenant men cried. We…
ma red/ de da lta dngul khang ste/ srin po des bdag tu bzung yod/ khyod tsho sa gzhis 'di dang kha 'bral dgos/
No. The bank, the monster owns it. You'll have to go.
in Di'i mi rigs slebs skabs nga'i a mes kyi byed stangs ltar/ nga tshos me mda' lag tu 'dzin rgyu yin/ de nas khyod tshos ci zhig byed dam/
We'll get our guns, like Grampa when the Indians came. What then?

un/ thog mar nyen rtog pa yong gi red la/ de nas dmag dpung yong gi red/ gal srid khyod tsho mu mthud du sa gzhis 'di'i steng du 'dug thabs byas na/ de ni rku 'phrog la brtsi yi red la/ gal srid khyod tshos mi gsod thabs byas na/ khyod tsho mi gsod nyes can du 'gyur gyi red/ srin po de mi ma yin mod/ 'on kyang / des rang nyid kyis ci zhig 'dod na mi la de sgrub tu 'jug thub pa yin/
Well- first the sheriff, and then the troops. You'll be stealing if you try to stay, you'll be murderers if you kill to stay. The monster isn't men, but it can make men do what it wants.
'on kyang / sa gzhis 'di dang kha bral na/ nga tsho gang du 'gro dgos/ ji ltar 'gro dgos/ nga tshor sgor mo med ya/
But if we go, where'll we go? How'll we go? We got no money.

sa bdag tshos tshig lan btab/ dgongs dag dngul khang ste/ sa zhing dbyin mu'u stong phrag lnga bcu bdag tu bzung ba'i sa bdag gis de thad la 'gan 'khur mi thub/ khyod tsho ni rang nyid la mi dbang ba'i sa gzhis kyi steng du bsdad yod pa red/ gnad don 'di sel ba yin na/ gcig byas na ston ka khyod tsho sring bal 'thog tu yong chog srid/ gcig byas na khyod tsho dbul sel las gzhi 'tshol du 'gro chog rgyu red khyod tsho kha li h+phor ne ya mnga' sde la 'gro rgyu min nam/ der las ka las rgyu yod la dbyar dgun khyad par med/ der khyod tshos lag pa gang du bsrings na de ru tsha lu ma 'thog rgyu yod/ yul der dus nam yang lo tog gi rigs re brnga sdud byed rgyu yod pas khyod tsho yul der ci'i phyir mi 'gro/ de ltar bshad rjes sa bdag tshos rang nyid kyi rlangs 'khor gyi me kha gsos nas bzhud/

We're sorry, said the owner men. The bank, the fifty-thousand-acre owner can't be responsible. You're on land that isn't yours. Once over the line maybe you can pick cotton in the fall. Maybe you can go on relief. Why don't you go on west to California? There's work there, and it never gets cold. Why, you can reach out anywhere and pick an orange. Why, there's always some kind of crop to work in. Why don't you go there? And the owner men started their cars and rolled away.

thal rdul khrod du rtags ris 'god ched dang / 'char gzhi 'then ched/ bsam blo gtong ched du/ bogs len zhing pa tsho rang nyid kyi sgyid khug gi steng du yang bskyar tsog pur phyir bsdad/ kho tsho'i nyi mas tshig pa'i gdong pa nag po red la/ kho tsho'i nyi 'od kyis gtses pa'i mig mdangs dkar po red/ bud med tsho sgo lam bar nas gzab gzab ngang phyir bud nas so so'i skyes pa tsho'i phyogs su song zhing / byis pa tsho bud med tsho'i rgyab phyogs su gzab gzab ngang 'jab bzhin yong nas/ gal la thug tshe 'bro chog chog byas/ gzhon nu rnams kho tsho'i a pha tsho'i 'gram du tsog pur bsdad 'dug ste/ 'di ltar bsdad na rang nyid kyang skyes pa'i gras su tshud pa'i snang ba ster gyi yod/ yud tsam rjes nas bud med tshos dri ba bton/ khos ci zhig dgos zer ram/

The tenant men squatted down on their hams again to mark the dust with a stick, to figure, to wonder. Their sunburned faces were dark, and their sun-whipped eyes were light. The women moved cautiously out of the doorways toward their men, and the children crept behind the women, cautiously, ready to run. The bigger boys squatted beside their fathers, because that made them men. After a time the women asked, What did he want?

skyes pa tshos mgo bo yar btegs nas lta tsam byas shing / kho tsho'i mig nang du sdug bsngal gyi dud sprin 'khrigs/ nga tsho sa 'di dang kha 'bral dgos zer la/ de nas shul du 'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor dang lta rtog pa mngags nas sa 'di bzo grwa ltar 'dzin skyong byed dgos zer/
And the men looked up for a second, and the smolder of pain was in their eyes. We got to get off. A tractor and a superintendent. Like factories.
bud med tshos/ 'di dang bral nas nga tsho gang du 'gro'am/ zhes dris/
Where'll we go? the women asked.
nga tshos mi shes/ nga tshos mi shes/
We don't know. We don't know.

bud med tsho mgyogs por phar phyin/ phar so so'i khang pa'i nang du phyin zhing / mdun phyogs kyi byis pa tsho yang phar ded/ kho mo tshos gsal por shes pa ni/ 'di ltar sdug bsngal gyis gtses shing mgo bo 'thoms pa'i skyes pa ni khong khro za sla la/ tha na rang nyid dga' ba'i gnyen nye'i steng du'ang khong khro za srid/ kho tshos skyes pa tsho gcig pur bzhag nas/ kho tshor sa rdul khrod nas bsam blo gtong bzhin 'char gzhi 'then pa'i go skabs byin/

And the women went quickly, quietly back into the houses and herded the children ahead of them. They knew that a man so hurt and so perplexed may turn in anger, even on people he loves. They left the men alone to figure and to wonder in the dust.

yud tsam rjes su/ bogs len zhing pas phar phyogs ra skor nang du mig bsher byas/ khos lo bcu'i sngon la bsgar ba'i khron chu 'then 'khor dang de'i ngang pa'i ske dang 'dra ba'i lag 'ju/ wa kha'i steng gi lcags kyi me tog gi ri mo/ khyim bya stong phrag lhag bsad myong sa'i gtsab gdan/ lag cha 'jog khang du bzhag yod pa'i lag skyor rmos gshol/ de'i steng phyogs kyi lcam shing nas mar dpyangs pa'i kha bres sogs yod tshad la re re bzhin mig bsher byas/

After a time perhaps the tenant man looked about- at the pump put in ten years ago, with a goose-neck handle and iron flowers on the spout, at the chopping block where a thousand chickens had been killed, at the hand plow lying in the shed, and the patent crib hanging in the rafters over it.
byis pa tsho khang pa'i nang nas bud med tsho'i mtha' ru rub/ a ma/ da nga tshos ci byed dgos sam/ nga tsho gang du 'gro dgos sam/
The children crowded about the women in the houses. What we going to do, Ma? Where we going to go?

bud med tshos ngas mi shes/ phyi logs su rtsed mo rtse ru rgyugs/ 'on kyang / a pha'i nye sar ma 'gro/ nye sar song na gcar rdung gzed srid zer/ bud med tsho mu mthud du so so'i lag gi las ka la brel/ 'on kyang / kho tshos mgo 'thoms shing 'dang rgyag bzhin pa'i rang nyid kyi skyes pa tsho mig gis 'tshos/

The women said, We don't know, yet. Go out and play. But don't go near your father. He might whale you if you go near him. And the women went on with the work, but all the time they watched the men squatting in the dust- perplexed and figuring.

'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor rnams gzhung lam brgyud nas slebs shing zhing kha'i nang du song / stobs che ba'i gog nur mkhan 'di dag ni 'bu srin dang 'dra la/ 'di dag la 'bu srin dang 'dra ba'i bla na med pa'i stobs shugs kyang ldan/ kho tsho zhing kha'i steng du gog nur gyis yong / kho tsho 'gro skabs rang nyid la lcags thag gi lam bu zhig 'ding la/ kho tsho de'i steng nas 'gril nas 'gro zhing / song ba dang chabs cig tu lcags thag lam bu de ltebs nas 'khyer 'gro/ bud snum gyi shugs la brten pa'i 'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor rnams bsdad yod dus pur sgra sgrog la/ 'gro mgo rtsom dus ldir sgra sgrog cing / bang tshad rgyun ldan la slebs tshe zir sgra sgrog bzhin 'gro/ sna gdong ril ril can gyi srin po 'dis thal rdul gnam la sprugs shing / rang nyid kyi sna gdong de rdul phung khrod du gtad nas ra ba dang sgo ra brgyud cing / grog rong nas mar la 'bab cing la ngos su yar la thon nas/ lung pa 'phred kyis bcad nas drang mor 'gro/ srin po 'di dag sa steng du mi 'gro bar rang nyid kyi thag lam steng du 'gro bzhin yod/ kho tshos de'u 'bur dang grog shur/ chu rgyun/ ra ba dang khang pa bcas snang med du btang nas 'gro/

THE TRACTORS came over the roads and into the fields, great crawlers moving like insects, having the incredible strength of insects. They crawled over the ground, laying the track and rolling on it and picking it up. Diesel tractors, puttering while they stood idle; they thundered when they moved, and then settled down to a droning roar. Snubnosed monsters, raising the dust and sticking their snouts into it, straight down the country, across the country, through fences, through dooryards, in and out of gullies in straight lines. They did not run on the ground, but on their own roadbeds. They ignored hills and gulches, water courses, fences, houses.

lcags kyi 'dug stegs steng du bsdad yod pa'i mi de ni mi zhig dang ye nas mi 'dra/ khos lag mgor lag shubs gyon zhing gdong la bye 'gog mig shel gon pa dang / kha sna'i steng du rdul 'gog gdong 'bag gyon yod/ kho ni srin po 'di'i cha shas shig yin la/ kho ni 'dug stegs steng du bsdad pa'i 'phrul mi zhig yin/ dbugs mdong khag gi ldir sgra yis yul lung hril po khengs yod la/ ldir sgra de mkha' dbugs dang sa gzhir ngo bor dbyer med du 'dres pas/ da cha sa gzhi dang mkha' dbugs kyis gdung sems mnyam skyed ngang g.yo 'gul dang bcas mur sgra 'don bzhin mchis/ 'phrul 'khor 'dis sa zhing rnams phar la bcad nas 'gro zhing tshur la gcod bzhin yong na'ang / kha lo bar der stangs 'dzin byed pa'i nus pa med/ stangs 'dzin yo chas ngos su lag pa 'khyug tsam gyis 'phrul 'khor 'dir gtor brlag gtong thub mod/ 'on kyang / kha lo ba'i lag pas de ltar byed thub kyi med/ srin po lta bu'i 'phrul 'khor 'di bzo mkhan dang / srin po lta bu'i 'phrul 'khor 'di mar mngags mkhan gyis mi mngon pa'i nus pa gang zhig la brten nas kha lo ba'i lag pa dang sems pa/ kho'i sha gnad bcas dbang sgyur byas shing / des kho'i sems la bye 'gog mig shel bkon nas kho'i ngag lkugs pa bzos yod/ des kho'i tshor snang la bye 'gog mig shel bskon nas kho'i ngo rgol gyi nus pa lkugs pa bzos yod/ khos da lta sa zhing 'di sngon chad ji ltar yin pa de ltar du mthong mi thub la/ khos sa zhing 'di'i dri ma'ang sngon chad ji ltar yin pa de ltar snom thub kyi med/ deng sang kho'i rkang pas spo tho la rdog brdzis thebs kyi med la/ sa zhing gi drod dang nus pa tshor gyi med/ deng sang kho'i 'phongs tshos lcags kyi 'dug stegs steng du bsdad yod la/ kho'i rkang pa lcags kyi rkang gdan steng du brdzis yod/ khos rang nyid kyi gsar bskyed nus stobs 'dir spro snang skye mi thub la/ 'di pham nyes su'ang gtong mi thub/ khos 'dir dmod mo gtong mi thub la skul slong yang byed mi thub/ rgyu mtshan de'i dbang gis/ khos rang nyid kyi ched du spro snang skye mi thub la/ rang nyid la mnar gcod kyang gtong mi thub/ khos rang nyid la dmod mo gtong mi thub la skul slong yang byed mi thub/ kho sa zhing 'dir rgyus mnga' med cing / sa zhing 'di kho la mi dbang / khos sa zhing 'dir yid ches mi byed la/ de la gsol 'debs kyang mi byed/ gal srid sa la thor pa'i sa bon zhig la myu gu ma 'bus kyang kho la mtshon na de ni ci yang ma red/ gal srid gsar du 'tshar longs 'byung bzhin pa'i myu gu zhig than pas gtses te skem par byas pa'am/ yang na drag char gyi chu log gis bsnubs na/ de ni 'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor la mtshon na ci yang min pa bzhin du/ de'i kha lo par mtshon na'ang ci yang ma red/

The man sitting in the iron seat did not look like a man; gloved, goggled, rubber dust mask over nose and mouth, he was a part of the monster, a robot in the seat. The thunder of the cylinders sounded through the country, became one with the air and the earth, so that earth and air muttered in sympathetic vibration. The driver could not control it- straight across country it went, cutting through a dozen farms and straight back. A twitch at the controls could swerve the cat', but the driver's hands could not twitch because the monster that built the tractors, the monster that sent the tractor out, had somehow got into the driver's hands, into his brain and muscle, had goggled him and muzzled him- goggled his mind, muzzled his speech, goggled his perception, muzzled his protest. He could not see the land as it was, he could not smell the land as it smelled; his feet did not stamp the clods or feel the warmth and power of the earth. He sat in an iron seat and stepped on iron pedals. He could not cheer or beat or curse or encourage the extension of his power, and because of this he could not cheer or whip or curse or encourage himself. He did not know or own or trust or beseech the land. If a seed dropped did not germinate, it was nothing. If the young thrusting plant withered in drought or drowned in a flood of rain, it was no more to the driver than to the tractor.

kho dngul khang la dga' rgyu med pa bzhin sa zhing la'ang de mtshungs yin/ kho 'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor la yid smon skye bzhin yod de/ de'i 'phrul chas kyis gang ba'i ngos dang de'i ngar shugs ldan pa'i nus stobs/ de'i 'bar skad sgrog pa'i dbugs mdong bcas kyis kho'i yid sems 'gug bzhin yod/ 'on kyang / 'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor 'di kho rang nyid la mi dbang / 'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor gyi rgyab phyogs su 'od krig krig gi sa gshag gshol sder rnams 'khor bzhin yod la/ gshol sder gyi rno kha yis sa zhing rnams rmo bzhin mi 'gro bar gshag bcos byed bzhin 'gro/ gshags zin pa'i sa leb rnams g.yas phyogs su spung la/ de ma thag tu gshol sder bstar ba rjes ma tsho yong nas sa leb de tsho yang bskyar thengs shig gshags nas g.yon phyogs su spung / gshol sder dag sa nag khrod du yang yang drud pa'i rkyen gyis da lta sa gshag spu gri'i rno kha 'od krig krig byed/ sa gshag gshol sder gyi rgyab phyogs su lcags kyi mche ba ldan pa'i spo rdung 'phrul chas drud yod pa'i rkyen gyis/ des spo tho rnams dum par brdungs pas sa ngos rnams phyir snyoms por bzos yong / spo rdung 'phrul chas kyi rgyab phyogs su son 'debs 'phrul chas te/ gzhi gdan gyi steng nas yar 'greng ba'i lcags kyi pho mtshan bcu gnyis kyis bang sgyur dang bstun nas khu ba gtong zhing / thabs shes dang ldan pas btsan g.yem byed la/ chags sems dang bral bas btsan g.yem byed/ lcags kyi 'dug stegs steng gi kha lo bas rang nyid kyis 'char bkod 'then pa ma yin pa'i thig lam drang mo der yid smon skye bzhin yod la/ rang nyid la mi dbang zhing rang nyid kyis brtse ba'ang ma bcangs pa'i 'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor gyi don du spobs pa skye zhing / khos rang nyid kyis dbang sgyur mi thub pa'i 'phrul 'khor gyi stobs shugs la'ang spobs pa skye bzhin yod/ 'di ltar btab pa'i 'bru rigs rnams yar skyes nas brnga sdud byed skabs mi zhig gi mdzub mos sa tho dron po rnams la thug mi dgos shing / sa nag rnams mdzub bar nas sim par byed mi dgos/ mi gcig gis kyang sa bon la ma reg cing / de yar skye ba'i phyogs la zhen pa ma chags/ mi rnams kyis ci zhig bza' ba de rang nyid kyis btab pa ma yin zhing / kho tsho tshang ma rang nyid kyis bza' ba'i bag leb dang 'brel ba gtan nas med/ sa nag gis lcags nag gi 'og tu 'thab rtsod byed cing lcags nag gi 'og nas rim bzhin 'chi/ rgyu mtshan ni/ sa 'di dag la brtse ba 'chang mkhan med la sdang sems 'dzin mkhan yang med/ sa 'di dag la dmod mo gtong mkhan med la/ sa 'di dag gi ched du gsol ba 'debs mkhan yang med/

He loved the land no more than the bank loved the land. He could admire the tractor- its machined surfaces, its surge of power, the roar of its detonating cylinders; but it was not his tractor. Behind the tractor rolled the shining disks, cutting the earth with blades-not plowing but surgery, pushing the cut earth to the right where the second row of disks cut it and pushed it to the left; slicing blades shining, polished by the cut earth. And pulled behind the disks, the harrows combing with iron teeth so that the little clods broke up and the earth lay smooth. Behind the harrows, the long seeders- twelve curved iron penes erected in the foundry, orgasms set by gears, raping methodically, raping without passion. The driver sat in his iron seat and he was proud of the straight lines he did not will, proud of the tractor he did not own or love, proud of the power he could not control. And when that crop grew, and was harvested, no man had crumbled a hot clod in his fingers and let the earth sift past his fingertips. No man had touched the seed, or lusted for the growth. Men ate what they had not raised, had no connection with the bread. The land bore under iron, and under iron gradually died; for it was not loved or hated, it had no prayers or curses.

nyin gung la slebs tshe/ kha lo bas bogs len zhing pa zhig gi khang pa dang nye sa ru gung tshigs rum bro'i kha phyes/ bro khug nang du snum shog tu btum pa'i sha bag leb dang bag leb skya bo/ bsnyal tshal/ phyur ba/ 'phrul chas lhu lag gi tshong rtags shig gi ming dang mtshungs pa'i si pham [5]zhes pa'i krin bcug phag sha bcas yod/ khos zas kyi ro bcud la myong khom med par hob kyis zos/ da dung gnas spo byas med pa'i bogs len zhing pa zhig phyi ru yong nas kha lo bar mtshar snang dang bcas bltas/ kha lo bas bye 'gog mig shel dang 'gyig gi rdul 'gog gdong 'bag phud pa na/ kho'i mig zung gi mtha' ru gor thig dkar po chung chung re babs yod pa mthong thub cing / kho'i kha sna'i mtha' ru gor thig dkar po chen po zhig babs yod pa'ang mthong thub/ bud snum 'phrul chas kyi me kha yang bskyar gso ba las 'phrul chas mu mthud du 'khor du bcug ste bzhag na bud snum gron chung byed thub pas/ kha lo bas gung tshigs bza' ring la 'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor gyis pur sgra sgrog bzhin bsdad/ mtshar snang che ba'i byis pa tsho kha lo ba'i mtha' ru rub yong la/ gyon gos rtsab hral can gyi byis pa de tshos rang nyid kyi lag gi bag zan bsregs ma bza' bzhin kho la ltad mor bltas/ kho tsho'i bkres ltogs kyi mig gis kha lo bas sha bag leb kyi thum sgril bshigs par lta la/ kho tsho'i bkres ltogs kyis skyen pa'i sna yis bsnyal tshal dang phyur ba/ si pham phag sha bcas kyi dri zhim tshor/ kho tshos kha lo ba la skad cha mi bshad par mig zung gis kho'i lag pas kha nang du za ma 'jug pa'i 'gul skyod la lta/ kho tsho'i mig zung gis khos bar 'tshang bag leb de ji ltar bldad par mi lta bar/ sha bag leb de bzung ba'i kho'i lag pa'i rjes su 'brangs/ cung tsam rjes su zhing gzhis 'di dang kha 'bral ma thub pa'i bogs len zhing pa de tshur yong nas 'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor gyi 'gram nas tsog pur bsdad/

At noon the tractor driver stopped sometimes near a tenant house and opened his lunch: sandwiches wrapped in waxed paper, white bread, pickle, cheese, Spam, a piece of pie branded like an engine part. He ate without relish. And tenants not yet moved away came out to see him, looked curiously while the goggles were taken off, and the rubber dust mask, leaving white circles around the eyes and a large white circle around nose and mouth. The exhaust of the tractor puttered on, for fuel is so cheap it is more efficient to leave the engine running than to heat the Diesel nose for a new start. Curious children crowded close, ragged children who ate their fried dough as they watched. They watched hungrily the unwrapping of the sandwiches, and their hunger-sharpened noses smelled the pickle, cheese, and Spam. They didn't speak to the driver. They watched his hand as it carried food to his mouth. They did not watch him chewing; their eyes followed the hand that held the sandwich. After a while the tenant who could not leave the place came out and squatted in the shade beside the tractor.

The tenant sat in his doorway, and the driver thundered his engine and started off, tracks falling and curving, harrows combing, and the phalli of the seeder slipping into the ground. Across the dooryard the tractor cut, and the hard, foot-beaten ground was seeded field, and the tractor cut through again; the uncut space was ten feet wide. And back he came. The iron guard bit into the house-corner, crumbled the wall, and wrenched the little house from its foundation so that it fell sideways, crushed like a bug. And the driver was goggled and a rubber mask covered his nose and mouth. The tractor cut a straight line on, and the air and the ground vibrated with its thunder. The tenant man stared after it, his rifle in his hand. His wife was beside him, and the quiet children behind. And all of them stared after the tractor.

THE REVEREND CASY and young Tom stood on the hill and looked down on the Joad place. The small unpainted house was mashed at one corner, and it had been pushed off its foundations so that it slumped at an angle, its blind front windows pointing at a spot of sky well above the horizon. The fences were gone and the cotton grew in the dooryard and up against the house, and the cotton was about the shed barn. The outhouse lay on its side, and the cotton grew close against it. Where the dooryard had been pounded hard by the bare feet of children and by stamping horses' hooves and by the broad wagon wheels, it was cultivated now, and the dark green, dusty cotton grew. Young Tom stared for a long time at the ragged willow beside the dry horse trough, at the concrete base where the pump had been.

They paused at the dry watering trough, and the proper weeds that should grow under a trough were gone and the old thick wood of the trough was dry and cracked. On the well-cap the bolts that had held the pump stuck up, their threads rusty and the nuts gone.

“Le's look in the house. She's all pushed out a shape. Something knocked the hell out of her.” They walked slowly toward the sagging house. Two of the supports of the porch roof were pushed out so that the roof flopped down on one end. And the house-corner was crushed in. Through a maze of splintered wood the room at the corner was visible. The front door hung open inward, and a low strong gate across the front door hung outward on leather hinges.

He pointed to the low gate across the front door. “If Ma was anywheres about, that gate'd be shut an' hooked. He climbed to the split porch and looked into the kitchen. The windows were broken out, and throwing rocks lay on the floor, and the floor and walls sagged steeply away from the door, and the sifted dust was on the boards. Joad pointed to the broken glass and the rocks. “Kids,” he said. “They'll go twenty miles to bust a window. I done it myself. They know when a house is empty, they know. That's the fust thing kids do when folks move out.”

The kitchen was empty of furniture, stove gone and the round stovepipe hole in the wall showing light. On the sink shelf lay an old beer opener and a broken fork with its wooden handle gone. Joad slipped cautiously into the room, and the floor groaned under his weight. An old copy of the Philadelphia Ledger was on the floor against the wall, its pages yellow and curling. Joad looked into the bedroom- no bed, no chairs, nothing. On the wall a picture of an Indian girl in color, labeled Red Wing. A bed slat leaning against the wall, and in one corner a woman's high button shoe, curled up at the toe and broken over the instep. Joad picked it up and looked at it. “I remember this,” he said. “This was Ma's. It's all wore out now. Ma liked them shoes. Had 'em for years. No, they've went- an' took ever'thing.”

The sun had lowered until it came through the angled end windows now, and it flashed on the edges of the broken glass. Joad turned at last and went out and crossed the porch. He sat down on the edge of it and rested his bare feet on the twelve-by-twelve step. The evening light was on the fields, and the cotton plants threw long shadows on the ground, and the molting willow tree threw a long shadow.

“No. Like I said, they wasn't people to write. Pa could write, but he wouldn't. Didn't like to. It give him the shivers to write. He could work out a catalogue order as good as the nex' fella, but he wouldn't write no letters just for ducks.” They sat side by side, staring off into the distance. Joad laid his rolled coat on the porch beside him. His independent hands rolled a cigarette, smoothed it and lighted it, and he inhaled deeply and blew the smoke out through his nose. “Somepin's wrong,” he said. “I can't put my finger on her. A lean gray cat came sneaking out of the barn and crept through the cotton plants to the end of the porch. It leaped silently up to the porch and crept low-belly toward the men. It came to a place between and behind the two, and then it sat down, and its tail stretched out straight and flat to the floor, and the last inch of it flicked. The cat sat and looked off into the distance where the men were looking.

“I don' know. Seems like maybe there ain't any neighbors. If there was, would all them nice planks be here? Why, Jesus Christ! “Sure. They wasn't stealin' it. They thought he lef' it, an' they jus' took it. He got all of it back- all but a sofa pilla, velvet with a pitcher of an Injun on it. Albert claimed Grampa got it. Claimed Grampa got Injun blood, that's why he wants that pitcher. Well, Grampa did get her, but he didn't give a damn about the pitcher on it. He jus' liked her. Used to pack her aroun' an' he'd put her wherever he was gonna sit. He never would give her back to Albert. Says, 'If Albert wants this pilla so bad, let him come an' get her. But he better come shootin', 'cause I'll blow his goddamn stinkin' head off if he comes messin' aroun' my pilla.' So finally Albert give up an' made Grampa a present of that pilla. It give Grampa idears, though. He took to savin' chicken feathers. Says he's gonna have a whole damn bed of feathers. But he never got no feather bed. One time Pa got mad at a skunk under the house. Pa slapped that skunk with a two-by-four, and Ma burned all Grampa's feathers so we could live in the house.” He laughed. “Grampa's a tough ol' bastard. Jus' set on that Injun pilla an' says, 'Let Albert come an' get her. Why,' he says, 'I'll take that squirt and wring 'im out like a pair of drawers.'”

The cat crept close between the men again, and its tail lay flat and its whiskers jerked now and then. The sun dropped low toward the horizon and the dusty air was red and golden. The cat reached out a gray questioning paw and touched Joad's coat. He looked around. “Hell, I forgot the turtle. I ain't gonna pack it all over hell.” He unwrapped the land turtle and pushed it under the house. But in a moment it was out, headed southwest as it had been from the first. The cat leaped at it and struck at its straining head and slashed at its moving feet. The old, hard, humorous head was pulled in, and the thick tail slapped in under the shell, and when the cat grew tired of waiting for it and walked off, the turtle headed on southwest again.

The approaching man stopped, startled by the call, and then he came on quickly. He was a lean man, rather short. His movements were jerky and quick. He carried a gunny sack in his hand. His blue jeans were pale at knee and seat, and he wore an old black suit coat, stained and spotted, the sleeves torn loose from the shoulders in back, and ragged holes worn through at the elbows. His black hat was as stained as his coat, and the band, torn half free, flopped up and down as he walked. Muley's face was smooth and unwrinkled, but it wore the truculent look of a bad child's, the mouth held tight and small, the little eyes half scowling, half petulant.
