jo Di yis [“]mi dmangs tsho sa gzhis las mtha' skrod gtong dgos don ci zhig yin nam/[”] zhes dris/
Joad said, “What's the idear of kickin' the folks off?”

[“]o/ kho tshos de thad la skad cha snyan mo zhig bshad byung / lo 'di dag la nam zla ci 'dra yin pa khyod kyis shes yod rgyu red/ lo rer thal rdul langs nas lo tog tshang ma bcom nas 'gro la/ brnga sdud kyi skabs su 'bru rigs zer ba grog ma'i skyag khung nang la btsang rgyu tsam yang mi 'dang ba'i tshod red/ khyim tshang tshang mas skam zas tshong khang nas rtsis tho bkod de dngos zog len gyi yod la/ de'i mjug 'bras ci zhig yin pa khyod kyis kyang shes rgyu red/ red ya/ de nas sa gzhis kyi bdag po sa bdag dag gis/ [‘]deng sang nga tshos bogs len zhing pa nyar thub kyi mi 'dug ma gzhi bogs len zhing par sprod pa'i khe spogs de da lta nga tshos sprod thub kyi mi 'dug nga tshos sa gzhis tshang ma phyogs gcig tu bsdus kyang 'di'i steng gi 'gro song khebs tsam pa red/[’]ces zer la/ de nas kho tshos 'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor btang yong nas bogs len zhing pa tshang ma sa zhing steng nas bskrad pa red/ red ya/ nga ma gtogs pa'i gzhan pa tshang ma bskrad pa red/ nga sa 'di dang gcig 'bral na zhes dkon mchog dpang la btsugs yod/ a Thom/ khyod kyis nga mi ga 'dra yin min shes kyi red/ khyod kyis nga chung dus nas bzung ngo shes pa red/[”]

“Oh! They talked pretty about it. You know what kinda years we been havin'. Dust comin' up an' spoilin' ever'thing so a man didn't get enough crop to plug up an ant's ass. An' ever'body got bills at the grocery. You know how it is. Well, the folks that owns the lan' says, 'We can't afford to keep no tenants.' An' they says, 'The share a tenant gets is jus' the margin a profit we can't afford to lose.' An' they says, 'If we put all our lan' in one piece we can jus' hardly make her pay.' So they tractored all the tenants off a the lan'. All 'cept me, an' by God I ain't goin'. Tommy, you know me. You knowed me all your life.”
jo Di yis [“]los shes/ mi tshe gang por mthong nas yong ba red/[”] ces bshad/
“Damn right,” said Joad, “all my life.”

[“]red ya/ nga yang glen pa zhig min pa khyod kyis shes rgyu red la/ sa zhing 'di de 'dra sa bcud 'dzoms pa zhig min pa ngas kyang shes kyi yod/ sngon chad yin rung phyugs zog 'tsho sa ma gtogs 'bru rigs 'debs sa de 'dra yag po min/ sa 'di thog ma nyid nas ma rmos na 'grig yod pa red/ da deng sang de'i steng du sring bal btab nas sa rgyu'i dbugs rgyun phal cher bcad zin pa red/ gal srid kho tshos nga sa 'di dang kha 'bral dgos zhes lab med rgyu na/ nga deng sang kha li h+phor ne ya mnga' sde ru slebs nas nga rang gis ci 'dod ltar rgun 'brum bza' zhing tsha lu ma 'thog bzhin pa'i sgang yin yang srid/ 'on kyang / khyi phrug de tshos nga sa 'di dang kha 'bral dgos zhes btsan bka' btang yong dus/ mi zhig yin na de 'dra'i las sla pos 'gro ga la 'dod/[”]

“Well, you know I ain't a fool. I know this land ain't much good. Never was much good 'cept for grazin'. Never should a broke her up. An' now she's cottoned damn near to death. If on'y they didn't tell me I got to get off, why, I'd prob'y be in California right now a-eatin' grapes an' a-pickin' an orange when I wanted. But them sons-a-bitches says I got to get off- an', Jesus Christ, a man can't, when he's tol' to!”

jo Di yis [“]red ya/ ngas kyang a pha de 'dra las sla pos kha bral yod rgyu ma red 'dod/ a mes kyis kyang de'i don du mi zhig bsad med dam 'dod/ mi su zhig gis kyang nga'i a mes la kho'i rkang pa gang du brdzi bar bkod 'doms byas myong med/ a ma lags kyang gang 'dod kyis thub tshod la lta thub pa zhig min/ thengs shig la nga'i a mas khyim bya gson po zhig lag tu bzung yod pa'i skabs shig tu/ kho mo skor skyod mgar pa zhig dang rtsod pa shor song / kho mo'i lag pa gcig tu khyim bya bzung zhing lag pa gzhan pas sta re bzung nas khyim bya'i ske gcod rtsis byed bzhin yod cing / kho tsho rtsod pa shor ba na a mas sta re yis sgo tshong mkhan la gzhu 'dod pa red mod/ 'on kyang / kho mos lag pa gang gi nang du dngos po ci zhig bzung yod pa brjed nas khyim bya des sgo tshong mkhan de la gzhus pa red/ kho gnyis 'dzing mo byas tshar dus bya sha za thabs med pa byas 'dug kho mo'i lag tu khyim bya'i rkang pa cha gcig ma gtogs gzhan pa ci yang lhag mi 'dug de mthong nas a mes gad mo bgad de dpyi tshigs kyang thor grabs byas/ nga'i khyim mi tsho de 'dra las sla pos kha ga la 'bral/[”] zhes bshad/

“Sure,” said Joad. “I wonder Pa went so easy. I wonder Grampa didn' kill nobody. Nobody never tol' Grampa where to put his feet. An' Ma ain't nobody you can push aroun' neither. I seen her beat the hell out of a tin peddler with a live chicken one time 'cause he give her a argument. She had the chicken in one han', an' the ax in the other, about to cut its head off. She aimed to go for that peddler with the ax, but she forgot which hand was which, an' she takes after him with the chicken. Couldn' even eat that chicken when she got done. They wasn't nothing but a pair a legs in her han'. Grampa throwed his hip outa joint laughin'. How'd my folks go so easy?”

[“]red ya/ 'di phyogs su yong nas skad cha bshad mkhan de'i skad cha sbrang rtsi las kyang mngar/ [‘]khyod tsho sa zhing 'di dang kha 'bral dgos pa de nga'i skyon ma red/[’] ngas kho la [‘]des na su'i skyon red/[’]ces dris pa na/ khos [‘]sho ne zhing phyugs spyi gnyer khang red/ ngas bka' bkod dang len byed bzhin pa tsam yin/[’] zer bar/ ngas kho la [‘]sho ne zhing phyugs spyi gnyer khang zer na su red/[’] ces dris pa na/ khos nga la [‘]de su yang ma red/ de spyi gnyer khang zhig red/[’]zer/ dngos gnas mi zhig smyo ru 'jug byed 'dra red/ don dam par su zhig yin pa khag dkri sa tsam yang mi rnyed/ mi mang po zhig la khong khro ston sa tsam yang ma rnyed par thang chad pa red/ 'on kyang / nga thang chad kyi med/ nga tshang ma'i steng du khong khro langs yod/ nga gnas 'dir 'dug rgyu yin/[”]

“Well, the guy that comes aroun' talked nice as pie. 'You got to get off. It ain't my fault.' 'Well,' I says, 'whose fault is it? I'll go an' I'll nut the fella.' 'It's the Shawnee Lan' an' Cattle Company. I jus' got orders.' 'Who's the Shawnee Lan' an' Cattle Company?' 'It ain't nobody. It's a company.' Got a fella crazy. There wasn't nobody you could lay for. Lot a the folks jus' got tired out lookin' for somepin to be mad at- but not me. I'm mad at all of it. I'm stayin'.”

dmar la gor ba'i nub kha'i nyi ma de gnam sa 'dres mtshams su 'dar lhem lhem gyis yud tsam bsdad rjes/ rim bzhin mi snang bar gyur/ nyi ma nub shul gyi nam mkha' de bkrag mdangs dang ldan zhing / khrag gis sbags pa'i gos hrul zhig dang 'dra ba'i sprin pa ral po zhig nyi ma nub shul gyi nam mkha' ru dpyangs nas gda'/ shar phyogs kyi gnam sa 'dres mtshams su sa srod kyi snang ba zhig 'jab bzhin yong la/ shar phyogs kyi sa gzhi'i ngos su mun pa'i snang ba zhig 'jab bzhin slebs/ byi la skya bo de khu sim mer phar phyogs kyi 'bru khang gi phyogs su song nas 'bru khang gi nang du grib ma bzhin mi snang bar gyur/

A large red drop of sun lingered on the horizon and then dripped over and was gone, and the sky was brilliant over the spot where it had gone, and a torn cloud, like a bloody rag, hung over the spot of its going. And dusk crept over the sky from the eastern horizon, and darkness crept over the land from the east. The evening star flashed and glittered in the dusk. The gray cat sneaked away toward the open barn shed and passed inside like a shadow.

jo Di yis [“]ya/ nga tsho mtshan mo'i mun pa'i khrod nas le dbar brgyad brgal nas a khu jon gyi sar rkang thang la 'gro thub rgyu ma red/ nga'i rkang pa na nas 'gul mi thub/ ya/ mu le/ nga tsho do nub khyod tshang gi sar song na ga 'dra 'dug de 'di nas le dbar gcig tsam ma gtogs med a/[”] zhes bshad/
Joad said, “Well, we ain't gonna walk no eight miles to Uncle John's place tonight. My dogs is burned up. How's it if we go to your place, Muley? That's on'y about a mile.”

[“]song ma song yod pa ma red/[”] mu le yi gdong la ngo nongs pa'i nyams shig babs/ [“]nga'i chung ma dang phru gu tsho/ kho mo'i ming bo bcas kyis ca lag tshang ma 'khyer nas kha li h+phor ne ya mnga' sde la phyin song / khang pa'i nang na bza' rgyu 'bru rdog gcig kyang med/ kho tsho ni nga rang ltar khong khro zos med pa'i rkyen gyis nub phyogs su phyin song / khang pa'i nang du bza' rgyu ci yang med/[”]

“Won't do no good.” Muley seemed embarrassed. “My wife an' the kids an' her brother all took an' went to California. They wasn't nothin' to eat. They wasn't as mad as me, so they went. They wasn't nothin' to eat here.”
chos dpon 'tsher snang dang bcas 'gul tsam bya/ [“]khyod kyang kho tsho dang mnyam du phyin na 'grig yod pa red/ khyod kyis khyim tshang kha 'thor la ma btang na 'grig gi red/[”]
The preacher stirred nervously. “You should of went too. You shouldn't of broke up the fambly.”
mu le yis [“]nga 'gro ma thub/ ci zhig gis nga gtong gi mi 'dug[”] ces bshad/
“I couldn',” said Muley Graves. “Somepin jus' wouldn' let me.”

jo Di yis [“]a dkon mchog da ltogs nas shi grabs byed kyi 'dug lo ngo bzhi hril por zas thun dus thog la bzas pa yin/ nga'i grod khog 'di lu gu lding lding byed bzhin 'dug mu le/ khyod kyis ci zhig bza' rgyu yin nam/ khyod kyis dgong zas ji ltar 'tshol bzhin yod/[”] ces bshad/
“Well, by God, I'm hungry,” said Joad. “Four solemn years I been eatin' right on the minute. My guts is yellin' bloody murder. What you gonna eat, Muley? How you been gettin' your dinner?”

mu le yis ngo nongs pa'i sgo nas [“]dus yun gang 'tshams ring la ngas sbal ba dang thang byi zos pa yin la 'phyi ba'ang zos pa yin/ de tsho mi za thabs med red/ 'on kyang / deng sang ngas phar phyogs gyi gram rtswa skam po'i khrod kyi rgyu lam khag tu rnyi 'dzugs kyi yod pas/ mtshams la lar ri bong zin la mtshams la lar ri bya'ang 'dzin thub kyi 'dug da dung sre mong yang zin la dom khra rnga ring yang zin gyi 'dug[”]ces zer bzhin/ khos rtswa khug lag tu blangs nas sgo khyams kyi mthil gcal steng du mgo rting bslogs pas/ rtswa khug las spu 'jam sob sob ldan pa'i ri skya rnga dkar gnyis dang ri bong rna ring gcig bcas lhod kyis 'gril song /

Muley said ashamedly, “For a while I et frogs an' squirrels an' prairie dogs sometimes. Had to do it. But now I got some wire nooses on the tracks in the dry stream brush. Get rabbits, an' sometimes a prairie chicken. Skunks get caught, an' coons, too.” He reached down, picked up his sack, and emptied it on the porch. Two cottontails and a jackrabbit fell out and rolled over limply, soft and furry.
jo Di yis [“]dkon mchog mkhyen/ ngas lo ngo bzhi'i ring la gson por bsad pa'i sha gsar zhig bza' rgyu ma byung /[”] zhes bshad/
“God Awmighty,” said Joad, “it's more'n four years sence I've et fresh-killed meat.”
kha se yis ri skya rnga dkar gcig yar blangs te lag tu bzung nas [“]khyod kyis nga tshor bza' skal sprod rgyu red a/ e red/ mu le g+hi reb/[”] ces dris/
Casy picked up one of the cottontails and held it in his hand. “You sharin' with us, Muley Graves?” he asked.

mu le ngo nongs nas 'tshab 'tshub tu gyur/ [“]de thad la nga la gdam ka 'dug gam/[”] khos rang nyid kyi byams sems dang bral ba'i skad cha de bshad mtshams bcad nas/ [“]ngas de zer ba min/ de zer ba min/ ngas zer rgyu ni/[”] zhes kha nor rgyag bzhin du [“]ngas bshad 'dod pa ni/ gal srid mi zhig la bza' rgyu yod cing / mi gzhan pa zhig grod khog ltogs kyi yod dus/ mi dang po de la gdam ka yod pa ma red/ de ma yin par/ ngas nga'i ri bong tsho 'khyer nas khug kyog cig tu gcig pur bzas na ga 'dra red/ gnas lugs de e mthong /[”] zhes bshad/

Muley fidgeted in embarrassment. “I ain't got no choice in the matter.” He stopped on the ungracious sound of his words. “That ain't like I mean it. That ain't. I mean”- he stumbled- “what I mean, if a fella's got somepin to eat an' another fella's hungry- why, the first fella ain't got no choice. I mean, s'pose I pick up my rabbits an' go off somewheres an' eat 'em. See?”

kha se yis [“]mthong gi 'dug gnas lugs de ngas mthong gi 'dug Thom/ mu le yis gnas lugs shig mthong gi 'dug gnas lugs chen po zhig mthong gi 'dug gnas lugs de kho las stobs che la nga las kyang stobs che/[”] zhes bshad/
“I see,” said Casy. “I can see that. Muley sees somepin there, Tom. Muley's got a-holt of somepin, an' it's too big for him, an' it's too big for me.”
Thom gzhon pas rang nyid kyi lag pa gnyis 'phur 'phur byas/ [“]su la gri yod/ nyam thag pa'i srog chags 'di tsho bsha'/ da lta bsha'/[”]
Young Tom rubbed his hands together. “Who got a knife? Le's get at these here miserable rodents. Le's get at 'em.”

mu le yis rang nyid kyi dor ma'i glo khug tu bsnyabs nas rwa yi yu ba can gyi ltebs gri chen po zhig blangs/ Thom jo Di yis ltebs gri de tshur blangs nas gri dngo gcig phyis rjes dri snom zhig byas/ khos gri dngo sa nang du yang dang yang du bsnun rjes yang bskyar dri snom byas shing / de nas de kho'i dor ma'i ngos su phyis rjes mthe bong gis rno kha brtags/

Muley reached in his pants pocket and produced a large horn-handled pocket knife. Tom Joad took it from him, opened a blade, and smelled it. He drove the blade again and again into the ground and smelled it again, wiped it on his trouser leg, and felt the edge with his thumb.
mu le yis rang nyid kyi dpyi mgo'i khug ma las chu dam zhig blangs nas sgo khyams thog tu bzhag ste [“]gron chung byos/ 'di tsam las med/ khron pa tshang ma'i kha rubs zin/[”] zhes bshad/
Muley took a quart bottle of water out of his hip pocket and set it on the porch. “Go easy on that there water,” he said. “That's all there is. This here well's filled in.”

Thom gyis ri bong zhig lag tu bzung [“]khyod gnyis las gcig song nas 'bru khang nas lcags skud dum pa zhig 'khyer shog nga tshos khang pa'i nang gi shing leb chag po 'di dag spyad nas me zhig sbar thabs bya/[”] khos lag gi ri bong shi bo la gcig bltas rjes [“]ri bong bsha' rgyu'i yan gyi las ka sla po zhig gang na yod/[”] ces bshad/

Tom took up a rabbit in his hand. “One of you go get some bale wire outa the barn. We'll make a fire with some a this broken plank from the house.” He looked at the dead rabbit. “There ain't nothin' so easy to get ready as a rabbit,” he said.

khos ri bong gi sgal ba'i pags pa yar 'then nas gri yis i khung zhig btod/ de rjes i khung nang du mdzub mo brgyab nas pags pa bshus/ ri bong gi rgyab kyi pags pa de rkang shubs phud pa ltar ske ru yar ded byung la/ sug pa'i steng gi pags pa rnams sder mo'i rtsa ru mar ded/ de nas jo Di yis ltebs gri de yang bskyar lag tu blangs nas ri bong gi mgo dang sug mgo bcad cing / de nas pags pa thang la bzhag rjes/ ri bong gi rtsib rus mtshams nas ltebs gris gshags nas rgyu ma rnams ko ba'i steng du gsig gsig byas te blugs shing / de nas nang khrol rnams sring bal sdong po'i khrod du g.yugs/ da ni gtsang la sha rgyus ldan pa'i gzugs gzhi chung chung de gra sgrig byas zin/ jo Di yis sug bzhi bcad rjes sha dang ldan pa'i sgal gzhung de dum bu gnyis su gtubs/ khos ri bong gnyis pa de lag tu len bzhin pa'i skabs der kha se yis lag tu lcags skud 'khril ma zhig 'khyer nas phyir slebs/ jo Di yis [“]da me bus nas phur ba re gdab rogs/ ston pa ye shu/ srog chags 'di tsho bza' dgos bsam nas ltogs shi thebs grabs byed kyi 'dug[”] ces bshad/

He lifted the skin of the back, slit it, put his fingers in the hole, and tore the skin off. It slipped off like a stocking, slipped off the body to the neck, and off the legs to the paws. Joad picked up the knife again and cut off head and feet. He laid the skin down, slit the rabbit along the ribs, shook out the intestines onto the skin, and then threw the mess off into the cotton field. And the clean-muscled little body was ready. Joad cut off the legs and cut the meaty back into two pieces. He was picking up the second rabbit when Casy came back with a snarl of bale wire in his hand. “Now build up a fire and put some stakes up,” said Joad. “Jesus Christ, I'm hungry for these here creatures!”

khos de'i shul gyi ri bong gnyis ka'ang gtsang ma bzos nas dum bur gtubs rjes lcags skud la brgyus/ mu le dang kha se gnyis kyis zur khang gi zhig 'phro de nas shing leb chag po 'ga' re 'khyer yong nas me kha gsos/ de nas kho tshos lcags skud 'then sa'i ched du me'i phar phyogs tshur phyogs gnyis su phur ba re gdabs/

He cleaned and cut the rest of the rabbits and strung them on the wire. Muley and Casy tore splintered boards from the wrecked house-corner and started a fire, and they drove a stake into the ground on each side to hold the wire.

mu le phyir jo Di yi rtsar yong nas [“]ri bong rna ring gi lus steng du gnyan 'bur yod med ltos a/ ngas gnyan 'bur can gyi ri bong bza' 'dod med/[”] ces bshad rjes/ khos rang nyid kyi glo khug las ras khug chung chung zhig blangs yong nas sgo khyams steng du bzhag
Muley came back to Joad. “Look out for boils on that jackrabbit,” he said. “I don't like to eat no jackrabbit with boils.” He took a little cloth bag from his pocket and put it on the porch.

jo Di yis [“]rna ring 'di gtsang ma yang dag pa red/ dkon mchog ye shu/ khyod kyis tshwa yang 'khur 'dug a/ khyod kyi glo khug de'i nang na da dung sder ma 'ga' re dang ras gur zhig kyang med dam/[”] zhes zer bzhin/ khos lag mthil du tshwa cung tsam blangs rjes lcags skud la brgyus pa'i ri bong gi steng du stor/

Joad said, “The jack was clean as a whistle- Jesus God, you got salt too? By any chance you got some plates an' a tent in your pocket?” He poured salt in his hand and sprinkled it over the pieces of rabbit strung on the wire.

me phung je cher song ba dang bstun nas grib ma de khang pa'i ngos su phog cing / shing leb skam po rnams gad nas kag sgra lhang lhang du sgrog da ni mun pa phal cher rub zin pas nam mkha'i skar tshogs kyang dgung sngon dbyings su je gsal nas je gsal du gyur/ byi la skya bo de 'bru khang las phyir bud nas me phung gi phyogs su sme'o zer bzhin yong zhing / me phung gi nye sa tsam du slebs mtshams su kha phar 'khor nas sa ngos su stor yod pa'i ri bong gi nang khrol dam dum gyi phyogs su brgyugs/ byi las nang khrol kha nang du bldad rjes khog tu mid pa dang / da dung nang khrol 'ga' re kha 'gram nas phyi ru dpyangs/

The fire leaped and threw shadows on the house, and the dry wood crackled and snapped. The sky was almost dark now and the stars were out sharply. The gray cat came out of the barn shed and trotted miaowing toward the fire, but, nearly there, it turned and went directly to one of the little piles of rabbit entrails on the ground. It chewed and swallowed, and the entrails hung from its mouth.

kha se me phung gi 'gram du thang la bsdad nas/ shing leb chag 'phro re me phung gi steng du snon la/ sne mo 'bar zin pa'i shing leb chen po de me phung gi dbus su phar bsnur/ dgong kha'i pha wang tsho me phung gi 'od kor nang du 'khyug tsam gyis 'phur nas yong zhing / 'khyug tsam gyis 'phur nas bud 'gro/ byi la de rang nyid kyi 'phongs mgo ru tsog pur bsdad nas mchu to lce ldag byed cing / gdong pa dang kha spu 'khrud/

Casy sat on the ground beside the fire, feeding it broken pieces of board, pushing the long boards in as the flame ate off their ends. The evening bats flashed into the firelight and out again. The cat crouched back and licked its lips and washed its face and whiskers.

jo Di yis steng du ri bong brgyus yod pa'i lcags skud de lag pa gnyis kyis bzung nas tshur me phung gi phyogs su yong / [“]ya/ mu le/ sne mo gcig nas zung / khyod phyogs kyi sne de phur ba de'i steng du sdoms shog da 'grig song / ya/ da dam por 'then/ spyir yin na nga tshos me phung 'jags par sgug dgos mod/ 'on kyang / ngas sgug thub kyi mi 'dug[”] khos lcags skud drang mor 'then rjes thang nas shing thur zhig blangs nas lcags skud steng gi sha rdog rnams me phung gi steng du slebs pa'i bar du phar ded/ de nas me lce yis sha rdog gi mtha' ru yar lce ldag byas byung la/ sha rdog gi phyi ngos rnams mkhregs po dang 'od krig krig tu gyur/ jo Di me phung gi 'gram du thang la bsdad mod/ 'on kyang / ri bong gi sha rnams lcags skud kyi steng du 'byar mi 'gro ba'i ched du kho'i lag gi shing thur des ri sha mu mthud du phar sgul tshur sgul byas/ jo Di yis [“]'di ni spro gseng zhig red/ red ya/ 'di ni dngos gnas spro gseng zhig red/ mu le 'di la tshwa dgos na tshwa 'dug chu dgos na chu 'dug ri bong dgos na ri bong 'dug da 'di'i glo khug nang na skyo ldur sla nga gang yod rgyu na/ de ma gtogs re ba gzhan pa med/[”] ces bshad/

Joad held up his rabbit-laden wire between his two hands and walked to the fire. “Here, take one end, Muley. Wrap your end around that stake. That's good, now! Let's tighten her up. We ought to wait till the fire's burned down, but I can't wait.” He made the wire taut, then found a stick and slipped the pieces of meat along the wire until they were over the fire. And the flames licked up around the meat and hardened and glazed the surfaces. Joad sat down by the fire, but with his stick he moved and turned the rabbit so that it would not become sealed to the wire. “This here is a party,” he said. “Salt, Muley's got, an' water an' rabbits. I wish he got a lot of hominy in his pocket. That's all I wish.”
mu le yis me phung gi steng nas tshur bltas te [“]nga'i 'tsho ba rol tshul la bltas na khyod tshos nga smyos 'dug bsam gyi yod rgyu red/[”] ces bshad/
Muley said over the fire, “You fellas'd think I'm touched, the way I live.”
jo Di yis [“]med/ bsam gyi med/ gal srid khyod smyon pa yin na tshang ma smyon pa yin rgyu red/[”] ces bshad/
“Touched nothin',” said Joad. “If you're touched, I wisht ever'body was touched.”

mu le yis mthud du [“]red ya/ de dgod bro ba zhig red/ kho tshos nga rang nyid kyi sa gzhis dang kha 'bral dgos zhes bshad pa de nas bzung / nga la ci zhig babs pa'am ci zhig byung ba'i tshor ba byung / thog mar nga song nas mi skor zhig gsod rgyu'i 'char gzhi 'then pa yin la/ de nas nga'i bza' mi tshang ma nub rgyud du phyin pa red/ de nas bzung nga yar 'khyam mar 'khyam byas nas bsdad pa yin/ nam yang thag ring la ma song la/ gang du mun rub na de ru nyal nas bsdad pa yin/ do nub nga 'di nas nyal dgos bsam yod/ nga 'dir yong don yang de yin/ ngas rang nyid la/ ngas yul mi tsho'i ca lag la lta rtog byas te bsdad pa yin na kho tsho phyir yong dus rtsis sprod rgyu zhig yod pa red zer gyi yod/ 'on kyang / ngas de bden pa min pa shes kyi yod/ 'di na lta rtog byed rgyu zhig lhag med la/ yul mi tsho yang nam yang phyir yong gi ma red/ nga ni dur khrod kyi 'dre rgan 'khyam po zhig dang 'dra bar yar 'khyam mar 'khyam byas nas bsdad yod/[”] ces bshad/

Muley continued, “Well, sir, it's a funny thing. Somepin went an' happened to me when they tol' me I had to get off the place. Fust I was gonna go in an' kill a whole flock a people. Then all my folks all went away out west. An' I got wanderin' aroun'. Jus' walkin' aroun'. Never went far. Slep' where I was. I was gonna sleep here tonight. That's why I come. I'd tell myself, 'I'm lookin' after things so when all the folks come back it'll be all right.' But I knowed that wan't true. There ain't nothin' to look after. The folks ain't never comin' back. I'm jus' wanderin' aroun' like a damn ol' graveyard ghos'.”

kha se yis [“]mi zer ba 'di gnas shig la goms song dus de dang kha 'bral rgyu dka' mo red/ mi zer ba 'di la bsam blo zhig skyes tshar dus de bsgyur rgyu dka' mo red/ nga ni deng sang chos dpon zhig min na'ang / ngas rgyun par rang shugs kyis gsol ba 'debs kyi 'dug la/ de thad la rig pa tsam yang bsgrim dgos kyi mi 'dug[”] ces bshad/

“Fella gets use' to a place, it's hard to go,” said Casy. “Fella gets use' to a way a thinkin' it's hard to leave. I ain't a preacher no more, but all the time I find I'm prayin', not even thinkin' what I'm doin.”

jo Di yis lcags skud kyi steng gi sha rdog rnams brje slog brgyab pas/ da ni sha'i steng nas snum khu re 'dzags kyi 'dug la/ snum thigs re me nang du lhung tshe me lce leb mo re yar mchongs yong / sha'i ngos 'jam sa dag tu da lta gnyer khum dod nas kha mdog smug skya ru 'gyur bzhin 'dug jo Di yis [“]dri snom zhig byos dang / ston pa ye shu/ mar sgur nas dri snom zhig byos dang /[”] zhes bshad/

Joad turned the pieces of meat over on the wire. The juice was dripping now, and every drop, as it fell in the fire, shot up a spurt of flame. The smooth surface of the meat was crinkling up and turning a faint brown. “Smell her,” said Joad. “Jesus, look down an' just smell her!”

mu le yis mu mthud du [“]dur khrod kyi 'dre rgan 'khyam po zhig dang 'dra bar/ sngon chad don dag byung myong sa'i sa cha tshang mar 'khyam nyul byas pa yin/ dper na/ phar phyogs kyi grog shur du shing phran gyi nags tshal zhig yod la/ de ni nga thog dang por bu mo zhig dang nyal sa de yin/ skabs der nga rang lo na bcu bzhi yin la/ de dus ngas ni shwa pho zhig dang 'dra bar rkang rdeb dang 'phongs gsig byas te 'khun sgra sgrog gi yod la/ de dus nga ni ra pho gcig dang 'dra bar chags sred kyis tshos yod/ de bas nga sa der yang bskyar song nas thang la gan rkyal du nyal nas bsdad tshe sngon chad kyi bya ba de dag re re bzhin mig lam du phyir shar yong / nged tshang gi 'bru khang gi phar phyogs kyi sa de ni glang rgan zhig gis nga'i a pha rwa rdung byas nas gsod sa de yin la/ kho'i khrag dmar rnams dus da lta'ang sa nang der 'gos yod/ 'gos yod nges yin/ mi su gcig gis kyang khrag dmar de bkrus myong med/ ngas nga'i a pha'i zungs khrag 'dres yod sa'i sa ngos su lag pas reg pa yin/[”] zhes bshad cing / de nas khos dogs mi bde ba'i rnam pas bshad mtshams cung bzhag [“]khyod gnyis kyis bltas na nga smyon pa 'dra po zhig yin rgyu red/ ma red dam/[”]

Muley went on, “Like a damn ol' graveyard ghos'. I been goin' aroun' the places where stuff happened. Like there's a place over by our forty; in a gully they's a bush. Fust time I ever laid with a girl was there. Me fourteen an' stampin' an' jerkin' an' snortin' like a buck deer, randy as a billygoat. So I went there an' I laid down on the groun', an' I seen it all happen again. An' there's the place down by the barn where Pa got gored to death by a bull. An' his blood is right in that groun', right now. Mus' be. Nobody never washed it out. An' I put my han' on that groun' where my own pa's blood is part of it.” He paused uneasily. “You fellas think I'm touched?”

jo Di yis sha brje slog brgyab cing / kho'i mig mdangs nang du bkug yod/ kha se yis skyil krung je dam du btang nas mig gis me phung du cer nas bsdad/ sar bsdad yod pa'i mi 'di dag las dbyin khre bco lnga tsam gyi sar grod khog rgyags nas yod pa'i byi la de tsog pur bsdad 'dug la/ kho'i mjug ma rang nyid kyi rgyab sug gi mtha' ru gra dag pos 'khyil/ 'ug pa chen po zhig gis 'dzer skad sgrog bzhin kho tsho'i mgo thog nas 'phur song la/ me 'od khrod nas 'ug pa'i dkar lam lam gyi gsus pa dang gshog 'og gsal por mthong thub/

Joad turned the meat, and his eyes were inward. Casy, feet drawn up, stared into the fire. Fifteen feet back from the men the fed cat was sitting, the long gray tail wrapped neatly around the front feet. A big owl shrieked as it went overhead, and the firelight showed its white underside and the spread of its wings.
kha se yis [“]ma red/ khyod rang kher rkyang yin pa bden pa red/ 'on kyang / khyod rang smyon pa ma red/[”] ces bshad/
“No,” said Casy. “You're lonely- but you ain't touched.”

mu le yi chung la dam pa'i gdong par nan tan gyi mdangs shig babs/ [“]zungs khrag da dung yang 'gos yod sa'i sa thog tu ngas lag pa bzhag pa yin/ ngas skabs der nga'i a pha'i brang khar btod yod pa'i i khung mthong thub la/ kho nga'i ngos su 'thams nas gzugs po 'dar tsam 'dar tsam byed pa'ang tshor thub/ de nas kho dal mos ltag tu nyal song la/ rkang lag tshang mas spar 'brad lta bu byed kyi yod/ ngas kho'i dkar log log gi mig mdangs las na zug gi sdug bsngal de mthong thub la/ de nas kho 'gul rgyu med par gyur nas/ gsal la dwangs pa'i mig zung gis gnam la cer ba'ang mthong / skabs der nga ni phru gu chung chung zhig yin pas ngu rgyu ma dran la ci yang byed rgyu ma dran par/ de gar langs nas bsdad/[”] khos mgo bo shugs kyis 'phred du g.yugs/

Muley's tight little face was rigid. “I put my han' right on the groun' where that blood is still. An' I seen my pa with a hole through his ches', an' I felt him shiver up against me like he done, an' I seen him kind of settle back an' reach with his han's an' his feet. An' I seen his eyes all milky with hurt, an' then he was still an' his eyes so clear- lookin' up. An' me a little kid settin' there, not cryin' nor nothin', jus' settin' there.” He shook his head sharply.

jo Di yis sha brje slog brgyab/ [“]de nas nga jo'e btsa' sa'i khang pa de'i nang du phyin pa yin/ nyal khri da lta mthong rgyu mi 'dug mod/ khang pa de ga rang red/ 'di dag tshang ma de 'dra'i gsal la gson po zhig red ang / sngon ma'i don dag khag re re bzhin sa gnas dang bstun nas phyir 'char yong gi 'dug khang pa de ni jo'e yi tshe srog gi mgo rtsom sa de red/ kho btsas nas yud tsam rjes su da gzod dbugs ring zhig blangs byung la/ de nas ngu skad le dbar gcig gi sa nas go thub pa zhig bsgrags song / skabs der nga'i a phyi de gar langs nas yod cing / kho mos/ [‘]ha cang yag po red/ ha cang yag po red/[’] ces yang dang bskyar du bsgrags shing / kho mo dga' spobs skyes drags pas dgong mo der bstud mar shel phor gsum bcag song /[7][”]

Joad turned the meat over and over. “An' I went in the room where Joe was born. Bed wasn't there, but it was the room. An' all them things is true, an' they're right in the place they happened. Joe came to life right there. He give a big ol' gasp an' then he let out a squawk you could hear a mile, an' his granma standin' there says, 'That's a daisy, that's a daisy,' over an' over. An' her so proud she bust three cups that night.”
[7] shel phor gcog pa ni je'u chos lugs kyi shugs rkyen 'dres pa'i rten 'brel zhu stangs shig
jo Di yis mid pa bsangs [“]ngas bltas na da zos na 'grig sa red/[”]
Joad cleared his throat. “Think we better eat her now.”

mu le yis khro nyams kyis [“]de yag po zhig tshos su chug tshos nas smug po byos/ phal cher nag po lta bu 'gyur dgos/ ngas skad cha bshad 'dod/ ngas yun ring la skad cha bshad rgyu ma byung / gal srid nga smyo yod na smyo yod/ de la'ang thabs shes ci yang yod pa ma red/ dur khrod kyi 'dre 'khyam bzhin mtshan mor khyim mtshes tsho'i khang pa nyul/ phe Ther tshang dang je khob tshang / ran si tshang dang jo Di tshang sogs re re bzhin nyul/ khang pa 'di rnams deng sang nag thib be thor la khad kyi sgam chag 'ga' re dang 'dra/ 'on kyang / khang pa 'di dag gi nang du spro skyid chen po btang myong yod la/ 'du 'dzoms byas pa dang dgod sgra'ang grag myong / da dung khang pa 'di dag tshang ma'i nang du gnyen ston yang bshams myong ang / 'di dag mthong tshe nga grong rdal du brgyugs nas ltas ngan de tsho gsod 'dod skyes/ kho tshos 'drud 'then la brten nas sa gzhis 'di dag mgo rting bslogs na kho tshor phan khe ci zhig yod pa red/ kho tsho'i bar khe srung skyob byed pa'i don du kho tshor ci zhig thob kyi yod dam/ kho tshor thob pa ni a pha sa thog nas 'chi sa dang jo'e yis dbugs kyi thog ma len sa/ ngas mtshan mor sdong gseb nas ra pho gcig dang 'dra bar gsig rdeb byed sa tsam red/ de min kho tshor ci zhig thob bam/ sa zhing 'di'i sa rgyu mi bzang ba gnam rgan mas kyang shes/ lo ngo mang po'i ring la khyim tshang gcig gis kyang ston thog yag po zhig bsdu rgyu byung med/ 'on kyang / gzhung las sgrog tse'i steng gi khyi phrug de tshos kho tsho'i bar khe zhig gi ched du nga tsho'i yul mi tsho phyed ka phyed kar btang ba red/ kho tshos yul mi tsho dum bu gnyis su btang ba red/ yul mi tsho dang kho tsho gnas sa'i gzhi gnyis ka ngo bo gcig yin mod/ kho tshos 'di gnyis kha khar btang bas/ da lta yul mi tsho ni 'tshang kha brgyab pa'i rlangs 'khor du bsdad nas gzhung lam steng du kher rkyang gis 'khyam bzhin yod/ da lta kho tsho ni gom pa spo bzhin pa'i bem po tsam red/ khyi phrug de tshos kho tsho bsad pa red/[”] ces bshad rjes/ mu le khu sim por gyur/ kho'i mchu to da dung yang 'gul bzhin 'dug la/ kho'i brang kha da dung yang rdeb bzhin 'dug kho thang la bsdad nas me 'od kyi khrod nas rang nyid kyi lag pa gnyis la lta bzhin skad dma' mos dgongs sel zhus pa'i nyams kyis [“]ngas dus yun ha cang ring po zhig gi ring la mi zhig la gleng mol byed rgyu ma byung / nga ni dur khrod kyi 'dre rgan 'khyam po zhig dang 'dra bar/ yar 'jab mar 'jab byas nas bsdad pa yin/[”] zhes bshad/

“Let her get good an' done, good an' brown, awmost black,” said Muley irritably. “I wanta talk. I ain't talked to nobody. If I'm touched, I'm touched, an' that's the end of it. Like a ol' graveyard ghos' goin' to neighbors' houses in the night. Peters', Jacobs', Rance's, Joad's; an' the houses all dark, standin' like miser'ble ratty boxes, but they was good parties an' dancin'. An' there was meetin's and shoutin' glory. They was weddin's, all in them houses. An' then I'd want to go in town an' kill folks. 'Cause what'd they take when they tractored the folks off the lan'? What'd they get so their 'margin a profit' was safe? They got Pa dyin' on the groun', an' Joe yellin' his first breath, an' me jerkin' like a billy goat under a bush in the night. What'd they get? God knows the lan' ain't no good. Nobody been able to make a crop for years. But them sons-a-bitches at their desks, they jus' chopped folks in two for their margin a profit. They jus' cut 'em in two. Place where folks live is them folks. They ain't whole, out lonely on the road in a piled-up car. They ain't alive no more. Them sons-a-bitches killed 'em.” And he was silent, his thin lips still moving, his chest still panting. He sat and looked down at his hands in the firelight. “I- I ain't talked to nobody for a long time,” he apologized softly. “I been sneakin' aroun' like a ol' graveyard ghos'.”

kha se yis shing leb ring po zhig me phung gi khrod du bsnur ba na/ me lce rnams shing leb kyi ngos su 'khril yong la/ de nas yang bskyar sha'i phyogs su yar mchongs/ dgong mo'i grang rlung gis khang pa'i shing cha rnams phyir 'khum du bcug pas/ da lta khang pas kyang kag sgra sgrog mgo brtsams/ kha se yis skad dma' mos [“]nga song nas lam la bud zin pa'i yul mi tsho la lta bar 'dod/ nga la kho tshor blta ru 'gro dgos pa'i tshor ba shugs chen skye/ kho tsho la chos dpon sus kyang stsol mi thub pa'i rogs ram dgos/ kho tshos mi yul gyi 'tsho ba tsam yang rol mi thub na/ lha yul gyi bde skyid la re bas ci zhig phan/ kho tsho rang nyid kyi rnam shes kyi mgo 'phangs dma' sar lhung nas sdug gi mun par lhung yod dus/ dam pa'i rnam shes shig gis ci zhig phan/ kho tshor dgos pa ni rogs ram red/ kho tshor 'chi ba'i cha rkyen ma 'dzoms sngon du/ gson pa'i mthun rkyen nges par du 'dzoms dgos/[”] zhes bshad/

Casy pushed the long boards into the fire and the flames licked up around them and leaped up toward the meat again. The house cracked loudly as the cooler night air contracted the wood. Casy said quietly, “I gotta see them folks that's gone out on the road. I got a feelin' I got to see them. They gonna need help no preachin' can give 'em. Hope of heaven when their lives ain't lived? Holy Sperit when their own sperit is downcast an' sad? They gonna need help. They got to live before they can afford to die.”

jo Di yis 'tshab 'tshub ngang [“]ston pa ye shu/ sha 'di tsig sha 'tshig ro 'dra po zhig tu ma gyur gong du zos na mi bzang ngam/ ltos dang / snoms dang /[”] zhes zer bzhin yar langs nas/ lcags skud kyi steng gi sha rdog rnams me lces mi snyobs sar phar ded/ khos rang nyid kyi glo khug las mu le yi ltebs gri blangs yong nas lcags skud las sha rdog cig mar gtub rjes [“]ya/ 'di chos dpon gyi yin/[”] zhes bshad/

Joad cried nervously, “Jesus Christ, le's eat this meat 'fore it's smaller'n a cooked mouse! Look at her. Smell her.” He leaped to his feet and slid the pieces of meat along the wire until they were clear of the fire. He took Muley's knife and sawed through a piece of meat until it was free of the wire. “Here's for the preacher,” he said.
[“]nga deng sang chos dpon min zhes khyod la bshad zin pa yin a/[”]
“I tol' you I ain't no preacher.”

[“]ya des na/ 'di skyes pa khyod kyi yin/[”] khos yang bskyar sha rdog cig gtub/ [“]ya/ mu le/ gal srid khyod khong khro langs drags nas sha yang bza' 'dod med pa min na/ 'di khyod kyi yin/ ri bong rna ring gi sha 'di glang gog cig gi sha las kyang mkhregs/[”] kho yang bskyar sar phyir bsdad nas/ mdun so ring po rnams sha nang du bsnun nas sha rdog kham chen zhig btogs nas bldad [“]ston pa ye shu/ hrob sgra 'dir gcig nyon dang /[”]

“Well, here's for the man, then.” He cut off another piece. “Here, Muley, if you ain't too goddamn upset to eat. This here's jackrabbit. Tougher'n a bull-bitch.” He sat back and clamped his long teeth on the meat and tore out a great bite and chewed it. “Jesus Christ! Hear her crunch!” And he tore out another bite ravenously.

mu le da dung yang 'gul med du bsdad de rang nyid kyi sha rdog la cer bzhin [“]gcig byas na ngas skad cha 'di 'dra bshad na 'grig gi yod rgyu ma red/ mi zhig yin na don dag 'di 'dra rang nyid kyi sems khong du bcug nas bsdad na bzang rgyu red/[”] ces bshad/
Muley still sat regarding his meat. “Maybe I oughtn' to a-talked like that,” he said. “Fella should maybe keep stuff like that in his head.”

kha se yis kha nang sha rdog gis gang nas tshur bltas/ khos sha rdog so yis bldad rjes mid par mid pa na/ kho'i sha rgyus dod pa'i mgrin pa rkyong skum thengs gsum byas/ de nas khos [“]skad cha bshad na yag po yod pa red/ mtshams la lar sdug bsngal gyis mnar ba'i mis sdug bsngal de kha nas bshad na lus nas phud thub kyi yod pa red/ mtshams la lar mi gsod mkhan gyis gsod rgyu kha nas bshad de/ dngos su gsod mi dgos pa de 'dra'ang yod pa red/ khyod kyi byed stangs de 'grig 'dug thabs shes med pa 'dra min na mi ma gsod a/[”] zhes bshad cing / de nas khos yang bskyar ri sha kham btog cig byas/

Casy looked over, his mouth full of rabbit. He chewed, and his muscled throat convulsed in swallowing. “Yes, you should talk,” he said. “Sometimes a sad man can talk the sadness right out through his mouth. Sometimes a killin' man can talk the murder right out of his mouth an' not do no murder. You done right. Don't you kill nobody if you can help it.” And he bit out another hunk of rabbit.

jo Di yis rus pa me nang du 'phangs rjes/ yar tog se langs nas rang nyid la yang bskyar sha rdog cig blangs/ mu le yis sha dal mos bza' bzhin 'dug la/ kho'i mig zung gis 'tsher snang dang bcas rang nyid kyi rogs pa gnyis la phar lta tshur lta byed/ jo Di yis gcan gzan zhig dang 'dra bar rngam bza' byed cing / kho'i kha mtha' ru zhag tshil gyi mtha' ra zhig 'khor/

Joad tossed the bones in the fire and jumped up and cut off the wire. Muley was eating slowly now, and his nervous little eyes went from one to the other of his companions. Joad ate scowling like an animal, and a ring of grease formed around his mouth.
mu le yis kho la dus yun ring tsam la cung dogs mi bde ba'i rnam pas bltas rjes/ sha bzung yod pa'i lag pa de mar phab nas [“]a Thom/[”] zhes bos/
For a long time Muley looked at him, almost timidly. He put down the hand that held the meat. “Tommy,” he said.
jo Di yis bza' mtshams mi 'jog par yar la bltas nas [“]a/[”] zhes kha zas kyis gang nas lan btab/
Joad looked up and did not stop gnawing the meat. “Yeah?” he said, around a mouthful.
[“]a Thom/ ngas mi de tsho gsod rgyu'i skor bshad pas khyod khong khro za yi yod rgyu ma red/ e yod/ a Thom/ khyod tshig pa zos med dam/[”]
“Tommy, you ain't mad with me talkin' about killin' people? You ain't huffy, Tom?”
Thom gyis [“]med/ nga tshig pa zos med/ de ni 'das zin pa'i don dag cig red/[”] ces bshad/
“No,” said Tom. “I ain't huffy. It's just somepin that happened.”

mu le yis [“]mi tshang mas de khyod kyi nor 'khrul min pa shes kyi yod/ rgan po Thun b+hul lags kyis khyod phyir bud tshe sha 'khon rtsod rgyu yin zer gyi yod la/ mi sus kyang kho'i bu bsad chog gi ma red zer gyi yod/ 'on kyang / rjes sor yul mi tshos kho la kha ta slob gso byas nas kho'i sems kha bsgyur yod/[”] ces bshad/

“Ever'body knowed it was no fault of yours,” said Muley. “Ol' man Turnbull said he was gonna get you when ya come out. Says nobody can kill one a his boys. All the folks hereabouts talked him outa it, though.”

jo Di yis skad dma' mos [“]skabs der nga tsho chang rag gis bzi yod/ zhabs bro'i dgong tshogs shig gi steng nas ra bzi ba red/ ngas 'dzing mo de ji ltar mgo btsugs pa'ang ma shes/ ngas gcig shes dus nga la gri zhig gis bsnun 'dug cing / des nga bzi dwangs su bcug pa red/ ngas thog mar mthong dus her b+hi yis gri 'khyer nas nga la yang bskyar 'dzugs grabs byed kyi 'dug skabs der slob grwa'i khang ngos su sbyag ma zhig khen nas 'dug cing / ngas de lag tu blangs nas kho'i mgo la brgyab pa yin/ nga dang her b+hi'i bar na rtsod rgyu ci yang med/ kho mi yag po zhig yod pa red/ kho chung chung yin dus nga'i gcung mo ro si sha ron la thub tshod gtong du yong myong mod/ nged gnyis bar na rtsod rgyu ci yang med/ nga her b+hi la dga' bo yod/[”] ces bshad/

“We was drunk,” Joad said softly. “Drunk at a dance. I don' know how she started. An' then I felt that knife go in me, an' that sobered me up. Fust thing I see is Herb comin' for me again with his knife. They was this here shovel leanin' against the schoolhouse, so I grabbed it an' smacked 'im over the head. I never had nothing against Herb. He was a nice fella. Come a-bullin' after my sister Rosasharn when he was a little fella. No, I liked Herb.”

[“]red ya/ tshang mas mi rgan khong la de ltar lab pas da gzod kho 'jags la babs pa red/ 'ga' res bshad na/ Thun b+hul 'di a ma'i phyogs nas had h+phild kyi khrag rgyud 'dres yod pas/ khos de'i tshod kyi rnam 'gyur zhig ston dgos kyi yod pa red zer/ de'i skor ngas ci yang mi shes/ gang ltar kho dang kho'i khyim mi tsho zla ba drug gi sngon du kha li h+phor ne ya mnga' sde ru phyin song /[”]

“Well, ever'body tol' his pa that, an' finally cooled 'im down. Somebody says they's Hatfield blood on his mother's side in ol' Turnbull, an' he's got to live up to it. I don't know about that. Him an' his folks went on to California six months ago.”

jo Di yis lcags skud kyi steng nas ri bong rjes ma de'i sha blangs nas tshang mar brgyud sprod byas/ kho yang bskyar phyir thang la bsdad nas sha dal mos zos shing / dal myur snyoms pos so bldad byas/ de nas khos phu thung spyad nas kha mtha'i zhag tshil rnams gtsang mar phyis shing / kho'i gnag la snum pa'i mig zung de phye ma btsum gyis ci zhig la bsam gzhig byed bzhin pa ltar me phung gi khrod du cer nas [“]mi tshang ma nub rgyud du 'gro bzhin 'dug mod/ 'on kyang / nga bzang btson dam bca'i 'og tu yod pas mnga' sde 'di dang 'bral mi chog[”] ces bshad/

Joad took the last of the rabbit from the wire and passed it around. He settled back and ate more slowly now, chewed evenly, and wiped the grease from his mouth with his sleeve. And his eyes, dark and half closed, brooded as he looked into the dying fire. “Ever'body's goin' west,” he said. “I got me a parole to keep. Can't leave the state.”
mu le yis [“]bzang btson dam bca' e/ ngas de go myong yod/ de'i 'gro stangs 'dra po de ga 'dra zhig red/[”] ces bshad/
“Parole?” Muley asked. “I heard about them. How do they work?”

[“]red ya/ nga dus bcad las sngon la sgor bud pa red/ lo ngo gsum gyis snga ba red/ 'on kyang / nga rang la bsgrub dgos pa'i 'gan khur re yod cing / de dag ma bsgrub na nang du phyir 'jug gi red/ de min da dung / dus dang dus su gnas tshul yar snyan gseng 'bul dgos kyi yod pa red/[”]
“Well, I got out early, three years early. They's stuff I gotta do, or they send me back in. Got to report ever' so often.”
[“]mag le si Thir btson khang nas kho tsho khyod la ji 'dra red/ nga'i chung ma'i pha ma spun gcig mag le si Thir du bsdad myong yod la/ kho tshos kho la dmyal ba zhig myong du bcug rabs 'dug[”]
“How they treat ya there in McAlester? My woman's cousin was in McAlester an' they give him hell.”

jo Di yis [“]de de 'dra sdug po zhig kyang ma red/ de ni sa cha ga sa gang dang gcig mtshungs red/ khyod kyis dmyal ba'i sgo phyes na kho tshos khyod la dmyal ba zhig myong du 'jug gi red/ btson srung pas khyod la dmyal sgo zhig phyes na red ma gtogs de min khyod kyis mthun lam yag po byas na mi skyon/ ngas tshang mar mthun lam byas pa yin la/ mi gzhan pa tshang ma dang 'dra bar/ jus med jus gtogs ma byas par bsdad pa yin/ btson khang nas ngas 'bri rtsal yag po zhig kyang sbyong thub song / yi ge dang tha snyad tsam ma yin par bya bye'u lta bu'i ri mo 'bri tshul yang sbyangs pa yin/ nged tshang gi mi rgan gyis ngas pir rtse 'drud thengs gcig gis bye'u zhig 'bri thub pa mthong na sems nad 'phar rgyu red/ ngas de ltar byed pa mthong tshe nga'i a pha tshig pa za nges yin/ kho 'di lta bu'i mdzes chos la mi dga'/ kho tha na 'bri zhes pa'i tshig 'di la'ang mi dga'/ yi ge 'bri rgyu des kho la 'jigs snang 'dra slong gi yod pa 'dra/ nam yang khos yi ge 'bri bzhin pa mthong rgyu yod tshe/ de ni su zhig gis kho'i lag nas ci zhig 'khyer song bas khos brjed tho 'god bzhin pa yin nges/[”] zhes bshad/

“It ain't so bad,” said Joad. “Like ever'place else. They give ya hell if ya raise hell. You get along O.K. les' some guard gets it in for ya. Then you catch plenty hell. I got along O.K. Minded my own business, like any guy would. I learned to write nice as hell. Birds an' stuff like that, too; not just word writin'. My ol' man'll be sore when he sees me whip out a bird in one stroke. Pa's gonna be mad when he sees me do that. He don't like no fancy stuff like that. He don't even like word writin'. Kinda scares 'im I guess. Ever' time Pa seen writin', somebody took somepin away from 'im.”
[“]kho tshos khyod la gcar rdung de 'dra ma btang ngam/[”]
“They didn't give you no beatin's or nothin' like that?”

[“]btang ma song / ngas rang don kho nar kha ya byas nas bsdad pa yin/ yin dang yin/ 'di ltar nyin 'phror nyin dang / lo 'phror lo mthud nas song na dngos gnas sun byed cig yin/ khyod kyis nongs 'gyod skye dgos pa'i bya ba zhig bsgrubs pa yin na/ khyod la de thad la phyir 'dang rgyag rgyu'i khom pa yod mod/ 'on kyang / nga la mtshon na/ her phu Thun b+hul gyis lag tu gri zhig bzung nas nga'i thog tu shor yong gi yod na/ ngas the tshom med par yang bskyar kho'i mgo la sbyag mas thengs gcig gzhu nges yin/[”]

“No, I jus' tended my own affairs. 'Course you get goddamn good an' sick a-doin' the same thing day after day for four years. If you done somepin you was ashamed of, you might think about that. But, hell, if I seen Herb Turnbull comin' for me with a knife right now, I'd squash him down with a shovel again.”
mu le yis [“]su zhig yin rung de ltar byed nges yin/[”] zhes bshad/
“Anybody would,” said Muley.

chos dpon gyis me phung gi khrod du cer nas 'dug cing / mun pa'i rgyab ljongs nang du kho'i thod pa chen po de dkar zhing gsal/ me lce'i 'od rlabs kyis kho'i ske yi rtsa rgyus rnams gsal por mngon par byas 'dug la/ kho'i pus mo'i steng nas phan tshun bsnol ba'i lag pa gnyis kyis mdzub tshigs rnams phar 'then tshur 'then byed/

The preacher stared into the fire, and his high forehead was white in the settling dark. The flash of little flames picked out the cords of his neck. His hands, clasped about his knees, were busy pulling knuckles.

jo Di yis ches mtha' ma'i rus pa de yang me nang du 'phangs rjes/ rang nyid kyi mdzub mo rnams lce ldag re byas rjes dor ma'i steng du phyis/ khos sgo khyams steng gi chu dam de 'khyer yong nas bsri tshags kyi sgo nas hub chung zhig btungs/ khos chu dam de rogs pa gnyis la brgyud sprod byas rjes mu mthud du [“]nga'i sems nas nam yang 'dang mi phog rgyu de ci red zer na/ ngas 'di'i rgyab kyi gnas lugs mi shes pa de red/ thog mda' brgyab nas ba lang zhig bsad pa'am/ yang na chu log 'dra brgyugs pa yin na/ de'i rgyab kyi gnas lugs 'tshol thabs byed mkhan med/ de ni rang byung gi chos nyid red/ 'on kyang / mi 'ga' res khyod rang bzung nas btson la lo bzhir bcug pa na/ de la don snying zhig yod dgos kyi red/ mi zhig yin na ci byed ci las tshang mar de'i rgyab kyi gnas lugs shig dgos kyi yod pa red/ 'on kyang / kho tshos nga btson du lo bzhir bcug cing / lo bzhi'i ring nga gsos nas bzhag pa red/ 'dis ngas yang bskyar de 'dra mi byed pa'am/ yang na nga la nyes chad bcad nas yang bskyar de 'dra byed mi phod pa byed dgos pa red/[”] ces bshad rjes khos bshad mtshams cung tsam bzhag cing / de nas mu mthud du [“]'on kyang / her phu'am yang na mi su zhig nga'i thog tu shor yong na ngas sngar bzhin byed nges yin/ ngas ci byas ha ma go gong du de ltar yang bskyar byas yod nges red la/ lhag par du nga bzi yod na de bas kyang the tshom med/ 'di lta bu'i don snying med pa'i snang tshul 'dis nga'i sems pa 'khrug tu 'jug gi 'dug[”] ces bshad/

Joad threw the last bones into the fire and licked his fingers and then wiped them on his pants. He stood up and brought the bottle of water from the porch, took a sparing drink, and passed the bottle before he sat down again. He went on. “The thing that give me the mos' trouble was, it didn' make no sense. You don't look for no sense when lightnin' kills a cow, or it comes up a flood. That's jus' the way things is. But when a bunch of men take an' lock you up four years, it ought to have some meaning. Men is supposed to think things out. Here they put me in, an' keep me an' feed me four years. That ought to either make me so I won't do her again or else punish me so I'll be afraid to do her again”- he paused- “but if Herb or anybody else come for me, I'd do her again. Do her before I could figure her out. Specially if I was drunk. That sort of senselessness kind a worries a man.”
mu le yis do snang dang bcas [“]de khyod kyi nor 'khrul ma yin pa'i rkyen gyis/ khrims dpon gyis khyod la khrims thag yang mo bcad pa yin lab song a/[”] zhes bshad/
Muley observed, “Judge says he give you a light sentence 'cause it wasn't all your fault.”

jo Di yis [“]mag le si Thir btson khang du tshe btson la bcug pa'i btson pa zhig yod cing / khos rgyun par slob sbyong byed kyi yod/ kho btson dpon gyi drung yig yin la/ khos btson dpon gyi 'phrin yig sogs 'bri yi yod/ red ya/ kho ni mi ha cang blo rig can zhig yin la/ khos rgyun par khrims lugs dang de 'brel gyi dpe deb klog gi yod/ khos khrims lugs skor la de 'dra mang po klog gi yod pa'i rkyen gyis/ ngas nyin zhig kho la de'i skor dris pa yin/ khos zer na dpe cha klog pas phan pa ci yang 'byung gi mi 'dug zer la/ khos deng sang gi btson khang dang gna' dus kyi btson khang gi skor tshang ma bklags pa yin mod/ 'on kyang / dpe deb de dag bklags rjes ma bklags gong las kyang mgo 'thom gyi 'dug zer/ khos zer na de ni dmyal ba zhig gi sgo 'byed byed yin la/ sgo phyes tshar rjes mi su zhig gis kyang sgo de phyir rgyag mi thub cing / mi su zhig la'ang der 'gyur ba gtong ba'i rtogs pa med zer/ khos gnas tshul gang la 'phrad kyang khrims lugs skor gyi deb ma klogs ma gtogs/ gal srid bklags pa yin na/ gcig nas des khyod rang sngar las kyang mgo 'thom du 'jug la/ gnyis nas des khyod la srid gzhung gi mi snar brtsi bkur med par 'gyur du 'jug gi red zer/[”] zhes bshad/

Joad said, “They's a guy in McAlester- lifer. He studies all the time. He's sec'etary of the warden- writes the warden's letters an' stuff like that. Well, he's one hell of a bright guy an' reads law an' all stuff like that. Well, I talked to him one time about her, 'cause he reads so much stuff. An' he says it don't do no good to read books. Says he's read ever'thing about prisons now, an' in the old times; an' he says she makes less sense to him now than she did before he starts readin'. He says it's a thing that started way to hell an' gone back, an' nobody seems to be able to stop her, an' nobody got sense enough to change her. He says for God's sake don't read about her because he says for one thing you'll jus' get messed up worse, an' for another you won't have no respect for the guys that work the gover'ments.”

mu le yis [“]nga da lta mi de dag la brtsi bkur chen po med/ deng sang yul mi nga tsho'i steng du khen nas yod pa'i srid gzhung ni [‘]bar khe gang 'tshams [’]len dgos mkhan can po de kho na red/ nga'i sems khong du da dung yang shong mi thub pa ni/ wi le h+phe le yis 'drud 'then de bskor nas/ rang nyid kyi yul mi tshos rmo 'debs byas myong ba'i sa zhing 'di'i thog nas/ rang nyid kyi yul mi tsho'i steng du sprang po'i nang gi dpon po byed bzhin pa de red/ red ya/ 'dis nga'i sems pa 'khrug tu 'jug phyi mi zhig yong nas nga tsho'i mgo la 'di 'dra byed kyi yod na de'ang bsam shes thub pa zhig red/ 'on kyang / wi le yis kyang 'di 'dra byas yong dus/ red ya/ 'dis ni nga'i sems pa 'khrug tu 'jug nga'i sems pa 'khrugs pa'i rkyen gyis/ nga kho'i rtsar song nas gnas lugs bshad pa yin/ 'on kyang / kho thad kar khong khro langs nas [‘]nga la phru gu chung chung gnyis yod la/ chung ma dang chung ma'i a ma yang yod/ mi 'di dag gis kha la za ma bza' dgos kyi red/[’] ces zer/ kho dngos gnas khong khro ngan pa langs nas [‘]ngas ang dang po bsam blo gtong dgos sa de nga rang nyid kyi bza' mi tsho yin/ gzhan pa'i bza' mi la gzhan pa tshos blta rgyu red/[’] ces zer/ kho ngo nongs pa 'dra zhing / de'i rkyen gyis kho khong khro zos pa 'dra/[”] zhes bshad/

“I ain't got a hell of a lot of respec' for 'em now,” said Muley. “On'y kind a gover'ment we got that leans on us fellas is the 'safe margin a profit.' There's one thing that got me stumped, an' that's Willy Feeley- drivin' that cat', an' gonna be a straw boss on lan' his own folks used to farm. That worries me. I can see how a fella might come from some other place an' not know no better, but Willy belongs. Worried me so I went up to 'im and ast 'im. Right off he got mad. 'I got two little kids,' he says. 'I got a wife an' my wife's mother. Them people got to eat.' Gets madder'n hell. 'Fust an' on'y thing I got to think about is my own folks,' he says. 'What happens to other folks is their look-out,' he says. Seems like he's 'shamed, so he gets mad.”

jim kha se yis 'jags bzhin pa'i me phung la cer nas 'dug cing / kho'i mig zung gi kha zheng je cher song zhing / ske yi rtsa rgyus khag yar la 'grengs/ khos glo bur du skad mgo mthon pos [“]nga la dam pa'i rnam shes zhugs myong / gal srid mi zhig la dam pa'i rnam shes 'jug rgyu zhig yod na/ de nga la'ang zhugs myong / de glog dmar zhig dang 'dra bar zhugs/[”] zhes zer bzhin kho yar la langs nas phar 'gro tshur 'gro byas shing / mgo bo yang de dang bstun nas phar g.yug tshur g.yug byas [“]sngon chad cig la nga la ras gur zhig yod/ skabs der dgong mo re rer dad ldan mang tshogs lnga brgya lhag 'du bzhin yod pa red/ de ni khyod tshos nga mthong yang ma myong ba'i sngon red/[”] kho yar la langs nas bsdad de mig gis kho gnyis la mar bltas [“]khyod tsho'i sa nas/ ngas 'bru khang nang dang yang na phyi logs gang du'ang chos 'chad skabs/ ngas 'bul ba nam yang bsdus myong med a/ e yod/[”]

Jim Casy had been staring at the dying fire, and his eyes had grown wider and his neck muscles stood higher. Suddenly he cried, “I got her! If ever a man got a dose of the sperit, I got her. Got her all of a flash!” He jumped to his feet and paced back and forth, his head swinging. “Had a tent one time. Drawed as much as five hundred people ever' night. That's before either you fellas seen me.” He stopped and faced them. “Ever notice I never took no collections when I was preachin' out here to folks- in barns an' in the open?”

mu le yis [“]de dkon mchog dpang la btsugs chog khyod kyis 'bul ba bsdus myong med/ sa 'di'i yul mi tshos khyod la 'bul ba mi sprod rgyur goms yod pa'i rkyen gyis/ chos dpon gzhan pa tsho yong nas zhwa mo sngon la gzed na tshang mas mi dga' ba'i rnam 'gyur ston gyi yod pa red/ red ya/ khyod kyis 'bul ba zhig bsdus myong med/[”] ces bshad/
“By God, you never,” said Muley. “People around here got so use' to not givin' you money they got to bein' a little mad when some other preacher came along an' passed the hat. Yes, sir!”

kha se yis [“]ngas bza' rgyu re blangs myong yod/ nga'i dor ma ral nas tshar song dus dor ma re blangs pa yin la/ lham ral nas rkang pa sa rjen la 'khel yong dus lham cha re blangs pa yin/ 'on kyang / nga la ras gur zhig yod pa'i skabs der nga rang de 'dra zhig ga la yin/ skabs der mtshams la lar ngas sgor mo bcu lhag dang nyi shu len thub kyi yod/ 'on kyang / de ltar byas na sems khams mi skyid pas spyod pa de mtshams bzhag pa yin la/ de'i dbang gis yud tsam ring la sems khams skyid po byung / ngas bltas na nga'i rtogs pa cung sad yod pa 'dra/ ngas de ci yin thag gis chod pa zhig bshad mi thub la/ bshad e thub lta 'dun yang med/ 'on kyang / gcig byas na chos dpon gyi dgos mkho yod pa yin rgyu red/ gcig byas na ngas yang bskyar chos phyir 'chad dgos rgyu red/ yul mi tsho gzhung lam steng du yod la/ yul mi de dag la sa zhing med la khang khyim yang med pas/ kho tshor rnam pa gang yang rung ba'i rten sa'i gzhis shig dgos rgyu red/ gcig byas na [...] /[”] zhes zer bzhin kho'i bshad mtshams chad/ kho me phung gi gong phyogs su langs yod pas ske yi rtsa rgyus brgya phrag mang po mngon gsal dod pos tshur 'bur zhing / me 'od dag kho'i mig zung gi zab sar 'dzul bas kho'i mig zung las dmar lhog lhog gi me lce 'bar/ kho de gar langs nas me phung la cer zhing / khos ci zhig la rna nyan byed bzhin pa ltar gdong pa je dam du phyin/ blo yi 'char sgo rnams tshur btus nas lag tu bzung ste phar 'phen pa dgos pa ltar/ kho'i lag zung 'gul skyod la brel zhing / de nas lag zung gi g.yo 'gul cung je dal du btang nas lag pa glo khug gi nang du bsrings/ pha wang re me 'od gnyom po'i khrod du tshur 'phur nas yong zhing phar 'phur nas 'gro la/ mtshan mo'i bya khra 'ga' res zhing kha'i phar phyogs su chu sgra dang 'dra ba'i ca co chung chung re sgrog

“I took somepin to eat,” said Casy. “I took a pair a pants when mine was wore out, an' a ol' pair a shoes when I was walkin' through to the groun', but it wasn't like when I had the tent. Some days there I'd take in ten or twenty dollars. Wasn't happy that-a-way, so I give her up, an' for a time I was happy. I think I got her now. I don't know if I can say her. I guess I won't try to say her- but maybe there's a place for a preacher. Maybe I can preach again. Folks out lonely on the road, folks with no lan', no home to go to. They got to have some kind of home. Maybe…” He stood over the fire. The hundred muscles of his neck stood out in high relief, and the firelight went deep into his eyes and ignited red embers. He stood and looked at the fire, his face tense as though he were listening, and the hands that had been active to pick, to handle, to throw ideas, grew quiet, and in a moment crept into his pocket. The bats flittered in and out of the dull firelight, and the soft watery burble of a night hawk came from across the fields.

Thom gyis lag pa dal mos glo khug tu bsrings nas rdo tha'i khug ma phyir phyungs yong nas rang nyid la tha mag rkang gcig dal mos bsgril/ de nas khos tha mag de 'then bzhin mig zung gis tha mag gi sne mo'i me sgong la bltas/ chos dpon gyi skad cha de ni gzhan gyis go mi rung ba'i sger gyi gsang ba zhig yin pa ltar/ Thom gyis kho'i skad cha hril po snang med du btang nas [“]nga'i btson khang gi nyal khri'i steng nas ngas nub mo re rer/ nga rang btson las grol skabs phyi rol gyi 'jig rten de ci 'dra zhig yin nam snyam nas stong 'dang mang po brgyab myong / ngas nga'i a mes sam yang na a phyi tshe las 'das yod rgyu red snyam myong la/ de'i shul du phru gu gsar pa 'ga' re'ang btsas yod srid snyam/ gcig byas na a pha lags sngon chad nang bzhin mkhregs po min yang srid la/ a ma khyim las kyi 'gan khur las phyi nur byas nas/ ro si sha ron la khyim las gnyer du 'jug gi yod kyang srid snyam myong / ngas don dag mang po zhig sngon ma dang 'dra po min nges pa shes kyi yod/ red ya/ gang ltar/ do nub nga tsho 'di nas zhag 'dug byas nas/ sang nyin nyi rtse brgyab pa dang chabs cig lam la bud nas a khu jon tshang la 'gro rgyu bya/ gang ltar de ma gtogs las rgyu gzhan med/ khyod rang yang nga dang mnyam du 'gro 'dod yod dam/ kha se/[”] zhes bshad/

Tom reached quietly into his pocket and brought out his tobacco, and he rolled a cigarette slowly and looked over it at the coals while he worked. He ignored the whole speech of the preacher, as though it were some private thing that should not be inspected. He said, “Night after night in my bunk I figgered how she'd be when I come home again. I figgered maybe Grampa and Granma'd be dead, an' maybe there'd be some new kids. Maybe Pa'd not be so tough. Maybe Ma'd set back a little an' let Rosasharn do the work. I knowed it wouldn't be the same as it was. Well, we'll sleep here, I guess, an' come daylight we'll get on to Uncle John's. Leastwise I will. You think you're comin' along, Casy?”

chos dpon gyis da dung yang sol thal gyi khrod du cer nas 'dug la/ de nas khos dal mos [“]'gro 'dod yod/ nga khyod dang mnyam du 'gro rgyu yin/ khyod kyi khyim mi tshang ma lam la 'bud dus nga'ang mnyam du 'gro rtsis yin/ kho tsho lam la bud nas gang du song na nga yang der 'gro rgyu yin/[”] zhes bshad/

The preacher still stood looking into the coals. He said slowly, “Yeah, I'm goin' with you. An' when your folks start out on the road I'm goin' with them. An' where folks are on the road, I'm gonna be with them.”

jo Di yis [“]khyod la dga' bsu zhu nges yin/ a ma nam rgyun khyod la dga' la/ kho mos khyod ni yid rton chog pa'i chos dpon zhig yin zer myong / de dus ro si sha ron da dung nar son med/[”] ces bshad cing / de nas kho'i gdong pa mu le la 'khor/ [“]mu le/ khyod nga tsho dang mnyam du 'gro rgyu yin nam/[”] mu le yis kho tsho da sngon yong sa'i gzhung lam de'i phyogs su bltas nas 'dug pas/ jo Di yis yang bskyar [“]khyod rang yang nga tsho dang mnyam du 'gro 'dod yod dam/ mu le/[”] zhes dris/

“You're welcome,” said Joad. “Ma always favored you. Said you was a preacher to trust. Rosasharn wasn't growed up then.” He turned his head. “Muley, you gonna walk on over with us?” Muley was looking toward the road over which they had come. “Think you'll come along, Muley?” Joad repeated.

[“]a/ o/ nga gang du'ang 'gro rgyu min/ nga sa cha 'di dang kha 'bral rgyu min/ phar phyogs kyi dkar 'od de mthong gi 'dug gam/ yar mchong mar lhung byed bzhin pa'i 'od de mthong gi 'dug gam/ 'di phyogs kyi sring bal zhing kha'i lta rtog dpon po yin pa 'dra/ gcig gis nga tshos me sbar ba mthong ba yin rgyu red/[”]
“Huh? No. I don't go no place, an' I don't leave no place. See that glow over there, jerkin' up an' down? That's prob'ly the super'ntendent of this stretch a cotton. Somebody maybe seen our fire.”

Thom gyis phar phyogs su bltas dus/ glog 'od cig phar phyogs kyi de'u 'bur steng nas thag je nye je nye red/ de bas Thom gyis [“]nga tshos don ngan ci yang sgrub kyin med/ nga tsho 'di nas sngar bzhin 'dug rgyu yin/ nga tshos don ngan ci yang sgrub kyin med/[”] ces bshad/
Tom looked. The glow of light was nearly over the hill. “We ain't doin' no harm,” he said. “We'll jus' set here. We ain't doin' nothin'.”

mu le gad mo shor [“]don ngan sgrub kyi yod pa red ya/ nga tsho 'di gar bsdad pa 'di don ngan du gyur yod pa red/ nga tshos gzhan sa khrims 'gal gyis bzung yod pa red/ nga tsho 'di nas 'dug mi rung / kho tshos 'das pa'i zla ngo gnyis lhag ring la nga 'dzin thabs byed bzhin yod/ da nyon a/ gal srid rlangs 'khor de tshur nga tsho'i sar yong na/ nga tsho sring bal zhing nang du bros nas 'jab skung bya/ de 'dra thag ring la 'gro mi dgos/ de nas kho tshor 'dod pa yod na 'tshol du chug kho tshos 'tshol na sring sdong bstar ba re re bzhin btsal nas yong dgos/ so so'i mgo 'phangs dma' mos bskung bsdad pas chog[”]

Muley cackled. “Yeah! We're doin' somepin jus' bein' here. We're trespassin'. We can't stay. They been tryin' to catch me for two months. Now you look. If that's a car comin' we go out in the cotton an' lay down. Don't have to go far. Then by God let 'em try to fin' us! Have to look up an' down ever' row. Just keep your head down.”
jo Di yis [“]khyod la ci zhig byung song / mu le/ khyod nam yang bros byol dang sbas skung byed mkhan gyi mi zhig min a/ khyod rang ham pa chen po can zhig yin a/[”] zhes bshad/
Joad demanded, “What's come over you, Muley? You wasn't never no run-an'-hide fella. You was mean.”

mu le yis thag je nyer yong bzhin pa'i glog 'od la bltas [“]red ya/ nga sngon chad spyang ki lta bu'i ham pa can zhig yin mod/ deng sang sre mong lta bu'i ham pa can zhig yin/ khyod kyis ci zhig phar rngon bzhin pa'i skabs der khyod rang rngon pa yin pas/ khyod la stobs shugs ldan/ su zhig gis kyang rngon pa pham par rgyag mi thub/ 'on kyang / su zhig gis khyod rang tshur rngon yong dus/ de ni gnas tshul tha dad cig red/ des khyod la don dngos gsar pa zhig rtogs su 'jug gi red/ de dus khyod la stobs shugs med/ khyod rang da dung sngar bzhin gtum po yin srid mod/ 'on kyang / khyod la stobs shugs med/ kho tshos nga yun ring zhig la brngon byung / deng sang nga rang rngon pa min pas ngas mun nag khrod nas gang zhig la me mda' 'phen thub srid mod/ 'on kyang / ra ba'i phur ba zhig gis mi zhig rdung ba'i dus rabs de nga la mtshon na mjug rdzogs zin pa red/ rang mgo rang gis skor thabs byed pa des khyod dang nga su la'ang mi phan/ de don dngos red/[”]

I'd maybe shoot a fella in the dark, but I don't maul nobody with a fence stake no more. It don't do no good to fool you or me. That's how it is.”

Muley said, “There's one more thing about bein' hunted. You get to thinkin' about all the dangerous things. If you're huntin' you don't think about 'em, an' you ain't scared. Like you says to me, if you get in any trouble they'll sen' you back to McAlester to finish your time.”

“That's right,” said Joad. “That's what they tol' me, but settin' here restin' or sleepin' on the groun'- that ain't gettin' in no trouble. That ain't doin' nothin' wrong. That ain't like gettin' drunk or raisin' hell.”

mu le gad mo bgad [“]da khyod kyis ltos dang / khyod 'dir sdod dang rlangs 'khor yong gi red/ yong mkhan wi le h+phe le yin srid la/ kho dang mnyam du nyen rtog pa'ang yong gi yod rgyu red/ wi le yis khyod la [‘]khyod tshos gzhan sa khrims 'gal gyis 'dzin don ci yin/[’]zhes 'dri rgyu red/ wi le ni gad snyigs lta bu zhig yin pa khyod kyis kyang shes gsal red/ de bas khyod kyis [‘]de khyod la jus gtogs ci yod/[’]ces lan 'debs rgyu red/ de dus wi le khong khro zos nas [‘]'di dang kha ma bral na ngas khyod 'dzin bzung bya rgyu yin/[’] zer nges/ h+phe le lta bu'i mi 'di 'dra khros shing zhed nas khyod rang gang 'dod du thub tshod gtong rtsis byas na/ khyod kyang kha rog la 'dug thub rgyu ma red/ khos khyod la zhed snang slong ba'i skad cha rdzig po mang po bshad nges red la/ de dus khyod kyang khong khro zos nas kho la ya lan slog nges red/ o/ da g.yug shog de las sring sdong nang du sbas skung byas nas kho tshor lta rtog byed du bcug na mi dga' 'am/ 'di ltar byas na skyid po yang yin te/ kho tsho khong khro ha cang langs nges mod/ 'on kyang / kho tshor byed rgyu ci yang yod pa ma red/ nga tshos rgyang ring sa nas kho tsho 'phya dgod byas te bsdad chog de ma yin par/ khyod kyis wi le dang / yang na kho tsho'i 'go pa gang rung la kha brda byas na/ khyod kyis kho tsho skyag pa shor shor zhig rdung dgos 'khel zhing / de dus kho tshos khyod bzung nas mag le si Thir btson khang du phyir bskyal nas btson yun lo gsum po de gar mjug skyong dgos 'khel yong gi red/[”]

Muley laughed. “You'll see. You jus' set here, an' the car'll come. Maybe it's Willy Feeley, an' Willy's a deputy sheriff now. 'What you doin' trespassin' here?' Willy says. He's made a bluff an' he got to go on with it, an' here's you gettin' tough an' you got to go through- oh, hell, it's a lot easier to lay out in the cotton an' let 'em look. “You're talkin' sense,” said Joad. “Ever' word you say is sense. But, Jesus, I hate to get pushed around! I lots rather take a sock at Willy.”

“Come on, then, over this way,” Muley moved around the house and out into the cotton field about fifty yards. “This is good,” he said. “Now lay down. You on'y got to pull your head down if they start the spotlight goin'. It's kinda fun.” The three men stretched out at full length and propped themselves on their elbows. Muley sprang up and ran toward the house, and in a few moments he came back and threw a bundle of coats and shoes down. “They'd of taken 'em along just to get even,” he said. The lights topped the rise and bore down on the house.

Joad asked, “Won't they come out here with flashlights an' look aroun' for us? I wisht I had a stick.”

Muley giggled. “No, they won't. I tol' you I'm mean like a weasel. Willy done that one night an' I clipped 'im from behint with a fence stake. Knocked him colder'n a wedge. He tol' later how five guys come at him.”

That keeps Willy careful. A scratching sound came from near the house. “Puttin' out the fire,” Muley whispered. “Kickin' dust over it.” The car doors slammed, the headlights swung around and faced the road again. “Now duck!” said Muley. They dropped their heads and the spotlight swept over them and crossed and recrossed the cotton field, and then the car started and slipped away and topped the rise and disappeared.

Muley sat up. “Willy always tries that las' flash. He done it so often I can time 'im. An' he still thinks it's cute.”

Casy said, “Maybe they left some fellas at the house. They'd catch us when we come back.”

“Maybe. You fellas wait here. I know this game.” He walked quietly away, and only a slight crunching of clods could be heard from his passage. The two waiting men tried to hear him, but he had gone. In a moment he called from the house, “They didn't leave nobody. Come on back.” Casy and Joad struggled up and walked back toward the black bulk of the house. Muley met them near the smoking dust pile which had been their fire. “I didn't think they'd leave nobody,” he said proudly. “Me knockin' Willy over an' takin' a shot at the lights once-twice keeps 'em careful. They ain't sure who it is, an' I ain't gonna let 'em catch me. I don't sleep near no house. If you fellas wanta come along, I'll show you where to sleep, where they ain't nobody gonna stumble over ya.”

“Lead off,” said Joad. “We'll folla you. I never thought I'd be hidin' out on my old man's place.”

“I ain't sleepin,” said Casy. “I got too much to puzzle with.” He drew up his feet and clasped his legs. He threw back his head and looked at the sharp stars. Joad yawned and brought one hand back under his head. They were silent, and gradually the skittering life of the ground, of holes and burrows, of the brush, began again; the gophers moved, and the rabbits crept to green things, the mice scampered over clods, and the winged hunters moved soundlessly overhead.
