IN THE TOWNS, ON the edges of the towns, in fields, in vacant lots, the used-car yards, the wreckers' yards, the garages with blazoned signs- Used Cars, Good Used Cars. Cheap transportation, three trailers. '27 Ford, clean. Checked cars, guaranteed cars. Free radio. Car with 100 gallons of gas free. Come in and look. Used Cars. No overhead.

gzhung las sgrog tse gcig dang rkub stegs gcig deb sngon gcig bcas shong thub pa'i khang pa dang sa mig khag tu/ zur sne rnams ltebs rtseg brgyab nas shog 'dzer gyis bsdams yod pa'i gan rgya'i shog bu chag pa dang / gra dag por brtsigs shing da dung bed ma spyad pa'i gan rgya chag pa bcas yod/ smyu gu/ red/ smyu gur snag tsha gang blugs nas spyod chog chog byos/ thengs sngon mar smyu gu zhig yag por ma 'gos pa'i rkyen gyis nyo tshong gcig lam lhong ma byung ba red/

A lot and a house large enough for a desk and chair and a blue book. Sheaf of contracts, dog-eared, held with paper clips, and a neat pile of unused contracts. Pen- keep it full, keep it working. A sale's been lost 'cause a pen didn't work.

phar phyogs khyi phrug de tshos ci yang nyo yi mi 'dug sgo ra re re'i nang du kho tsho yong gi 'dug mod/ kho tsho ni lta mkhan las nyo mkhan ma red/ kho tshos bltas nas dus tshod tshang ma bskyal rgyu red/ rlangs 'khor chung ba mi nyo bar khyod kyi dus tshod bkag nas 'dug gi red/ kho tshos khyod kyi dus tshod la kha ya tsam yang byed rgyu ma red/ phar phyogs kyi de/ mi gnyis can po/ ma red/ phru gu 'khrid bsdad mkhan de tsho/ kho tsho rlangs 'khor chung ba'i nang du 'bud du chug sgor mo gnyis brgya nas mgo brtsams nas/ rim bzhin mar phob/ kho tsho sgor mo brgya dang nyi shu rtsa lnga la ran po 'dug kho tshor skor du chug kho tsho 'khor rnying zhig gi nang du zhog de kho tsho'i mgo la skon shog kho tshos nga tsho'i dus tshod chud zos su btang song /

Those sons-of-bitches over there ain't buying. Every yard gets 'em. They're lookers. Spend all their time looking. Don't want to buy no cars; take up your time. Don't give a damn for your time. Over there, them two people- no, with the kids. Get 'em in a car. Start 'em at two hundred and work down. They look good for one and a quarter. Get 'em rolling. Get 'em out in a jalopy. Sock it to 'em! They took our time.

bdag pos phu thung yar la brdzes/ tshong pas gtsang zhing dag la ha cang nan tan gyi rnam pa babs pa'i tshong sgyur pa'i dmigs don ldan pa'i mig zung chung chung gis phar phyogs kyi zhan cha zhig e rnyed 'tshol bzhin gda'/
Owners with rolled-up sleeves. Salesmen, neat, deadly, small intent eyes watching for weaknesses.

bud med de'i gdong la ltos/ gal srid bud med 'di'i blo la babs na rgad po de las sla po yin gyi red/ kho tshor kha Di lag [8]gi thog nas mgo tshugs dang / de ltar byas na khyod kyis mtha' mar kho tsho b+hi'u khi [26]rtags can po'i thog la mar 'bab du bcug na 'grig gi red/ gal srid khyod kyis b+hi'u khi yi steng nas mgo btsugs na kho tsho h+phord cig gi steng du mar 'gro yi red/ ya/ phu thung brdzes te las kar zhugs dang / 'di ni rdzogs rgyu med pa zhig yin gyi ma red/ kho tshor na she rtags can de ston dang / nga song nas 'khor dbugs ga ler shor bzhin pa'i Do je [25]rtags can po der dbugs shig rgyag dgos/ nga 'grig pa'i skabs su ngas khyod la brda zhig rgyag

Watch the woman's face. If the woman likes it we can screw the old man. Start 'em on that Cad'. Then you can work 'em down to that '26 Buick. 'F you start on the Buick, they'll go for a Ford. Roll up your sleeves an' get to work. This ain't gonna last forever. Show 'em that Nash while I get the slow leak pumped up on that '25 Dodge. I'll give you a Hymie when I'm ready.
[8] le'u 'di'i nang gi rlangs 'khor gyi ming dang tshong rtags bod dbyin shan sbyar/ kha Di lag [Cadillac •] b+hi'u khi/ [Buick •] na she/ [Nash •] Do je/ [Dodge •] ha'e me/ [Hymie]

khyod kyis 'dod pa ni 'grul bzhud cig red/ ma red dam/ ya/ khyod la skyag rdzun bshad don med/ red/ 'bol khri'i khebs g.yogs la i khung yod pa bden pa red/ 'on kyang 'bol gdan gyis 'khor lo bskor bar mi 'gyur/
What you want is transportation, ain't it? No baloney for you. Sure the upholstery is shot. Seat cushions ain't turning no wheels over.

rlangs 'khor chung ba mang po bstar la bsgrigs 'dug cing / tshang ma'i sna gdong mdun la gtad yod/ sna gdong btsa' yis zos shing 'khor lo'i dbugs kyang shor/ rlangs 'khor chung ba tshang ma mnyam gcig tu btsangs nas bzhag yod/
Cars lined up, noses forward, rusty noses, flat tires. Parked close together.
rlangs 'khor nang la bsdad nas bltas na 'dod dam/ yin dang yin/ dka' ngal mi 'dug ngas rlangs 'khor de gral phreng las phyir bton yong /
Like to get in to see that one? Sure, no trouble. I'll pull her out of the line.

kho tshor 'gan sems slebs su chug dang / kho tshor khyod kyi dus tshod spyod du chug dang / 'on kyang / kho tshos khyod kyi dus tshod spyod bzhin pa brjed du ma 'jug mi mang che ba ya rabs yin pas kho tshos khyod dka' las la gtod 'dod med/ kho tshos khyod dka' las la gtod du chug dang / de nas tshong de kho tsho'i mgo la skon zhog
Get 'em under obligation. Make 'em take up your time. Don't let 'em forget they're takin' your time. People are nice, mostly. They hate to put you out. Make 'em put you out, an' then sock it to 'em.

rlangs 'khor chung ba mang po bstar la bsgrigs 'dug cing / thon dpe [T]can po de ni mtho zhing 'bur la/ 'khor lor gtser sgra ldan zhing 'khor shubs zad nas yod/ b+hi'u khi rtags can/ na she rtags can/ Di so Tho si rtags can/[9]
Cars lined up, Model T's, high and snotty, creaking wheel, worn bands. Buicks, Nashes, De Sotos.

[9] le'u 'di'i nang gi rlangs 'khor gyi ming dang tshong rtags bod dbyin shan sbyar/ Di so Tho si/ [De Sotos •] phi le mod/ [Plymouth •] rog ne si/ [Rocknes •] si Thar si/ [Stars •] ab pher son/ [Apperson •] ar khi/ [Ark •] chal mer/ [Chalmer •] chan Di ler/ [Chandler •] sheb ro le/ [Chevrolet, Chevvy]

ya ya/ sku zhabs/ Do je [22]rtags can po/ 'di ni Do je tshang gis bzos pa'i rlangs 'khor tshang ma las yag shos de yin la rnying zhig tu 'gro rgyu med/ gnon btsir shugs chung ba can po yin/ gnon btsir shugs che ba can po de rigs thog mar rgyugs na cung mgyogs mod/ 'on kyang / gnon btsir ma lag gi rgyu cha'i lcags sra mo ma yin pa'i rkyen gyis gnon shugs yun ring la theg gi med/ phi le mod rtags can/ rog ne si rtags can/ si Thar si rtags can/

Yes, sir, '22 Dodge. Best goddamn car Dodge ever made. Never wear out. Low compression. High compression got lots a sap for a while, but the metal ain't made that'll hold it for long. Plymouths, Rocknes, Stars.

ston pa ye shu/ ab pher son de gang zhig nas slebs pa red/ ar khi rtags can de/ da dung chal mer rtags can dang chan De ler rtags can 'di gnyis/ rlangs 'khor 'di gnyis bzo mtshams bzhag nas lo ngo mang po phyin pa red/ las stangs 'di la 'khor tshong rgyag pa zer ba ma red/ gad snyigs spung ba zer ba red/ snying rlung langs byed/ nga la spyad zin pa'i 'khor rnying dgos kyi yod/ nga la sgor mo nyer lnga nas sum cu'i yan can zhig mi dgos/ de nas de tsho sgor mo lnga bcu nga lnga nas bdun cu don lnga bar byas te btsong na chog gi red/ de khe spogs yag po red/ ston pa ye shu/ rlangs 'khor gsar pa zhig gi steng nas rin gong ga tshod gcog thub kyi red dam/ 'khor rnying nyos/ tshur ga tshod nyo thub na ngas phar de tshod btsong thub/ sgor mo nyis brgya lnga bcu yan can zhig mi dgos/ we/ jim/ lam 'gram gyi rgad po ltas ngan de tshur e khug ltos dang / sa 'og gi i khung du 'dzul bsdad na kho'i cha rgyus lon gyi ma red/ kho la ab pher son de 'tshong thabs byos/ ya/ ab pher son de gang na yod/ btsongs zin pa yin nam/ da nga tshos 'khor rnying re tshur bsdu rgyu ma byung na phar btsong rgyu mi 'dug a/

Jesus, where'd that Apperson come from, the Ark? And a Chalmers and a Chandler- ain't made 'em for years. We ain't sellin' cars-rolling junk. Goddamn it, I got to get jalopies. I don't want nothing for more'n twenty-five, thirty bucks. Sell 'em for fifty, seventy-five. That's a good profit. Christ, what cut do you make on a new car? Get jalopies. I can sell 'em fast as I get 'em. Nothing over two hundred fifty. Jim, corral that old bastard on the sidewalk. Don't know his ass from a hole in the ground. Try him on that Apperson. Say, where is that Apperson? Sold? If we don't get some jalopies we got nothing to sell.
lam 'gram gyi them pa yar mar tshang ma dmar khra dang sngo khra can gyi dar cha sna tshogs kyis gang yod/ spyad zin pa'i rlangs 'khor/ spyad zin pa'i rlangs 'khor spus dag yin/
Flags, red and white, white and blue- all along the curb. Used Cars. Good Used Cars.

de ring gi rin phab dngos po de mdun gyi stegs bu'i steng du bsgrigs yod/ nam yang mi 'tshong / 'on kyang / des mi rnams nang du yong du 'jug par phan/ gal srid nga tshos rin phab rin gong ltar du dngos su btsongs pa yin na/ nga tshor de'i steng du sgor zur gcig gi khe spogs kyang yod dka' mo red/ kho tshor de btsongs tshar ba yin lob shog a/ ya/ phar phyogs la rtsis sprod ma byas gong de'i nang gi glog rdzas blangs nas shul du glog rdzas skyon can de bsgar shog ye shu/ kho tshos sgor mo drug gis ci zhig nyo 'dod pa yin nam/ phu thung yar la brdzes nas las ka'i nang du mchongs shig 'dis mang po 'dang gi ma red/ gal srid nga la 'khor rnying 'dang nges shig yod na/ ngas zla ba drug gi nang du las 'khyur ngal gso byed thub/

Today's bargain- up on the platform. Never sell it. Makes folks come in, though. If we sold that bargain at that price we'd hardly make a dime. Tell 'em it's jus' sold. Take out that yard battery before you make delivery. Put in that dumb cell. Christ, what they want for six bits? Roll up your sleeves- pitch in. This ain't gonna last. If I had enough jalopies I'd retire in six months.

nyon dang / jim/ sheb ro le de'i mjug ma nas sgra zhig grag gi 'dug dam be gcag pa'i sgra 'dra zhig grag gi 'dug nang du sog phye cung tsam blugs shog bang sgyur gyi nang du'ang gcig blugs shog gdon rdzas de sgor mo so lnga byas te ma btsongs na 'grig gi med/ ltas ngan des 'di'i thad nas nga la mgo skor btang 'dug ngas kho la bcu sprod rgyu byas kyang khos nga la bco lnga sprod du bcug song / de nas khyi phrug des 'gro khar lag cha tshang ma blangs nas 'khyer zin/ dkon mchog thugs rje can po/ nga la 'khor rnying lnga brgya yod na ang / 'dis ci yang 'dang gi ma red/ 'khor lo kho'i blo la 'bab kyi mi 'dug gam/ kho tshor 'di da dung le dbar stong phrag lnga bcu lhag rgyug thub kyi red lob shog de nas sgor mo gcig dang phyed ka mar phab nas tshongs/

Listen, Jim, I heard that Chevvy's rear end. Sounds like bustin' bottles. Squirt in a couple quarts of sawdust. Put some in the gears, too. We got to move that lemon for thirty-five dollars. Bastard cheated me on that one. I offer ten an' he jerks me to fifteen, an' then the son-of-a-bitch took the tools out. God Almighty! I wisht I had five hundred jalopies. This ain't gonna last. He don't like the tires? Tell 'im they got ten thousand in 'em, knock off a buck an' a half.

btsa' yis zos pa'i chag ro'i phung po rnams ra ba'i ngos su khen nas spungs yod la/ rgyab kyi ra ba'i nang du chag grum gyi phung po bstar ba nas bstar bar bsgrigs yod/ 'dam 'gog dang da dung snum nag gis zos pa'i lhu lhag sna tshogs/ dbugs mdong gzhi gdan bcas sa thog tu g.yugs yod la/ dbugs mdong gi gseng nas rtsa ldum re skye yong gi yod/ kha 'gog yu ba dang snyigs 'don dud khung rnams sbrul nag dang 'dra bar spungs nas yod cing / de dag tshang ma snum nag dang rlangs snum gyis tshos yod/

Piles of rusty ruins against the fence, rows of wrecks in back, fenders, grease-black wrecks, blocks lying on the ground and a pig weed growing up through the cylinders. Brake rods, exhausts, piled like snakes. Grease, gasoline.

song nas me cha gas med pa zhig e rnyed ltos dang / gal srid nga la rin gong brgya man gyi 'drud 'khor lnga bcu yod rgyu na ngas khe spogs chen po lon rgyu red/ khos da dung klan ka ci zhig 'tshol bzhin pa yin nam/ nga tshos 'di dag btsong gi yod pa red ma gtogs 'di dag kho tsho'i khyim la ded nas 'gro yi med/ de yag po 'dug kho tsho khyim la phyir 'gror ma 'jug zla deb khang gi mi der lag e zhog ltos/ khyod kyis kho nyo mkhan zhig ma red 'dod dam/ ya/ des na kho sgor phud shog nga tshor don dag 'di 'dra mang bas sems thag mi chod mkhan zhig la kha ya byas nas 'dug khom med/ g+hi ram [1] rtags can de'i 'khor lo mdun ma longs shog bzo bcos brgyab yod pa'i ngos de mar gtad shog de min tshang ma rtse gra red/ rkang gdan dang yod tshad 'dzoms 'dug

See if you can find a spark plug that ain't cracked. Christ, if I had fifty trailers at under a hundred I'd clean up. What the hell is he kickin' about? We sell 'em, but we don't push 'em home for him. That's good. Don't push 'em home. Get that one in the Monthly, I bet. You don't think he's a prospect? Well, kick 'im out. We got too much to do to bother with a guy that can't make up his mind. Take the right front tire off the Graham. Turn that mended side down. The rest looks swell. Got tread an' everything.
los yin/ 'khor rgan 'di da dung le dbar stong phrag lnga bcu lhag la rgyug thub par sems khur mi dgos/ snum rdzogs med cig shong gi red/ ya bde mo/ bsam don lhun 'grub/
Sure! There's fifty thousan' in that ol' heap yet. Keep plenty oil in. So long. Good luck.

rlangs 'khor chung ba zhig nyo 'dod dam/ sems na 'char gzhi ga 'dra zhig yod/ 'di dag khrod na dga' sa re 'dug gam/ cung shugs chen zhig la bltas na ga 'dra 'dug shog dang / khyod kyi chung mas la so le si la lta bzhin pa'i sgang red/ khyod kyis la so le si zhig nyo na 'dod rgyu ma red/ de la ral khung re yod la snum yang ha cang mang po bza' yi red/ lin khon [24]rtags can po zhig yod/ 'dir rlangs 'khor chung ba zhig yod/ da rung rdzogs med cig rgyug thub la dos skyel rlangs 'khor du'ang sgyur thub/

Lookin' for a car? What did you have in mind? See anything attracts you? I'm dry. How about a little snort a good stuff? Come on, while your wife's lookin' at that La Salle. You don't want no La Salle. Bearings shot. Uses too much oil. Got a Lincoln '24. There's a car. Run forever. Make her into a truck.
[1] le'u 'di'i nang gi rlangs 'khor gyi ming dang tshong rtags bod dbyin shan sbyar/ g+hi ram/ [Graham •] lin khon/ [Lincoln •] lA sal/ [La Salle •] ze h+pher/ [Zephyr •] phon Thi yag [Pontiac]

tsha gdug che ba'i nyi ma de btsa' yis zos pa'i lcags rigs dang thang du zags pa'i snum rigs kyi thog tu 'phros shing / mgo 'thoms pa'i mi rnams kyis rlangs 'khor re nyo ched du de dag gi khrod du rkyal bzhin 'dug
Hot sun on rusted metal. Oil on the ground. People are wandering in, bewildered, needing a car.

gdong pa phyis shig rlangs 'khor chung ba de'i steng du ma khen/ de btsog pa red/ rlangs 'khor zhig nyo na ji ltar nyo'am/ gcig la rin gong ga tshod yin rgyu red/ ya/ da byis pa tsho bdag byos/ 'di la sgor ga tshod yin rgyu red snyam/ nga tshos dris chog rin gong 'dri bar sgor mo dgos kyi ma red/ nga tshos dris chog ma red dam/ sgor mo don lnga'i yan nas skar lnga yang sprod mi thub/ de ma gtogs nga tsho kha li h+phor ne ya ru 'gro ba'i lam gron gyis 'dang gi ma red/

Wipe your feet. Don't lean on that car, it's dirty. How do you buy a car? What does it cost? Watch the children, now. I wonder how much for this one? We'll ask. It don't cost money to ask. We can ask, can't we? Can't pay a nickel over seventy-five, or there won't be enough to get to California.
dkon mchog mkhyen/ da nga la 'khor rnying brgya tham pa yod pas chog ang / 'gro rgyu yod med kyi 'khor rnying gang yang rung /
God, if I could only get a hundred jalopies. I don't care if they run or not.
ser kha shor ba'i 'gyig 'khor rnying pa rnams mdong mdong du brtsegs nas yod la/ sbu gu dmar po dang skya bo rnams rgyu ma bzhin du dpyangs nas yod/
Tires, used, bruised tires, stacked in tall cylinders; tubes, red, gray, hanging like sausages.

'khor lo 'tshem spyad e dgos/ drod sel chas gtsang ma bzo spyad e dgos/ me sgo che ru gtong spyad e dgos/ ril bu 'di snum sgam nang du g.yugs dang le dbar bcu phrag re lhag ma rgyug thub/ 'di steng du skus dang / sgor zur lngas khyod kyi rlangs 'khor gyi phyi gzugs gsar pa bzo thub/ 'byid spyad kyi dbang gis e red/ rlung 'khor gyi rgyu thag gis e red/ gzer gdan gyis e red/ o/ dbugs sgo'i dbang gis yin rgyu red/ dbugs sgo gsar pa zhig nyos dang / sgor skar lngas ci zhig gi go chod dam/

Tire patch? Radiator cleaner? Spark intensifier? Drop this little pill in your gas tank and get ten extra miles to the gallon. Just paint it on- you got a new surface for fifty cents. Wipers, fan belts, gaskets? Maybe it's the valve. Get a new valve stem. What can you lose for a nickel?

ya da 'grig song / jo'e/ khyod kyis kho tsho snyi mor btang rjes 'dir thongs shog ngas tshong de mjug sdom byed/ tshong 'grig na 'grig pa red/ ma 'grig na ngas kho tsho gsod rgyu yin/ nga la sprang 'khyam pa de 'dra mi dgos/ nga la dgos pa ni nyo tshong yin/
All right, Joe. You soften 'em up an' shoot 'em in here. I'll close 'em, I'll deal 'em or I'll kill 'em. Don't send in no bums. I want deals.
'o ya/ sku zhabs/ nang du phebs/ 'di khyod la rin gong khe po byas te btsong / red ya/ sku zhabs/ rin gong phab nas sgor mo brgyad cu byed ya/
Yes, sir, step in. You got a buy there. Yes, sir! At eighty bucks you got a buy.
ngas sgor mo lnga bcu'i yan ster mi thub/ phyi logs kyi mi des sgor mo lnga bcu red zer/
I can't go no higher than fifty. The fella outside says fifty.

lnga bcu/ lnga bcu e/ kho smyos song ba yin rgyu red/ rlangs 'khor chung ba de la sgor mo bdun cu don brgyad dang zur lnga sprad pa red/ jo'e/ glen rgan khyod kyis nga tsho'i tshong rdib tu 'jug bsam gyi yod pa min nam/ mi 'di las gnas nas dbyung dgos kyi 'dug sgor mo drug cu byas te nyos na 'tshams po red/ ya sku zhabs/ nga la nyin gang po 'di ltar phud khom med/ nga tshong pa zhig yin pa bden rung / nga 'di ltar gcig gi ngos su 'thams nas bsdad na 'grig gi ma red/ tshong sgyur byed rgyu 'dra e yod/

Fifty. Fifty? He's nuts. Paid seventy-eight fifty for that little number. Joe, you crazy fool, you tryin' to bust us? Have to can that guy. I might take sixty. Now look here, mister, I ain't got all day. I'm a business man but I ain't out to stick nobody. Got anything to trade?
nga la drel gnyis yod la de gnyis tshong sgyur byed chog
Got a pair of mules I'll trade.

drel e/ wa ye/ jo'e/ go song ngam/ mi 'dis drel dang tshong sgyur byed na 'dod zer/ deng sang ni 'phrul chas kyi dus rabs yin pa khyod la su gcig gis kyang bshad ma song ngam/ deng sang drel ni bsad nas spyin khu bzo ba las gzhan phan pa ci yang med/
Mules! Hey, Joe, hear this? This guys wants to trade mules. Didn't nobody tell you this is the machine age? They don't use mules for nothing but glue no more.
drel ha cang stobs chen gnyis yin/ gcig lo lnga yin la gzhan pa de lo bdun yin/ song nas gcig bltas na ga 'dra 'dug gam/
Fine big mules- five and seven years old. Maybe we better look around.

song nas bltas na e/ nga tsho brel zing che dus khyod nga tsho'i nang du yong nas nga tsho'i dus tshod tshang ma brlags shing / da lta yang phyi logs su 'gro zer/ a rogs jo'e/ khyod kyis mi snying chung zhig la skad cha bshad kyin yod pa ma tshor ram/
Look around! You come in when we're busy, an' take up our time an' then walk out! Joe, did you know you was talkin' to pikers?
nga snying chung min/ ngas rlangs 'khor chung ba zhig nyo dgos/ nga tsho kha li h+phor ne ya la 'gro dgos shing / nga tshos rlangs 'khor zhig nyo dgos/
I ain't a piker. I got to get a car. We're goin' to California. I got to get a car.

red ya/ nga glen pa zhig yin/ jo'e yis nga glen pa zhig red zer/ khos zer na gal srid ngas sbyin pa gtong mtshams ma bzhag na nyin zhig la ltogs shi thebs nges red zer/ ya/ da 'di ltar byed/ ngas sgo khyi gso byed du khyod kyi drel rgan re rer sgor lnga re byin te nyo/
Well, I'm a sucker. Joe says I'm a sucker. Says if I don't quit givin' my shirt away I'll starve to death. Tell you what I'll do- I can get five bucks apiece for them mules for dog feed.
ngas 'di gnyis khyi la sbyin rgyu byas na mi 'dod/
I wouldn't want them to go for dog feed.

ya/ gcig byas na ngas 'di re la sgor mo bdun nas bcu bar ster thub srid/ ya/ des na 'di byed/ ngas khyod kyi drel rgan gnyis kar sgor mo nyi shu byas te nyo rgyu byed/ shing rta yang 'di gnyis dang mnyam du yin rgyu red/ e red/ khyod kyis sngon la sgor mo lnga bcu zhog dang / de'i shul lhag rnams zla rer sgor mo bcu re bskur yong rgyu byas te gan rgya bzhag kyang chog

Well, maybe I can get ten or seven maybe. Tell you what we'll do. We'll take your mules for twenty. Wagon goes with 'em, don't it? An' you put up fifty, an' you can sign a contract to send the rest at ten dollars a month.
'on kyang / khyod kyis sgor mo brgyad cu red lab ma song ngam/
But you said eighty.

khyod kyis dus bcad bun 'jal skyed ka dang nyen srung zer ba go ma myong ngam/ 'di dag gis rin gong je mthor cung gtong gi yod pa red/ khyod kyis zla ba bzhi lnga'i nang du rin pa lhag ma tshang ma sprad tshar ba bya dgos/ 'dir khyod kyi ming rtags khod dang / gzhan pa tshang ma nga tshos bsgrub yong /
Didn't you never hear about carrying charges and insurance? That just boosts her a little. You'll get her all paid up in four-five months. Sign your name right here. We'll take care of ever'thing.
red ya/ de ngas mi [...] /

THE SKY GRAYED among the stars, and the pale, late quarter-moon was insubstantial and thin. Tom Joad and the preacher walked quickly along a road that was only wheel tracks and beaten caterpillar tracks through a cotton field. Only the unbalanced sky showed the approach of dawn, no horizon to the west, and a line to the east. The two men walked in silence and smelled the dust their feet kicked into the air.

“No, somepin jus' bust in her. Ap-appendick or somepin. Well, Uncle John, he's always been a easy-goin' fella, an' he takes it hard. Takes it for a sin. Made a damn nuisance of hisself. Ever' time one of us kids got worms or a gutache Uncle John brings a doctor out. Pa finally tol' him he got to stop. Kids all the time gettin' a gutache. He figures it's his fault his woman died. Funny fella. He's all the time makin' it up to somebody- givin' kids stuff, droppin' a sack a meal on somebody's porch. Give away about ever'thing he got, an' still he ain't very happy. Gets walkin' around alone at night sometimes. He's a good farmer, though. Keeps his lan' nice.”
chos dpon gyis [“]rgad po snying rje/ mi rkyang rgad po snying rje/ kho'i chung ma tshe las 'das rjes kho nam rgyun chos khang du song e myong ngam/[”] zhes bshad/
“Poor fella,” said the preacher, “Poor lonely fella. Did he go to church much when his woman died?”

[“]ma song / kho ma song / kho yul mi tsho'i nye sar rtsa ba nas 'gro 'dod med cing / rgyun du kher rkyang du sdod kyi yod/ kho la mi dga' mkhan gyi phru gu zhig mthong myong med/ kho mtshams mtshams su dgong mor nga tsho'i khang pa'i nang du yong gi yod/ kho yong skabs khos nga tsho phru gu re re'i nyal khri'i 'gram nas 'gyig byi ril chag pa re 'jog gi yod cing / de'i rkyen gyis nga tshos kho dgong mor nga tsho'i sar yong gi yod pa shes kyi yod/ nga tshos kho ston pa ye shu mthu stobs can po red bsam gyi yod/[”]

“No, he didn'. Never wanted to get close to folks. Wanted to be off alone. I never seen a kid that wasn't crazy about him. He'd come to our house in the night sometimes, an' we knowed he'd come 'cause jus' as sure as he come there'd be a pack a gum in the bed right beside ever' one of us. We thought he was Jesus Christ Awmighty.”

chos dpon gyis mgo bo dud nas mdun du 'gro bzhin tshig lan ma btab/ zhogs pa'i skya mda'i 'od kyis kho'i dpral ba'i steng nas 'od snang lta bu zhig mngon du bcug yod la/ kho'i lag pa gnyis ka 'gram nas g.yug skabs lag mgo gnyis po 'od kyi nang nas yib res gab res byed/
The preacher walked along, head down. He didn't answer. And the light of the coming morning made his forehead seem to shine, and his hands, swinging beside him, flicked into the light and out again.

Thom yang rang nyid kyi mi sger gyi gsang ba zhig phyi la bshad nas kha skyengs song ba dang 'dra bar/ kha khu sim po red/ khos gom kha je mgyogs su btang bas chos dpon gyis kyang kho'i gom rjes chod thabs byas/ da lta kho tshos mdun phyogs kyi skya 'od khrod nas rgyang mig cung chod/ sbrul zhig sring bal zhing nang nas lam nang du dkris nur kyis slebs shing / Thom gyis de mthong rjes glo bur du 'gro mtshams bzhag ste mig gis sbrul la bltas nas [“]bra gzan sbrul red/ kho 'gro ru chug[”] ces bshad/

Tom was silent too, as though he had said too intimate a thing and was ashamed. He quickened his pace and the preacher kept step. They could see a little into gray distance ahead now. A snake wriggled slowly from the cotton rows into the road. Tom stopped short of it and peered. “Gopher snake,” he said. “Let him go.”

kho tshos sbrul de bskor nas song ste mu mthud du lam bu ded nas song / nam mkha' ru tshon mdog chung chung zhig mngon byung la/ de ma thag tu sa gzhi'i steng du kher rkyang gi skya rengs 'od snang zhig lhung / sring bal sdong po'i steng du ljang mdangs mngon byung zhing / sa gzhi ni smug cing skya/ da lta mi 'di gnyis kyi ngo gdong gi skya 'od kyang mi snang bar gyur/ shar phyogs su 'od snang 'phros pa dang lhan du jo Di yi gdong mdangs nag por gyur pa'i snang ba ster/ jo Di yis skad mgo dma' mos [“]dus tshod 'di ha cang skyid/ nga rang lo na chung dus/ nam tshod 'di 'dra yin dus mal las langs nas nga rang gcig po 'cham 'cham du 'gro yi yod/ mdun phyogs kyi de ci zhig red dam/[”] zhes bshad/

They walked around the snake and went on their way. A little color came into the eastern sky, and almost immediately the lonely dawn light crept over the land. Green appeared on the cotton plants and the earth was gray-brown. The faces of the men lost their grayish shine. Joad's face seemed to darken with the growing light. “This is the good time,” Joad said softly. “When I was a kid I used to get up an' walk around by myself when it was like this. What's that ahead?”

de ni khyi pho lnga yis khyi mo zhig gi ngo so bstod ched du lam nang du 'dus pa'i khyi tshogs shig red/ rdzi khyi rgyud 'dres dang kho li rdzi khyi rgyud 'dres sogs rang dbang 'dres sdeb kyis rigs rgyud kyi sa mtshams rab rib tu btang ba'i khyi pho 'di dag gis khyi mo de la ngo so bstod par brel/ khyi pho tshos re re bzhin khyi mo la zhim mdog kha pos dri snom re byas rjes sug pa rengs po'i gom stabs la brten nas sring bal gyi sdong po'i rtsar brgyugs shing / de gar rgyab sug gcig yar la bkyags nas gcin pa re btang rjes yang bskyar dri snom byed du phyir brgyugs/ jo Di dang chos dpon gnyis kyis 'gro mtshams bzhag nas ltad mo bltas shing / jo Di yis glo bur du [“]dkon mchog dkon mchog[”] ces hab cha brgyab/ da lta khyi pho tshang ma phan tshun ngo thug song la/ tshang mas sna snyer zhing zug skad 'don bzhin brtan por langs/ tshang mas gcig gis gcig la 'dzing mgo slong re la sgug nas bsdad/ skabs der khyi pho zhig khyi mo'i steng du 'dzegs thub song / khyi pho des rgyal kha blangs pa'i rkyen gyis khyi pho gzhan pa tsho phyi nur byas nas/ do snang dang bcas ltad mo bltas/ kho tsho'i lce ring phyi la bsnar zhing lce rtse nas mchil ma 'dzar/ mi gnyis ka mu mthud du mdun du bskyod/

A committee of dogs had met in the road, in honor of a bitch. Five males, shepherd mongrels, collie mongrels, dogs whose breeds had been blurred by a freedom of social life, were engaged in complimenting the bitch. For each dog sniffed daintily and then stalked to a cotton plant on stiff legs, raised a hind foot ceremoniously and wetted, then went back to smell. Joad and the preacher stopped to watch, and suddenly Joad laughed joyously. “By God!” he said. “By God!” Now all dogs met and hackles rose, and they all growled and stood stiffly, each waiting for the others to start a fight. One dog mounted and, now that it was accomplished, the others gave way and watched with interest, and their tongues were out, and their tongues dripped. The two men walked on.

jo Di yis [“]dkon mchog ngas bltas na steng du 'dzegs 'dug mkhan de nged tshang gi khyi rgan h+phi la she yin pa 'dra/ ngas kho snga sa nas shi song ba yin rgyu red bsam yod/ h+phi la she/ 'dir shog[”] ces bshad cing /
“By God!” Joad said. “I think that up-dog is our Flash. I thought he'd be dead. Come, Flash!”

de nas khos yang bskyar hab cha brgyab [“]snying rje/ khag ci la yod/ 'di 'dra'i skabs su zhig gis nga la bos na ngas kyang go rgyu ma red/ 'dis nga la dngos sgrung zhig dran du bcug song / de ni wi le h+phe le lo chung yin skabs kyi sgrung zhig red/ wi le ni ngo tsha can zhig yin/ ha cang ngo tsha can zhig yin/ nyin zhig la khos kho tshang gi ba mo de g+hi reb tshang gi glang gog gi sar khrid yong / skabs der mi tshang ma phyi la bud song bas/ khyim du el se g+hi reb ma gtogs med/ el se ni ngo tsha med pa zhig yin/ wi le ngo tsha nas gdong mdog dmar por gyur te/ tha na skad cha tsam yang shod ma nus par langs nas bsdad pas/ el se yis/ [‘]khyod yong don ci yin ngas shes kyi yod/ nged tshang gi glang gog rgyab phyogs kyi 'bru khang nang du yod/[’] ces bshad/

He laughed again. “What the hell, if somebody called me, I wouldn't hear him neither. 'Minds me of a story they tell about Willy Feeley when he was a young fella. Willy was bashful, awful bashful. Well, one day he takes a heifer over to Graves' bull. Ever'body was out but Elsie Graves, and Elsie wasn't bashful at all. Willy, he stood there turnin' red an' he couldn't even talk. Elsie says, 'I know what you come for; the bull's out in back a the barn.'

de nas kho gnyis kyis ba mo de glang gog yod sar khrid/ el se dang wi le gnyis kas phar phyogs kyi ra ba'i steng nas ltad mo bltas nas bsdad cing / cang ma 'gor bar wi le la tshor ba slebs/ skabs der el se yis ha ma go ba'i tshul gyis/ [‘]wi le/ khyod la ci zhig byung song /[’] zhes dris par/ wi le rtsa langs drags pa'i rkyen gyis gzugs po drang mor 'greng mi bde ba gyur nas/ [‘]dkon mchog de las mkhan nga rang yin na ang /[’] zhes ngag nas shor bar/ el se yis/ [‘]wi le/ 'o na khyod kyis ci'i phyir mi las sam/ gang ltar de ni khyod tshang gi ba mo red/[’] ces bshad/[”]

Well, they took the heifer out there an' Willy an' Elsie sat on the fence to watch. Purty soon Willy got feelin' purty fly. Elsie looks over an' says, like she don't know, 'What's a matter, Willy?' Willy's so randy, he can't hardly set still. 'By God,' he says, 'by God, I wisht I was a-doin' that!' Elsie says, 'Why not, Willy? It's your heifer.'”

chos dpon lhod 'jam gyis gad mo bgad [“]ltos dang / chos dpon zhig ma byas na 'di 'dra'i dge mtshan 'dug nga yod sa nas su gcig gis kyang sgrung de 'dra bshad ma myong la/ gal srid gcig gis bshad pa'i dbang du btang rung / nga dgod nus rgyu ma red/ de bzhin dmod mo yang gtong mi thub/ deng sang ngas dmod mo ga 'dra gtong 'dod na gtong chog la/ ga dus gtong na 'dod na gtong chog dmod mo gtong 'dod dus gtong chog rgyu 'di'ang mi zhig la mtshon na ha cang gal chen red/[”]

The preacher laughed softly. “You know,” he said, “it's a nice thing not bein' a preacher no more. Nobody use' ta tell stories when I was there, or if they did I couldn' laugh. An' I couldn' cuss. Now I cuss all I want, any time I want, an' it does a fella good to cuss if he wants to.”

shar phyogs kyi gnam sa 'dres mtshams nas 'od dmar zhig je gsal nas je gsal du 'gro bzhin yod la/ sa steng nas bye'u tshogs kyis cir cir gyi skad sgra lhang lhang du sgrog jo Di yis [“]ltos dang / mdun phyogs kyi de a khu jon tshang gi chu mdzod red/ rlung 'thag 'khor lo mi mthong mod/ khong gi chu mdzod de 'di red/[”] ces bshad nas gom kha je mgyogs su btang / [“]nga'i khyim mi tshang ma der e yod dam/[”] chu mdzod de sa mgo mtho sa zhig tu yod/ jo Di brel 'tshab kyis brgyugs pas khos rang nyid kyi pus mo'i mtshams la slebs tsam gyi thal rdul bslangs/ [“]nga'i a mas [...] /[”] kho tshos da lta chu mdzod kyi rkang pa mthong thub la/ tshon rtsi med pa'i sgam chung lta bu'i khang pa dang / klad khebs dma' zhing 'tshang kha brgyab pa'i 'bru khang bcas kyang mthong thub/ khang steng gi krin gyi dud khung las dud pa nam mkhar 'then 'dug la/ sgo ra'i nang du rlung 'thag 'khor lo'i rlung gshog dang 'phrul 'khor a ma/ nyal khri/ rkub stegs/ sgrog tse sogs khyim chas kyi phung po zhig spungs 'dug jo Di yis [“]dkon mchog ye shu/ kho tsho 'gro grabs byed kyi 'dug[”] ces bshad/

A redness grew up out of the eastern horizon, and on the ground birds began to chirp, sharply. “Look!” said Joad. “Right ahead. That's Uncle John's tank. Can't see the win'mill, but there's his tank. See it against the sky?” He speeded his walk. “I wonder if all the folks are there.” The hulk of the tank stood above a rise. Joad, hurrying, raised a cloud of dust about his knees. “I wonder if Ma…” They saw the tank legs now, and the house, a square little box, unpainted and bare, and the barn, low-roofed and huddled. Smoke was rising from the tin chimney of the house. In the yard was a litter, piled furniture, the blades and motor of the windmill, bedsteads, chairs, tables. “Holy Christ, they're fixin' to go!” Joad said.

sgo ra'i nang du dos skyel rlangs 'khor zhig bzhag 'dug la/ dos 'khor de ni 'gram gnyis mtho ba'i dos 'khor khyad mtshar can zhig red/ de'i mdun ni rlangs 'khor gyi mdun red la/ klad pa'i dkyil nas bkog ste de'i shul du dos 'khor gyi gzhug sgam sbyar 'dug kho gnyis khang pa'i nye sar slebs pa dang chabs cig tu sgo ra'i nang nas khyab 'ong ba'i tong sgra zhig thos/ zhogs pa'i nyi gzhon gyi mig la gzan pa'i 'od gor de gnam sa 'dres mtshams nas yar 'phags nas/ 'od kyi phung po de dos 'khor gyi steng du 'phros/ de dus kho gnyis kyis dos 'khor steng gi skyes pa de dang / kho'i lag gi yar 'gyog mar rdeg byed bzhin pa'i tho ba'i ldog 'od bcas mthong thub/ de nas nyi 'od de khang pa'i sge'u khung ngos su 'phros byung la/ des char rlung gis brdar ba'i pang leb rnams la bkrag mdangs dkrigs/ sa steng gi bya de dmar po de gnyis ldog 'phros kyi 'od snang las dmar lam lam du snang /

A truck stood in the yard, a truck with high sides, but a strange truck, for while the front of it was a sedan, the top had been cut off in the middle and the truck bed fitted on. And as they drew near, the men could hear pounding from the yard, and as the rim of the blinding sun came up over the horizon, it fell on the truck, and they saw a man and the flash of his hammer as it rose and fell. And the sun flashed on the windows of the house. The weathered boards were bright. Two red chickens on the ground flamed with reflected light.

Thom gyis [“]'ur ma rgyag kho tsho'i steng du 'di ltar 'jab nas 'gro/[”] zhes zer bzhin gom stabs je mgyogs su btang nas brgyugs pas/ da cha kho'i sked mtshams la slebs pa'i thal rdul 'phyur/ de nas kho sring bal zhing tshigs kha ru song / da lta kho tsho sgo ra dngos kyi nang du 'byor 'dug sgo ra'i sa mthil 'jags nas 'od krig krig byed la/ sa steng du thal mdog babs pa'i ldum bu 'ga' re 'khyil nas 'dug skabs der jo Di mu mthud du 'gro ma phod pa ltar 'gro mtshams bzhag cing / chos dpon gyis kho la lta bzhin gom kha je dal du btang nas kho'i gom 'gros dang bstun/ Thom gyis 'cham 'cham byed pa ltar mdun du song zhing / de nas ngo gnong ba'i rnam pas dos 'khor phyogs su gseg 'gros kyis song / dos skyel rlangs 'khor de ni hud son dbugs mdong drug ldan can gyi rlangs rlangs 'khor chung ba zhig red la/ de'i klad khebs de sog le zhig gis dum bu gnyis su gtubs yod/ Thom jo Di rgan po dos 'khor gyi gzhug sgam nang du langs nas/ dos 'khor kyi 'gram skyor pang leb gong ma de 'dzer bzhin pa'i sgang red/ kho'i sma ras gang ba'i gdong pa sngo skya de lag gi las ka'i thog tu mar dud nas 'dug cing / ang ki drug can gyi 'dzer ma chag pa gcig kho'i mchu bar du btsir nas 'dug khos 'dzer ma zhig pang leb steng du bzung nas tho bas de'i steng du shugs kyis bsnun/ khang pa'i nang nas thab ka'i kha leb kyi khrob sgra dang byis pa'i ngud mo'i 'ur sgra grag yong / jo Di dos 'khor gyi 'gram du gseg 'gros kyis song nas dos 'khor la khen nas bsdad pa na/ kho'i pha rgan gyis mgo bo yar la bkyags nas gcig bltas byung / 'on kyang / khos su yin gsal po ma mthong / pha rgan gyis yang bskyar 'dzer ma zhig pang leb thog tu bzhag nas gting du brdabs/ phug ron khyu gcig chu mdzod khang gi thog g.yab las 'phur yong nas lding skor zhig brgyab rjes/ yang bskyar rang sar phyir babs shing / de nas 'gying nyams dang bcas thog g.yab kyi sne ru song nas mar ltad mor bltas te bsdad/ kho tsho'i nang du phug ron dkar po dang sngon po/ skya bo bcas yod la/ de tsho'i gshog pa la 'ja' tshon gyi ri mo babs/

“Don't yell,” said Tom. “Let's creep up on 'em, like,” and he walked so fast that the dust rose high as his waist. And then he came to the edge of the cotton field. Now they were in the yard proper, earth beaten hard, shiny hard, and a few dusty crawling weeds on the ground. And Joad slowed as though he feared to go on. The preacher, watching him, slowed to match his step. Tom sauntered forward, sidled embarrassedly toward the truck. It was a Hudson Super-Six sedan, and the top had been ripped in two with a cold chisel. Old Tom Joad stood in the truck bed and he was nailing on the top rails of the truck sides. His grizzled, bearded face was low over his work, and a bunch of six-penny nails stuck out of his mouth. He set a nail and his hammer thundered it in. From the house came the clash of a lid on the stove and the wail of a child. Joad sidled up to the truck bed and leaned against it. And his father looked at him and did not see him. His father set another nail and drove it in. A flock of pigeons started from the deck of the tank house and flew around and settled again and strutted to the edge to look over; white pigeons and blue pigeons and grays, with iridescent wings.

jo Di yis dos 'khor 'gram ngos kyi skyor mda' 'og ma'i steng du lag mdzub rnams bskon nas/ lo na rgas bzhin pa'i skyes pa skya mdangs can der yar bltas/ khos rang nyid kyi kha sha mthug po de lce yis sbangs rjes skad ngag 'jam pos [“]a pha/[”] zhes bos/
Joad hooked his fingers over the lowest bar of the truck side. He looked up at the aging, graying man on the truck. He wet his thick lips with his tongue, and he said softly, “Pa.”

Thom rgan pos mchu sgros kyi 'dzer ma'i gseng nas [“]ci red/[”] ces mug mug gis bshad/ khos nag nog gis gos pa'i 'dab ldan zhwa mo nag po zhig gon 'dug la/ kho'i las gos nang stod sngon po'i steng du sgrog mtheb med pa'i khan sbyar zhig g.yogs 'dug rag gi chab mgo gru bzhi ma yod pa'i chab ma srab skyogs lta bu zhig gis kho'i rdzi dor de yar la mdud 'dug kho'i lham la gas kha brgyugs yod cing / lo zla'i nyi 'od dang char rlung gis zos pa'i lham mthil de sbos nas ko gru lta bu zhig tu gyur 'dug kho'i nang stod kyi phu thung gnyis ka stobs che ba'i sha gnad kyis mar 'then yod pas/ da lta dpung pa'i ngos su dam por 'byar 'dug kho'i lto ba dang dpyi mgo skam zhing rid la/ rkang pa gnyis ka thung zhing sbom la stobs dang ldan/ dkar shur babs pa'i sma ras bskor ba'i kho'i gdong pa ni stobs che ba'i ma ne'i steng du 'then nas 'dug la/ ma ne de yang de 'dra skya rgyu med pa'i sma ra bzhar 'phro can dang bcas phyi phyogs su 'bur zhing / des ma ne'i ljid shugs dang stobs shugs phyi ru mngon yod/ kho'i gdong spu bral ba'i mkhur mgo'i steng gi skyi lpags de rdza 'dam ltar smug cing / btsum ma phyes kyi mig mtha' ru gnyer mas bskor/ kho'i mig 'bras kyi mdog ni 'tshig ja nag khu'i mdog ltar smug po yin la/ smug nag gi mig zung gi nus pa nyams kyi yod pa'i rkyen gyis/ khos dngos po zhig la lta skabs mgo bo mdun la bsring yong / bar gseng nas 'dzer ma phyir bud pa'i kho'i kha sha ni srab cing dmar/

“What do you want?” old Tom mumbled around his mouthful of nails. He wore a black, dirty slouch hat and a blue work shirt over which was a buttonless vest; his jeans were held up by a wide harness-leather belt with a big square brass buckle, leather and metal polished from years of wearing; and his shoes were cracked and the soles swollen and boat-shaped from years of sun and wet and dust. The sleeves of his shirt were tight on his forearms, held down by the bulging powerful muscles. Stomach and hips were lean, and legs, short, heavy, and strong. His face, squared by a bristling pepper and salt beard, was all drawn down to the forceful chin, a chin thrust out and built out by the stubble beard which was not so grayed on the chin, and gave weight and force to its thrust. Over old Tom's unwhiskered cheek bones the skin was as brown as meerschaum, and wrinkled in rays around his eye-corners from squinting. His eyes were brown, black-coffee brown, and he thrust his head forward when he looked at a thing, for his bright dark eyes were failing. His lips, from which the big nails protruded, were thin and red.

khos tho ba gnam la 'phyar nas 'dzer ma skor zhig rdeb grabs byed bzhin pa'i skabs der/ dos 'khor gyi 'gram du langs nas yod pa'i Thom la gcig bltas shing / kho'i las kar bar chad btang ba'i rkyen gyis mig nang du khro nyams shig shar/ de nas kho'i ma ne mdun du bsrings shing mig gis Thom gyi gdong par bltas pa na/ kho'i mig gis mthong ba de ci zhig yin pa kho'i klad pas rim gyis rtogs byung / khos lag gi tho ba dal mos thang la phab cing / lag g.yon pas kha nang gi 'dzer ma rnams phyir blangs/ de nas khos rang nyid la kher bshad rgyag pa bzhin [“]a Thom/[”] zhes smras shing / yang bskyar rang nyid la gsal 'debs byed pa bzhin [“]a Thom khyim la bslebs 'dug[”] ces bshad/ de nas kho'i mig mdangs las sems khral gyi nyams shig mngon nas skad dma' mos [“]a Thom/ khyod btson nas bros yong ba min nam/ khyod sbas skung byed du yong ba min nam/[”] zhes dris rjes/ nan tan gyis dris lan la nyan/

He held his hammer suspended in the air, about to drive a set nail, and he looked over the truck side at Tom, looked resentful at being interrupted. And then his chin drove forward and his eyes looked at Tom's face, and then gradually his brain became aware of what he saw. The hammer dropped slowly to his side, and with his left hand he took the nails from his mouth. And he said wonderingly, as though he told himself the fact, “It's Tommy-” And then, still informing himself, “It's Tommy come home.” His mouth opened again and a look of fear came into his eyes. “Tommy,” he said softly, “you ain't busted out? You ain't got to hide?” He listened tensely.

“Naw,” said Tom. “I'm paroled. I'm free. I got my papers.” He gripped the lower bars of the truck side and looked up.

Old Tom laid his hammer gently on the floor and put his nails in his pocket. He swung his leg over the side and dropped lithely to the ground, but once beside his son he seemed embarrassed and strange. “Tommy,” he said, “we are goin' to California. But we was gonna write you a letter an' tell you.” And he said, incredulously. “But you're back. You can go with us. You can go!” The lid of a coffee pot slammed in the house. Old Tom looked over his shoulder. “Le's surprise 'em,” he said, and his eyes shone with excitement. “Your ma got a bad feelin' she ain't never gonna see you no more. She got that quiet look like when somebody died. Almost she don't want to go to California, fear she'll never see you no more.” A stove lid clashed in the house again. “Le's surprise 'em,” old Tom repeated. “Le's go in like you never been away. Le's jus' see what your ma says.” At last he touched Tom, but touched him on the shoulder, timidly, and instantly took his hand away. He looked at Jim Casy.

Two rangy shepherd dogs trotted up pleasantly, until they caught the scent of strangers, and then they backed cautiously away, watchful, their tails moving slowly and tentatively in the air, but their eyes and noses quick for animosity or danger. One of them, stretching his neck, edged forward, ready to run, and little by little he approached Tom's legs and sniffed loudly at them. Then he backed away and watched Pa for some kind of signal. The other pup was not so brave. He looked about for something that could honorably divert his attention, saw a red chicken go mincing by, and ran at it. There was the squawk of an outraged hen, a burst of red feathers, and the hen ran off, flapping stubby wings for speed. The pup looked proudly back at the men, and then flopped down in the dust and beat its tail contentedly on the ground.

“Come on,” said Pa, “come on in now. She got to see you. I got to see her face when she sees you. Come on. She'll yell breakfast in a minute. I heard her slap the salt pork in the pan a good time ago.” He led the way across the fine-dusted ground. There was no porch on this house, just a step and then the door; a chopping block beside the door, its surface matted and soft from years of chopping. The graining in the sheathing wood was high, for the dust had cut down the softer wood. The smell of burning willow was in the air, and as the three men neared the door, the smell of frying side-meat and the smell of high brown biscuits and the sharp smell of coffee rolling in the pot. Pa stepped up into the open doorway and stood there blocking it with his wide short body. He said, “Ma, there's a coupla fellas jus' come along the road, an' they wonder if we could spare a bite.”

Tom heard his mother's voice, the remembered cool, calm drawl, friendly and humble. “Let 'em come,” she said. “We got a'plenty. Tell 'em they got to wash their han's. The bread is done. I'm jus' takin' up the side-meat now.” And the sizzle of the angry grease came from the stove.

Pa stepped inside, clearing the door, and Tom looked in at his mother. She was lifting the curling slices of pork from the frying pan. The oven door was open, and a great pan of high brown biscuits stood waiting there. She looked out the door, but the sun was behind Tom, and she saw only a dark figure outlined by the bright yellow sunlight. She nodded pleasantly. “Come in,” she said. “Jus' lucky I made plenty bread this morning.”

Tom stood looking in. Ma was heavy, but not fat; thick with child-bearing and work. She wore a loose Mother Hubbard of gray cloth in which there had once been colored flowers, but the color was washed out now, so that the small flowered pattern was only a little lighter gray than the background. The dress came down to her ankles, and her strong, broad, bare feet moved quickly and deftly over the floor. Her thin, steel-gray hair was gathered in a sparse wispy knot at the back of her head. Strong, freckled arms were bare to the elbow, and her hands were chubby and delicate, like those of a plump little girl. She looked out into the sunshine. Her full face was not soft; it was controlled, kindly. Her hazel eyes seemed to have experienced all possible tragedy and to have mounted pain and suffering like steps into a high calm and a superhuman understanding. She seemed to know, to accept, to welcome her position, the citadel of the family, the strong place that could not be taken.

And since old Tom and the children could not know hurt or fear unless she acknowledged hurt and fear, she had practiced denying them in herself. And since, when a joyful thing happened, they looked to see whether joy was on her, it was her habit to build up laughter out of inadequate materials. But better than joy was calm.

Imperturbability could be depended upon. And from her great and humble position in the family she had taken dignity and a clean calm beauty. From her position as healer, her hands had grown sure and cool and quiet; from her position as arbiter she had become as remote and faultless in judgment as a goddess. She seemed to know that if she swayed the family shook, and if she ever really deeply wavered or despaired the family would fall, the family will to function would be gone.

She looked up pleasantly from the frying pan. And then her hand sank slowly to her side and the fork clattered to the wooden floor. Her eyes opened wide, and the pupils dilated. She breathed heavily through her open mouth. She closed her eyes. “Thank God,” she said. “Oh, thank God!” And suddenly her face was worried. “Tommy, you ain't wanted? You didn't bust loose?”

She moved toward him lithely, soundlessly in her bare feet, and her face was full of wonder. Her small hand felt his arm, felt the soundness of his muscles. And then her fingers went up to his cheek as a blind man's fingers might. And her joy was nearly like sorrow. Tom pulled his underlip between his teeth and bit it. Her eyes went wonderingly to his bitten lip, and she saw the little line of blood against his teeth and the trickle of blood down his lip. Then she knew, and her control came back, and her hand dropped. Her breath came out explosively. “Well!” she cried. “We come mighty near to goin' without ya. An' we was wonderin' how in the worl' you could ever find us.” She picked up the fork and combed the boiling grease and brought out a dark curl of crisp pork. And she set the pot of tumbling coffee on the back of the stove.

Grampa yells, 'Don't shoot no fledglin's, Al; wait till a growed-up one goes over,' an' then he whacked 'imself an' throwed his hip out.”

Across the yard came four people. Grampa was ahead, a lean, ragged, quick old man, jumping with quick steps and favoring his right leg- the side that came out of joint. He was buttoning his fly as he came, and his old hands were having trouble finding the buttons, for he had buttoned the top button into the second buttonhole, and that threw the whole sequence off. He wore dark ragged pants and a torn blue shirt, open all the way down, and showing long gray underwear, also unbuttoned. His lean white chest, fuzzed with white hair, was visible through the opening in his underwear. He gave up the fly and left it open and fumbled with the underwear buttons, then gave the whole thing up and hitched his brown suspenders. His was a lean excitable face with little bright eyes as evil as a frantic child's eyes. A cantankerous, complaining, mischievous, laughing face. He fought and argued, told dirty stories. He was as lecherous as always. Vicious and cruel and impatient, like a frantic child, and the whole structure overlaid with amusement. He drank too much when he could get it, ate too much when it was there, talked too much all the time.

Behind him hobbled Granma, who had survived only because she was as mean as her husband. She had held her own with a shrill ferocious religiosity that was as lecherous and as savage as anything Grampa could offer. Once, after a meeting, while she was still speaking in tongues, she fired both barrels of a shotgun at her husband, ripping one of his buttocks nearly off, and after that he admired her and did not try to torture her as children torture bugs. As she walked she hiked her Mother Hubbard up to her knees, and she bleated her shrill terrible war cry: “Pu-raise Gawd fur vittory.”

Behind them, moving slowly and evenly, but keeping up, came Pa and Noah- Noah the first-born, tall and strange, walking always with a wondering look on his face, calm and puzzled. He had never been angry in his life. He looked in wonder at angry people, wonder and uneasiness, as normal people look at the insane. Noah moved slowly, spoke seldom, and then so slowly that people who did not know him often thought him stupid. He was not stupid, but he was strange. He had little pride, no sexual urges. He worked and slept in a curious rhythm that nevertheless sufficed him. He was fond of his folks, but never showed it in any way. Although an observer could not have told why, Noah left the impression of being misshapen, his head or his body or his legs or his mind; but no misshapen member could be recalled.

Pa thought he knew why Noah was strange, but Pa was ashamed, and never told. For on the night when Noah was born, Pa, frightened at the spreading thighs, alone in the house, and horrified at the screaming wretch his wife had become, went mad with apprehension. Tom and the preacher looked up the road. And randy Al, seeing he was being noticed, threw back his shoulders, and he came into the yard with a swaying strut like that of a rooster about to crow. Cockily, he walked close before he recognized Tom; and when he did, his boasting face changed, and admiration and veneration shone in his eyes, and his swagger fell away. His stiff jeans, with the bottoms turned up eight inches to show his heeled boots, his three-inch belt with copper figures on it, even the red arm bands on his blue shirt and the rakish angle of his Stetson hat could not build him up to his brother's stature; for his brother had killed a man, and no one would ever forget it. Al knew that even he had inspired some admiration among boys of his own age because his brother had killed a man. He had heard in Sallisaw how he was pointed out: “That's Al Joad. His brother killed a fella with a shovel.”

IN THE LITTLE HOUSES the tenant people sifted their belongings and the belongings of their fathers and of their grandfathers. Picked over their possessions for the journey to the west. The men were ruthless because the past had been spoiled, but the women knew how the past would cry to them in the coming days. The men went into the barns and the sheds.

That plow, that harrow, remember in the war we planted mustard? Remember a fella wanted us to put in that rubber bush they call guayule? Get rich, he said. Bring out those tools- get a few dollars for them. Eighteen dollars for that plow, plus freight- Sears Roebuck.

Harness, carts, seeders, little bundles of hoes. Bring em out. Pile 'em up. Load 'em in the wagon. Take 'em to town. Sell 'em for what you can get. Sell the team and the wagon, too. No more use for anything.

Fifty cents isn't enough to get for a good plow. That seeder cost thirty-eight dollars. Two dollars isn't enough. Can't haul it all back- Well, take it, and a bitterness with it. Take the well pump and the harness. Take halters, collars, hames, and tugs. Take the little glass brow-band jewels, roses red under glass. Got those for the bay gelding. 'Member how he lifted his feet when he trotted?

Well, take it- all junk- and give me five dollars. You're not buying only junk, you're buying junked lives. And more- you'll see- you're buying bitterness. Buying a plow to plow your own children under, buying the arms and spirits that might have saved you. Five dollars, not four. I can't haul 'em back- Well, take 'em for four. But I warn you, you're buying what will plow your own children under. And you won't see. You can't see. Take 'em for four. Now, what'll you give for the team and wagon? Those fine bays, matched they are, matched in color, matched the way they walk, stride to stride. In the stiff pull-straining hams and buttocks, split-second timed together. And in the morning, the light on them, bay light. They look over the fence sniffing for us, and the stiff ears swivel to hear us, and the black forelocks! I've got a girl. She likes to braid the manes and forelocks, puts little red bows on them. Likes to do it. Not any more.

And the wagon- Oh, Jesus Christ! I'd shoot 'em for dog feed first. Oh, take 'em! Take 'em quick, mister. You're buying a little girl plaiting the forelocks, taking off her hair ribbon to make bows, standing back, head cocked, rubbing the soft noses with her cheek. You're buying years of work, toil in the sun; you're buying a sorrow that can't talk. But watch it, mister. There's a premium goes with this pile of junk and the bay horses- so beautiful- a packet of bitterness to grow in your house and to flower, some day. We could have saved you, but you cut us down, and soon you will be cut down and there'll be none of us to save you. And the tenant men came walking back, hands in their pockets, hats pulled down. Some bought a pint and drank it fast to make the impact hard and stunning. But they didn't laugh and they didn't dance. They didn't sing or pick the guitars. They walked back to the farms, hands in pockets and heads down, shoes kicking the red dust up.

But you can't start. Only a baby can start. You and me- why, we're all that's been. The anger of a moment, the thousand pictures, that's us. This land, this red land, is us; and the flood years and the dust years and the drought years are us. We can't start again. The bitterness we sold to the junk man- he got it all right, but we have it still. And when the owner men told us to go, that's us; and when the tractor hit the house, that's us until we're dead. To California or any place- every one a drum major leading a parade of hurts, marching with our bitterness. And some day- the armies of bitterness will all be going the same way. And they'll all walk together, and there'll be a dead terror from it.

Now you know well what we can take and what we can't take. We'll be camping out- a few pots to cook and wash in, and mattresses and comforts, lantern and buckets, and a piece of canvas. Use that for a tent. This kerosene can. Know what that is? That's the stove. And clothes- take all the clothes. And- the rifle? Wouldn't go out naked of a rifle. When shoes and clothes and food, when even hope is gone, we'll have the rifle. When grampa came- did I tell you?- he had pepper and salt and a rifle. Nothing else. That goes. And a bottle for water. That just about fills us. Right up the sides of the trailer, and the kids can set in the trailer, and granma on a mattress. Tools, a shovel and saw and wrench and pliers. An ax, too. We had that ax forty years. Look how she's wore down. And ropes, of course. The rest? Leave it-or burn it up.

If Mary takes that doll, that dirty rag doll, I got to take my Injun bow. I got to. An' this roun' stick- big as me. I might need this stick. I had this stick so long- a month, or maybe a year. I got to take it. And what's it like in California? The women sat among the doomed things, turning them over and looking past them and back. This book. My father had it. He liked a book. Pilgrim's Progress. Used to read it. Got his name in it. And his pipe- still smells rank. And this picture- an angel. I looked at that before the fust three come- didn't seem to do much good. Think we could get this china dog in? Aunt Sadie brought it from the St. Louis Fair. See? Wrote right on it. No, I guess not. Here's a letter my brother wrote the day before he died. Here's an old-time hat. These feathers- never got to use them. No, there isn't room.

nga tsho rang nyid kyi 'tsho ba dang kha bral nas 'tsho ba ji ltar rol dgos/ nga tsho'i 'das song med na nga tshos rang nyid rang ngo ji ltar 'phrod/ ma 'khyer/ skyur shog sregs shog
How can we live without our lives? How will we know it's us without our past? No. Leave it. Burn it.

They sat and looked at it and burned it into their memories. How'll it be not to know what land's outside the door? How if you wake up in the night and know- and know the willow tree's not there? Can you live without the willow tree? Well, no, you can't. The willow tree is you. The pain on that mattress there- that dreadful pain- that's you.

Suddenly they were nervous. Got to get out quick now. Can't wait. We can't wait. And they piled up the goods in the yards and set fire to them. They stood and watched them burning, and then frantically they loaded up the cars and drove away, drove in the dust. The dust hung in the air for a long time after the loaded cars had passed.

WHEN THE TRUCK had gone, loaded with implements, with heavy tools, with beds and springs, with every movable thing that might be sold, Tom hung around the place. He mooned into the barn shed, into the empty stalls, and he walked into the implement leanto and kicked the refuse that was left, turned a broken mower tooth with his foot. He visited places he remembered- the red bank where the swallows nested, the willow tree over the pig pen. Two shoats grunted and squirmed at him through the fence, black pigs, sunning and comfortable. And then his pilgrimage was over, and he went to sit on the doorstep where the shade was lately fallen. Behind him Ma moved about in the kitchen, washing children's clothes in a bucket; and her strong freckled arms dripped soapsuds from the elbows. She stopped her rubbing when he sat down. She looked at him a long time, and at the back of his head when he turned and stared out at the hot sunlight. And then she went back to her rubbing.
kho mos [“]Thom/ kha li h+phor ne ya ru yod tshad bde blag yin par smon/[”] zhes bshad/
She said, “Tom, I hope things is all right in California.”

He turned and looked at her. “What makes you think they ain't?” he asked.

“Well- nothing. Seems too nice, kinda. I seen the han'bills fellas pass out, an' how much work they is, an' high wages an' all; an' I seen in the paper how they want folks to come an' pick grapes an' oranges an' peaches. That'd be nice work, Tom, pickin' peaches. Even if they wouldn't let you eat none, you could maybe snitch a little ratty one sometimes. An' it'd be nice under the trees, workin' in the shade. I'm scared of stuff so nice. I ain't got faith. I'm scared somepin ain't so nice about it.”
Thom gyis [“]re ba mthon po nam mkha'i bya 'dra ba ma brgyab na/ re 'bras don med 'bu srin kha la bza' dgos 'khel mi yong /[”] zhes bshad/

[“]gnas lugs de bden pa yin pa ngas kyang shes/ de dam pa'i gsung rab nang gi tshig red/ ma red dam/[”]
“I know that's right. That's Scripture, ain't it?”

Ma chuckled lightly and scrounged the clothes in and out of the bucket. And she wrung out overalls and shirts, and the muscles of her forearms corded out. “Your Pa's pa, he quoted Scripture all the time. He got it all roiled up, too. It was the Dr. Miles' Almanac he got mixed up. Used to read ever' word in that almanac out loud-letters from folks that couldn't sleep or had lame backs. An' later he'd give them people for a lesson, an' he'd say, 'That's a par'ble from Scripture.' Your Pa an' Uncle John troubled 'im some about it when they'd laugh.” She piled wrung clothes like cord wood on the table. “They say it's two thousan' miles where we're goin'. How far ya think that is, Tom? I seen it on a map, big mountains like on a post card, an' we're goin' right through 'em. How long ya s'pose it'll take to go that far, Tommy?”

Thom gyis [“]mi shes/ gza' 'khor gnyis 'dra dgos rgyu red/ nga tsho kha las dge na nyin bcu'i nang du slebs kyang srid/ a ma/ da sems khur byed kyi ma 'dug ngas khyod la btson khang la bsdad pa'i nyams myong zhig bshad/ btson khang du yod dus/ rang nyid ga dus phyir 'bud thub rgyu yin min thad la bsam blo rtsa ba nas gtong mi rung / de ma gtogs rang nyid smyon pa chags rgyu red/ de ring ci zhig byed rgyu yin min dang / sang nyin ci zhig byed dgos min/ gza' spen pa'i nyin gyi lgang rtsed sogs la bsam blo btang nas bsdad na bzang / de ni thabs lam yag shos de yin/ btson pa rnying pa tshos de ltar byed kyin yod/ btson pa gsar pa tshos rang nyid kyi mgo bo btson sgo la brdabs nas klad pa 'gas kyi yod/ rgyu mtshan ni/ kho tshos rang nyid btson grol thob pa'i bar du dus yun ga tshod sgug dgos min thad la bsam blo gtong gi yod pas yin/ khyod kyis kyang ci'i phyir thabs lam de mi spyod dam/ nyin re'i don dag nyin re byas te song dang de bzang /[”] zhes bshad/

“I dunno,” he said. “Two weeks, maybe ten days if we got luck. Look, Ma, stop your worryin'. I'm a-gonna tell you somepin about bein' in the pen. You can't go thinkin' when you're gonna be out. You'd go nuts. You got to think about that day, an' then the nex' day, about the ball game Sat'dy. That's what you got to do. Ol' timers does that. A new young fella gets buttin' his head on the cell door. He's thinkin' how long it's gonna be. Whyn't you do that? Jus' take ever' day.”

kho mos [“]de thabs lam yag[”] ces zer bzhin thab thog gi chu dron po de zo ba'i nang du blugs shing / de'i nang du gyon gos btsog pa rnams g.yugs rjes lbu ba sob sob kyi chu nang du 'phur brdar byas/ [“]red ya/ de thabs lam yag po zhig red/ 'on kyang / kha li h+phor ne ya de ga 'dra'i skyid po zhig yin nam snyam nas de thad la bsam blo 'khor 'gro/ nam yang 'khyag rgyu med la ga sa gang du shing tog yod pa/ mi rnams khang pa skyid shos kyi nang du sdod pa/ tsha lu ma'i sdong po'i khrod kyi khang chung dkar po/ ngas 'dang brgyab na/ gal srid nga tsho tshang mar las ka rnyed pa yin na/ gcig byas na nga tshos nga tsho rang nyid la'ang khang pa dkar po chung chung de 'dra zhig nyo thub srid/ de nas sgor bud ma thag tu byis pa chung chung tshos tsha lu ma 'thog chog kho tshos mig gis mthong mthong la bsran thub kyi ma red/ kho tshos ki co dang bcas steng du shor 'gro rgyu red/[”]

“That's a good way,” she said, and she filled up her bucket with hot water from the stove, and she put in dirty clothes and began punching them down into the soapy water. “Yes, that's a good way. But I like to think how nice it's gonna be, maybe, in California. Never cold. An' fruit ever'place, an' people just bein' in the nicest places, little white houses in among the orange trees. I wonder- that is, if we all get jobs an' all work- maybe we can get one of them little white houses. An' the little fellas go out an' pick oranges right off the tree. They ain't gonna be able to stand it, they'll get to yellin' so.”

Thom gyis kho mos las ka byed bzhin par bltas nas mig zung las 'dzum 'od cig 'khor bzhin [“]'di'i skor la bsam blo btang nas bsdad na skyid po 'dra red/ ngas kha li h+phor ne ya nas yin pa'i mi zhig ngo shes/ kho'i skad cha bshad stangs de nga tsho'i bshad stangs dang mi 'dra/ kho'i skad cha bshad stangs la bltas na/ kho rang sa cha thag ring zhig nas yong ba yin pa shes thub/ 'on kyang khos zer na/ deng sang kho tsho'i sa cha na mi ha cang mang po zhig gis las ka 'tshol bzhin pa'i sgang red zer la/ shing tog 'thog mkhan gyi gla pa tsho ni rnying zhing btsog pa'i sgar gyi nang du 'dug dgos la/ kho tshor bza' rgyu'ang 'dang nges shig med zer/ khos zer na/ gla cha ni ha cang dma' la las ka rnyed rgyu ha cang dka' zer/[”] zhes bshad/

Tom watched her working, and his eyes smiled. “It done you good jus' thinkin' about it. I knowed a fella from California. He didn't talk like us. You'd of knowed he come from some far-off place jus' the way he talked. But he says they's too many folks lookin' for work right there now. An' he says the folks that pick the fruit live in dirty ol' camps an' don't hardly get enough to eat. He says wages is low an' hard to get any.”

a ma'i gdong du grib nag cig 'thibs byung / kho mos [“]o/ de 'dra yin sa ma red/ khyod kyi a phas mi zhig gi lag nas shog bu ser po'i steng du dpar ba'i brda yig cig blangs yod la/ de'i steng du kho tshor las ka byed mkhan dgos skor gsal po bris 'dug der las ka las rgyu de 'dra'i mang po zhig med na kho tshos rang nyid la de 'dra'i dka' las gtod rgyu ma red/ kho tshos brda yig 'di 'dra bzos te 'grems par 'gro song yod pa red/ kho tshos skyag rdzun bshad pa'i don du 'gro song de 'dra gtong rgyu ma red 'dod/[”] ces bshad/

A shadow crossed her face. “Oh, that ain't so,” she said. “Your father got a han'bill on yella paper, tellin' how they need folks to work. They wouldn't go to that trouble if they wasn't plenty work. Costs 'em good money to get them han'bills out. What'd they want ta lie for, an' costin' 'em money to lie?”

Tom shook his head. “I don't know, Ma. It's kinda hard to think why they done it. Maybe…” He looked out at the hot sun, shining on the red earth.

“Maybe what?”

“Maybe it's nice, like you says. Where'd Grampa go? Where'd the preacher go?”

a mas lag bar du gyon gos mthon po zhig brtsigs nas khang pa las phyir bud yong gi yod pas/ Thom zur du bcar nas kho mor lam bu phyes/ [“]chos dpon kho rang 'cham 'cham du 'gro rgyu yin zer nas phyin song / a mes khang pa'i nang du gnyid 'dug kho rang nyin dkar khang pa'i nang du yong nas mtshams la lar nyal gyi yod/[”] kho mo lcags skud 'then yod sa de ru song nas rdzi dor sngon po dang nang stod sngon po/ 'og 'jug skya bo ring po bcas lcags skud kyi steng du 'phangs/

Thom gyis rang nyid kyi rgyab phyogs nas rkang pa drud nas yong ba'i rdog sgra zhig thos pas/ kha phyir 'khor nas bltas/ a mes nyal khang nang nas phyir bud nas da nangs zhogs pa ltar lag pas l+wa ba'i sgrog bu sgrog thabs byed bzhin [“]ngas skad cha bshad pa go byung / khyi phrug tshos gnyid 'jug gi mi 'dug[”] ces zer bzhin drag tu khros pa'i mdzub mos dor ma'i thog gi bsgrogs nas yod pa'i sgrog bu de gnyis ka'ang phyes byung la/ de nas kho'i lag pas rang nyid kyis ci zhig byed bzhin pa yongs su brjed pas/ lag pa brlig sgro'i 'og tu mar bsrings nas yid tshims pa zhig 'phrugs/ a ma lag pa rlon tsar tsar gyis nang du slebs byung la/ kho mo'i lag pa 'dag rdzas dang chu dron po'i nang du sbangs pa'i rkyen gyis lag steng gnyis ka gnyer 'khum dang chu sbos thebs yod/

Behind him Tom heard a shuffling step, and he turned to look in. Grampa was emerging from the bedroom, and as in the morning, he fumbled with the buttons of his fly. “I heerd talkin',” he said. “Sons-a-bitches won't let a ol' fella sleep. When you bastards get dry behin' the ears, you'll maybe learn to let a ol' fella sleep.” His furious fingers managed to flip open the only two buttons on his fly that had been buttoned. And his hand forgot what it had been trying to do. His hand reached in and contentedly scratched under the testicles. Ma came in with wet hands, and her palms puckered and bloated from hot water and soap.

“Thought you was sleepin'. Here, let me button you up.” And though he struggled, she held him and buttoned his underwear and his shirt and his fly. “You go aroun' a sight,” she said, and let him go.

And he spluttered angrily, “Fella's come to a nice- to a nice-when somebody buttons 'em. I want ta be let be to button my own pants.”

The old man thrust out his bristly chin, and he regarded Ma with his shrewd, mean, merry eyes. “Well, sir,” he said, “we'll be a-startin' 'fore long now. An', by God, they's grapes out there, just a-hangin' over inta the road. Know what I'm a-gonna do? I'm gonna pick me a wash tub full a grapes, an' I'm gonna set in 'em, an' scrooge aroun', an' let the juice run down my pants.”

Tom laughed. “By God, if he lives to be two hundred you never will get Grampa house broke,” he said. “You're all set on goin', ain't you, Grampa?”

rgad pos sgam zhig drud yong nas de'i steng du ljid ltig ser bsdad rjes [“]yin ya yin/ ga tshod mgyogs na de tshod dga'/ nga'i gcung po lo ngo bzhi bcu'i sngon la de phyogs su phyin pa red/ dus de nas bzung kho'i skor go rgyu ma byung / kho khyi phrug khram pa zhig yin/ kho la dga' mkhan su yang med/ khos nga'i khold [2] dkrum mda' kher 'phen de 'khyer nas bros pa red/ gal srid da thengs nga tsho kha li h+phor ne ya ru kho dang yang na kho'i bu phrug tsho la 'phrad na/ gal srid kho la byis phrug 'dra yod na/ nga'i khold dkrum mda' de phyir sprod shog zer dgos/ ngas kho'i skor rgyus lon byas pa nor med na/ kho la bu phrug yod pa'i dbang du btang rung de ni thang bu yin rgyu red la/ da lta mi gzhan pa zhig gis skyong gi yod rgyu red/ sa de phyogs su slebs na nga dngos gnas dga' rgyu red/ des nga rang mi gsar pa zhig tu bzo rgyu red bsam pa'i tshor snang 'dug der slebs ma thag tu thad kar shing tog zhing ra'i nang du las kar 'gro rgyu yin/[”] zhes bshad/

The old man pulled out a box and sat down heavily on it. “Yes, sir,” he said. “An' goddamn near time, too. My brother went on out there forty years ago. Never did hear nothin' about him. Sneaky son-of-a-bitch, he was. Nobody loved him. Run off with a single-action Colt of mine. If I ever run across him or his kids, if he got any out in California, I'll ask 'em for that Colt. But if I know 'im, an' he got any kids, he cuckoo'd 'em, an' somebody else is a-raisin' 'em. I sure will be glad to get out there. Got a feelin' it'll make a new fella outa me. Go right to work in the fruit.”

a mas mgo bo nang du gug bzhin [“]khos dngos gnas de ltar 'dod kyi yod pa red/ zla ba gsum gyi sngon bar du las ka las kyi yod pa red/ de nas khos rang nyid kyi dpyi tshigs gcus pa red/[”] ces bshad/
Ma nodded. “He means it, too,” she said. “Worked right up to three months ago, when he throwed his hip out the last time.”
a mes kyis [“]de da yin dang yin/[”] zhes bshad/
“Damn right,” said Grampa.
Thom gyis rang nyid bsdad yod sa'i sgo them nas phar bltas nas [“]chos dpon phyir yong gi 'dug 'bru khang gi 'gram ngogs nas tshur yong gi 'dug[”] ces bshad/

“He's a funny fella,” said Tom. “Talks funny all the time. Seems like he's talkin' to hisself, though. He ain't tryin' to put nothin' over.”

a mas [“]kho'i mig gi lta stangs la ltos dang / khrus dbang zhus pa dang 'dra/ zhib 'tshol zhes 'bod pa'i rnam pa de babs 'dug dngos gnas khrus dbang zhus pa zhig dang 'dra/ mgo bo dud nas 'gro yang sa thog gi dngos po ci la'ang cer mig gis mi blta/ ya/ 'dir khrus dbang zhus pa'i mi zhig 'dug[”] ces bshad cing / kha se sgo'i nye sar slebs bzhin pa'i skabs su a ma 'jam cag ger bsdad/

“Watch the look in his eye,” said Ma. “He looks baptized. Got that look they call lookin' through. He sure looks baptized. An' a-walkin' with his head down, a-starin' at nothin' on the groun'. There is a man that's baptized.” And she was silent, for Casy had drawn near the door.
Thom gyis [“]de ltar 'cham 'cham byas nas bsdad na khyod la tsha dug phog rgyu red do//[”] zhes bshad/
“You gonna get sun-shook, walkin' around like that,” said Tom.

Casy said, “Well, yeah- maybe.” He appealed to them all suddenly, to Ma and Grampa and Tom. “I got to get goin' west. I got to go. I wonder if I kin go along with you folks.” And then he stood, embarrassed by his own speech.

Thom ni khyim 'di'i skyes pa pho zhig yin pas a mas kho'i gdong la bltas/ 'on kyang / Thom gyis skad cha ma bshad/ a mas Thom la skyes pa pho'i thob thang longs su spyod du bcug zin pas/ da lta kho mos [“]khyod nga tsho dang mnyam du yod na de ni nga tsho'i gzi brjid cig yin/ 'on kyang / ngas da lta kha tshon chod pos shod ga la nus/ a phas zer na nga tsho ga dus lam la 'bud rgyu'i skor do nub skyes pa tshos gros bsdur byed rgyu yin zer/ de bas skyes pa tsho khyim du 'dzoms pa'i bar du nga tshos ci yang ma bshad na bzang rgyu red/ kho tsho phyir slebs ma thag tu jon dang a pha/ no ya/ Thom/ a mes/ al dang khon ne bcas kyis thag gcod byed rgyu red/ 'on kyang / gal srid dos 'khor steng du shong gi yod na tshang mas khyod rang nga tsho'i gzi brjid cig tu brtsi thag chod yin/[”] zhes bshad/

Ma looked to Tom to speak, because he was a man, but Tom did not speak. She let him have the chance that was his right, and then she said, “Why, we'd be proud to have you. He would have liked Rose of Sharon to sit there. This was impossible, because she was young and a woman. But Uncle John sat uneasily, his lonely haunted eyes were not at ease, and his thin strong body was not relaxed. Nearly all the time the barrier of loneliness cut Uncle John off from people and from appetites. He ate little, drank nothing, and was celibate. But underneath, his appetites swelled into pressures until they broke through. Then he would eat of some craved food until he was sick; or he would drink jake or whisky until he was a shaken paralytic with red wet eyes; or he would raven with lust for some whore in Sallisaw. It was told of him that once he went clear to Shawnee and hired three whores in one bed, and snorted and rutted on their unresponsive bodies for an hour. But when one of his appetites was sated, he was sad and ashamed and lonely again. He hid from people, and by gifts tried to make up to all people for himself. Then he crept into houses and left gum under pillows for children; then he cut wood and took no pay.

The three men on the seat were glum as they drove toward home over the dusty road. Al, bending over the wheel, kept shifting eyes from the road to the instrument panel, watching the ammeter needle, which jerked suspiciously, watching the oil gauge and the heat indicator. And his mind was cataloguing weak points and suspicious things about the car. He listened to the whine, which might be the rear end, dry; and he listened to tappets lifting and falling. He kept his hand on the gear lever, feeling the turning gears through it. And he had let the clutch out against the brake to test for slipping clutch plates. He might be a musking goat sometimes, but this was his responsibility, this truck, its running, and its maintenance. If something went wrong it would be his fault, and while no one would say it, everyone, and Al most of all, would know it was his fault. And so he felt it, watched it, and listened to it.
