a phas [“]med/ nga tsho phyi la phyung ba red/ kho tsho'i 'drud 'then gyis nga tsho'i khang pa dkyil gshags btang song /[”] zhes bshad/
“No,” said Pa. “We're out. They put a tractor past the house.”
[“]des na khyod tsho rang yul du phyir log rgyu ma red a/[”]
“You wouldn' go back then?”
[“]ci la log gam/[”]
“'Course not.”
skyes pa rtsab hral pa des [“]des na ngas khyod tshor 'jigs skrag mi slong /[”] zhes bshad/
“Then I ain't gonna fret you,” said the ragged man.

[“]de red/ khyod kyis nga tshor 'jigs skrag slong ga la thub/ nga'i lag tu brda yig cig yod la/ de'i steng du kho tshor las ka pa dgos lab kyi 'dug kho tshor las ka pa dgos kyi med na brda yig 'di 'dra bkram nas ci zhig bya'am/ brda yig 'di tsho dpar na 'gro song yod pas/ kho tshor las ka pa dgos kyi med na kho tshos 'di 'dra dgram rgyu ma red a/[”]
“'Course you ain't gonna fret me. I got a han'bill says they need men. Don't make no sense if they don't need men. Costs money for them bills. They wouldn' put 'em out if they didn' need men.”
[“]ngas khyod tshor 'jigs skrag slong 'dod mi 'dug[”]
“I don' wanna fret you.”

a phas khong khro dang bcas [“]khyod kyis smyo bshad lung pa gang brgyab byung la/ da dung yang khyi kha mi btsum pa ci red/ nga'i lag gi brda yig gi steng du kho tshor las ka pa dgos lab kyi 'dug mod/ khyod rang gis khrel dgod byed bzhin las ka pa dgos kyi mi 'dug zer/ ya/ don du su zhig gis skyag rdzun bshad pa red/[”] ces bshad/
Pa said angrily, “You done some jackassin'. You ain't gonna shut up now. My han'bill says they need men. You laugh an' say they don't. Now, which one's a liar?”

skyes pa rtsab hral pas khong khros gang ba'i a pha'i mig zung la bltas shing / de nas kho rang yang cung 'gyod pa skyes pa 'dra bas [“]brda yig steng du bris pa 'grig 'dug kho tshor las ka pa dgos kyi 'dug[”] ces bshad/
The ragged man looked down into Pa's angry eyes. He looked sorry. “Han'bill's right,” he said. “They need men.”
[“]des na khyod kyis de 'dra'i khrel dgod byed don ci'i phyir yin/[”]
“Then why the hell you stirrin' us up laughin'?”
[“]rgyu mtshan ni/ khyod tshos kho tshor las ka pa ga 'dra'i rigs dgos pa shes kyi med pas yin/[”]
“'Cause you don't know what kind a men they need.”
[“]khyod kyis ci zer ba yin/[”]
“What you talkin' about?”
skyes pa rtsab hral pas mjug mthar sems thag bcad nas [“]ltos dang / khyod kyi brda yig steng du kho tshor mi ga tshod dgos lab kyi 'dug gam/[”] zhes bshad/
The ragged man reached a decision. “Look”, he said. “How many men they say they want on your han'bill?”
[“]mi brgyad brgya/ da dung de sa cha chung chung zhig red/[”]
“Eight hunderd, an' that's in one little place.”
[“]shog bu dmar ser can de red dam/[”]
“Orange color han'bill?”
[“]ci red/ red/[”]
“Why- yes.”
[“]steng du mi zhig gi ming bris nas/ las rigs ga ge mo'i 'gan len las dpon ga ge mo yin rabs bris yod rgyu red/[”]
“Give the name a the fella- says so and so, labor contractor?”
a phas glo khug tu lag pa bsrings nas ltebs rtseg brgyab pa'i brda yig cig phyir blangs yong [“]red/ de 'dra bris 'dug khyod kyis ji ltar shes pa yin/[”]
Pa reached in his pocket and brought out the folded handbill. “That's right. How'd you know?”

skyes pa des [“]ltos dang / der snying po ci yang yod pa ma red/ mi 'dir las ka pa brgyad brgya dgos dus khos brda yig 'di 'dra tshar lnga stong tsam dpar yod rgyu red la/ de dag mi stong phrag nyi shu tsam gyis mthong yod rgyu red/ dka' khag la 'phrad yod pa'i mi grangs stong phrag gnyis gsum tsam gyis brda yig 'di la yid ches byas nas nub phyogs su 'gro bzhin yod rgyu red/[”] ces bshad/

“Look,” said the man. “It don't make no sense. This fella wants eight hunderd men. So he prints up five thousand of them things an' maybe twenty thousan' people sees 'em. An' maybe two-three thousan' folks gets movin' account a this here han'bill. Folks that's crazy with worry.”
a phas [“]'on kyang / de ltar byas na don snying ci zhig 'dug gam/[”] zhes 'ur brgyab/
“But it don't make no sense!” Pa cried.

[“]khyod rang brda yig 'di 'grem mkhan la ma thug bar du 'di la don snying ci yod ha go rgyu ma red/ khyod tsho song na brda yig 'di 'grem mkhan nam yang na kho'i lag rogs shig la thug gi red/ khyod tsho song nas lam 'gram gyi yur ba'i nang nas sgar rgyag rgyu red la/ de gar khyod tsho dang khyod tsho lta bu'i khyim tshang lnga bcu lhag yod rgyu red/ de nas kho yong gi red la/ khos khyod tsho'i ras gur nang nas bza' rgyu ci zhig lhag yod med blta rgyu red/ gal srid khyod tshor bza' rgyu ci yang lhag med na de nas khos/ [‘]las ka byed 'dod dam/[’] zhes 'dri rgyu red la/ khyod tshos de'i lan du/ [‘]los 'dod/ sku zhabs/ nga tshor las ka re las rgyu'i go skabs gnang bar mkhyen/[’] zer rgyu red/ de dus khos/ [‘]ya/ nga la khyod tsho dgos/[’] zer zhing / khyod tshos/ [‘]las mgo ga dus 'dzugs dgos/[’] zhes 'dri nges/ khos khyod tshor las ka gang du las su 'gro dgos pa dang / ga dus 'gro dgos pa bshad rgyu red la/ de nas kho mu mthud du las ka pa 'tshol du 'gro rgyu red/ gcig byas na kho la mi nyis brgya ma gtogs mi dgos mod/ 'on kyang / khos las ka pa lnga brgya la kha brda byed rgyu red la/ de dag gis mi gzhan pa la bshad rgyu red/ de bas/ khyod tsho las yul du slebs dus/ de gar mi grangs stong phrag lhag 'dzoms yod rgyu red la/ de nas mi des/ [‘]ngas chu tshod re la las gla sgor zur gnyis re sprod rgyu yin/[’] zer nges/ skad cha de thos tshe/ mi tshogs phyed ka tsam rang rang gi gur du phyir log 'gro yi red/ 'on kyang / da dung yang shul du mi lnga brgya yas mas lhag yod nges shing / kho tsho ltogs drags pa'i rkyen gyis/ sob gor gcig gi don du las ka ci zhig yin rung las rgyu red/ ltos dang / kho la kham bu 'thog mkhan dang / yang na sring bal 'thog mkhan gyi las ka pa dgos pa bden pa red/ da gnas lugs de rtogs song ngam/ las ka pa ga tshod mang mang dang / kho tsho grod khog ga tshod ltogs yod na/ khos de tshod kyis gla cha dma' sar phab thub kyi yod pa red/ de bzhin/ khos gang thub thub kyis phru gu yod mkhan gyi las ka pa gla e thub blta la/ rgyu mtshan ni/ ltas ngan/ ngas khyod tshor skrag slong gi min lab pa min nam/[”]

“Not till you see the fella that put out this here bill. You'll see him, or somebody that's workin' for him. You'll be a-campin' by a ditch, you an' fifty other famblies. An' he'll look in your tent an' see if you got anything lef' to eat. An' if you got nothin', he says, 'Wanna job?' An' you'll say, 'I sure do, mister. I'll sure thank you for a chance to do some work.' An' he'll say, 'I can use you.' An' you'll say, 'When do I start?' An' he'll tell you where to go, an' what time, an' then he'll go on. Maybe he needs two hunderd men, so he talks to five hunderd, an' they tell other folks, an' when you get to the place, they's a thousan' men. This here fella says, 'I'm payin' twenty cents an hour.' An' maybe half a the men walk off. But they's still five hunderd that's so goddamn hungry they'll work for nothin' but biscuits. Well, this here fella's got a contract to pick them peaches or- chop that cotton. You see now? The more fellas he can get, an' the hungrier, less he's gonna pay. An' he'll get a fella with kids if he can, 'cause- hell, I says I wasn't gonna fret ya.”

gor gor du bsdad pa'i skyes pa tsho'i grang shur shur gyi mig mdangs kyis kho'i gdong la cer nas 'dug cing / kho tsho'i mig zung gis kho'i gtam de bden min gyi brdar sha gcod bzhin yod pas/ skyes pa rtsab hral pa der cung dogs mi bde ba shar/ [“]ngas khyod tshor skrag slong gi min lab yod mod/ 'on kyang / ngas snang med sgos de ltar byed bzhin 'dug khyod tsho mu mthud du mdun skyod byed rgyu red la/ phyir pha yul du log rgyu ma red/[”]

The circle of faces looked coldly at him. The eyes tested his words. The ragged man grew self-conscious. “I says I wasn't gonna fret ya, an' here I'm a-doin' it. You gonna go on. You ain't goin' back.”

sgo khyams hril po khu sim por gyur/ sgron mes sir sgra sgrog bzhin yod la/ sgron me'i mtha' skor du srin 'bu mug pa khyu gcig 'phur lding byed bzhin gda'/ skyes pa rtsab hral pas dogs mi bde ba'i rnam 'gyur dang bcas mu mthud du skad cha bshad/ [“]las ka las rgyu yod zer mkhan de tshor thug skabs/ khyod tshos ci zhig bshad dgos pa ngas khyod tshor gcig bshad/ de ngas khyod tshor bshad chog kho la gla cha ga tshod sprod min dris/ kho la gla cha ga tshod sprod min de yig thog tu 'bri ru chug kho la re ba de 'don dgos/ de ltar ma byas na khyod tsho mgo skor 'og tu tshud rgyu ma gtogs med/[”]

The silence hung on the porch. And the light hissed, and a halo of moths swung around and around the lantern. The ragged man went on nervously, “Lemme tell ya what to do when ya meet that fella says he got work. Lemme tell ya. Ast him what he's gonna pay. Ast him to write down what he's gonna pay. Ast him that. I tell you men you're gonna get fooled if you don't.”

gnas bdag de rkub stegs steng nas mdun du dgye nas skyes pa rtsab hral pa de la lta yag cig byas/ khos brang kha'i brang spu tsho'i khrod du 'phrug tsam 'phrug tsam byed bzhin/ drod khol bral ba'i skad gdangs dang bcas [“]khyod rang rnyog dra bzo mkhan de tsho'i gras min pa thag chod yin nam/ khyod rang las ka par mgo skor gtong mkhan de tsho'i gcig min nam/[”] zhes bshad/ skyes pa rtsab hral pas [“]de 'dra min/ dkon mchog dpang du btsugs chog[”] ces skad cor brgyab/

The proprietor leaned forward in his chair, the better to see the ragged dirty man. He scratched among the gray hairs on his chest. He said coldly, “You sure you ain't one of these here troublemakers? You sure you ain't a labor faker?” And the ragged man cried, “I swear to God I ain't!”

gnas bdag gis [“]kho tsho mang po zhig gis yar mar nas rnyog dra mang po bzo bzhin 'dug yul mi tsho'i sems khams dkrugs nas mgo skor gtong / deng sang de 'dra ha cang mang / nyin gcig la nga tshos rnyog dra bzo mkhan tshang ma 'dzin bzung byed dgos thug gi red la/ kho tsho tshang ma sa gnas 'di nas mtha' skrod gtong dgos 'khel rgyu red/ mi tshang mas las ka las dgos la/ de las 'dod med na da 'di gar 'khyams nas skyag pa bza' rgyu yin nam/ nga tshos kho tshor rnyog dra bzo ru mi 'jug thag chod yin/[”] zhes bshad/

“They's plenty of 'em,” the proprietor said. “Goin' aroun' stirrin' up trouble. Gettin' folks mad. Chiselin' in. They's plenty of 'em. Time's gonna come when we string 'em all up, all them troublemakers. We gonna run 'em outa the country. Man wants to work, O.K. If he don't- the hell with him. We ain't gonna let him stir up trouble.”

skyes pa rtsab hral pa de yar langs nas [“]ngas khyod tshor bshad 'dod pa ni/ gnad don zhig ngas ma rtogs par lo ngo gcig 'gor song / gnad don de ma rtogs pas phru gu gnyis ka rkyen lam du brdzangs song la/ chung ma'ang tshe las 'das song / gnad don 'di bshad pa tsam gyis khyod tshos ha go yong ba de 'dra ma red/ de ngas sngon nas shes na 'grig gi red/ de dus nga la bshad mkhan mi su gcig kyang ma byung / phru gu gnyis ka'i lto ba skrangs te phyi la 'bur nas nyal sa'i nang du nyal yod la/ kho tsho'i lus steng na lhag pa ni keng rus dang pags pa kho na red/ kho tsho ni btsas ma thag pa'i khyi phrug dang 'dra bar 'dar sig rgyag bzhin rngu zug 'don gyi yod la/ de dus nga yar mar la brgyugs nas las ka re e rnyed lta bzhin yod/ de yang sgor mo gsog pa dang gla dngul len pa'i ched du ma yin par/ las ka gang yang rung ba zhig las rgyu tsam yod pa'i ched du red ya/[”] ces skad cor bton/ [“]ston pa ye shu/ de ni gro phye phor pa gang re dang phag tshil khem bu gang re'i don du red ya/ de nas bem po zhib bsher dpon slebs nas/ [‘]phru gu snying nad kyis 'das pa red/[’] ces zer zhing / yig tshags steng du de ltar bris pa red/ kho tsho ma shi sngon du 'dar sig kho na rgyag gi 'dug la/ kho tsho'i lto ba de phag pa'i gcin lgang dang 'dra bar phyi logs su 'bur nas yod/[”]

The ragged man drew himself up. “I tried to tell you folks,” he said. “Somepin it took me a year to find out. Took two kids dead, took my wife dead to show me. But I can't tell you. I should of knew that. Nobody couldn't tell me, neither. I can't tell ya about them little fellas layin' in the tent with their bellies puffed out an' jus' skin on their bones, an' shiverin' an' whinin' like pups, an' me runnin' aroun' tryin' to get work- not for money, not for wages!” he shouted. “Jesus Christ, jus' for a cup a flour an' a spoon a lard. An' then the coroner come. 'Them children died a heart failure,' he said. Put it on his paper. Shiverin', they was, an' their bellies stuck out like a pig bladder.”
gor gor gyis 'dus yod pa'i skyes pa tsho khu sim du gnas shing / tshang ma'i kha cung tsam gdangs nas dbugs dma' mo re len bzhin kho la bltas nas bsdad/
The circle was quiet, and mouths were open a little. The men breathed shallowly, and watched.

skyes pa rtsab hral pas kho'i mtha' 'khor gyi skyes pa tshang mar gcig bltas rjes/ kha phar 'khor nas mun nag khrod du mgyogs por phyin song / kho'i gzugs phung de dgong mo'i mun pa yis khyur mid btang zin mod/ 'on kyang / kho'i thang la 'drud bzhin 'gro ba'i rdog sgra de yun ring zhig la thos thub/ kho'i rdog pa gzhung lam steng du 'khel bas kho tshos thrig thrig gi rdog sgra thos thub/ gzhung lam steng nas rlangs 'khor chung ba re song tshe/ de'i glog 'od kyi 'og nas skyes pa rtsab hral pa de gzhung lam brgyud nas lhab be lhab be 'gro bzhin pa mthong thub/ khos mgo bo dud cing lag zung stod l+wa'i khug ma ru bcug nas mdun du 'gro/

The ragged man looked around at the circle, and then he turned and walked quickly away into the darkness. The dark swallowed him, but his dragging footsteps could be heard a long time after he had gone, footsteps along the road; and a car came by on the highway, and its lights showed the ragged man shuffling along the road, his head hanging down and his hands in the black coat pockets.
skyes pa tshang ma'i sems blong blong bor gyur/ kho tsho las gcig gis [“]un/ da ni nam tshod snga rgyu mi 'dug pas song nas nyal na 'grig rgyu red/[”] ces bshad/
The men were uneasy. One said, “Well- gettin' late. Got to get to sleep.”

gnas bdag gis [“]kho phal cher gar 'gro gang 'dug med pa zhig yin rgyu red/ deng sang 'di 'dra'i lam 'grul ldom po ha cang mang /[”] zhes bshad cing / de nas khu sim mer bsdad/ khos rkub stegs kyi rgyab ngos yang bskyar gyang la bsnyes nas lag pas mgrin pa 'phur 'phur byas/
The proprietor said, “Prob'ly shif'less. They's so goddamn many shif'less fellas on the road now.” And then he was quiet. And he tipped his chair back against the wall again and fingered his throat.
Thom gyis [“]nga song nas a mar ngo cung tsam thug rjes/ de nas lam la bud na 'grig rgyu red/[”] ces bshad cing / de dang bstun nas jo Di tshang gi skyes pa tshang ma phar song /
Tom said, “Guess I'll go see Ma for a minute, an' then we'll shove along a piece.” The Joad men moved away.
a phas [“]khyod tshos bltas na khos bshad pa don dngos yin rgyu e red/ da sngon skyes pa de/[”] zhes bshad/
Pa said, “S'pose he's tellin' the truth- that fella?”
chos dpon gyis [“]khos bshad pa don dngos red/ don dngos red/ de kho'i don dngos red/ khos de rdzun bzo byas pa ma red/[”] ces lan btab/
The preacher answered, “He's tellin' the truth, awright. The truth for him. He wasn't makin' nothin' up.”
Thom gyis [“]'o na/ nga tshor mtshon na/ de nga tsho'i don dngos yin rgyu e red/[”] ces dris/
“How about us?” Tom demanded. “Is that the truth for us?”
kha se yis [“]de ngas mi shes/[”] zhes lan btab/
“I don' know,” said Casy.
a phas [“]ngas kyang mi shes/[”] zhes bshad/
“I don' know,” said Pa.

kho tsho kho tshang gi ras gur te/ thag pa zhig gi steng du ras rgod leb mo zhig bkal yod pa de'i rtsar song / kho tshang gi ras gur gyi nang mun nag dang khu sim red/ kho tsho thag nyer slebs pa na/ mi lus kyi ring tshad yod pa'i dngos gzugs skya bo zhig 'gul 'gul byas nas yar langs/ a ma yong nas kho tsho bsus/

They walked to the tent, tarpaulin spread over a rope. And it was dark inside, and quiet. When they came near, a grayish mass stirred near the door and arose to person height. Ma came out to meet them.

kho mos [“]tshang ma gnyid song / a phyi yang gzhi nas gnyid song /[”] zhes bshad cing / de nas kho mos Thom mthong bas [“]khyod 'dir ji ltar 'byor ba yin/ khyod tsho dka' las 'drar 'phrad med dam/[”] zhes 'tshab 'tshub ngang dris/
“All sleepin',” she said. “Granma finally dozed off.” Then she saw it was Tom. “How'd you get here?” she demanded anxiously. “You ain't had no trouble?”
Thom gyis [“]nga tshos zhig gso byed thub song / tshang ma gra sgrig yin dus nga tsho 'gro chog chog yin/[”] zhes bshad/
“Got her fixed,” said Tom. “We're ready to go when the rest is.”
a mas [“]dkon mchog thugs rje can po/ nga rang 'gro rgyur brel 'tshab langs nas yod/ sa zhing gshin la ljang mdog can gyi sa cha der slebs na 'dod/ sa der myur du slebs na 'dod/[”] ces bshad/
“Thank the dear God for that,” Ma said. “I'm just a-twitterin' to go on. Wanta get where it's rich an' green. Wanta get there quick.”
a phas mgrin pa bsal [“]da sngon lam 'gro pa zhig gis zer na [...] /[”]
Pa cleared his throat. “Fella was jus' sayin'…”
Thom gyis kho'i dpung pa nas 'jus te hob 'then byas nas [“]mi des skad cha khyad mtshar 'dra bshad kyi 'dug nub rgyud du 'gro mkhan ha cang mang zer/[”] zhes bshad/
Tom grabbed his arm and yanked it. “Funny what he says,” Tom said. “Says they's lots a folks on the way.”

a mas mun nag khrod nas kho tsho'i gdong pa mthong thabs byas/ gur nang du ru the yis gnyid lam nas glo lu rgyag bzhin sngur ba 'then/ a mas [“]ngas kho tsho gtsang mar bkrus pa yin/ ngas sngon la blangs yong ba'i chus kho tsho bkrus pa yin la/ da dung phyi logs su chu chu zo 'ga' re khyod tshor khrus rgyag byed du bzhag yod/ lam nang du gtsang sbra zer ba 'di rtsa ba nas yong gi mi 'dug[”] ces bshad/

Ma peered through the darkness at them. Inside the tent Ruthie coughed and snorted in her sleep. “I washed 'em up,” Ma said. “Fust water we got enough of to give 'em a goin'-over. Lef' the buckets out for you fellas to wash too. Can't keep nothin' clean on the road.”
a phas [“]tshang ma nang du yod dam/[”] zhes dris/
“Ever'body in?” Pa asked.
[“]khon ne dang ro si sha ron gnyis ka ma gtogs gzhan pa tshang ma yod/ kho gnyis phyi logs su gnam sngon po'i 'og nas nyal rgyu yin zer la/ nang du ras gur 'og nas tsha ba che drags 'dug zer/[”]
“All but Connie an' Rosasharn. They went off to sleep in the open. Says it's too warm in under cover.”
a phas ma rangs pa'i tshul gyis [“]ro si sha ron 'di deng sang snying je chung nas je chung dang / rnam rtog je che nas je cher 'gro bzhin 'dug[”] ces bshad/
Pa observed querulously, “That Rosasharn is gettin' awful scary an' nimsy-mimsy.”
a mas [“]'di kho mor mngal chags thengs dang po red/ kho mo dang khon ne gnyis kas 'di thad la ha cang mthong chen byed bzhin 'dug skabs der khyod rang yang de 'dra ma yin nam/[”] zhes bshad/
“It's her first,” said Ma. “Her an' Connie sets a lot a store by it. You done the same thing.”

Thom gyis [“]da lta nga tsho 'gro rgyu yin/ mdun phyogs su cung tsam song nas lam 'gram du 'dug rgyu yin/ nga tshos khyod tsho ma mthong na khyod tshos nga tsho 'tshol rogs/ nga tsho lam gyi g.yas 'gram nas zhag sdod bya/[”] zhes bshad/
“We'll go now,” Tom said. “Pull off the road a little piece ahead. Watch out for us ef we don't see you. Be off right-han' side.”
[“]al 'di gar 'dug rgyu yin nam/[”]
“Al's stayin'?”
[“]red/ kho 'di gar bzhag nas a khu jon nga dang mnyam du 'gro rgyu byas yod/ gzim sa bde/ a ma/[”]
“Yeah. Leave Uncle John come with us. 'Night, Ma.”

kho tsho gnyid kyi klong la 'thim pa'i zhag sgar brgyud nas phar song / ras gur zhig gi mdun du me phung zhig dma' mor 'bar gyi 'dug la/ de'i 'gram du bud med cig gis rdza ma'i nang du zhogs zas skol bzhin yod cing / kho mos btso bzhin pa'i sran ma'i dri ma btsan zhing zhim/
They walked away through the sleeping camp. In front of one tent a low fitful fire burned and a woman watched a kettle that cooked early breakfast. The smell of the cooking beans was strong and fine.
kho tsho de'i 'gram brgyud nas 'gro skabs Thom gyis [“]'di sder ma gcig bza' rgyu byung na ang /[”] zhes gus zhabs dang bcas bshad/
“Like to have a plate a them,” Tom said politely as they went by.
bud med de'i gdong la 'dzum mdangs shig babs nas [“]'di da dung tshos mi 'dug ma gtogs zos na chog dang chog nam langs rjes shog dang /[”] zhes bshad/
The woman smiled. “They ain't done or you'd be welcome,” she said. “Come aroun' in the daybreak.”

Thom gyis [“]thugs rje che/ lcam lags/[”] zhes bshad cing / de nas kho dang kha se/ a khu jon bcas sgo khyams brgyud nas song / skabs der gnas bdag de da dung yang rkub stegs steng du bsdad 'dug kho'i snum sgron gyis sir sgra sgrog cing / sgron 'od 'khyom 'khyom du 'gul/ skyes pa gsum po de gar 'gro skabs kho'i mgo bo de phyogs su 'khor bas/ Thom gyis [“]khyod kyi rlangs snum rdzogs kyi 'dug[”] ces bshad/

“Thank you, ma'am,” Tom said. He and Casy and Uncle John walked by the porch. The proprietor still sat in his chair, and the lantern hissed and flared. He turned his head as the three went by. “Ya runnin' outa gas,” Tom said.
[“]o red/ gang ltar tshong sgo yang rgyag ran 'dug[”]
“Well, time to close up anyways.”

THE CARS OF THE migrant people crawled out of the side roads onto the great cross-country highway, and they took the migrant way to the West. In the daylight they scuttled like bugs to the westward; and as the dark caught them, they clustered like bugs near to shelter and to water. And because they were lonely and perplexed, because they had all come from a place of sadness and worry and defeat, and because they were all going to a new mysterious place, they huddled together; they talked together; they shared their lives, their food, and the things they hoped for in the new country. Thus it might be that one family camped near a spring, and another camped for the spring and for company, and a third because two families had pioneered the place and found it good. And when the sun went down, perhaps twenty families and twenty cars were there.

In the evening a strange thing happened: the twenty families became one family, the children were the children of all. The loss of home became one loss, and the golden time in the West was one dream. And it might be that a sick child threw despair into the hearts of twenty families, of a hundred people; that a birth there in a tent kept a hundred people quiet and awestruck through the night and filled a hundred people with the birth-joy in the morning. A family which the night before had been lost and fearful might search its goods to find a present for a new baby. In the evening, sitting about the fires, the twenty were one. They grew to be units of the camps, units of the evenings and the nights. A guitar unwrapped from a blanket and tuned- and the songs, which were all of the people, were sung in the nights. Men sang the words, and women hummed the tunes.

Every night a world created, complete with furniture- friends made and enemies established; a world complete with braggarts and with cowards, with quiet men, with humble men, with kindly men. Every night relationships that make a world, established; and every morning the world torn down like a circus.

At first the families were timid in the building and tumbling worlds, but gradually the technique of building worlds became their technique. Then leaders emerged, then laws were made, then codes came into being. And as the worlds moved westward they were more complete and better furnished, for their builders were more experienced in building them.

The families learned what rights must be observed- the right of privacy in the tent; the right to keep the past black hidden in the heart; the right to talk and to listen; the right to refuse help or to accept, to offer help or to decline it; the right of son to court and daughter to be courted; the right of the hungry to be fed; the rights of the pregnant and the sick to transcend all other rights.

In the morning the tents came down, the canvas was folded, the tent poles tied along the running board, the beds put in place on the cars, the pots in their places. And as the families moved westward, the technique of building up a home in the evening and tearing it down with the morning light became fixed; so that the folded tent was packed in one place, the cooking pots counted in their box. And as the cars moved westward, each member of the family grew into his proper place, grew into his duties; so that each member, old and young, had his place in the car; so that in the weary, hot evenings, when the cars pulled into the camping places, each member had his duty and went to it without instruction: children to gather wood, to carry water; men to pitch the tents and bring down the beds; women to cook the supper and to watch while the family fed. And this was done without command. The families, which had been units of which the boundaries were a house at night, a farm by day, changed their boundaries. In the long hot light, they were silent in the cars moving slowly westward; but at night they integrated with any group they found.

Thus they changed their social life- changed as in the whole universe only man can change. They were not farm men any more, but migrant men. And the thought, the planning, the long staring silence that had gone out to the fields, went now to the roads, to the distance, to the West. That man whose mind had been bound with acres lived with narrow concrete miles. And his thought and his worry were not any more with rainfall, with wind and dust, with the thrust of the crops. Eyes watched the tires, ears listened to the clattering motors, and minds struggled with oil, with gasoline, with the thinning rubber between air and road. Then a broken gear was tragedy. Then water in the evening was the yearning, and food over the fire. Then health to go on was the need and strength to go on, and spirit to go on. The wills thrust westward ahead of them, and fears that had once apprehended drought or flood now lingered with anything that might stop the westward crawling. The camps became fixed- each a short day's journey from the last.

lam thog tu khyim tshang 'ga' re brel 'tshab langs drags pa'i rkyen gyis nyin mtshan bstud nas 'gro la/ ngal gso rgyag dus rlangs 'khor bsdad nas thad kar rlangs 'khor nang nas nyal gyi yod/ de ltar nus shugs yod tshad nub rgyud 'grul bzhud kyi steng du bton nas/ gzhung lam dang da lta'i gnas skabs bcas las bros nas 'gro bzhin yod/ kho tsho nub rgyud du gzhis chags pa'i steng du 'dod rngam langs drags pa'i rkyen gyis/ kha nub phyogs su 'khor nas bang sgra sgrog pa'i rlangs 'khor gyi sgul 'phrul de gzhung lam steng du btsan gyis 'ded bzhin yod/

And on the road the panic overcame some of the families, so that they drove night and day, stopped to sleep in the cars, and drove on to the West, flying from the road, flying from movement. And these lusted so greatly to be settled that they set their faces into the West and drove toward it, forcing the clashing engines over the roads.

But most of the families changed and grew quickly into the new life. And when the sun went down…
zhag sdod byed sa zhig 'tshol ran 'dug o/ mdun phyogs su ras gur 'ga' re mthong rgyu 'dug
Time to look out for a place to stop. And- there's some tents ahead.

rlangs 'khor lam 'gram du yong nas bsdad/ gzhan dag tshos sngon nas de gar sa bzung yod pa'i rkyen gyis/ gus lugs nges can zhig tan tan dgos kyi yod/ de bas/ khyim tshang 'di'i dbu khrid du gyur pa'i skyes pa des mgo bo sge'u khang nas phyir bsrings/
The car pulled off the road and stopped, and because others were there first, certain courtesies were necessary. And the man, the leader of the family, leaned from the car.
nga tsho 'di gar bsdad nas zhag sgar brgyab na e chog los chog khyod tshang 'dug par dga' bsu zhu bzhin yod/ khyod tsho mnga' sde gang nas yin/ sa thag ring ar khan sa mnga' sde nas yong ba yin/
Can we pull up here an' sleep? Why, sure, be proud to have you. What State you from? Come all the way from Arkansas.
phar phyogs kyi ras gur bzhi pa'i nang gi mi de tsho yang ar khan sa mnga' sde nas yong ba red/ e red/ de nas dri ba gal chen de 'dri dgos/ 'thung chu ga 'dra 'dug
They's Arkansas people down that fourth tent. That so? And the great question, How's the water?
un/ bro ba zhim rgyu mi 'dug kyang / ga tshod dgos dgos shig 'dug ya/ bka' drin che/ bka' drin zhu mi dgos/
Well, she don't taste so good, but they's plenty. Well, thank ya. No thanks to me.

gus lugs 'di ni nges par du yod dgos pa zhig yin/ rlangs 'khor de ras gur gyi sne phyogs su yong nas de gar bsdad/ de nas rlangs 'khor gyi steng nas ngal dub kyis mnar ba'i mi rnams mar babs shing / rengs por gyur pa'i gzugs po rkyong skum byas/ de nas ras gur phub byung la/ byis pa tsho chu len du song ba dang / na gzhon tsho 'bud shing 'thu ru song / de nas me kha gsos byung la/ de'i steng du dgong tshigs skol rgyu'am yang na brngo rgyu bskyon/ sngon la yong mkhan tsho tshur yong nas pha yul sa phyogs gang yin 'dri res byed cing / mtshams la lar kha khar 'thor ba'i nye 'brel dang yang bskyar 'phrad pa yang 'byung gi yod/

But the courtesies had to be. The car lumbered over the ground to the end tent, and stopped. Then down from the car the weary people climbed, and stretched stiff bodies. Then the new tent sprang up; the children went for water and the older boys cut brush or wood. The fires started and supper was put on to boil or to fry. Early comers moved over, and States were exchanged, and friends and sometimes relatives discovered.
o/ og la ho ma mnga' sde nas yin e/ rdzong gang gi yin/ che ro khe rdzong nas yin/
Oklahoma, huh? What county? Cherokee.
o/ de gar nga'i nye 'brel zhig yod/ a len tshang ngo shes kyi e yod/ a len zer ba'i khyim tshang che ro khe rdzong gi ga sa gang du yod/ wi li si tshang e shes/ o/ de los shes/
Why, I got folks there. Know the Allens? They's Allens all over Cherokee. Know the Willises? Why, sure.

de ltar tshan pa gsar pa zhig grub byung / sa srod kyi mun pa yongs su ma rub pa'i sngon la kho tsho gzhi nas zhag sgar 'di'i khyim tshang gsar pa zhig tu gyur 'dug la/ khyim tshang re rer kho tsho'i skor gyi brda lan 'phrod/ kho tshang ni yongs kyis shes pa'i khyim tshang ya rabs shig yin 'dug
And a new unit was formed. The dusk came, but before the dark was down the new family was of the camp. A word had been passed with every family. They were known people- good people.
nga a len tshang la cha rgyus ha cang yod/ a len rgan pa sa'e mon a len dang kho'i chung ma gnyis ka kha ma mthun pa red/ kho mo che ro khe [3] yi rgyud pa yin la/ mdzes ma rta nag ma 'dra zhig yin/
I knowed the Allens all my life. Simon Allen, ol' Simon, had trouble with his first wife. She was part Cherokee. Purty as- as a black colt.
[3] che ro khe/ [Cherokee] ste/ [1.] a ri'i shar lho'i phyogs su gnas pa'i rigs kyi tsho khag cig [2.] og la ho ma mnga' sde'i nang gi rdzong zhig

red ya/ sa'e mon gzhon pa de ru Dol h+phi tshang gi bu mo zhig la gnyen sgrig byas pa ma red dam/ ngas bsam na de red/ kho tsho e ni Di grong rdal du song nas gzhis bcas pa red la/ 'tsho ba yag po 'khyongs 'dug dngos gnas yag po 'khyongs 'dug
Sure, an' young Simon, he married a Rudolph, didn't he? That's what I thought. They went to live in Enid an' done well- real well.
kho ni a len tshang gi lam lhong byung mkhan gcig pu de red/ rlangs 'khor zhig gso khang zhig yod/
Only Allen that ever done well. Got a garage.

'thung chu blangs shing / 'bud shing gtubs rjes/ byis pa tsho ras gur tsho'i khrod nas sems chung ngang 'khyam nyul byas shing / kho tshos grogs po sgrig pa'i ched du spyang grung ldan pa'i thabs lam re spyad/ bu zhig bu gzhan pa zhig dang nye sar slebs skabs kho 'gro mtshams bzhag nas thang gi rdo ba zhig la bltas/ de nas rdo ba de lag tu blangs yong nas zhib lta byas/ khos de'i steng du mchil ma btab nas 'phur 'phur byas nas bu gzhan pa der mtshar snang bslangs/ khyod kyis ci zhig rnyed song /

When the water was carried and the wood cut, the children walked shyly, cautiously among the tents. And they made elaborate acquaintanceship gestures. A boy stopped near another boy and studied a stone, picked it up, examined it closely, spat on it, and rubbed it clean and inspected it until he forced the other to demand, What you got there?
bu des cung snang med kyi rnam pa bstan nas/ ci yang ma red/ rdo ba zhig red zer/
And casually, Nothin'. Jus' a rock.
des na khyod kyis de la ci'i phyir zhib lta byas pa yin/
Well, what you lookin' at it like that for?
ngas 'di'i nang nas gser mthong byung /
Thought I seen gold in it.
khyod kyis ji ltar shes/ gser de rdo nang du yod dus ser po min/ de nag po red/
How'd you know? Gold ain't gold, it's black in a rock.
de los yin/ de tshang mas shes kyi yod/
Sure, ever'body knows that.
ngas bltas na de lcags gter ser po yin rgyu red/ khyod kyis de gser red bsam pa red/
I bet it's fool's gold, an' you figgered it was gold.
de 'dra ma red/ rgyu mtshan ni nga'i a phar gser mang po rnyed myong yod la/ khos nga la gser la lta stangs bslabs myong /
That ain't so, 'cause Pa, he's foun' lots a gold an' he tol' me how to look.
khyod kyis gser rdog rdog rdo pha bong 'dra zhig lag tu len 'dod 'dug gam/
How'd you like to pick up a big ol' piece a gold?

skyag pa/ de las sngon chad mthong myong tsam yang med pa'i byi ril zhig yod na snyam/ nga la skad cha btsog pa bshad du mi 'jug mod/ 'on kyang / rgyun par kha nas shor 'gro/ nga yang de mtshungs yin/ chu mig yod sar 'gro/
Sa-a-ay! I'd git the bigges' old son-a-bitchin' piece a candy you ever seen. I ain't let to swear, but I do, anyways. Me too. Le's go to the spring.

bu mo chung chung tsho phan tshun thug tshe so sor ga 'dra snyan grags yod skor dang / ga 'dra'i re ba yod skor bshad/ bud med tshos thab ka'i mtha' na las ka byed kyi 'dug cing / kho tsho khyim mi'i grod khog tu btsang rgyu'i lto chas gra sgrig byed par brel/ lag tu sgor mo cung zad yod tshe phag sha yod sa'i za ma gra sgrig byed cing / phag sha dang zhog khog tsong ril mnyam du bzo nges/ da dung ho lan rgyal khab kyi lugs srol ltar slang bsregs sob gor dang / yang na ma rmos lo tog gi bag leb sreg nges shing / de'i steng du ldur khu mang po zhig blug nges/ yang min na sha rtsib dang rtsib ma btso srid la/ da dung lcags krin nang du nag cing kha ba'i ja nag khu skol srid/ gal srid lag tu sgor mo srab mo zhig ma gtogs lhag med tshe/ snum thigs tsam gyi nang du phye ldur sreg srid la/ bsregs zin pa'i phye ldur bag leb de sob sob dang smug po yin nges/ de'i steng du yang bskyar snum thigs 'ga' re 'bab tu 'jug rgyu red/

And young girls found each other and boasted shyly of their popularity and their prospects. The women worked over the fire, hurrying to get food to the stomachs of the family- pork if there was money in plenty, pork and potatoes and onions. Dutch-oven biscuits or cornbread, and plenty of gravy to go over it. Side-meat or chops and a can of boiled tea, black and bitter. Fried dough in drippings if money was slim, dough fried crisp and brown and the drippings poured over it.

khyim tshang ha cang phyug po dang / yang na sgor mo spyod mi shes pa'i khyim tshang ha cang glen pa tshos rgyun du krin bcug sran ma dang krin bcug kham bu/ thum brgyab bag leb dang bzo grwa nas bzos pa'i skyo bag sogs bza' la/ bza' btung 'di 'dra'i phun sum tshogs po de tshang mas shes par byas nas zos na mi 'grig pas/ kho tshos rang nyid kyi gur nang nas lkog bza' byed/ de ltar byas na'ang / bag zan bsregs ma bza' bzhin pa'i byis pa tshos tsha po bzo bzhin pa'i sran ma'i dri ma tshor nas ma dga' ba'i rnam 'gyur ston gyi yod/

Those families which were very rich or very foolish with their money ate canned beans and canned peaches and packaged bread and bakery cake; but they ate secretly, in their tents, for it would not have been good to eat such fine things openly. Even so, children eating their fried dough smelled the warming beans and were unhappy about it.
dgong tshigs zos tshar nas sder ma tsho chu nang du bshal zhing lag ras kyis phyis tshar dus/ sa srod kyi mun pa slebs yod pas/ skyes pa tsho pus btsugs su bsdad nas gleng mol byed mgo rtsom/
When supper was over and the dishes dipped and wiped, the dark had come, and then the men squatted down to talk.
kho tshos shul du bskyur pa'i rang nyid kyi sa zhing gi skor gleng / kho tshos ci'i phyir 'di 'dra zhig 'byung bzhin pa dngos gnas ha mi go zhes gleng / gzhi rim gyi sa zhing rbad de brlags song /
And they talked of the land behind them. I don't know what it's coming to, they said. The country's spoilt.
sa zhing yang bskyar je legs su phyir 'gro nges/ gnad don ni de dus nga tsho de gar yod rgyu ma red/
It'll come back though, on'y we won't be there.
kho tsho'i sems su/ gcig byas na kho tshos shes med tshor med ngang nas sdig pa zhig bsags pas/ da lta rnam smin 'khor ba yin rgyu red snyam/
Maybe, they thought, maybe we sinned some way we didn't know about.

mi zhig gis nga la bshad myong / kho srid gzhung gi las byed pa red/ khos zer na 'di ni sa rgyu nyams song bas red zer la/ srid gzhung gi mi des zer na gal srid nga tshos zhing gi sul ris 'phred rgyug gis rmos na da gzod sa rgyu mi nyams zer/ 'on kyang / de ltar tshod lta byed mkhan gcig kyang ma byung la/ sa bdag gsar pa des kyang sul ris 'phred rgyug gis rmo yi mi 'dug khos btod pa'i rmos shur la yang le dbar bzhi tsam yod pas khos gang du'ang rmo mtshams mi 'jog la/ ston pa ye shu kho'i mdun du bzhugs bsdad rung khos bskor nas mi 'gro thag chod red/

Fella says to me, gov'ment fella, an' he says, she's gullied up on ya. Gov'ment fella. He says, if ya plowed 'cross the contour, she won't gully. Never did have no chance to try her. An' the new super' ain't plowin' 'cross the contour. Runnin' a furrow four miles long that ain't stoppin' or goin' aroun' Jesus Christ Hisself.

kho tshos rang khyim gyi skor bshad dus skad mgo ha cang dma'/ nged tshang gi rlung 'thag khang pa'i 'og tu bsil khang chung chung zhig yod la/ de ni 'o mar kha spri chags sa dang / chu kub 'jog sar spyod kyi yod/ nyin gung tsha gdug me ltar 'bar ba'i skabs su yang khang pa de'i nang bsil lhang lhang yin la/ der bzhag yod pa'i chu kub cig gshag nas zos na/ de grang mo yin drags pa'i rkyen gyis kha nang la 'khyag pas na zug gtong / chu kub kyi pags pa'i ngos su chu thigs thar thor du 'gril gyi yod/

And they spoke softly of their homes: They was a little cool-house under the win'mill. Use' ta keep milk in there ta cream up, an' watermelons. Go in there midday when she was hotter'n a heifer, an' she'd be jus' as cool, as cool as you'd want. Cut open a melon in there an' she'd hurt your mouth, she was so cool. Water drippin' down from the tank.

kho tshos rang nyid la 'phrad pa'i chag sgo'i skor yang bshad/ nga la char le zer ba'i spun chung zhig yod la/ kho'i skra ni ma rmos lo tog ltar ser po yin/ kho 'tshar longs byung nas pho gsar du gyur yod la/ mdzub gnon rlung sbreng ha cang yag po dkrol shes/ nyin zhig la khos zhing nang du shal ba 'drud du song / shal bas spo tho snyoms por bzo bzhin pa'i skabs der glo bur du sbrul zhig sngon nas 'khyug pas/ kho'i rta 'drogs nas shal ba de char le'i steng du drud nas bros shing / shal ba'i rtse mo khag kho'i nang khrol dang grod pa'i nang du zug cing / de dag gis kho'i ngo gdong rbad de bkog song / a dkon mchog mkhyen/ kho tshos ma 'ongs pa'i skor la gleng mol byas/ de phyogs su slebs na ga 'dra zhig yin nam/

They spoke of their tragedies: Had a brother Charley, hair as yella as corn, an' him a growed man. Played the 'cordeen nice too. He was harrowin' one day an' he went up to clear his lines. Well, a rattlesnake buzzed an' them horses bolted an' the harrow went over Charley, an' the points dug into his guts an' his stomach, an' they pulled his face off an'- God Almighty! They spoke of the future: Wonder what it's like out there?

red ya/ 'dra par gyi steng nas bltas na sa cha ha cang yag ngas de ga'i sa cha mdzes shing lta na sdug pa zhig gi 'dra par mthong myong / de'i steng du star sdong dang lum 'bras yod cing / de'i rgyab phyogs kyi ha cang thag nye sa ru rtse mo gangs kyis g.yogs pa'i ri bo mthon po zhig 'dug la/ de ni dngos gnas bltas na yid du 'ong ba zhig red/ nga tshor de gar las ka las rgyu rnyed pa yin na/ de nas gnad don ci yang yod rgyu ma red/ sa cha de ru dgun kha yang gnam gshis mi grang bas byis pa tsho slob grwar 'gro skabs 'khyag sdug myong mi dgos/ ngas rang nyid kyi byis pa tshor bdag skyong yag po byed rgyu yin la/ de nas bzung slob thun chad du 'jug rgyu min/ ngas yi ge klog yag po shes mod/ 'on kyang / dpe klog la byang chub pa tsho lta bu'i spro snang med/

Well, the pitchers sure do look nice. I seen one where it's hot an' fine, an' walnut trees an' berries; an' right behind, close as a mule's ass to his withers, they's a tall up mountain covered with snow. That was a pretty thing to see. If we can get work it'll be fine. Won't have no cold in the winter. Kids won't freeze on the way to school. I'm gonna take care my kids don't miss no more school. I can read good, but it ain't no pleasure to me like with a fella that's used to it.

gcig byas na skyes pa gcig gis rang nyid kyi rgyud drug sgra snyan 'khur nas gur sgo ru bud nas/ sgam zhig gi steng du bsdad nas sgra snyan dkrol mgo rtsom srid la/ sgar nang gi mi gzhan pa tshang ma dal mor kho'i phyogs su yong nas kho'i mtha' ru 'tshog nges/
And perhaps a man brought out his guitar to the front of his tent. And he sat on a box to play, and everyone in the camp moved slowly in toward him, drawn in toward him.

spyir mi mang pos sgra snyan cung tsam re rdung shes mod/ 'on kyang / skyes pa 'di ni rdung mkhan byang cha can zhig red/ rgyud skud kyi sgra dbyangs zab mor rdung dus snyan 'jebs kyi dbyangs 'gros kyis rgyud skud kyi steng du gom stabs sgyur zhing / sra zhing sbom pa'i mdzub mo khag gis sgra snyan gyi gzhung rta'i steng du zhabs bro 'khrab/ khos sgra snyan rdung bzhin rdung bzhin mi rnams dal mor kho'i phyogs su yong zhing / mjug mthar mi tshogs kyis kho'i mtha' yongs su dam por bskor/ de nas khos [“]sgor zur gcig gi sring bal dang / sgor zur bzhi yi sha[”] zhes pa'i glu de blangs pas/ gor gor du 'dus pa'i mi tshogs kyis kho dang lhan du blangs/ de nas khos [“]bu mo tsho/ khyod tshos ci'i phyir skra lo bregs pa yin/[”] zhes pa blangs pas/ mi tshogs kyis mnyam du blangs/ de nas khos [“]nga Theg sa si dang kha 'bral rgyu yin/[”] zhes pa'i bred sha langs pa'i glu gzhas de blangs/ glu gzhas 'di ni si phen gyi mi a ri'i gling chen du ma slebs gong nas bzung yod pa'i glu gzhas shig yin la/ de dus de'i glu tshig ni in Di'i skad yin/

Many men can chord a guitar, but perhaps this man was a picker. There you have something- the deep chords beating, beating, while the melody runs on the strings like little footsteps. Heavy hard fingers marching on the frets. The man played and the people moved slowly in on him until the circle was closed and tight, and then he sang “Ten-Cent Cotton and Forty-Cent Meat.” And the circle sang softly with him. And he sang “Why Do You Cut Your Hair, Girls?” And the circle sang. He wailed the song, “I'm Leaving Old Texas,” that eerie song that was sung before the Spaniards came, only the words were Indian then.

da lta mi tshogs 'di ngo bo gcig dang cha shas gcig tu gyur yod/ kho tsho'i mig zung nang du bkug nas/ sems pa rnams yul dus gzhan pa zhig tu 'khyams la/ sems nang gi sdug bsngal yod tshad gnas skabs ring ngal gso brgyab nas gnyid la rol/ de nas [“]meg le si Thi'i skyo glu/[”] zhes pa yang blangs pa dang / de rjes lo lon tsho'i 'dod pa skong ba'i ched du [“]ye shus bdag la khong gi mdun du shog zer/[”] zhes pa yang blangs/ glu gzhas kyis byis pa tshor gnyid phab pas/ kho tsho so so'i gur nang du nyal du phyin song la/ glu gzhas khag kho tsho'i rmi lam du 'dzul/

And now the group was welded to one thing, one unit, so that in the dark the eyes of the people were inward, and their minds played in other times, and their sadness was like rest, like sleep. He sang the “McAlester Blues” and then, to make up for it to the older people, he sang “Jesus Calls Me to His Side.” The children drowsed with the music and went into the tents to sleep, and the singing came into their dreams.
yud tsam rjes nas/ lag tu sgra snyan bzung ba'i skyes pa de yar langs nas kha nas glal kha byed bzhin/ yul mi tsho/ gzim sa bde/ zhes bshad/
And after a while the man with the guitar stood up and yawned. Good night, folks, he said.
tshang mas/ ya/ gzim sa bde/ zhes kha mug mug tu lan btab/
And they murmured, Good night to you.

mi re res rang nyid kyis sgra snyan cung zad re rdung shes na ang 'dod la/ 'di ni dngos gnas spro skyid ldan pa zhig red 'dod/ de nas mi tshogs rnams rang rang sa nas nyal du phyin song la/ zhag sgar de 'jam thing nger gyur/ 'ug pa tsho kho tsho'i mgo thog nas 'phur mgo brtsams song la/ spyang khyi tshos kyang thag ring nas ca co 'don mgo brtsams/ sre mong tsho sgar nang du yong nas zas lhag 'thung lhag re e rnyed lta bzhin 'dug la/ sngangs sa skrag sa med pa'i sre mong 'di tsho nga rgyal gyis 'gying bzhin 'gro/ mtshan mo'i mun pa phar la phyin nas zhogs pa'i skya rengs tshur la slebs pa dang lhan du/ bud med cig gur nang nas bud de me kha gsos shing 'tshig ja bskol/ de nas skyes pa tsho sgor bud byung la/ skya rengs kyi snang ba'i khrod du skad mgo dma' mos gleng mol byed/ kho tshos kho lo ra Do gtsang po brgal rjes bye thang du slebs pa yin zhes gleng mol byed/ bye thang nas sems chung byed dgos shing / de gar lus mi rung / chu mang tsam 'khur sdod/ gal srid bye thang nas lus 'dra song na/

And each wished he could pick a guitar, because it is a gracious thing. Then the people went to their beds, and the camp was quiet. And the owls coasted overhead, and the coyotes gabbled in the distance, and into the camp skunks walked, looking for bits of food- waddling, arrogant skunks, afraid of nothing. The night passed, and with the first streak of dawn the women came out of the tents, built up the fires, and put the coffee to boil. And the men came out and talked softly in the dawn. When you cross the Colorado river, there's the desert, they say. Look out for the desert. See you don't get hung up. Take plenty water, case you get hung up.
nga rang gis dgong mor 'gro rgyu'i 'char gzhi 'then yod/ ngas kyang de ltar bsam yod/ nyin dkar la dkon mchog ye shu yin rung gson sreg byed rgyu red/
I'm gonna take her at night. Me too: She'll cut the living Jesus outa you.

khyim tshang tshos za ma mgyogs por zos shing / de nas sder ma rnams chu bshal byas nas lag ras kyis phyis/ de nas gur rnams mar phab song / skabs der tshang mar brel 'tshab cig langs yod/ nyi ma ri las shar dus sgar shul de stong pa red la/ shul du lus pa ni mi rnams kyis shul du bskyur pa'i gad snyigs kho na red/ de ltar sgar shul 'di dgong mo gsar pa zhig tu 'jig rten gsar pa zhig skrun par gra sgrig ang gsar red/

The families ate quickly, and the dishes were dipped and wiped. The tents came down. There was a rush to go. And when the sun arose, the camping place was vacant, only a little litter left by the people. And the camping place was ready for a new world in a new night.
'on kyang / gzhung lam gyi steng du yul mi gnas spo pa'i rlangs 'khor mang po 'bu srin bzhin gog nur byed bzhin 'dug la/ ar 'dam gyi gzhung lam phra mo de mdun phyogs su ring por bsrings yod/
But along the highway the cars of the migrant people crawled out like bugs, and the narrow concrete miles stretched ahead.
le'u bco brgyad pa/

jo Di tshang gis mtho sgang gi ri bo dang ri phran mang po brgal nas meg se kho gsar pa'i ri khul du bslebs shing / rim bzhin a ri zon na mnga' sde'i sa mtho'i ri khul du 'gos/ ri tshogs kyi bar gseng nas kho tshos mar phyogs na yod pa'i phen Thed bye thang la bltas/ de nas mtha' srung dmag mi zhig gis kho tsho bkag

THE JOAD FAMILY MOVED slowly westward, up into the mountains of New Mexico, past the pinnacles and pyramids of the upland. They climbed into the high country of Arizona, and through a gap they looked down on the Painted Desert. A border guard stopped them.
[“]khyod tsho gang du 'gro bzhin yod/[”]
“Where you going?”
Thom gyis [“]kha li h+phor ne ya la 'gro rgyu yin/[”] zhes lan btab/
“To California,” said Tom.
[“]khyod tsho a ri zon na mnga' sde ru ga tsam la sdod rtsis yod/[”]
“How long you plan to be in Arizona?”
[“]gzhung lam brgyud nas 'gro ba ma gtogs sdod rtsis med/[”]
“No longer'n we can get acrost her.”
[“]rtsi shing dang sngo ldum rigs 'khyer med dam/[”]
“Got any plants?”
[“]de 'dra 'khyer med/[”]
“No plants.”
[“]ngas khyod tsho'i ca lag sngog bsher byed dgos/[”]
“I ought to look your stuff over.”
[“]nga tshos dngos gnas rtsi shing dang sngo ldum rigs ci yang 'khyer med/[”] mtha' srung dmag mi des kho tsho'i rlung 'gog shel sgo'i steng du sbyar byang chung chung zhig sbyar/
“I tell you we ain't got no plants.” The guard put a little sticker on the windshield.
[“]ya/ des na song / 'on kyang / lam nas ma bsdad par yag po song a/[”]
“O.K. Go ahead, but you better keep movin'.”

They drove all night, and came to the mountains in the night. And they crawled the jagged ramparts in the night, and their dim lights flickered on the pale stone walls of the road. They passed the summit in the dark and came slowly down in the late night, through the shattered stone debris of Oatman; and when the daylight came they saw the Colorado river below them. And although they were dead weary and the morning heat was growing, they stopped.

[“]ya/ khyod rang dngos gnas shes 'dod mkhan zhig yin na/ nga yang skad cha tshur la dris na dris lan phar na ster rgyur dga' mkhan zhig yin/ yul de dngos gnas sa cha yag po red/ 'on kyang / sa de snga sa nas gzhan gyis sger bdag byas zin/ khyod tshos bye thang brgal te b+he kher si h+phild grong khyer bskor nas song na da gzod sa cha der slebs pa yin la/ de ni shing 'bras ldum ra dang rgun 'brum ra ba sogs kyis gang ba'i yul lung zhig red/ 'di ni sngon chad mthong myong tsam yang med pa'i mdzes shing lta na sdug pa'i yul lung zhig red/ de nas khyod kyis rim bzhin khod snyoms pa'i sa zhing dang / sa zhing dang nye sa'i rgyug chu mthong yong / 'on kyang / sa zhing de dag stong par bskyur yod la/ khyod la de'i gang nas sa nag lag mthil tsam yang bed spyod pa'i thob thang med/ de ni zhing phyugs spyi gnyer khang la dbang ba red/ kho tshos de'i steng du lo tog 'debs 'dod med pas sa zhing de dag de ltar stong par bskyur yod/ gal srid khyod rang nang du song nas ma rmos lo tog rdog gcig btab na/ kho tshos khyod rang btson du bskyal rgyu red/[”]

“Well, if you truly wanta know, I'm a fella that's asked questions an' give her some thought. She's a nice country. But she was stole a long time ago. From some little distance there came the sound of the beginning meeting, a sing-song chant of exhortation. The words were not clear, only the tone. The voice rose and fell, and went higher at each rise. Now a response filled in the pause, and the exhortation went up with a tone of triumph, and a growl of power came into the voice. It swelled and paused, and a growl came into the response. And now gradually the sentences of exhortation shortened, grew sharper, like commands; and into the responses came a complaining note. The rhythm quickened. Male and female voices had been one tone, but now in the middle of a response one woman's voice went up and up in a wailing cry, wild and fierce, like the cry of a beast; and a deeper woman's voice rose up beside it, a baying voice, and a man's voice traveled up the scale in the howl of a wolf. The exhortation stopped, and only the feral howling came from the tent, and with it a thudding sound on the earth. Ma shivered. Rose of Sharon's breath was panting and short, and the chorus of howls went on so long it seemed that lungs must burst.

Pa called, “Good-by, Mister and Mis' Wilson.” There was no answer from the tent. Tom started the engine and the truck lumbered away. And as they crawled up the rough road toward Needles and the highway, Ma looked back. Wilson stood in front of his tent, staring after them, and his hat was in his hand. The sun fell full on his face. Ma waved her hand at him, but he did not respond. Tom kept the truck in second gear over the rough road, to protect the springs. At Needles he drove into a service station, checked the worn tires for air, checked the spares tied to the back. He had the gas tank filled, and he bought two five-gallon cans of gasoline and a two-gallon can of oil. He filled the radiator, begged a map, and studied it.

THE TRUCK took the road and moved up the long hill, through the broken, rotten rock. The engine boiled very soon and Tom slowed down and took it easy. Up the long slope, winding and twisting through dead country, burned white and gray, and no hint of life in it. Once Tom stopped for a few moments to let the engine cool, and then he traveled on. They topped the pass while the sun was still up, and looked down on the desert- black cinder mountains in the distance, and the yellow sun reflected on the gray desert. The little starved bushes, sage and greasewood, threw bold shadows on the sand and bits of rock. The glaring sun was straight ahead. Tom held his hand before his eyes to see at all. They passed the crest and coasted down to cool the engine. They coasted down the long sweep to the floor of the desert, and the fan turned over to cool the water in the radiator. In the driver's seat, Tom and Al and Pa, and Winfield on Pa's knee, looked into the bright descending sun, and their eyes were stony, and their brown faces were damp with perspiration. The burnt land and the black, cindery hills broke the even distance and made it terrible in the reddening light of the setting sun.
