ONCE CALIFORNIA BELONGED to Mexico and its land to Mexicans; and a horde of tattered feverish Americans poured in. And such was their hunger for land that they took the land- stole Sutter's land, Guerrero's land, took the grants and broke them up and growled and quarreled over them, those frantic hungry men; and they guarded with guns the land they had stolen. They put up houses and barns, they turned the earth and planted crops. And these things were possession, and possession was ownership.

skabs de dus/ meg se kho'i mi rnams ni stobs shugs chung zhing grod khog rgyags yod cing / kho tsho la sa zhing thad du a ri pa tsho lta bu'i 'dod rngam med pa'i rkyen gyis kho tshos btsan 'dzul 'di 'gog thabs ma byung /
The Mexicans were weak and fled. They could not resist, because they wanted nothing in the world as frantically as the Americans wanted land.

de nas dus tshod yun gyis 'das pa dang chabs cig tu/ btsan bzung mkhan 'di tsho yang rim bzhin btsan bzung mkhan ma yin par sa bdag tu gyur/ kho tsho'i phru gu tsho sa gzhis 'di'i steng nas 'tshar longs byung nas rang nyid kyi phru gu bskyangs/ de ltar bkres ltogs zer ba de kho tsho dang gtan du bral zhing / sa zhing dang 'thung chu/ de'i steng gi mkha' dbyings dwangs mo/ sa steng du shig shig tu skye yong ba'i rtsi shing / sa 'og tu ljid tig tig gis zug yong ba'i rtsad pa bcas la so 'cha' zhing mchi ma shor bzhin gcan gzan ltar ham pa langs pa de ni deng sang kho tsho'i dran pa'i yul nas yongs su yal/ da lta longs spyod 'di dag kho tshor yongs su 'dzoms yod pa'i rkyen gyis/ deng sang kho tshos 'di dag gi byung rabs rtsa ba nas shes kyi med/ deng sang kho tshor sa zhing gshin po leb mo re dang / de dag rmo ba'i 'od krig krig gi thong gshol bcas kyi don du grod khog la na zug gtong ba'i rngam sems de med la/ sa bon dang bar snang du gshog 'gyur byed pa'i rlung 'thag 'khor lo bcas la yang 'dod rngam med/ deng sang kho tsho mun nag khrod nas mal las langs mi dgos la/ da dung gnyid la rol ba'i bya bye'u'i ca co la yang nyan mi dgos/ de bzhin/ khang pa'i phyi nang gi grang rlung khrod nas zhing las byed du 'gro ched zhogs pa'i 'od snang dang por yang sgug mi dgos/

Then, with time, the squatters were no longer squatters, but owners; and their children grew up and had children on the land. And the hunger was gone from them, the feral hunger, the gnawing, tearing hunger for land, for water and earth and the good sky over it, for the green thrusting grass, for the swelling roots. They had these things so completely that they did not know about them any more. They had no more the stomach-tearing lust for a rich acre and a shining blade to plow it, for seed and a windmill beating its wings in the air. They arose in the dark no more to hear the sleepy birds' first chittering, and the morning wind around the house while they waited for the first light to go out to the dear acres.

bya rim 'di dag ni 'das zin pa'i byung ba tsam yin la/ deng sang 'bru rigs de dngul lor la rtsi bzhin yod la/ sa zhing ni ma rtsa dang skyed ka'i rin thang steng 'jal gyi yod pa dang / 'bru rigs rnams sa la ma btab gong nas nyos zin la btsongs kyang zin pa red/ de bas/ deng sang lo nyes dang than pa/ chu log bcas kyis tshe srog gcig gi nang gi tshe srog phra mo zhig mtshon gyi med par/ des dngul lor gyi gyong gun mtshon gyi yod/ de nas rim bzhin kho tsho'i brtse ba dang snying rje de dngul lor dang lhan du je srab tu gyur song la/ bu lon gyi skyed ka'i khrod nas kho tsho'i hur sems kyang rim bzhin kho tsho dang thag je ring du gyur/ mjug mthar kho tsho tshang ma zhing pa ma yin par 'bru rigs kyi tshong khang chung chung re gnyer mkhan dang / thon skyed ma thub gong nas thon rdzas btsong dgos pa'i thon skyed pa ru gyur/ de nas tshong gnyer la mi mkhas pa'i zhing pa tsho'i sa zhing rnams tshong gnyer la mkhas pa tsho'i lag tu shor/ de dus gal srid khyod rang tshong gnyer la ma mkhas na/ khyod rang sa zhing dang rmo 'debs la ga tshod dga' ba'i zhing pa zhig yin rung khyod rang 'tsho thabs bral ba yin/ de ltar rim bzhin sa zhing tshang ma tshong pa tshor dbang bar gyur cing / kho tsho'i sa zhing gi sa rgya je che nas je cher gyur pa dang chabs cig tu/ tshong pa'i kha grangs je nyung nas je nyung du gyur pa red/

These things were lost, and crops were reckoned in dollars, and land was valued by principal plus interest, and crops were bought and sold before they were planted. Then crop failure, drought, and flood were no longer little deaths within life, but simple losses of money. And all their love was thinned with money, and all their fierceness dribbled away in interest until they were no longer farmers at all, but little shopkeepers of crops, little manufacturers who must sell before they can make. Then those farmers who were not good shopkeepers lost their land to good shopkeepers. No matter how clever, how loving a man might be with earth and growing things, he could not survive if he were not also a good shopkeeper. And as time went on, the business men had the farms, and the farms grew larger, but there were fewer of them.

da lta zhing las de bzo las su gyur cing / bdag po tsho ro man gyi lam lugs la zhugs yod/ 'on kyang / kho tshos lam lugs de ci 'dra zhig yin pa shes kyi med/ de nas kho tshos bran g.yog nang 'dren byas/ 'on kyang / kho tshos de dag la rgya nag pa/ 'jar pan pa/ meg se kho pa/ h+phi li phin pa zhes 'bod pa las bran g.yog ces mi 'bod/ tshong pa tshos mi 'di rigs la kha zas su sran ma dang 'bras skya las gzhan pa ci yang mi dgos zhes bshad/

Now farming became industry, and the owners followed Rome, although they did not know it. They imported slaves, although they did not call them slaves: Chinese, Japanese, Mexicans, Filipinos. They live on rice and beans, the business men said. They don't need much.

kho tshor mang po mi mkho la/ gla cha mthon po sprad rung kho tshos de ji ltar spyod dgos kyang mi shes/ rgyu mtshan ni/ ltos dang / kho tsho'i 'tsho ba rol stangs la ltos dang shes yong / kho tsho'i bza' stangs 'thung stangs la ltos dang shes yong / gal srid kho tshor byed rgyu las rgyu mang na thad kar rgyal khongs las phyir phud btang chog
They wouldn't know what to do with good wages. Why, look how they live. Why, look what they eat. And if they get funny- deport them.

sa zhing rnams rgyun chad med par je che nas je cher gyur cing / sa bdag gi kha grangs je nyung nas je nyung du gyur/ deng sang sa zhing thog tu yod pa'i zhing pa'i kha grangs ni dngos gnas nyam nga ba zhig red/ nang 'dren byas pa'i zhing bran rnams la gcar rdung skor gsum byas te 'jigs snang bslangs shing zas sdug gtad pa'i rkyen gyis/ 'ga' re ni rang khyim du phyir log 'gro la/ yang 'ga' re ni gtum por 'gyur ba yin/ gtum por 'gyur mkhan tshos dmar gsod dang rgyang phud myong gi yod/ de ltar sa zhing rnams je che nas je che dang / sa bdag gi kha grangs je nyung nas je nyung du gyur/

And all the time the farms grew larger and the owners fewer. And there were pitifully few farmers on the land any more. And the imported serfs were beaten and frightened and starved until some went home again, and some grew fierce and were killed or driven from the country. And the farms grew larger and the owners fewer.

de nas zhing nang du 'debs pa'i lo tog la'ang 'gyur ba byung / shing 'bras sdong pos 'bru rigs kyi tshab byas yod la/ zhing sa dma' sa tshang mar rjen tshal dang me tog pad tshal/ lga mngar dang zhog khog sogs 'dzam gling gi yul gru gang sar 'dren rgyu'i sngo ldum btab yod cing / 'di dag ni lus po sgur sgur gyis bdag skyong byed dgos pa'i lo tog yin/ zor ba dang thong gshol/ kha dbrag sogs ni gzugs po drang mor bsdad nas spyod chog mod/ 'on kyang / bstar pa dang bstar par btab pa'i rjen tshal gyi bar du zhing pa rnams ni srin 'bu zhig dang 'dra bar gog nas 'gro dgos/ bstar bar bsgrigs pa'i sring bal sdong po'i gseng du zhing pa tshos sked pa mar la sgur nas/ khug ma ring po drud nas 'gro dgos la/ me tog pad tshal gyi zhing nang du zhing pa tsho ni 'gyod gshags byed mkhan gyi nyes can zhig dang 'dra bar pus mo'i steng du nur nas 'gro dgos/

And the crops changed. Fruit trees took the place of grain fields, and vegetables to feed the world spread out on the bottoms: lettuce, cauliflower, artichokes, potatoes- stoop crops. A man may stand to use a scythe, a plow, pitchfork; but he must crawl like a bug between the rows of lettuce, he must bend his back and pull his long bag between the cotton rows, he must go on his knees like a penitent across a cauliflower patch.

de ltar rim bzhin/ zhing bdag tshos rang nyid kyi sa zhing gi steng du zhing las mi byed par shog bu'i steng du zhing las byed kyi yod cing / kho tshos sa zhing dang de'i dri ma/ de'i reg bya bcas rim bzhin brjed 'gro yi yod/ kho tshos sa zhing 'di rang nyid la dbang ba kho na dran gyi yod la/ sa zhing 'di'i steng nas rang nyid la ci zhig thob pa dang / rang nyid kyis ci zhig shor ba kho na dran gyi yod/ zhing sa 'ga' re che drags pa'i rkyen gyis/ de mi gcig gi sems ngor shong dka' ba'i tshod du slebs yod la/ de che drags pa'i rkyen gyis/ de'i steng gi yong 'bab dang 'gro song / skyed ka bcas brtsis nas rtsis gnyer pa tsho'i lus shugs 'dzad kyi yod la/ de che drags pa'i rkyen gyis/ de'i sa gshis tshod lta dang sa rgyu slar gso tshang ma rdzas 'gyur la brten yod cing / de che drags pa'i rkyen gyis/ sa zhing steng du sgur sgur gyis las la brel ba'i las ka pa tshos rang lus kyis theg tshod kyis 'phag 'tshag mgyogs po rgyag gi yod med la lta rtog byed pa'i ched du ched dmigs las dpon bskos yod/ tshad gzhi 'di 'dra zhig la slebs dus da gzod zhing pa zhig tshong gnyer mkhan du gyur pa yin la/ khos tshong khang zhig gnyer bzhin pa yin/ khos gla pa rnams la gla cha sprad rjes yang bskyar kho tsho la za ma btsongs nas sgor mo rnams phyir blangs yong gi yod/ yud tsam rjes su khos gla pa tshor gla cha rtsa ba nas ma sprad cing / rtsis tho yang med par bzo/ zhing bdag tshos las ka pa tshor za ma sprad rjes zas rin tho 'god byed kyi yod/ de ltar/ gla pa tshos las ka las nas rang kha gso bzhin yod/ 'on kyang / nyin gcig la las ka yongs su grub nas 'gro ran dus/ gla pa 'ga' rer tshur 'bab rgyu med par spyi gnyer khang la phar zas rin chad pa'i gnas tshul yang 'byung gi yod/ deng sang / zhing bdag tshos rang nyid kyi sa zhing steng du las ka ga la las te/ zhing bdag 'ga' res rang nyid la dbang ba'i sa zhing mthong myong tsam yang med/

And it came about that owners no longer worked on their farms. They farmed on paper; and they forgot the land, the smell, the feel of it, and remembered only that they owned it, remembered only what they gained and lost by it. And some of the farms grew so large that one man could not even conceive of them any more, so large that it took batteries of bookkeepers to keep track of interest and gain and loss; chemists to test the soil, to replenish; straw bosses to see that the stooping men were moving along the rows as swiftly as the material of their bodies could stand. Then such a farmer really became a storekeeper, and kept a store. He paid the men, and sold them food, and took the money back. And after a while he did not pay the men at all, and saved bookkeeping. These farms gave food on credit. A man might work and feed himself and when the work was done, might find that he owed money to the company. And the owners not only did not work the farms any more, many of them had never seen the farms they owned.

de nas/ rgyu dngos dbang thang gzhan gyis 'phrog song ba'i yul gyar pa tsho yul khams 'di la yong mgo brtsams/ kho tsho ni khan sa si mnga' sde dang og la ho ma mnga' sde/ Theg sa si mnga' sde dang meg se kho gsar pa'i mnga' sde/ ar khan sa mnga' sde sogs nas mkhar dbang gzhan gyis 'phrog nas khang khyim 'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor gyis bslogs pa'i khyim tshang dang tsho ba khag yin/ rlangs 'khor gang re gang re byas te yong mkhan/ rlangs 'khor ru khag ru khag byas te yong mkhan/ khyim gzhis shor nas grod khog ltogs nas yong mkhan/ kho tsho'i grangs ka ni stong phrag nyi shu/ stong phrag lnga bcu/ stong phrag brgya tham pa/ stong phrag nyis brgya/ ri bo mang po'i phrag steng nas chu rgyun bzhin bzhur yong ba'i mi 'di dag ni pho ba zas kyis stong zhing sems pa re bas stong la/ kho tsho ni brel 'tshub kyis 'dur rgyug byed pa'i grog ma dang 'dra bar yar 'gyog rgyu dang phar 'ded rgyu/ tshur 'then rgyu/ yar 'thu rgyu zhig dang mar gcod rgyu sogs kyi las ka ci rigs kyi ched du 'dur rgyug byed kyi yod la/ zas phor pa gcig gi don du las ka ci zhig byed dgos thug rung byed kyi yod/ byis pa tsho yang ltogs kyi yod/ nga tshor 'dug sa'i gnas med/ nga tsho ni grog ma dang 'dra bar las ka las thun gcig dang / za ma phor pa gang gi don du 'dur rgyug byed bzhin yod la/ lhag par du sa zhing leb mo zhig gi don du 'dur rgyug byed bzhin yod/

And then the dispossessed were drawn west- from Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas, New Mexico; from Nevada and Arkansas families, tribes, dusted out, tractored out. Carloads, caravans, homeless and hungry; twenty thousand and fifty thousand and a hundred thousand and two hundred thousand. They streamed over the mountains, hungry and restless-restless as ants, scurrying to find work to do- to lift, to push, to pull, to pick, to cut- anything, any burden to bear, for food. The kids are hungry. We got no place to live. Like ants scurrying for work, for food, and most of all for land.

nga tsho ni phyi rgyal pa min/ nga tsho ni a me ri kha'i rgyal khab tu gzhis chags nas mi rabs bdun phyin yod la/ nga tsho ni ar lan Di'i mi dang / si kho lan Di'i mi/ dbyin ji pa/ 'jar man pa sogs las kyang gzhis chags mgo snga ba yin/ nga tsho'i mes po zhig gsar brje'i dmag 'khrug tu zhugs myong yod la/ nga tsho'i mes po mang po zhig lho byang nang 'khrug tu'ang zhugs myong / phyogs gnyis kar zhugs mkhan yod/ nga tsho ni a ri pa yin/

We ain't foreign. Seven generations back Americans, and beyond that Irish, Scotch, English, German. One of our folks in the Revolution, an' they was lots of our folks in the Civil War- both sides. Americans.

kho tsho ni bkres shing ltogs la gtum zhing rtsub/ kho tshos khyim gzhis gsar pa zhig rnyed pa'i re ba bcangs nas yong ba yin mod/ kho tshor thob pa ni zhe sdang red/ sa bdag tsho og khe si 'di tsho la zhed kyi yod/ rgyu mtshan ni/ kho tshos rang nyid snyi mo yin pa dang / og khe si 'di tsho mkhregs po yin pa shes kyi yod la/ kho tsho grod khog rgyags yod la/ o khe'i si 'di tsho'i grod khog ltogs yod pa shes kyi yod/ gcig byas na sa bdag 'di tshos rang nyid kyi pha mes yang mes tsho'i ngag rgyun las gal srid rang nyid gtum po yin la grod khog ltogs yod cing / da dung lag tu mtshon cha yod na/ mi snyi mo tsho'i lag nas sa zhing 'phrog rgyu ni ci 'dra'i las sla po zhig yin rabs go myong yod srid/ 'di ltar sa bdag tsho kho tshor sdang la/ grong rdal nang du'ang kho tshor 'gro song gtong rgyu'i sgor mo med pa'i rkyen gyis tshong bdag tsho yang kho tshor sdang ba yin/ tshong bdag tshos mthong chung byed sla sa kho tsho'i yan med la/ tshong bdag tshos yid smon byed dka' sa yang kho tsho'i yan med/ grong rdal gyi mi dang dngul khang gnyer mkhan gyi tshong bdag chung chung tsho yang og khe si 'di tshor sdang ste/ rgyu mtshan ni kho tshos 'di dag gi lag nas skar rdog gcig kyang mi lon pas so// kho tsho ni lag stong mchan la bcug pa'i sprang 'khyam pa yin/ grod khog ltogs pa'i mi yis nges par du las ka byed dgos shing / khos las ka zhig byed dgos dus/ khos las ka zhig ma byas thabs med yin dus/ gla pa 'tshol mkhan tshos kyang rang shugs kyis gla cha dma' mo ma gtogs mi sprod la/ de ltar byas tshe su la'ang gla cha mthon po mi 'bab/ de bas/ tha na sa gnas kyi ngal rtsol mi dmangs kyang og khe si 'di tshor sdang ba yin/

They were hungry, and they were fierce. And they had hoped to find a home, and they found only hatred. Okies- the owners hated them because the owners knew they were soft and the Okies strong, that they were fed and the Okies hungry; and perhaps the owners had heard from their grandfathers how easy it is to steal land from a soft man if you are fierce and hungry and armed. The owners hated them. And in the towns, the storekeepers hated them because they had no money to spend. There is no shorter path to a storekeeper's contempt, and all his admirations are exactly opposite. The town men, little bankers, hated Okies because there was nothing to gain from them. They had nothing. And the laboring people hated Okies because a hungry man must work, and if he must work, if he has to work, the wage payer automatically gives him less for his work; and then no one can get more. And the dispossessed, the migrants, flowed into California, two hundred and fifty thousand, and three hundred thousand. Behind them new tractors were going on the land and the tenants were being forced off. And new waves were on the way, new waves of the dispossessed and the homeless, hardened, intent, and dangerous.

rang gnas nas phyung ba'i gnas spo pa 'di tsho kha li h+phor ne ya mnga' sde'i nang du chu bzhur bzhur gyis 'tshang yong / mi grangs stong phrag nyis brgya lnga bcu/ stong phrag sum brgya/ kho tsho song shul du gsar du slebs pa'i 'drud 'then 'phrul 'khor tsho kho tsho'i sa zhing steng du yong gi yod la/ bogs len zhing pa tsho re re bzhin phyir phud gtong gi yod/ de bas deng sang gnas spo pa'i rba rlabs gsar pa zhig 'phyur nas yong gi yod la/ 'di ni khyim gzhis shor nas rang sems mkhregs por gyur cing / dmigs yul gsal zhing nyen kha che ba'i gnas dbyung 'khyam po'i rlabs rgyun gsar pa de red/ kha li h+phor ne ya'i mi rnams la rgyu nor gsog 'phel dang spyi tshogs steng gi kha las/ spro skyid dang rgyas spros/ khyad mtshar pa'i dngul khang nyen srung sogs 'dod pa sna tshogs yod mod/ gsar du slebs pa'i kla klo 'di tshor 'dod pa gnyis ma gtogs med/ de ni sa zhing dang za ma yin la/ kho tshor mtshon na 'di gnyis ni ngo bo gcig yin/ kha li h+phor ne ya'i mi tsho'i 'dod pa ni rab rib dang gtan 'khel med pa zhig yin mod/ 'on kyang / og khe si tsho'i 'dod pa ni lam 'gram du bshams nas yod cing / gsar rnyed dang bdag bzung byed rgyur sgug nas yod/ de ni/ chu dang ldan la rko bar rung ba'i sa zhing legs po/ ljang mdog gi sa zhing legs po/ sa rgyu tshod lta'i tshul gyis lag mthil du 'phur 'phur byed chog pa'i sa nag snum po/ sna yis snom chog pa'i rtswa ljang / so bar du yun gyis ldad na mgrin pa ru mngar dri 'khyer yong ba'i ldem ldem du g.yo ba'i 'bru rigs kyi gzhung rta bcas so// kho tshos sa rgod la bzhag pa'i zhing sa 'di dag mthong tshe/ rang nyid kyi lus po mar la sgur nas dpung pa'i 'then bkug khrod nas lo 'khor pad tshal dang gser mdog gi bza' bca'i 'bru rigs/ da dung nyung ma dang la ser la sogs pa 'od snang khrod du yar 'dren bzhin pa'i rnam pa de yid kyi me long ngos su gsal ler 'char yong ang /

And while the Californians wanted many things, accumulation, social success, amusement, luxury, and a curious banking security, the new barbarians wanted only two things- land and food; and to them the two were one. And whereas the wants of the Californians were nebulous and undefined, the wants of the Okies were beside the roads, lying there to be seen and coveted: the good fields with water to be dug for, the good green fields, earth to crumble experimentally in the hand, grass to smell, oaten stalks to chew until the sharp sweetness was in the throat. A man might look at a fallow field and know, and see in his mind that his own bending back and his own straining arms would bring the cabbages into the light, and the golden eating corn, the turnips and carrots.

khyim gzhis shor zhing bkres ltogs kyis mnar ba'i skyes pa zhig gis rang nyid kyi chung ma 'gram du bzhag cing / skam zhing rid pa'i phru gu tsho rgyab gral rkub stegs su bzhag nas rlangs 'khor bskor te gzhung lam steng du 'gro skabs/ deng sang khe spogs ma gtogs 'bru rigs thon skyed mi byed pa'i sa rgod 'di dag mthong yong la/ de dus khos zhing sa sa rgod du bzhag pa ni sdig pa zhig yin pa shes la/ stong par bzhag pa'i sa zhing ni kho'i skam zhing rid pa'i phru gu tshor mnar gcod gtong ba'i nyes spyod cig yin pa shes kyi yod/ skyes pa zhig gis 'di ltar rlangs 'khor bskor te gzhung lam brgyud nas 'gro skabs/ phar phyogs kyi zhing sa re re ni 'dod ham slong byed kyi g.yab mo re re yin pa tshor la/ sa zhing 'di dag tshur blangs nas rang nyid kyi phru gu tshor lus stobs skyed cing / rang nyid kyi chung ma'i sems pa bde la phab 'dod pa'i sred pa skye bzhin pa'ang tshor gyi yod/ 'di ltar/ yid 'gug gi bslu brid tshang ma kho tsho'i mig mdun du bshams nas yod/ sa bcud 'dzoms pa'i zhing sa re re dang zhing phyugs spyi gnyer khang gi chu rka las 'bab bzhin pa'i rka chu re re ni kho'i sems pa ngar slong byed kyi lcag tshan re re yin/ lho phyogs su/ khos sdong steng nas lci mor dpyangs pa'i li khri'i mdog can gyi tsha lu ma mthong / li khri'i mdog can gyi tsha lu ma chung chung dag ljang nag gi sdong po'i steng nas mar dpyangs/ srung dmag tshos lag tu me mda' bzung nas zhing tshigs srung 'dug pas/ skyes pa des rang nyid kyi skam la rid pa'i phru gu tshor sbyin rgyu'i shing tog rdog gcig kyang 'thog mi thub/ tsha lu ma'i rin gong mar chag na tshang ma gad snyigs su g.yug rgyu red/

And a homeless hungry man, driving the roads with his wife beside him and his thin children in the back seat, could look at the fallow fields which might produce food but not profit, and that man could know how a fallow field is a sin and the unused land a crime against the thin children. And such a man drove along the roads and knew temptation at every field, and knew the lust to take these fields and make them grow strength for his children and a little comfort for his wife. The temptation was before him always. The fields goaded him, and the company ditches with good water flowing were a goad to him. And in the south he saw the golden oranges hanging on the trees, the little golden oranges in the dark green trees; and guards with shotguns patrolling the lines so a man might not pick an orange for a thin child, oranges to be dumped if the price was low.
khos rlangs 'khor bskor nas grong rdal zhig tu slebs pa na/ zhing ra tshang mar nyul nas las ka re e rnyed bltas/ dgong mo nga tsho gang du nyal dgos sam/
He drove his old car into a town. He scoured the farms for work. Where can we sleep the night?
o/ phar phyogs kyi chu 'gram de na ho h+pher grong tsho'am sprang sgar re yod/ de na og khe si'i mi tshogs kyis gang yod/
Well, there's Hooverville on the edge of the river. There's a whole raft of Okies there.

khos rang nyid kyi rlangs 'khor rnying pa de bskor nas ho h+pher grong tsho la song / dus de nas bzung khos zhag sdod byed sa gang yin 'dri dgos ma byung ste/ rgyu mtshan ni/ grong rdal re re'i grong sne ru ho h+pher grong tsho re re yod pas so// grong tsho gog po de chu 'gram du yod cing / de'i nang gi khang khyim ni ras gur dang 'bru khang / shog khang sogs kyis grub pa'i gad snyigs kyi phung gsog chen po zhig red/ skyes pa des rlangs 'khor bskor nas rang nyid kyi khyim mi dang lhan du ho h+pher grong tsho'i nang du 'dzul zhing / kho tsho grong tsho 'di'i mi ser du gyur/ grong tsho 'di 'dra ba la rgyun du ho h+pher grong tsho zhes 'bod kyi yod/ skyes pa des rang nyid kyi ras gur de chu dang kha thag gang nye nye zhig tu phub/ gal srid kho la ras gur med na kho rang grong rdal gyi gad snyigs 'phen sa ru song nas shog sgam stong pa re 'khyer yong nas/ gnyer sul dod pa'i shog bu'i khang khyim zhig phug rgyu red/ de nas char pa 'bab dus shog khang char chus zags nas shul med du ded 'gro/ kho rang ho h+pher grong tsho ru gzhis chags nas/ mtha' 'khor gyi yul lung khag tu las ka 'tshol du 'gro la/ kho rang la cung tsam lhag yod pa'i sgor mo de tsho ni las ka 'tshol bar 'gro skabs rlangs 'khor la snum snon byed du btang zin/ dgong mo/ skyes pa tshang ma lhan du 'dus nas gleng mol byed/ rang nyid kyi sgyid khug steng du tsog 'dug byas pa'i skyes pa 'di tshos nyin dkar rang nyid kyis mthong ba'i zhing sa'i skor gyi gleng mol byed/

He drove his old car to Hooverville. He never asked again, for there was a Hooverville on the edge of every town. The rag town lay close to water; and the houses were tents, and weed-thatched enclosures, paper houses, a great junk pile. The man drove his family in and became a citizen of Hooverville- always they were called Hooverville. The man put up his own tent as near to water as he could get; or if he had no tent, he went to the city dump and brought back cartons and built a house of corrugated paper. And when the rains came the house melted and washed away. He settled in Hooverville and he scoured the countryside for work, and the little money he had went for gasoline to look for work. In the evening the men gathered and talked together. Squatting on their hams they talked of the land they had seen.
'di nas cung nub phyogs mtshams su dbyin mu'u stong phrag sum cu can gyi zhing sa zhig 'dug de gar stong par bzhag 'dug
There's thirty thousan' acres, out west of here. Layin' there.

ston pa ye shu/ de nga'i lag tu 'byor rgyu na/ de'i nang gi dbyin mu'u lnga tsam nga'i lag tu 'byor rgyu na/ de nas nga la thabs bkod yod song ba red/ ci yin zer na/ des nga la bza' bca' gang dgos mkho sprod byed kyi red/ khyod tshos do snang byung ma song ngam/ kho tshos zhing gzhis steng du sngo ldum btab mi 'dug la/ khyim bya dang phag pa yang gsos mi 'dug kho tshos zhing gzhis khag gi steng du sna kha gcig ma gtogs gso skyong mi byed/ de gcig byas na sring bal yin rgyu red la/ yang min na kham bu yin rgyu red/ de min na rjen tshal yin rgyu red/ yang na gzhis ka yongs rdzogs su khyim bya gcig pu gsos yod rgyu red/ kho tshos rang nyid kyi sgo ra'i nang nas gso skyong byas chog pa'i rgyu nor de dag nges par du phyi logs nas nyo yi 'dug

Jesus, what I could do with that, with five acres of that! Why, hell, I'd have ever'thing to eat. Notice one thing? They ain't no vegetables nor chickens nor pigs at the farms. They raise one thing- cotton, say, or peaches, or lettuce. 'Nother place'll be all chickens. They buy the stuff they could raise in the dooryard.
ston pa ye shu/ nga la phag pa gcig gnyis shig yod rgyu na/ de nas nga la thabs bkod yod song ba red/
Jesus, what I could do with a couple pigs!
un/ de dag khyod kyi ma red la/ nam yang khyod kyi yin rgyu ma red/
Well, it ain't yourn, an' it ain't gonna be yourn.
da nga tshos ci zhig byed dgos/ phru gu tsho 'di ltar 'tshar longs 'byung du 'jug thabs mi 'dug a/
What we gonna do? The kids can't grow up this way.

gtam 'chal khag zhag sgar du shub shub tu slebs yong / shab Ther grong khyer du las ka 'dug zer/ de nas rlangs 'khor tsho dgong mo lam la chas 'gro zhing / gzhung lam tshang ma 'tshang khas gang 'gro la/ tshang ma gser brko bar 'gro ba lta bu'i brel 'tshub che/ las ka pa tshang ma shab Ther grong khyer du 'tshang kha brgyab nas 'dug cing / kho tsho'i grangs 'bor ni dngos su mkho ba'i las ka pa'i grangs 'bor gyi ldab lnga drug red/ gser brko bar 'gro ba lta bu'i brel 'tshub cig langs/ las ka lag la mi rnyed par skrag nas tshang ma dgong mor 'jab bros byas 'gro/ lam 'gram yongs su 'dod rngam gyi bslu brid kyis gang yod/ sa zhing 'di dag steng du za ma gang 'dod du skye thub ang / de dag bdag bzung byas zin/ de nga tsho'i ma red/

In the camps the word would come whispering, There's work at Shafter. And the cars would be loaded in the night, the highways crowded- a gold rush for work. At Shafter the people would pile up, five times too many to do the work. A gold rush for work. They stole away in the night, frantic for work. And along the roads lay the temptations, the fields that could bear food. That's owned. That ain't our'n.

un/ gcig byas na nga tshos 'di'i nang nas sa leb mo zhig len thub srid/ leb mo chung chung / gsham gyi sa leb de tsam/ deng sang steng du ldum bu d+ha tu ra skyes su bcug nas bzhag 'dug ston pa ye shu/ ngas sa leb de'i steng nas zhog khog btab na nga'i khyim tshang hril po'i kha gso thub ang /
Well, maybe we could get a little piece of her. Maybe- a little piece. Right down there- a patch. Jimson weed now. Christ, I could git enough potatoes off'n that little patch to feed my whole family!

de nga tsho'i ma red/ de ldum bu d+ha tu ra skye sar 'jog dgos/ mtshams dang mtshams su mi 'ga' res 'di ltar tshod lta byas myong yod/ kho sa zhing nang du rkang 'jab lag 'jab kyis 'dzul nas sa ngos chung chung zhig gtsang bzo byas te/ rkun po zhig dang 'dra bar sa gzhi'i 'byor phyug cung tsam rku thabs byed kyi yod/ khos rtswa ldum khrod du gsang ba'i ldum ra zhig bskrun nas/ de gar la ser dang nyung ma'i sa bon shog chag re 'debs pa'am/ yang na zhog khog gi dum bu 'ga' btab rjes/ dgong dro lkog lkog sud sud ngang rku 'debs byas pa'i zhing nang du yur ma yur du 'gro yi yod/

It ain't our'n. It got to have Jimson weeds. Now and then a man tried; crept on the land and cleared a piece, trying like a thief to steal a little richness from the earth. Secret gardens hidden in the weeds. A package of carrot seeds and a few turnips. Planted potato skins, crept out in the evening secretly to hoe in the stolen earth.
mtha' 'khor gyi rtswa ldum de dag rang dgar skyur zhog dang / de nas nga tshos ci zhig byed bzhin pa sus kyang mthong gi ma red/ dkyil du'ang ldum bu ring po dang chen po 'ga' re skyur zhog
Leave the weeds around the edge- then nobody can see what we're a-doin'. Leave some weeds, big tall ones, in the middle.
dgong dro btsa' yis zos pa'i lcags krin nang du chu 'khyer yong nas/ gsang ba'i sgo nas ldum ra skyong gi yod/
Secret gardening in the evenings, and water carried in a rusty can.
de nas nyin gcig la nyen rtog pa slebs nas/ ya/ khyod kyis ci zhig byed bsam gyi yod ces 'dri/
And then one day a deputy sheriff: Well, what you think you're doin'?
ngas gnod 'tshe ci yang gtong gi med/
I ain't doin' no harm.
ngas khyod rang mig thog tu blangs yod/ 'di khyod kyi sa ma red/ 'di ni gzhan sa btsan 'dzin gyi bya spyod red/
I had my eye on you. This ain't your land. You're trespassing.
sa zhing 'di rmos mi 'dug la/ ngas 'di la gnod pa ci yang gtong gi med/
The land ain't plowed, an' I ain't hurtin' it none.

gzhan sa btsan 'dzin mkhan ltas ngan khyod tsho/ cung tsam song rjes su khyod tshos sa 'di rang nyid la dbang yod par 'dod la/ de dus khyod btsan po rgya stag 'dra por 'gyur rgyu red/ sa 'di khyod la dbang ba red 'dod dam/ mgyogs por phar song /
You goddamned squatters. Pretty soon you'd think you owned it. You'd be sore as hell. Think you owned it. Get off now.

de nas sa ngos su cung tsam bud yod pa'i la ser gyi ljang myug rnams la rdog tho brgyab nas bkog song la/ nyung ma'i ljang lo rnams kyang rdog brdzis btang / de nas ldum bu d+ha tu ra rnams yang bskyar nang du phyir skyes yong / 'on kyang / nyen rtog pa'i skad cha la'ang gnas lugs med pa ma red/ lo tog cig btab zin rjes des khyod la bdag dbang gi tshor ba sbyin la/ sa zhing la yur ma yur nas de'i steng gi la ser grod khog tu song rjes/ rang nyid kyi bza' bca' len sa'i sa zhing de'i ched du su zhig yin rung 'thab rtsod byed srid/ kho mgyogs por mtha' skrod thong ma gtogs cung tsam 'gor rjes khos sa zhing de rang nyid kyi yin par cha 'jog byed nges la/ khos ldum bu d+ha tu ra'i bar gseng gi sa leb chung chung re re'i don du rang srog yin rung gtong nges yin/

And the little green carrot tops were kicked off and the turnip greens trampled. And then the Jimson weed moved back in. But the cop was right. A crop raised- why, that makes ownership. Land hoed and the carrots eaten- a man might fight for land he's taken food from. Get him off quick! He'll think he owns it. He might even die fighting for the little plot among the Jimson weeds.

nga tshos nyung ma rnams rdog brdzis gtong skabs kho'i ngo mdangs ga 'dra yin pa mthong byung ngam/ kho'i sdang sems kyi mig mdangs su dmar gsod kyi me lce 'bar/ nga tshos mi 'di tsho'i mgo mnan nas 'dug dgos red ma gtogs 'di tshos nga tsho'i sa cha 'phrog rgyu red/ 'di tshos nga tsho'i sa cha 'phrog rgyu red/
Did ya see his face when we kicked them turnips out? Why, he'd kill a fella soon's he'd look at him. We got to keep these here people down or they'll take the country. They'll take the country.
phyi mi 'di tsho/ gzhan rigs 'di tsho/
Outlanders, foreigners.

red/ nga tsho tshang mas skad rigs gcig bshad pa bden pa red/ 'on kyang / kho tsho dang nga tsho mi 'dra/ kho tsho'i 'tsho ba rol stangs la ltos dang / nga tsho su zhig gis 'tsho ba de ltar rol lam/ mi rol/ rol thabs med/
Sure, they talk the same language, but they ain't the same. Look how they live. Think any of us folks'd live like that? Hell, no!

dgong dro dag tu/ tshang ma tsog 'dug byas nas kha brda byed/ mi gcig gis tshor shugs drag pos gtam bshad byas/ nga tsho mi nyi shu tshang ma mnyam rub kyis sa zhing leb mo zhig btsan bzung byas na mi chog gam/ nga tshor me mda' yod a/ sa zhing tshur blangs rjes [“]nus pa yod na nga tsho mtha' skrod thong /[”] zhes bshad chog nga tshos ci'i phyir de ltar byed mi chog de ltar byas na/ kho tshos me mda' char pa bzhin phab nas nga tsho tsi gu bzhin du gsod rgyu red/

In the evening, squatting and talking. And an excited man: Whyn't twenty of us take a piece of lan'? We got guns. Take it an' say, “Put us off if you can.” Whyn't we do that? They'd jus' shoot us like rats.

'o na/ khyod rang 'chi na dga' 'am yang na 'di ltar 'tsho ba rol na dga'/ sa 'og gi dur khung du nyal na 'dod dam yang na rtswa ras kyis bzos pa'i khang pa 'di'i khang du bsdad na 'dod/ khyod kyi phru gu tsho la mtshon na'ang / kho tsho da lta shi na dga' 'am yang na ma 'ongs pa'i lo ngo gnyis kyi nang du/ kho tsho'i bshad stangs ltar/ 'tsho bcud kyis ma 'dang bar shi na dga'/ nga tshos gza' 'khor gcig gi ring la ci zhig zos nas bsdad pa shes sam/ zwa tshod btsos ma dang phye ldur skya brngos zos nas bsdad pa yin/ phye skya de gang nas 'khyer yong ba shes sam/ phye skya de dos 'khor 'khor sgam mthil gyi phye rdul phyags yong ba yin/

Well, which'd you ruther be, dead or here? Under groun' or in a house all made of gunny sacks? Which'd you ruther for your kids, dead now or dead in two years with what they call malnutrition? Know what we et all week? Biled nettles an' fried dough! Know where we got the flour for the dough? Swep' the floor of a boxcar.

kho tshos zhag sgar gyi nang nas de ltar gleng mol byed pa'i skabs su/ 'phongs tshos rgyags ril can gyi nyen rtog pa tshos so so'i dpyi mgo rgyags ril gyi steng nas dkrum mda' re dpyangs nas/ zhag sgar brgyud nas sgrob nyams dang bcas 'gro bzhin gleng mol byed/ kho tshor sems g.yeng sa re 'tshol dgos/ kho tsho'i mgo mnan nas ma bsdad na kho tshos ci byed dngos gnas shes dka'/ dkon mchog ye shu/ kho tsho lho phyogs kyi mi nag lta bu'i nyen kha che/ gal srid kho tsho tshang ma kha mthun song dus 'gog thub mkhan gcig kyang yod pa ma red/

Talking in the camps, and the deputies, fat-assed men with guns slung on fat hips, swaggering through the camps: Give 'em somepin to think about. Got to keep 'em in line or Christ only knows what they'll do! Why, Jesus, they're as dangerous as niggers in the South! If they ever get together there ain't nothin' that'll stop 'em.

lung zhig drangs na 'di lta ste/ lo ran si grong tsho ru nyen rtog pa zhig gis gzhan sa btsan bzung mkhan zhig mtha' skrod gtong skabs/ btsan bzung mkhan des ngo log byas/ de bas nyen rtog pas drag shugs mi bkol thabs med du gyur/ 'on kyang / skabs der btsan bzung mkhan de'i rang lo bcu gcig la son pa'i bu yis kha tshad [0.22] can gyi me mda' zhig 'khyer yong nas nyen rtog pa de bsad pa red/

Quote: In Lawrenceville a deputy sheriff evicted a squatter, and the squatter resisted, making it necessary for the officer to use force. The eleven-year-old son of the squatter shot and killed the deputy with a .22 rifle.

dug sbrul rnga sil can 'di tsho/ kho tshor go skabs shig gtan nas sprod mi rung / kho tshos tshig lan bslogs na thad kar me mda' gzhus shig kho tsho'i byis pa zhig gis nyen rtog pa zhig gsod dus mi chen po tshos ci byed tshod mi thig kho tsho gtum po yin na nga tsho de las kyang gtum po byed dgos la/ kho tsho gtum drag gis lag len byas te zhed du 'jug dgos/
Rattlesnakes! Don't take chances with 'em, an' if they argue, shoot first. If a kid'll kill a cop, what'll the men do? Thing is, get tougher'n they are. Treat 'em rough. Scare 'em.

'o na/ kho tsho ma zhed na ci bya/ gal srid kho tsho yar langs brgyab nas me mda'i kha mchu nga tsho la gtad yong na ci bya/ mi 'di tsho chung byis pa yin dus nas bzung mtshon cha lag len byas nas yong ba red/ kho tsho la mtshon na/ me mda' ni kho tsho'i cha shas lta bur gyur yod/ gal srid kho tsho ma zhed na ci bya/ nyin gcig la/ lom b+har Di'i mi rigs de dbyi ta li'i yul du dpung skyod byas pa dang / 'jar man pa rnams g+hol gyi yul du dpung skyod byas pa/ tur ki'i mi rigs rnams b+ha'e zan Thim gyi yul du dpung skyod byas pa dang 'dra bar/ mi 'di rigs kyi dpung tshogs shig nga tsho'i yul du dpung 'jug byas pa yin na ci bya/ mi 'di dag ni sa zhing gi steng du ham pa langs yod pa'i mi rigs yin la/ mtshon cha rnying gog thogs pa'i rtsab hral pa 'di tsho dmag dpung gang 'dra zhig gis kyang 'gog mi thub/ dmar gsod dang 'jigs skul gyis kyang kho tsho 'gog mi thub/ bkres ltogs de rang nyid kyi pho ba leb mo gcig pus myong bzhin pa ma yin par/ sdug bsngal de rang nyid kyi bu phrug gi nyam thag pa'i pho bas kyang myong bzhin pa'i mi zhig la mtshon na/ kho la ci zhig gis 'jigs skrag slong nus/ khyod kyis kho la zhed snang slong mi nus te/ khos sa steng gi 'jigs skrag yod tshad las kyang 'jigs su rung ba'i 'jigs snang zhig myangs yod pas so//

What if they won't scare? What if they stand up and take it and shoot back? These men were armed when they were children. A gun is an extension of themselves. What if they won't scare? What if some time an army of them marches on the land as the Lombards did in Italy, as the Germans did on Gaul and the Turks did on Byzantium? They were land-hungry, ill-armed hordes too, and the legions could not stop them. Slaughter and terror did not stop them. How can you frighten a man whose hunger is not only in his own cramped stomach but in the wretched bellies of his children? You can't scare him- he has known a fear beyond every other.
ho h+pher grong tsho nas skyes pa tshos gleng mol byed/ nga'i a mes kyis kho'i sa zhing rnams in jun mi'i lag nas blangs yong ba red/
In Hooverville the men talking: Grampa took his lan' from the Injuns.
'di nor 'khrul red/ da lta nga tshos shod bzhin pa 'di nor 'khrul gyi skad cha zhig red/ da lta khyod kyis bshad pa de ni rku 'phrog gi bya ba red/ nga ni rkun ma min/
Now, this ain't right. We're a-talkin' here. This here you're talkin' about is stealin'. I ain't no thief.

khyod rkun ma min zer ram/ snga nub dgong mo khyod kyis sgo khyams shig nas 'o ma shel dam gang brkus yong ba min nam/ da dung khyod kyis rag skud dum pa zhig kyang brkus yong nas sha dum bu zhig la brjes song a/
No? You stole a bottle of milk from a porch night before last. An' you stole some copper wire and sold it for a piece of meat.
de bden/ nga'i phru gu tsho'i grod khog ltogs kyi 'dug 'on kyang / de yang rku las red a/
Yeah, but the kids was hungry. It's stealin', though.

khyod kyis h+phar h+phild zhing ra chen mo de ji ltar blangs pa shes kyi yod dam/ ngas bshad ya/ skabs de dus sa zhing de srid gzhung gi yin zhing / len sla po yin pa red/ nyin gcig la rgad po h+phar h+phild kho rang san h+phi ran se si kho grong khyer gyi chang khang zhig tu song nas/ de ga'i chang rkyal sum brgya lhag btsal ba dang / chang rkyal de dag gis sa zhing tshur blangs pa red/ h+phar h+phild kyis bzi bo 'di dag la za ma dang chang rag sprad nas sa zhing 'dzin du bcug cing / rim bzhin sa zhing tshur dngos su thob nas bdag dbang la rtsod gleng med pa'i skabs su/ h+phar h+phild kyis sa zhing de chang rkyal tsho'i lag nas tshur blangs pa red/ rjes sor khos rgyun par rang nyid kyis sa zhing dbyin mu'u re la chang ngan phinaDa [3] gcig re tsam btang ba yin zhes bshad kyi yod rabs 'dug khyod kyis de yang rku byas pa red zer rgyu yin nam/

Know how the Fairfiel' ranch was got? I'll tell ya. It was all gov'ment lan', an' could be took up. Ol' Fairfiel', he went into San Francisco to the bars, an' he got him three hunderd stew bums. Them bums took up the lan'. Fairfiel' kep' 'em in food an' whisky, an' then when they'd proved the lan', ol' Fairfiel' took it from 'em. He used to say the lan' cost him a pint of rotgut an acre. Would you say that was stealin'?
[3] phinaDa/ [pint] ste/ gsher gzugs 'jal tshad cig yin la/ g+ha lon gcig gi brgyad cha gcig yin/
un/ byed stangs de'ang ma 'grig pa red/ 'on kyang / kho rang de'i don du btson du 'gro dgos byung med/
Well, it wasn't right, but he never went to jail for it.

red/ kho de'i don du btson du 'gro dgos ma byung ba bden pa red/ sa cha tshang ma chu yis gang yod tshul gyi snyan zhu rdzun ma 'bri ched du/ ko gru zhig shing rta'i steng du bzhag nas 'drud mkhan gyi mi de yang btson khang du 'gro dgos byung med la/[3] rgyal tshogs 'thus mi dang khrims bzo mi snar lkog rngan sprad pa'i mi de yang btson khang du 'gro dgos thug med/

No, he never went to jail for it. An' the fella that put a boat in a wagon an' made his report like it was all under water 'cause he went in a boat- he never went to jail neither. An' the fellas that bribed congressmen and the legislatures never went to jail neither.

[3] dus rab bcu dgu pa'i dus mjug tu/ zhing phyugs spyi gnyer khang chen po'i bdag po han re mi ler gyis/ bed med sa lhag bdag bzung byed pa'i dbang cha thob ched/ skam sa chen po zhig 'dam chu'i sa khul yin tshul gleng nas/ glang gog cig la ko gru zhig 'drud du bcug nas brnyan par blangs nas/ 'dam chu'i khrod du ko gru la ma bsdad na mi thar tshul gyi rdzun bzo byas pa'i gnas tshul de shod kyi yod/
ldab ldib kyi skad cha sna tshogs mnga' sde yongs kyi ho h+pher grong tsho khag tu grag bzhin yod/
All over the State, jabbering in the Hoovervilles.

de nas/ drag chas spras pa'i nyen rtog dpung zhig gis zhag sgar gyi nang du dpung 'jug byas/ phar rgyugs shig 'phrod bsten las khungs kyis bka' btang yod/ zhag sgar 'dis sa gnas 'phrod bsten la nyen kha bzo yi 'dug
And then the raids- the swoop of armed deputies on the squatters' camps. Get out. Department of Health orders. This camp is a menace to health.
'o na nga tsho gang du 'gro dgos/
Where we gonna go?
de nga tsho'i 'gan khur ma red/ khyod tsho 'di las mtha' skrod gtong zhes nga tshor bka' babs yod/ chu tshod phyed ka'i rjes su nga tshos zhag sgar 'di mer bsreg rgyu yin/
That's none of our business. We got orders to get you out of here. In half an hour we set fire to the camp.
rgyu tshad kyi nad rims slebs 'dug pas/ khyod tshos nad rims 'di yar mar la khyab tu 'jug 'dod dam/
They's typhoid down the line. You want ta spread it all over?
nga tshor khyod tsho 'di las mtha' skrod gtong ba'i bka' babs yod/ ya/ da song zhig
We got orders to get you out of here. Now get! In half an hour we burn the camp.

chu tshod phyed ka'i rjes su nga tshos zhag sgar 'di mer bsreg rgyu yin/ chu tshod phyed ka'i rjes su/ shog bu'i khang pa dang rtswa yi thog khebs bsregs pa'i du ba dgung sngon du 'phyur byung la/ mi rnams rang rang gi rlangs 'khor du bsdad nas gzhung lam brgyud de ho h+pher grong tsho gzhan pa zhig 'tshol du 'gro bzhin yod/
In half an hour the smoke of paper houses, of weed-thatched huts, rising to the sky, and the people in their cars over the highways, looking for another Hooverville.

khan sa si mnga' sde dang ar khan sa si mnga' sde/ og la ho ma mnga' sde dang Theg sa si mnga' sde/ meg se kho gsar pa mnga' sde bcas su 'drud 'then tsho yong nas bogs len zhing pa tsho mtha' skrod gtong bzhin yod/

And the great owners, who must lose their land in an upheaval, the great owners with access to history, with eyes to read history and to know the great fact: when property accumulates in too few hands it is taken away. And that companion fact: when a majority of the people are hungry and cold they will take by force what they need. And the little screaming fact that sounds through all history: repression works only to strengthen and knit the repressed. The great owners ignored the three cries of history. The land fell into fewer hands, the number of the dispossessed increased, and every effort of the great owners was directed at repression. The money was spent for arms, for gas to protect the great holdings, and spies were sent to catch the murmuring of revolt so that it might be stamped out. The changing economy was ignored, plans for the change ignored; and only means to destroy revolt were considered, while the causes of revolt went on.

The tractors which throw men out of work, the belt lines which carry loads, the machines which produce, all were increased; and more and more families scampered on the highways, looking for crumbs from the great holdings, lusting after the land beside the roads. The great owners formed associations for protection and they met to discuss ways to intimidate, to kill, to gas. And always they were in fear of a principal- three hundred thousand- if they ever move under a leader-the end. Three hundred thousand, hungry and miserable; if they ever know themselves, the land will be theirs and all the gas, all the rifles in the world won't stop them. And the great owners, who had become through their holdings both more and less than men, ran to their destruction, and used every means that in the long run would destroy them. Every little means, every violence, every raid on a Hooverville, every deputy swaggering through a ragged camp put off the day a little and cemented the inevitability of the day.

There was no order in the camp; little gray tents, shacks, cars were scattered about at random. The first house was nondescript. The south wall was made of three sheets of rusty corrugated iron, the east wall a square of moldy carpet tacked between two boards, the north wall a strip of roofing paper and a strip of tattered canvas, and the west wall six pieces of gunny sacking. Over the square frame, on untrimmed willow limbs, grass had been piled, not thatched, but heaped up in a low mound. The entrance, on the gunnysack side, was cluttered with equipment. A five-gallon kerosene can served for a stove. It was laid on its side, with a section of rusty stovepipe thrust in one end. A wash boiler rested on its side against the wall; and a collection of boxes lay about, boxes to sit on, to eat on. A Model T Ford sedan and a two-wheel trailer were parked beside the shack, and about the camp there hung a slovenly despair.

kha se yis rtsi shing gi gzhung rta dang 'dra ba'i ske'i steng gi mgo bo de tshur 'khor/ [“]nam yin yang nyan bsdad yod/ ngas rgyun du bsam blo gtong ba'i rgyu mtshan yang de yin/ mi rnams kyi skad cha la yud tsam nyan na/ mgyogs por kho tsho'i bsam blo gtong stangs de shes yong / 'grul bzhud kyi lam thag ring mo'i steng nas ngas mi tsho'i sems 'dun dang tshor ba mthong zhing myong thub song / mi rnams ni gzeb la tshud pa'i bye'u chung bzhin gshog zung thag thag tu rdeb la/ gzeb las grol ched gshog rdeb byas nas gshog pa gzeb bar nas gcog la nye/[”]

Casy turned his head on the stalk-like neck. “Listen all the time. That's why I been thinkin'. Listen to people a-talkin', an' purty soon I hear the way folks are feelin'. Goin' on all the time. I hear 'em an' feel 'em; an' they're beating their wings like a bird in a attic. Gonna bust their wings on a dusty winda tryin' ta get out.”

Thom gyis kho la mig zung cer gyis yud tsam la bltas shing / de nas phar phyogs kyi dbyin khre nyi shu yas mas kyi sar yod pa'i ras gur skya bo der bltas/ ras gur gyi chon thag steng du bkrus zin pa'i rdzi dor dang nang stod/ l+wa ba bcas nyi mar skam 'dug khos skad ngag 'jam pos [“]ngas khyod la bshad 'dod pa'i skad cha'ang de yin/ 'on kyang / khyod kyis gnad don 'di snga sa nas mthong 'dug a/[”] zhes bshad/

Tom regarded him with widened eyes, and then he turned and looked at a gray tent twenty feet away. Washed jeans and shirts and a dress hung to dry on the tent guys. He said softly, “That was about what I was gonna tell ya. An' you seen awready.”
kha se yis mos mthun gyi sgo nas [“]ngas mthong ba ni/ rten sa chags sa med pa'i nga tsho ni dmag dpung lta bu zhig yin pa de red/[”] ces bshad cing /

de nas khos mgo bo cung sgur zhing / lag pa dal mos dpral ba'i phyogs su yar bsrings yong nas skra gseb la sbar 'brad byed bzhin [“]gnad don 'di nyin 'di dag gi ring la ngas rgyun du mthong yong / nga tsho gang du gnas bcas na der mthong ba ni/ khyim tshang mang po'i kha la sha rtsib re ma rag par dka' yi yod la/ kha la rag pa'i dbang du btang rung khog la 'bab rgyu zhig med/ de nas kho tsho ltogs nas bzod bsran mi thub skabs nga la gsol ba 'debs su 'jug la/ ngas kyang mtshams la lar gsol ba btab pa yin/[”] zhes bshad cing / de nas khos bskums nas yod pa'i pus mo'i steng du sbar mo bskon nas rkang pa dal mos nang du phyir 'then/ [“]ngas sngon chad gsol ba smon lam btab na sdug bsngal sel thub snyam myong / sngon chad yin na gsol ba zhig btab na/ sdug bsngal yod tshad gsol 'debs de'i steng du thogs nas/ sbrang nag rnams sbrang shog gi steng du 'byar ba ltar thag ring thag ring la 'khyer 'gro bar 'dod kyi yod/ 'on kyang / deng sang der nus pa de 'dra zhig med pa 'dra/[”] zhes bshad/

He bowed his head and ran his extended hand slowly up his forehead and into his hair. “All along I seen it,” he said. “Ever' place we stopped I seen it. Folks hungry for side-meat, an' when they get it, they ain't fed. An' when they'd get so hungry they couldn' stan' it no more, why, they'd ast me to pray for 'em, an' sometimes I done it.” He clasped his hands around drawn-up knees and pulled his legs in. “I use' ta think that'd cut 'er,” he said. “Use' ta rip off a prayer an' all the troubles'd stick to that prayer like flies on flypaper, an' the prayer'd go a-sailin' off, a-takin' them troubles along. But don' work no more.”
Thom gyis [“]gsol 'debs kyis sha rtsib cig 'khyer nas slebs myong med/ phag sha dgos na phag pa 'tshol dgos kyi red/[”] ces bshad/
Tom said, “Prayer never brought in no side-meat. Takes a shoat to bring in pork.”

kha se yis [“]red ya/ dkon mchog mthu stobs can pos nam yang gla cha spar myong med/ yul mi gnyom chung 'di tshos 'tsho ba stabs bde zhig bskyal nas/ bu phrug tsho stabs bdes skyong 'dod pa tsam red la/ kho tsho lo na rgas pa'i skabs su/ sgo lam bar nas nub kha'i nyi mar lta 'dod pa tsam dang / lo na gzhon dus mnyam du zhabs bro 'khrab cing glu dbyangs blangs nas/ mnyam du nyal 'dod pa tsam red/ de bzhin kho tshos za ma zos nas chang rag 'thung zhing / las ka las rgyu/ kho tsho'i 'dod pa ni de ga tsam red/ sha gnad lhod nas thang chad du 'jug 'dod pa tsam red/ dkon mchog ye shu/ da ngas skad cha ji 'dra zhig bshad kyi 'dug ang /[”] zhes bshad/

An' that's it- they wanta jus' fling their goddamn muscles aroun' an' get tired. Christ! What'm I talkin' about?”

“I dunno,” said Tom. “Sounds kinda nice. When ya think you can get ta work an' quit thinkin' a spell? We got to get work. Money's 'bout gone. Pa gives five dollars to get a painted piece of board stuck up over Granma. We ain't got much lef'.”

A lean brown mongrel dog came sniffing around the side of the tent. He was nervous and flexed to run. He sniffed close before he was aware of the two men, and then looking up he saw them, leaped sideways, and fled, ears back, bony tail clamped protectively. Casy watched him go, dodging around a tent to get out of sight. Casy sighed. “I ain't doin' nobody no good,” he said. “Me or nobody else. I was thinkin' I'd go off alone by myself. I'm a-eatin' your food an' a-takin' up room. An' I ain't give you nothin'. Maybe I could get a steady job an' maybe pay back some a the stuff you've give me.”

Tom opened his mouth and thrust his lower jaw forward, and he tapped his lower teeth with a dried piece of mustard stalk. His eyes stared over the camp, over the gray tents and the shacks of weed and tin and paper. “Wisht I had a sack a Durham,” he said. “I ain't had a smoke in a hell of a time. Use' ta get tobacco in McAlester. Almost wisht I was back.” He tapped his teeth again and suddenly he turned on the preacher. “Ever been in a jail house?”

“No,” said Casy. “Never been.” “Don't go away right yet,” said Tom. “Not right yet.”
[“]nga ga tshod snga tsam la song na/ de tshod kyis las ka rnyed srid/[”]
“Quicker I get lookin' for work- quicker I'm gonna find some.”

Thom gyis mig phyes ma btsum gyis kho la zhib lta zhig byas nas/ zhwa mo yang bskyar mgo la phyir gon rjes [“]ltos dang / 'di ni chos dpon tshos rgyun par gsung ba'i sbrang rtsi dang 'o ma'i yul gru de 'dra ma red/ 'di ni ya nga snying rje med pa'i sa cha zhig red/ sa 'di'i yul mi tshang ma nga tsho nub phyogs su yong bzhin pa 'dir zhed kyi 'dug la/ de bas/ kho tshos nyen rtog pa btsal nas nga tshor tshur zhed snang slong thabs byed kyi 'dug[”] ces bshad/

Tom studied him with half-shut eyes and he put on his cap again. “Look,” he said, “this ain't no lan' of milk an' honey like the preachers say. They's a mean thing here. The folks here is scared of us people comin' west; an' so they get cops out tryin' to scare us back.”
kha se yis [“]red ya/ de ngas shes/ khyod kyis ci'i phyir nga btson la bsdad myong yod med dris pa yin/[”] zhes bshad/
“Yeah,” said Casy. “I know. What you ask about me bein' in jail for?”

Thom gyis dal mos [“]gal srid khyod rang btson khang du bsdad pa yin na/ de nas khyod la tshor shes gsar pa zhig 'khrungs yong / btson pa mang po mnyam du 'dzoms nas skad cha bshad mi chog la/ mi gnyis tsam 'du 'dzoms chog srid mod/ mi tshogs rtsa ba nas 'du ru 'jug gi red/ de bas mi rnams la tshor shes gsar pa zhig slebs yong / dper na/ gal srid btson pa zhig gi sems la za 'phrug langs nas/ btson srung pa zhig gi mgo la phyags ma'i yu ba zhig gis rgyag skabs/ btson pa gzhon pa tshos don dag 'di ma byung gong nas 'di 'dra 'byung rgyu yin pa tshor thub kyi yod/ gal srid btson khang du 'os langs 'byung rgyu yin pa'am yang na btson byol 'byung rgyu yin na/ btson pa tshor sus kyang ma bshad rung kho tshos tshor thub kyi yod/ 'di thad la rang shugs kyis tshor shes shig slebs yong / de 'dra zhig red/[”] ces bshad/

Tom said slowly, “When you're in jail- you get to kinda- sensin' stuff. Guys ain't let to talk a hell of a lot together- two maybe, but not a crowd. An' so you get kinda sensy. If somepin's gonna bust- if say a fella's goin' stir-bugs an' take a crack at a guard with a mop handle- why, you know it 'fore it happens. An' if they's gonna be a break or a riot, nobody don't have to tell ya. You're sensy about it. You know.”

[“]de 'dra red dam/[”] Thom gyis [“]'dir cung sdod dang / gang ltar sang nyin bar du sdod dang / de bar du don dag ci zhig yin rung 'byung rgyu red/ ngas lam thog nas gzhon nu zhig dang gleng mol byas pa yin/ kho ni spyang khyi zhig dang 'dra bar rnam rig rgod la g.yo sgyu che/ 'on kyang / kho ni rnam rig rgod drags pa zhig red/ spyang khyi tshos rang don gcig pu ma gtogs gzhan pa ci la'ang kha ya mi byed la/ de nas ha cang bag yod tshul ldan zhig yin pa'i tshul gyis gnod med spro dga'i ngang nas 'dug pa yin/ 'on kyang / nye 'gram nas bya mo zhig song tshe/ da gzod ltad mo gzhan pa zhig bstan yong gi red/[”] ces bshad/

“Yeah?” “Stick aroun'.” said Tom. “Stick aroun' till tomorra anyways. Somepin's gonna come up. I was talkin' to a kid up the road. An' he's bein' jus' as sneaky an' wise as a dog coyote, but he's too wise. Dog coyote a-mindin' his own business an' innocent an' sweet, jus' havin' fun an' no harm- well, they's a hen roost clost by.”

kha se yis kho la nan tan gyis bltas shing / kho la dri ba zhig 'dri grabs byas rjes kha phyir dam por btsums/ kho'i rkang mdzub khag 'gul 'gul byed cing / khos pus mo lhod nas rkang pa mar bsrings pa na da gzod rang nyid kyi 'gul bzhin pa'i rkang mdzub rnams gsal por mthong thub/ de nas khos [“]ya ya/ des na nga gnas skabs ring mi 'gro/[”] zhes bshad/

Casy watched him intently, started to ask a question, and then shut his mouth tightly. He waggled his toes slowly and, releasing his knees, pushed out his foot so he could see it. “Yeah,” he said, “I won't go right yet.”

“Yeah!” said Casy, and he waved his toes up and down and studied them gravely. Tom settled back on his elbow and closed his eyes. Inside the tent he could hear the murmur of Rose of Sharon's voice and Connie's answering. The tarpaulin made a dark shadow and the wedge-shaped light at each end was hard and sharp. Rose of Sharon lay on a mattress and Connie squatted beside her. “I oughta help Ma,” Rose of Sharon said. “I tried, but ever' time I stirred about I throwed up.”

khon ne yi ngo mdangs nag por gyur [“]gal srid 'di 'dra yin pa shes na/ snga sa nas yong rgyu ma byas na ci ma rung / ngas pha yul nas 'drud 'then 'khor lo'i skor la slob sbyong byas nas/ de 'brel gyi las ka zhig btsal yod rgyu na nyin rer sgor gsum re can gyi las ka zhig rnyed yod nges/ mi gcig gis nyin rer sgor gsum re blangs na 'tsho ba skyid po zhig rol thub la/ mtshan mor glog brnyan blta ru'ang 'gro thub/[”]

Connie's eyes were sullen. “If I'd of knowed it would be like this I wouldn' of came. I'd a studied nights 'bout tractors back home an' got me a three-dollar job. Fella can live awful nice on three dollars a day, an' go to the pitcher show ever' night, too.”

Rose of Sharon looked apprehensive. “You're gonna study nights 'bout radios,” she said. He was long in answering. “Ain't you?” she demanded. “Yeah, sure. Soon's I get on my feet. Get a little money.”

She rolled up on her elbow. “You ain't givin' it up!” “No- no- 'course not. But- I didn' know they was places like this we got to live in.”

When he looked down at her he saw in her eyes a measuring of him, a calculation of him. “But I'm gonna study,” he said. “Soon's I get on my feet.”

She said fiercely, “We got to have a house 'fore the baby comes. We ain't gonna have this baby in no tent.”

Ma knelt beside the fire, breaking twigs to keep the flame up under the stew kettle. The fire flared and dropped and flared and dropped. The children, fifteen of them, stood silently and watched. And when the smell of the cooking stew came to their noses, their noses crinkled slightly. The sunlight glistened on hair tawny with dust. The children were embarrassed to be there, but they did not go. Ma talked quietly to a little girl who stood inside the lusting circle. She was older than the rest. She stood on one foot, caressing the back of her leg with a bare instep. Her arms were clasped behind her. She watched Ma with steady small gray eyes. She suggested, “I could break up some bresh if you want me, ma'am.”

Ma looked up from her work. “You want ta get ast to eat, huh?” “Yes, ma'am,” the girl said steadily.

a ma me 'gram nas kha tshur 'khor nas [“]jon/ da de 'dra bshad kyi ma 'dug bshad dgos na dkon mchog gi mdun nas shod/ khyod kyi sdig pa mi gzhan la 'go ru ma 'jug de 'dra byas na mi yag po ma red/[”] ces bshad/
Ma turned from the fire. “Don' go tellin', John,” she said. “Tell 'em to God. Don' go burdenin' other people with your sins. That ain't decent.”

jon gyis [“]ma bshad na gsang ba de tshos sems la na zug gtong gi 'dug[”] ces bshad/ [“]gang ltar mi gzhan la ma bshad/ yang min na gtsang 'gram du mar song nas/ mgo bo chu 'og tu bcug ste/ chu bo'i gzhung la lkog lab byos/[”] a phas a ma'i skad cha la 'thad pa'i mgo bo dal mor ldem bzhin [“]kho mos bshad pa 'grig 'dug sems nang gi gsang ba ci yod na phyir bton na sems nas skyid po zhig yin mod/ 'on kyang / de ltar byas na sdig pa phyi la khyab tu 'jug gi red/[”] ces bshad/

“They're a-eatin' on me,” said John. “Well, don' tell 'em. Go down the river an' stick your head under an' whisper 'em in the stream.” Pa nodded his head slowly at Ma's words. “She's right,” he said. “It gives a fella relief to tell, but it jus' spreads out his sin.”

a khu jon gyis phyi dro'i nyi 'od 'og tu ser por gyur pa'i ri bo'i tshogs la bltas nas 'dug cing / ri bo'i ldog brnyan khag ni kho'i mig nang du tshur shar/ de nas khos [“]ngas kyang 'di mgo mar gnon thub na 'dod ang / 'on kyang / 'dis nga'i glo mchin pa'i bar nas na zug bslangs yong /[”] zhes bshad/ kho'i rgyab phyogs nas ro si sha ron gnyid ma sad kyis gur sgo la bud/ kho mos 'tshig pa za ba'i rnam 'gyur dang bcas [“]khon ne gang du phyin song / ngas khon ne yun ring zhig la ma mthong / kho gang du phyin pa yin nam/[”] zhes bshad/

Uncle John looked up to the sun-gold mountains, and the mountains were reflected in his eyes. “I wisht I could run it down,” he said. “But I can't. She's a-bitin' in my guts.” Behind him Rose of Sharon moved dizzily out of the tent. “Where's Connie?” she asked irritably. “I ain't seen Connie for a long time. Where'd he go?”

a mas [“]ngas kho rang mthong ma byung / gal srid ngas kho rang mthong na/ khyod kyis kho 'tshol bzhin 'dug ces lab yong /[”] zhes bshad/ ro si sha ron gyis [“]nga'i gzugs po bde yi mi 'dug khon ne yis nga bskyur bzhag pa yin rgyu ma red/[”] ces bshad/
“I ain't seen him,” said Ma. “If I see 'im, I'll tell 'im you want 'im.” “I ain't feelin' good,” said Rose of Sharon. “Connie shouldn' of left me.”
a mas bskrangs nas yod pa'i bu mo'i gdong par yar bltas nas [“]khyod rang ngus pa yin nam/[”] zhes bshad/ ro si sha ron gyi mig zung las mchi ma'i phreng rdog gsar pa 'ga' re 'thor yong /
Ma looked up to the girl's swollen face. “You been a-cryin',” she said. The tears started freshly in Rose of Sharon's eyes.

a mas nan tan gyi sgo nas [“]khyod kyis sra rgyobs shig 'dir nga tsho bza' mi mang po yod pas/ khyod kyis sra rgyobs shig mar shog la zhog khog gi shun lpags bshus/ khyod kyis rang sems rang gis dkrug gi yod pa red/[”] ces bshad/
Ma went on firmly, “You git aholt on yaself. They's a lot of us here. You git aholt on yaself. Come here now an' peel some potatoes. You're feelin' sorry for yaself.”

bu mo kha phyir 'khor nas gur nang du phyir 'gro grabs shig byas/ kho mos a ma'i grang lhang lhang gi mig mdangs las byol thabs byas mod/ 'on kyang / mig mdangs des kho mo dbang du bsdus pas/ kho mo dal mos tshur me phung gi 'gram du yong nas [“]kho 'di ltar kha bral song ba yin rgyu ma red/[”] ces bshad/ de nas kho mo'i gdong gi mig chu'i bzhur rgyun chad/
The girl started to go back in the tent. She tried to avoid Ma's stern eyes, but they compelled her and she came slowly toward the fire. “He shouldn' of went away,” she said, but the tears were gone.

a mas [“]khyod kyis las ka las dgos/ rtag par gur nang du 'dzul nas/ sems la mi 'char dgu 'char zhig dran/ ngas da bar du khyod la kha ya byed rgyu ma byung / 'on kyang / da nas bzung do snang byed rgyu yin/ ya/ gri 'di 'khyer nas zhog khog de dag gtubs shig[”] ces bshad/
“You got to work,” Ma said. “Set in the tent an' you'll get feelin' sorry about yaself. I ain't had time to take you in han'. I will now. You take this here knife an' get to them potatoes.”

bu mo pus btsugs su bsdad nas bka' dang du blangs shing / de nas rtsub spyod dang bcas [“]kho tshur slebs pa'i bar du gcig sgug dang / de nas kho la bshad rgyu yod tshad bshad rgyu yin/[”] zhes bshad/
The girl knelt down and obeyed. She said fiercely, “Wait'll I see 'im. I'll tell 'im.”

a ma'i gdong la dal mos 'dzum zhig 'khor/ [“]khos khyod rang rdung srid/ rgyun par rang sems rang gis dkrug nas/ khos khyod rdung rung / de khyod kyis rang sdug rang gis nyos pa red/ gal srid khos khyod brdungs nas khyod la cung bsam shes su bcug yod na/ ngas da rung kho la tshe ring lo brgya zhu rgyu yin/[”] bu mo'i mig nang du khong khro'i me lce 'bar gyin 'dug mod/ 'on kyang / khu sim mer bsdad/

Ma smiled slowly. “He might smack you. You got it comin' with whinin' aroun' an' candyin' yaself. If he smacks some sense in you I'll bless 'im.” The girl's eyes blazed with resentment, but she was silent.

a khu jon gyis rang nyid kyi zheng kha che ba'i mthe bong gis btsa' yis zin pa'i gzer ma de sa nang du zab mor bsnun nas [“]ngas ma bshad na bzod kyi mi 'dug[”] ces bshad/ a phas [“]a ltas ngan/ bzod mi thub na da shod/ ya/ khyod kyis su bsad pa yin/[”] zhes bshad/
Uncle John pushed his rusty nail deep into the ground with his broad thumb. “I got to tell,” he said. Pa said, “Well, tell then, goddamn it! Who'd ya kill?”

a khu jon gyis rang nyid kyi rdzi dor sngon po'i glo khug chung ba ru mthe bong bsrings nas/ ltebs rtseg brgyab pa'i shog sgor rnying hrul zhig phyir bton yong / khos de'i ltebs kha phyes nas tshur bstan te [“]sgor mo lnga red/[”] ces bshad/ a phas [“]'di brkus yong ba yin nam/[”] zhes dris/
Uncle John dug with his thumbs into the watch pocket of his blue jeans and scooped out a folded dirty bill. He spread it out and showed it. “Fi' dollars,” he said. “Steal her?” Pa asked.

[“]min/ 'di nga la ma gzhi nas yod/ logs su bskungs nas bzhag pa yin/[”] [“]'di khyod kyi red a/ e red/[”] [“]red/ 'on kyang / ngas 'di ltar sgor mo sger skung byas na 'grig gi yod pa ma red/[”] a mas [“]ngas der sdig pa yod pa ci yang mthong gi mi 'dug de khyod kyi red a/[”] zhes bshad/
“No, I had her. Kept her out.” “She was yourn, wasn't she?” “Yeah, but I didn't have no right to keep her out.” “I don't see much sin in that,” Ma said. “It's yourn.”

a khu jon gyis dal mos [“]'di ni rang gar bskungs bzhag pa tsam min/ 'di ngas chang rag 'thung byed du bskungs pa yin/ khog gi sdug bsngal 'dis na zug gtong thengs re rer/ ngas chang rag 'thung nas sdug mgo gnon gyi yod la/ dus tshod de 'dra zhig mi 'gyangs par slebs grabs yod pa tshor yod/ da dung dus tshod de 'dra zhig slebs med snyam yod mod/ 'on kyang / de nas chos dpon des Thom gyi ched du rang nyid nyen rtog pa la rtsis sprad pa'i don dag 'di byung ba red/[”] ces bshad/

Uncle John said slowly, “It ain't only the keepin' her out. I kep' her out to get drunk. I knowed they was gonna come a time when I got to get drunk, when I'd get to hurtin' inside so I got to get drunk. Figgered time wasn' yet, an' then- the preacher went an' give 'imself up to save Tom.”

a phas mgo bo ldem ldem byed la/ pha rol pa'i skad cha gsal por go thub pa'i ched du mgo bo tshur la 'khyogs/ ru the ni byi la zhig dang 'dra bar gru mo'i steng du gog nas nye sar nur zhing / win h+phild kyis kho mo'i rjes su 'brangs/ ro si sha ron gyis lag gi gri yis zhog khog steng du i khung gting zab pa zhig gtod/ dgong dro'i snang ba je stug dang je sngo red/ a mas bden don ra sprod byed pa'i nga ro yis [“]khos Thom bskyabs pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis/ khyod kyis chang 'thung dgos pa'i gnas lugs shig ngas mthong gi mi 'dug[”] ces bshad/

Pa nodded his head up and down and cocked his head to hear. Ruthie moved closer, like a puppy, crawling up on her elbows, and Winfield followed her. Rose of Sharon dug at a deep eye in a potato with the point of her knife. The evening light deepened and became more blue. Ma said, in a sharp matter-of-fact tone, “I don' see why him savin' Tom got to get you drunk.”

jon gyis skyo snang dang bcas [“]gnas lugs 'di yin zer rgyu dka' mod/ 'on kyang / nga'i sems pa ha cang sdug khos de 'dra'i las sla mos nyes pa rang steng du blangs song a/ kho kho tsho'i mdun la bud nas/ [‘]de ngas byas pa yin/[’] zhes de 'dra'i snang ba yang mos khas blangs song la/ de nas kho tshos kho khrid song ba red/ de bas ngas chang 'thung nas rang nyid bzi ru 'jug dgos/[”] ces bshad/
John said sadly, “Can't say her. I feel awful. He done her so easy. Jus' stepped up there an' says, 'I done her.' An' they took 'im away. An' I'm a-gonna get drunk.”

a phas da dung yang mgo bo ldem bzhin du [“]ngas bltas na khyod kyis bshad dgos don mi 'dug gal srid nga rang khyod yin rgyu na/ rang nyid ra bzi 'dod na thad kar chang 'thung du 'gro yi red/[”] ces bshad/
Pa still nodded his head. “I don't see why you got to tell,” he said. “If it was me, I'd jus' go off an' get drunk if I had to.”

a khu jon gyis skyo snang dang bcas [“]ma gzhi ngas rang nyid kyi sdig pa sbyong ba'i skal ba zhig ldan rgyu red bsam yod/ 'on kyang / de 'dra'i go skabs de shor zin pa red/ ngas go skabs de dam 'dzin byed ma thub pas/ da lta shor zin pa red/[”] ces bshad cing / de nas [“]wa ye/ khyod rang 'u tshang gi sgor bdag yin pas/ nga la sgor mo gnyis byin dang /[”] zhes bshad/

“Come a time when I could a did somepin an' took the big sin off my soul,” Uncle John said sadly. “An' I slipped up. I didn' jump on her, an'- an' she got away. Lookie!” he said, “You got the money. Gimme two dollars.”

a phas 'dod la mi 'dod kyis glo khug tu lag pa bsrings nas/ ko khug de phyir phyung yong / [“]chang gis bzi bar sgor mo bdun re dgos rgyu ma red/ khyod kyis sham phen chang [3]'dra 'thung dgos rgyu ma red a/[”]
Pa reached reluctantly into his pocket and brought out the leather pouch. “You ain't gonna need no seven dollars to get drunk. You don't need to drink champagny water.”

[3] sham phen chang / [champagny, Champagne] ste/ rgun 'brum dkar po las bzos pa'i rgun chang lbu ba sob sob kyi rigs shig yin zhing / ston mo dang mdzad sgo sogs su rten 'brel mtshon byed du rgyas spros kyis btung ba zhig yin/

a khu jon gyis sgor lnga lo can po de tshur bsrings/ [“]khyod kyis 'di 'khyer nas nga la sgor mo gnyis byin dang / sgor mo gnyis kyis nga yag thag chod bzi thub rgyu red/ ngas rang steng nas 'phro brlag gtong ba'i sdig pa de gsog mi 'dod/ ngas lag tu ga tshod yod na de tshod btung gi red/ nam rgyun de 'dra yin/[”] a phas shog sgor rnying pa de tshur blangs nas/ lcags sgor gnyis phar sprod bzhin [“]ya 'di/ mi zhig yin na rang nyid kyis ci zhig byed 'dod pa de byed dgos/ mi gzhan pas gnas lugs ci zhig bshad rung phan thogs kyi ma red/[”] ces bshad/

Uncle John held out his bill. “You take this here an' gimme two dollars. I can get good an' drunk for two dollars. I don' want no sin of waste on me. I'll spend whatever I got. Always do.” Pa took the dirty bill and gave Uncle John two silver dollars. “There ya are,” he said. “A fella got to do what he got to do. Nobody don' know enough to tell 'im.”
a khu jon gyis lcags sgor rnams tshur blangs/ [“]khyod rang khong khro zos med dam/ nga la'ang thabs shes med pa shes rgyu red/ e red/[”]
Uncle John took the coins. “You ain't gonna be mad? You know I got to?”
a phas [“]dkon mchog ye shu/ de los shes/ khyod rang nyid kyis ci zhig byed dgos min de/ khyod rang nyid la gsal ba red/[”] ces bshad/
“Christ, yes,” said Pa. “You know what you got to do.”
jon gyis [“]ngas 'di ma 'thung na/ do nub kyi mtshan mo 'di pha rol tu 'gro dka' mo red/[”] ces bshad cing /
“I wouldn' be able to get through this night no other way,” he said.
de nas a ma la kha 'khor nas [“]khyod kyis kyang nga'i steng du le 'khon mi dkri'am/[”] zhes bshad/
He turned to Ma. “You ain't gonna hold her over me?”
a mas mgo bo yar la mi 'gyog par/ skad ngag 'jam pos [“]mi dkri/ mi dkri/ khyod rang gis thungs shig[”] ces bshad/
Ma didn't look up. “No,” she said softly. “No- you go 'long.”

a khu jon yar langs nas/ 'u thug thabs zad kyi rnam pas dgong dro'i snang ba'i khrod du phyin/ kho rang ar 'dam byugs pa'i gzhung lam phyogs su song zhing / gzhung lam 'phred kyis brgal nas skam zas tshong khang de ru phyin/ tshong khang gi drwa tshags sgo mo'i mdun du/ khos rang nyid kyi zhwa mo phud nas thang gi thal rdul khrod du g.yugs shing / rang mthong rang gis gcog pa'i tshul gyis de'i steng du phyi rting gis rdog brdzis shig byas/ de nas khos rang nyid kyi ral zhing btsog pa'i zhwa mo nag po de de gar bskyur/ kho tshong khang gi nang du 'dzul nas/ lcags tshags kyi nang du chang dkar dam be sna tshogs bsgrigs yod pa'i tshong sgrom der song /

He stood up and walked forlornly away in the evening. He walked up to the concrete highway and across the pavement to the grocery store. In front of the screen door he took off his hat, dropped it into the dust, and ground it with his heel in self-abasement. And he left his black hat there, broken and dirty. He entered the store and walked to the shelves where the whisky bottles stood behind wire netting.
a pha dang a ma/ byis pa tsho bcas kyis a khu jon phar 'gro bar bltas/ ro si sha ron gyis zhog khog gi steng du sdang mig bgrad/
Pa and Ma and the children watched Uncle John move away. Rose of Sharon kept her eyes resentfully on the potatoes.
a mas [“]jon snying rje/ chang 'thung bas phan thogs min mi shes/ thogs rgyu ma red/ mi zhig tshad 'di 'dra la lhung ba mthong myong med/[”] ces bshad/
“Poor John,” Ma said. “I wondered if it would a done any good if-no- I guess not. I never seen a man so drove.”

ru the thal rdul khrod nas rang nyid kyi 'gram ngos su log nas bsdad/ kho mos mgo bo win h+phild dang thag nye sar bcar te/ kho'i rna ba kho mo'i kha rtsar tshur 'then nas [“]ngas kyang chang 'thung nas bzi rgyu yin/[”] zhes shub pur bshad/ win h+phild kyis sna khung du sngur ba 'then bzhin kha dam por btsums/

Ruthie turned on her side in the dust. She put her head close to Winfield's head and pulled his ear against her mouth. She whispered, “I'm gonna get drunk.” Winfield snorted and pinched his mouth tight.

byis pa gnyis kas dbugs kha btsan gyis bsdams nas gog ma nur gyis phar song zhing / kho tshos khong dgod byas pas gdong mdog dmar skya ru gyur/ kho tshos ras gur gyi ltag rgyab nas bskor nas song ste/ gur gyi phar phyogs su bzi skad re 'don bzhin mchong ma lding gis song / kho tsho lcang tshal phyogs su bros shing / lcang tshal nang du slebs pa na/ da gzod skad shugs chen pos 'dzer skad dang bcas bgad/ ru the yis mig gnyis btsums nas gzugs po'i lhu tshigs tshang ma lhod cing / de nas lce leb phyi la bsrings nas khyar khyor yar yor gyis 'gro bzhin [“]nga bzi 'dug[”] ces bshad/

The two children crawled away, holding their breath, their faces purple with the pressure of their giggles. They crawled around the tent and leaped up and ran squealing away from the tent. They ran to the willows, and once concealed, they shrieked with laughter. Ruthie crossed her eyes and loosened her joints; she staggered about, tripping loosely with her tongue hanging out. “I'm drunk,” she said.

win h+phild kyis skad gsang mthon pos [“]ltos dang / nga la ltos dang / nga 'dir a khu jon yin khul byed ya/[”] zhes zer bzhin/ khos lag pa gnyis ka rdeb bzhin dbugs thung blangs shing / mgo yu 'khor ba'i bar du dkris 'khor brgyab/
“Look,” Winfield cried. “Looka me, here's me, an' I'm Uncle John.” He flapped his arms and puffed, he whirled until he was dizzy.
ru the yis [“]de 'dra ma red/ 'di 'dra red/ 'di ltar red/ nga a khu jon yin/ nga bzi bo bzi rkyang chags 'dug[”] ces bshad/
“No,” said Ruthie. “Here's the way. Here's the way. I'm Uncle John. I'm awful drunk.”

al dang Thom gnyis ka lcang tshal khrod nas tshur yong nas/ smyon pa dang 'dra bar khyar khyor yar yor byed bzhin pa'i byis pa gnyis ka mthong / da lta dgong kha'i snang ba rab rib tu gyur 'dug pas/ Thom 'gro mtshams bzhag nas zhib lta byas [“]kho tsho ru the dang win h+phild gnyis ka ma red dam/ kho gnyis la ltas ngan ci zhig byung ba yin/[”] kho tsho nye sar song zhing / de nas Thom gyis [“]khyod gnyis smyos yod pa min nam/[”] zhes bshad/

Al and Tom walked quietly through the willows, and they came on the children staggering crazily about. The dusk was thick now. Tom stopped and peered. “Ain't that Ruthie an' Winfiel'? What the hell's the matter with 'em?” They walked nearer. “You crazy?” Tom asked.
byis pa gnyis ka ngo tsha nas rtsed mtshams bzhag cing / ru the yis [“]nga tshos/ nga tshos rtsed mo rtse bzhin pa yin/[”] zhes bshad/
The children stopped, embarrassed. “We was- jus' playin',” Ruthie said.
al gyis [“]rtsed stangs de smyon pa 'dra po zhig red/[”] ces bshad/
“It's a crazy way to play,” said Al.
ru the yis sba gsang med pa'i sgo nas [“]smyo rtags 'di las kyang che ba mang po mthong rgyu 'dug a/[”] zhes bshad/
Ruthie said pertly, “It ain't no crazier'n a lot of things.”

al sngun du song nas Thom la [“]deng sang ru the yis zur za'i skad cha mang po zhig sbyangs yong gi 'dug a/ kho mos 'di 'dra sbyong brdar byas nas yun ring zhig yin la/ da lta bed spyod gtong ba'i dus la babs pa yin rgyu red/[”] ces bshad/
Al walked on. He said to Tom, “Ruthie's workin' up a kick in the pants. She been workin' it up a long time. 'Bout due for it.”

ru the yis kho'i rgyab phyogs nas gdong pa snyer snyer byas shing / mdzub mos kha sha phyi la bslogs pa dang / lce leb sgo la bsrings nas g.yug g.yug byas te/ kho'i kha slong rgyu yod tshad bslangs mod/ al kha phyir ma 'khor zhing kho mor bltas kyang ma bltas/ kho mos kho tsho'i rtsed mo de'i mjug skyong ched win h+phild la bltas mod/ 'on kyang / rtsed mo de gzhi nas bro ba med pa chags zin la/ de kho gnyis kyis shes kyi yod/

Ruthie mushed her face at his back, pulled out her mouth with her forefinger, slobbered her tongue at him, outraged him in every way she knew, but Al did not turn back to look at her. She looked at Winfield again to start the game, but it had been spoiled. They both knew it.

win h+phild kyis [“]chu 'gram du mar song nas/ mgo bo chu nang du thim pa'i rtsed mo rtse ya/[”] zhes bsam tshul bton pas/ kho tsho lcang tshal brgyud nas mar la song / kho gnyis ka al gyi steng du khong khro zos yod/
“Le's go down the water an' duck our heads,” Winfield suggested. They walked down through the willows, and they were angry at Al.

sa srod kyi snang ba'i khrod nas/ al dang Thom gnyis ka khu sim pos song zhing / Thom gyis [“]kha se yis de 'dra ma byas na ang 'dod/ de ngas snga tsam nas tshor yod na chog nye char khos rgyun du nga tsho'i ched du ci yang ma bsgrubs pa'i skor bshad kyi yod/ kho ni mi khyad mtshar po zhig red/ nam rgyun bsam blo kho na btang nas/[”] zhes bshad/
Al and Tom went quietly in the dusk. Tom said, “Casy shouldn' of did it. I might of knew, though. He was talkin' how he ain't done nothin' for us. He's a funny fella, Al. All the time thinkin'.”
al gyis [“]chos dpon byas pa'i rkyen gyis yin rgyu red/ kho tshor nam rgyun bsam rgyu dran rgyu mang /[”] zhes bshad/
“Comes from bein' a preacher,” Al said. “They get all messed up with stuff.”
[“]khyod kyis bltas na khon ne gang du phyin pa yin rgyu red/[”] [“]ngas bltas na skyag pa gtong du phyin pa yin rgyu red/[”] [“]des na kho'i skyag lam dngos gnas thag ring red/[”]
“Where ya s'pose Connie was a-goin'?” “Goin' to take a crap, I guess.” “Well, he was goin' a hell of a long way.”

kho tsho ras gur tsho'i khrod nas gur rtsar bcar nas tshur yong / kho tsho h+phi lo'e Di tshang gi ras gur 'gram du slebs skabs su/ 'bod sgra chung chung zhig gis kho tsho'i 'gro mtshams bcad/ kho tsho gur gyi sgo phyar gyi nye sar bcar nas tsog pur mar sgur/ h+phi lo'e Di yis gur 'dabs cung yar bkyags [“]khyod tsho 'gro rgyu byas yod dam/[”]

They walked among the tents, keeping close to the walls. At Floyd's tent a soft hail stopped them. They came near to the tent flap and squatted down. Floyd raised the canvas a little. “You gettin' out?”

Thom gyis [“]da rung mi shes/ khyod kyis bltas na song na dga' rgyu red dam/[”] zhes bshad/ h+phi lo'e Di skyo snang gis gad mo bgad/ [“]glang rgan des ci zhig bshad song ba go ma song ngam/ khyod tsho 'di nas kha ma bral na/ kho tshos zhag sgar yongs rdzogs mer bsreg rgyu red/ nyen rtog pa des rdung rdeg cig gzed rjes yang bskyar 'di phyogs su phyir yong gi ma red 'dod na/ de khyod kyi glen rtags red/ kho tshos rgyan 'dzugs khang gi mi de tsho khrid yong nas sgar 'di do nub bsreg rgyu red/[”]

Tom said, “I don' know. Think we better?” Floyd laughed sourly. “You heard what the bull said. They'll burn ya out if ya don't. 'F you think that guy's gonna take a beatin' 'thout gettin' back, you're nuts. The pool-room boys'll be down here tonight to burn us out.”
Thom gyis [“]des na song na dga' rgyu red/ khyod tsho gang du 'gro rgyu yin/[”] zhes bshad/

THE MOVING, QUESTING people were migrants now. Those families who had lived on a little piece of land, who had lived and died on forty acres, had eaten or starved on the produce of forty acres, had now the whole West to rove in. And they scampered about, looking for work; and the highways were streams of people, and the ditch banks were lines of people. Behind them more were coming. The great highways streamed with moving people. There in the Middle- and Southwest had lived a simple agrarian folk who had not changed with industry, who had not farmed with machines or known the power and danger of machines in private hands. They had not grown up in the paradoxes of industry. Their senses were still sharp to the ridiculousness of the industrial life.
