Tom stopped and stood still. “Who are you?” A man stood up and walked near. Tom could see the gun in his hand. Then a flashlight played on his face. “Where you think you're going?” “Well, I thought I'd take a walk. Any law against it?” “You better walk some other way.”

Thom gyis [“]nga tha na 'di'i phyi la'ang 'bud mi chog pa red dam/[”] zhes dris/ [“]do nub mi chog khyod rang nyid yag po byas te phyir 'gro rgyu yin nam yang na ngas rogs pa re bos yong nas khyod rang phyir skyel du 'jug rgyu yin/[”]
Tom asked, “Can't I even get out of here?” “Not tonight you can't. Want to walk back, or shall I whistle some help an' take you?”

Thom gyis [“]o/ de mi dgos/ nga phyi logs su 'gro don gal chen 'dra med/ 'di de 'dra'i rnyog 'dzing can zhig yin na nga ni 'gro 'dod med do// ya/ des na nga nang du phyir 'gro rgyu yin/[”] zhes bshad/ grib gzugs nag po de lhod la babs shing / glog bzhu mar phab [“]de red ya/ 'di yang khyod kyi ched du red a/ gsang myul pa smyon pa de tshos khyod tshor lag e zhog blta yi red/[”] [“]gsang myul pa zer na/[”] [“]ltas ngan dmar phyogs pa de tsho/[”]

“Hell,” said Tom, “it ain't nothin' to me. If it's gonna cause a mess, I don't give a darn. Sure, I'll go back.” The dark figure relaxed. The flash went off. “Ya see, it's for your own good. Them crazy pickets might get you.” “What pickets?” “Them goddamn reds.”

Thom gyis [“]o/ ngas de tsho'i skor ma shes/[”] zhes bshad/ [“]khyod nang du yong skabs kho tsho mthong yod rgyu red/ mthong ma song ngam/[”] [“]o/ de dus phyi logs su mi mang po zhig 'dug 'on kyang / de gar nyen rtog pa ha cang mang bas/ ci zhig yin pa ha go ma song / 'grim 'grul don rkyen zhig byung ba yin nam bsam song /[”] [“]ya/ khyod phyir nang du song dang de dga'/[”]

“Oh,” said Tom. “I didn' know 'bout them.” “You seen 'em when you come, didn' you?” “Well, I seen a bunch a guys, but they was so many cops I didn' know. Thought it was a accident.” “Well, you better git along back.”

[“]ya ya/ nga la de mi chog rgyu ci yang med/ sku zhabs/[”] kho kha phyir 'khor nas phar song / khos khu sim pos lam bu brgyud nas yar gom pa brgya lhag song rjes/ 'gro mtshams bzhag nas rna nyan byas te bsdad/ zhing chu'i yur bu'i 'gram nas byi la lta bu'i dom khra rnga ring gi zug skad re 'tsher yong la/ ha cang thag ring sa zhig nas 'dogs khyi'i zug skad kyang grag yong / Thom lam 'gram du mar bsdad nas rna nyan byas te bsdad/ khos mtshan rgyu bya khra'i hab cha thos shing / sog ma'i zhing nang du mtshan rgyu srog chags tsho 'jab rgyug byed bzhin pa'i tshag sgra yang go nus/ khos shar nub gnyis kyi gnam sa 'dres mtshams la bltas pa na/ phyogs gnyis ka nag thom me yin pas/ rgyab ljongs dang ri mo'i dbye ba mi 'dug da lta kho yar langs nas/ dal mos lam gyi g.yas phyogs su song ste sog ma'i zhing nang du babs/ de gar khos gzugs po sog phung gi mtho dma' dang mnyam par dma' mor sgur nas dal mos song zhing / mtshams la lar 'gro mtshams bzhag nas rna nyan re byas/ mjug mthar kho rang ra ba'i 'gram du slebs byung la/ ra ba de ni gze ma ra mgo'i lcags skud rkya lnga las grub pa zhig red/ kho lcags tsher ra ba'i 'gram du gan rkyal du log nas/ lcags skud rkya 'og ma de'i 'og tu mgo bo bcug cing / de nas lag pas gze ma ra mgo'i lcags skud de dag yar la bkyags nas rkang pa sa la gtad de/ rang nyid kyi gzugs po dal mos 'og tu bsnur/

“That's O.K. with me, mister.” He swung about and started back. He walked quietly along the road a hundred yards, and then he stopped and listened. The twittering call of a raccoon sounded near the irrigation ditch and, very far away, the angry howl of a tied dog. Tom sat down beside the road and listened. He heard the high soft laughter of a night hawk and the stealthy movement of a creeping animal in the stubble. He inspected the skyline in both directions, dark frames both ways, nothing to show against. Now he stood up and walked slowly to the right of the road, off into the stubble field, and he walked bent down, nearly as low as the haycocks. He moved slowly and stopped occasionally to listen. At last he came to the wire fence, five strands of taut barbed wire. Beside the fence he lay on his back, moved his head under the lowest strand, held the wire up with his hands and slid himself under, pushing against the ground with his feet.

kho rang yar langs grabs yod pa'i skabs der mi skor zhig gzhung lam gyi 'gram nas tshur yong / kho tsho phar thag ring la song ba'i bar du Thom gyis de gar rang sor sgug cing / de nas kho yar langs nas kho tsho'i rjes ded nas song / khos lam 'gram du ras gur e yod lta bzhin song / skabs der rlangs 'khor 'ga' res gzhung lam brgyud nas phar phyin song / zhing gi dkyil nas mar rgyug chu zhig yod cing / gzhung lam gyi ar 'dam gyi zam pas rgyug chu de 'phred kyis brgal yod/ Thom gyis zam pa'i steng nas mar zam 'gram du bltas pa na/ grog shur zab mo de'i mthil du ras gur zhig tu sgron me bkar yod pa mthong / khos de la yud tsam bltas shing / de nas khos gur nang gi mi'i grib gzugs gur gyi ras gzhi'i ngos su phog yod pa mthong / Thom ra ba zhig gi steng du 'gos nas/ rtsi shing dang lcang sdong thung thung mang po zhig brgyud nas mar grog rong du babs/ grog rong gi mthil du chu phran zhig yod cing / khos de'i 'gram nas lam phran zhig rnyed/ mi zhig gur mdun du sgam zhig gi steng du bsdad 'dug

He was about to get up when a group of men walked by on the edge of the highway. Tom waited until they were far ahead before he stood up and followed them. He watched the side of the road for tents. A few automobiles went by. A stream cut across the fields, and the highway crossed it on a small concrete bridge. Tom looked over the side of the bridge. In the bottom of the deep ravine he saw a tent and a lantern was burning inside. He watched it for a moment, saw the shadows of people against the canvas walls. Tom climbed a fence and moved down into the ravine through brush and dwarf willows; and in the bottom, beside a tiny stream, he found a trail. A man sat on a box in front of the tent.

Thom gyis [“]dgong mo bde legs/[”] zhes bshad/ [“]khyod su yin/[”] [“]a/ un/ nga rang / nga lam 'gro pa zhig yin/[”] [“]'di gar khyod kyis ngo shes pa yod dam/[”] [“]med/ ngas nga rang lam 'gro pa zhig yin lab pa ma yin nam/[”] gur nang nas mi zhig gis mgo bo phyi la bsrings nas [“]don dag ci red/[”] ces bshad/

“Evenin',” Tom said. “Who are you?” “Well- I guess, well- I'm jus' goin' past.” “Know anybody here?” “No. I tell you I was jus' goin' past.” A head stuck out of the tent. A voice said, “What's the matter?”

Thom gyis [“]kha se/[”] zhes skad mthon pos [“]kha se/ dkon mchog ye shu/ khyod kyis 'di gar ci zhig byed bzhin yod/[”] ces bshad/ [“]o/ dkon mchog mkhyen/ Thom jo Di red 'dug a/ nang du shog a Thom/ nang du shog[”] gur mdun gyi mi des [“]kho ngo shes kyi 'dug a/ e red/[”] ces dris/ [“]ngo e shes e/ dkon mchog ye shu/ shes dang shes/ lo mang po'i ring gi ngo shes yin/ nga rang nub phyogs su kho dang 'grogs nas yong ba yin/ nang du shog Thom/[”] khos Thom gyi gru mor 'jus nas gur nang du khrid/

“Casy!” Tom cried. “Casy! For Chris' sake, what you doin' here?” “Why, my God, it's Tom Joad! Come on in, Tommy. Come on in.” “Know him, do ya?” the man in front asked. “Know him? Christ, yes. Knowed him for years. I come west with him. Come on in, Tom.” He clutched Tom's elbow and pulled him into the tent.

gur nang du skyes pa gsum thang la bsdad yod cing / gur gyi dbus su sgron me zhig bzhag yod/ skyes pa gsum pos dogs snang dang bcas yar bltas/ gdong pa nag la smin ma bsdus pa'i mi zhig gis lag pa mdun du bsrings nas [“]khyod dang 'phrad par dga' bo byung / ngas kha se yis khyod kyi skor bshad pa go myong / 'di khyod kyis bshad bzhin pa'i mi de red a/ e red/[”] ces bshad/ [“]red ya/ kho red/ a dkon mchog khyod tshang gi bza' mi tsho gang du yod/ khyod kyis 'di gar ci zhig byed bzhin pa yin/[”]

Three other men sat on the ground, and in the center of the tent a lantern burned. The men looked up suspiciously. A dark-faced, scowling man held out his hand. “Glad to meet ya,” he said. “I heard what Casy said. This the fella you was tellin' about?” “Sure. This is him. Well, for God's sake! Where's your folks? What you doin' here?”

Thom gyis [“]un/ nga tshos 'di phyogs su las ka 'dug zer ba go byung / de bas nga tsho 'di gar yong ba yin/ de nas mnga' sde'i nyen rtog pa skor zhig gis nga tsho zhing ra 'di'i nang du khrid byung la/ de nas nga tshos phyi dro hril por las ka las pa yin/ ngas mi skor zhig gis skad cor rgyag bzhin pa mthong byung / 'on kyang / zhing ra'i nang gi mi tshos de yin 'di yin gcig kyang bshad kyi mi 'dug de bas nga 'di gar gnas tshul rtsad gcod byed du yong ba yin/ khyod 'di gar ji ltar 'byor ba yin/ kha se/[”] zhes bshad/

“Well,” said Tom, “we heard they was work this-a-way. An' we come, an' a bunch a State cops run us into this here ranch an' we been a-pickin' peaches all afternoon. I seen a bunch a fellas yellin'. They wouldn' tell me nothin', so I come out here to see what's goin' on. How'n hell'd you get here, Casy?”
chos dpon mdun la khen pas/ sgron me'i 'od kor ser po de kho'i mtho zhing skya ba'i dpral ba'i steng du phog
The preacher leaned forward and the yellow lantern light fell on his high pale forehead. “Jail house is a kinda funny place,” he said.

chos dpon gyis [“]btson khang zer ba de gnas khyad mtshar zhig red/ ston pa ye shu khong chos kyi gnas lugs 'tshol du song ba ltar/ nga yang de gar dben gnas 'khyams pa lta bu red/ ngas sngon chad mtshams la lar chos kyi gnas lugs rtogs grabs rtogs grabs byas mod/ da thengs btson khang gi nang nas ngas gnas lugs cha tshang ba zhig rtogs song /[”] zhes bshad cing / kho'i mig zung la rno kha dang 'jam sha dus mnyam du babs [“]btson khang rnying pa chen po zhig red/ rgyun du nang du btson pas gang yod pa bshad ci dgos/ btson pa gsar pa nang du yong zhing / btson pa rnying pa phyi la bud 'gro/ de nas/ yin dang yin/ ngas kho tsho tshang mar kha brda byas pa yin/[”]

“Here's me, been a-goin' into the wilderness like Jesus to try find out somepin. Almost got her sometimes, too. But it's in the jail house I really got her.” His eyes were sharp and merry. “Great big ol' cell, an' she's full all a time. New guys come in, and guys go out. An' 'course I talked to all of 'em.”

Thom gyis [“]khyod kyis tshang mar kha brda byas yod dang yod/ khyod rgyun du skad cha bshad rgyur dga'/ khyod 'di srog khrims stegs bu'i steng du bskyon rung / da dung srog gcod shan pa dang lhan du kha brda byas nas 'dug mkhan de 'dra red/ khyod 'dra 'dra'i gtam bshad la dga' mkhan zhig mthong myong med/[”] ces bshad/ gur nang gi skyes pa tsho gad mo bgad/ lus po skam zhing rid la gdong par gnyer mas khengs pa'i skyes pa gzugs chung zhig gis/ rang nyid kyi pus mo'i steng du thal lcag gis gzhus nas [“]khos nam rgyun gcig bshad nas bsdad yod/ yul mi tsho yang kho'i skad char nyan rgyur dga'/[”] zhes bshad/

“'Course you did,” said Tom. “Always talk. If you was up on the gallows you'd be passin' the time a day with the hangman. Never seen sech a talker.” The men in the tent chuckled. A wizened little man with a wrinkled face slapped his knee. “Talks all the time,” he said. “Folks kinda likes to hear 'im, though.”
Thom gyis [“]kho sngon chad chos dpon zhig red ya/ de khos khyod tshor bshad byung ngam/[”] zhes bshad/ [“]los bshad/ bshad byung /[”]
“Use' ta be a preacher,” said Tom. “Did he tell that?” “Sure, he told.”

kha se yis kha snyer tsam byas nas [“]un/ de nas/ ngas don dag mang po zhig ha go mgo brtsams byung / btson khang du lhung ba'i btson pa 'ga' re ni ra bzi nas don rkyen bslangs pa de 'dra yin pa ma gtogs/ de'i nang gi mang che ba ni rku byas pa'i rkyen gyis btson du tshud pa red la/ brkus pa'i ca lag khag kyang kho tshor kha tsha dgos gtugs kyi mkho dngos de 'dra yin la/ mkho dngos de tsho yang brkus na ma gtogs kho tsho'i lag tu mi yong ba de 'dra red/ ha go yi 'dug gam/[”] zhes bshad nas tshig mjug dri bas bsdus/

Casy grinned. “Well, sir,” he went on, “I begin gettin' at things. Some of them fellas in the tank was drunks, but mostly they was there 'cause they stole stuff; an' mostly it was stuff they needed an' couldn' get no other way. Ya see?” he asked.

Thom gyis [“]ha go yi mi 'dug[”] ces lan btab/ [“]red ya/ kho tsho tshang ma ma gzhi nas ya rabs sha stag red/ de shes sam/ ca lag de tsho kho tshor ha cang mkho yod pa'i rkyen gyis/ kho tsho ma rabs kyi lam la mi 'gro thabs med byung ba red/ de nas mi 'gyangs par ngas gnas lugs shig mthong mgo brtsams byung la/ de ni/ dgos mkho zer ba 'di rnyog dra yod tshad kyi rgyu red/ 'on kyang / gnas lugs mgo mjug tshang ba zhig de dus da dung rtogs ma thub/ de nas nyin zhig la/ btson khang gis nga tshor sran ma skyur babs yod pa zhig sprad byung / mi gcig gis skad cor brgyab song mod/ de la kha ya byed mkhan gcig kyang ma byung / de nas khos skad 'gag pa'i bar du skad brgyab/ do dam mi sna nang du yong nas gcig bltas rjes kha ya tsam yang mi byed par phyin song / skabs der btson pa gzhan pa zhig gis kyang skad brgyab byung la/ de nas nga tsho tshang mas skad brgyab pa yin/ nga tsho tshang mas mgrin gcig dbyangs gcig gis skad brgyab pas/ btson khang hril po 'ur sgras 'gad grabs 'gad grabs byas/ dkon mchog mkhyen/ de nas don dag ya mtshan de byung ba red/ kho tsho mgyogs por nang du brgyugs yong nas/ nga tshor bza' rgyu gzhan pa sprad song / de ltar thad kar sprad pa red/ de ha go yi 'dug gam/[”]

“No,” said Tom. “Well, they was nice fellas, ya see. What made 'em bad was they needed stuff. An' I begin to see, then. It's need that makes all the trouble. I ain't got it worked out. Well, one day they give us some beans that was sour. One fella started yellin', an' nothin' happened. He yelled his head off. Trusty come along an' looked in an' went on. Then another fella yelled. Well, sir, then we all got yellin'. And we all got on the same tone, an' I tell ya, it jus' seemed like that tank bulged an' give and swelled up. By God! Then somepin happened! They come a-runnin', and they give us some other stuff to eat- give it to us. Ya see?”

Thom gyis [“]ha go yi mi 'dug[”] ces bshad/ kha se yis ma ne lag pa'i steng du khen nas [“]'di gcig byas na ngas khyod la gsal por bshad thub pa zhig yin rgyu ma red/ gcig byas na gnas lugs 'di khyod rang nyid kyis 'tshol dgos rgyu zhig yin rgyu red/ khyod kyi zhwa mo gang du yod/[”] ces bshad/ [“]ngas zhwa mo ma gon par yong ba yin/[”] [“]khyod kyi sring mo ga 'dra 'dug[”] [“]o/ kho mo da lta lto ba chen po ba lang lta bu zhig red/ ngas bltas na kho mor mtshe ma zhig btsa' rgyu yin pa 'dra/ grod khog gcig pu 'khor lo'i steng du 'drud dgos pa 'dra ba zhig 'dug kho mo phar 'gro tshur 'gro byed dus lag pas grod khog skyor nas 'gro dgos/ 'di gar don dag ci zhig 'byung bzhin pa khyod kyis da dung nga la bshad ma song a/[”]

“No,” said Tom. Casy put his chin down on his hands. “Maybe I can't tell you,” he said. “Maybe you got to find out. Where's your cap?” “I come without it.” “How's your sister?” “Hell, she's big as a cow. I bet she got twins. Gonna need wheels under her stomach. Got to holdin' it with her han's, now. You ain' tol' me what's goin' on.”

skyes pa gzugs skam des [“]nga tshos las mtshams bzhag pa yin la/ 'di ni las bcad ngo rgol zhig yin/[”] zhes bshad/ [“]red ya/ sgam rer sgor zur phyed ka byas na mang rgyu med mod/ 'on kyang / ma mtha' yang des bza' mi'i kha gso thub kyi 'dug[”]
The wizened man said, “We struck. This here's a strike.” “Well, fi' cents a box ain't much, but a fella can eat.”

skyes pa gzugs skam des [“]sgor zur phyed ka e/[”] zhes skad cor dang bcas [“]sgor zur phyed ka/ kho tshos khyod tshor sgor zur phyed ka re ster gyi 'dug gam/[”] zhes bshad/ [“]red/ nga tshos de ring sgor gcig dang sgor phyed len thub song /[”] ras gur nang yud tsam la 'jam cag ger gyur/ kha se yis sgo nang nas mtshan mo'i mun pa la bltas nas/ ches mjug mthar [“]ltos dang / Thom/ nga tsho 'di gar las ka byed du yong ba yin la/ kho tshos gla cha sgor zur phyed ka re yin zer/ de bas las ka las mkhan ha cang mang po slebs pa red/ nga tsho 'di gar slebs pa na/ kho tshos skar gnyis dang phyed ma gtogs sprod rgyu min zer/ gal srid mi zhig la bu phrug gcig gnyis re yod na/ gla cha des za ma bza' byed kyang mi 'dang / de bas nga tshos gla cha de dang len byed rgyu min lab pa yin/ de dus kho tshos nga tsho phyir phud pa red la/ mnga' sde hril po'i nyen rtog pa 'di gar 'dus yong ba red/ da lta kho tshos khyod tshor sgor zur phyed ka re sprod kyi yod mod/ 'on kyang / kho tshos las bcad ngo rgol 'di kha gtor tshar dus/ kho tshos khyod tshor mu mthud du sgor zur phyed ka re sprod rgyu red dam/[”] zhes bshad/

“Fi' cents?” the wizened man cried. “Fi' cents! They payin' you fi' cents?” “Sure. We made a buck an' a half.” A heavy silence fell in the tent. Casy stared out the entrance, into the dark night. “Lookie, Tom,” he said at last. “We come to work there. They says it's gonna be fi' cents. They was a hell of a lot of us. We got there an' they says they're payin' two an' a half cents. A fella can't even eat on that, an' if he got kids- So we says we won't take it. So they druv us off. An' all the cops in the worl' come down on us. Now they're payin' you five. When they bust this here strike- ya think they'll pay five?”

Thom gyis [“]de ngas mi shes/ gang ltar deng sang sgor zur phyed re sprod kyi 'dug[”] ces bshad/ kha se yis [“]ltos dang / nga tsho mthun sgril mnyam 'brel byed skabs/ kho tshos nga tsho phag pa bzhin du yar bda' mar bda' byas nas/ nga tsho yongs su kha thor du btang byung la/ 'ga' rer rdung rdeg tshabs chen btang ba red/ dngos gnas phag pa bzhin du bdas byung la/ kho tshos khyod tsho yang phag pa bzhin du nang du khrid pa red/ 'on kyang / nga tshos 'di ltar yun ring la rgyun mthud byed dka' mo red/ nga tsho'i nang nas mi 'ga' res nyin gnyis gsum la za ma zos med/ khyod rang do nub sgar nang du phyir 'gro rgyu yin nam/[”] zhes bshad/

“I dunno,” Tom said. “Payin' five now.” “Lookie,” said Casy. “We tried to camp together, an' they druv us like pigs. Scattered us. Beat the hell outa fellas. Druv us like pigs. They run you in like pigs, too. We can't las' much longer. Some people ain't et for two days. You goin' back tonight?”

Thom gyis [“]'gro 'char yod/[”] ces bshad/ [“]ya/ des na sgar nang gi mi rnams la gnas tshul ngo ma ci yin ngo sprod byed rogs/ khyod tshos nga tsho mu ger gtod bzhin pa dang chabs cig tu/ rang mgo rang gis rdung bzhin yod ces zer rogs/ rgyu mtshan ci yin zer na/ kho tshos nga tsho gtsang sel byas pa'i skad cig de nyid du/ gla cha de ba lang gi skyag pa bzhin du skar ma gnyis dang phyed du mar lhung gi red/[”]

“Aim to,” said Tom. “Well- tell the folks in there how it is, Tom. Tell 'em they're starvin' us an' stabbin' theirself in the back. 'Cause sure as cowflops she'll drop to two an' a half jus' as soon as they clear us out.”

Thom gyis [“]ya/ de ngas kho tshor bshad/ 'on kyang / ji ltar shod dgos pa da dung mi shes/ lag tu me mda' bzung ba'i mi 'di 'dra mang po sngon chad mthong myong med/ kho tshos mi phan tshun la skad cha tsam yang shod du mi 'jug pa'i tshad red/ nang gi mi rnams la'ang kha brda byas nas 'dug pa'i dus tshod cig gang na yod/ tshang mas mgo bo sgur nas/ tha na phan tshun la 'tshams 'dri tsam yang byed khom med pa de 'dra red/[”] ces bshad/ [“]kho tshor gnas tshul ci yin bshad thabs byos/ nga tsho 'di dang kha bral ma thag tu khyod tsho'i gla cha skar ma gnyis dang phyed kar phyir lhung gi red/ sgam re la skar ma gnyis dang phyed ka zer na ga 'dra yin pa e shes/ de ni kham bu tun gcig gi 'thog gla dang skyel gla tshang ma brtsis na sgor mo gcig ma gtogs med/[”] khos mgo bo dud nas yud tsam la bsdad [“]des ci yang byed mi thub/ de tsam gyis khyod la za ma nyo mi thub la/ de tsam gyis khyod kyis za ma bza' mi thub/[”]

“I'll tell 'em,” said Tom. “I don' know how. Never seen so many guys with guns. Don' know if they'll even let a fella talk. An' folks don' pass no time of day. They jus' hang down their heads an' won't even give a fella a howdy.” “Try an' tell 'em, Tom. They'll get two an' a half, jus' the minute we're gone. You know what two an' a half is- that's one ton of peaches picked an' carried for a dollar.” He dropped his head. “No-you can't do it. You can't get your food for that. Can't eat for that.”

[“]ngas yul mi tshor go brda sprod thabs byed/[”] [“]khyod kyi a ma ga 'dra 'dug[”] [“]kho mo bde mo red/ kho mo gzhung btsugs gzhis sgar der ha cang dga'/ der khrus khang dang chu dron po 'dug[”] [“]red ya/ de ngas go byung /[”] [“]der dngos gnas skyid po 'dug 'on kyang / las ka rnyed kyi mi 'dug pas/ kha mi 'bral thabs med red/[”]

“I'll try to get to tell the folks.” “How's your ma?” “Purty good. She liked that gov'ment camp. Baths an' hot water.” “Yeah- I heard.” “It was pretty nice there. Couldn' find no work, though. Had a leave.”

kha se yis [“]nga yang de 'dra'i gcig la 'gro 'dod/ song nas gcig blta na 'dod/ mi tshos de gar nyen rtog pa mi 'dug zer/[”] zhes bshad/ [“]mang tshogs rnams rang nyid kyi nyen rtog pa red/[”] kha se yis mtshar snang dang bcas mgo bo yar bkyags [“]'o na de gar 'khrug 'dzing dang rkun po/ ra bzi sogs kyi gnad don 'byung gi mi 'dug gam/[”]
“I'd like to go to one,” said Casy. “Like to see it. Fella says they ain't no cops.” “Folks is their own cops.” Casy looked up excitedly. “An' was they any trouble? Fightin', stealin', drinkin'?”

Thom gyis [“]'byung gi mi 'dug[”] ces bshad/ [“]'on kyang / gal srid mi zhig gi ngan spyod tshad las brgal song na/ de nas ci bya/ kho tshos der thag gcod ji ltar byed/[”] [“]kho sgar las phyir phud gtong gi yod/[”] [“]'on kyang / phyir phud gtong dgos rgyu mang po yod rgyu ma red/ e red/[”]
“No,” said Tom. “Well, if a fella went bad- what then? What'd they do?” “Put 'im outa the camp.” “But they wasn' many?”

Thom gyis [“]mang po ga la yod/ nga tsho de gar zla ba gcig gi ring la bsdad pa yin la/ de lta bu'i gnad don thengs gcig ma gtogs ma byung /[”] zhes bshad/ kha se yi mig la dga' tshor gyi snang ba shar zhing / kho skyes pa gzhan pa tshor 'khor nas [“]go song ngam/ ngas kyang khyod tshor/ nyen rtog pa tshos rnyog dra slong rogs byed pa las sel rogs byed kyi med ces bshad pa ma yin nam/ ya/ Thom/ sgar nang gi mi tshor phyi logs su shog lab rogs/ da lta kham bu yongs su smin zin pas/ kho tshos kyang nyin gnyis gsum ring la ma gtogs ngo rgol byed dgos rgyu ma red lab rogs/[”] zhes bshad/

“Hell, no,” said Tom. “We was there a month, an' on'y one.” Casy's eyes shone with excitement. He turned to the other men. “Ya see?” he cried. “I tol' you. Cops cause more trouble than they stop. Look, Tom. Try an' get the folks in there to come on out. They can do it in a couple days. Them peaches is ripe. Tell 'em.”

Thom gyis [“]kho tsho yong gi ma red/ kho tshos da lta sgor zur phyed ka re len gyi yod pas/ kho tshos gzhan pa ci zhig la'ang kha ya byed kyi ma red/[”] [“]'on kyang / las bcad ngo rgol 'di mtshams bzhag ma thag tu/ kho tshos sgor zur phyed ka sprod kyi ma red a/[”] [“]kho tshos de 'dra'i bsam blo gtong shes kyi ma red/ kho tshor da lta sgor zur phyed ka re sprod kyi yod la/ kho tshos de ma gtogs gzhan pa ci la yang kha ya byed kyi ma red/[”] [“]de yang red/ 'on kyang / gang ltar kho tshor de ltar shod dang /[”]

“They won't,” said Tom. “They're a-gettin' five, an' they don' give a damn about nothin' else.” “But jus' the minute they ain't strikebreakin' they won't get no five.” “I don' think they'll swalla that. Five they're a-gettin'. Tha's all they care about.” “Well, tell 'em anyways.”

Thom gyis [“]a phas de 'dra byed kyi ma red/ de ngas tshor thub/ khos de kho dang 'brel ba med zer gyi red/[”] ces bshad/ kha se yis blo pham dang bcas [“]red ya/ dngos gnas de 'dra zhig yin pa 'dra/ gyong kha zhig ma 'khur bar du bsam blo gtong mi shes/[”] zhes bshad/ Thom gyis [“]nye sngon nga tsho'i za ma rdzogs grabs yod mod/ 'on kyang / do nub nga tsho'i kha la sha zhig bza' rgyu rag pa red/ mang po med mod/ bza' rgyu rag song / a phas mi gzhan pa'i kha phor gyi don du rang nyid kyi kha nang gi sha rdog de blos gtong thub rgyu red dam/ de nas da dung ro si sha ron la 'o ma dgos kyi yod pa red/ mi mang pos sgo chen gyi phyi logs nas skad 'bod byed bzhin pa tsam gyis/ a mas ro si sha ron gyi khog gi phru gu de mu ges 'chi ru 'jug rgyu red dam/[”] zhes bshad/

“Pa wouldn' do it,” Tom said. “I know 'im. He'd say it wasn't none of his business.” “Yes,” Casy said disconsolately. “I guess that's right. Have to take a beatin' fore he'll know.” “We was outa food,” Tom said. “Tonight we had meat. Not much, but we had it. Think Pa's gonna give up his meat on account a other fellas? An' Rosasharn oughta get milk. Think Ma's gonna wanta starve that baby jus' 'cause a bunch a fellas is yellin' outside a gate?”

kha se yis skyo snang dang bcas [“]dngos gnas kho tshos gnas lugs 'di mthong thub na ang 'dod/ kho tshos rang nyid kyi kha nang gi sha rdog de mi shor ba'i thabs shes ngo ma de ci zhig yin pa'i gnas lugs de mthong thub na ang / a ltas ngan/ mtshams la lar thang chad kyi 'dug dkon mchog mkhyen/ dngos gnas thang chad kyi 'dug ngas mi zhig ngo shes kyi yod/ nga btson khang du yod skabs shig la kho yang btson du bzung yong / khos ngal rtsol pa'i skyid sdug tshogs pa zhig 'dzugs grabs byed bzhin yod 'dug la/ tshogs pa gcig btsugs zin yod 'dug de nas gsang myul pa tshos kho bzung ba red/ kho ji ltar bzung ba shes sam/ khos rogs ram byed sa'i yul mi de tshos kho g.yo 'tshong byas pa red/ don dag de ma gzhi kho la 'brel ba rtsa ba nas med/ mi de tshos rang nyid kho dang 'brel ba 'dug zer bar skrag pa red/ de bas kho tshos/ [‘]khyod phar song / khyod rang nga tsho la mtshon na nyen kha zhig red/[’] ces bshad pa red/ des kho rang sems pa ha cang sdug tu bcug pa red/ 'on kyang / de nas khos/ [‘]bsam blo zhib mor btang na/ nga'i steng du yong ba ni de 'dra'i sdug po ma red/[’] ces bshad cing / de nas khos/ [‘]h+pha ran si'i gsar brje'i skabs su'ang / go rtogs sad yod pa tsho'i mgo bo bcad pa red/ 'gro stangs 'di ni chos nyid lta bur grub yod/ 'di ni gnam nas char pa 'bab pa ltar/ chos nyid lta bur grub yod/ 'di lta bu'i mgo 'dzugs mkhan tshos de ltar mi byed thabs med yin pas/ de ltar byas pa red la/ 'di lta bu'i bya gzhag dang du len rgyu de kho tsho'i rang gshis su grub yod pas/ kho tshos de ltar byas pa red/ dper na/ wa shin Ton la ltos dang /[’] zhes bshad cing / de nas khos mu mthud du/ [‘]khos gsar brje'i rgyal kha blangs rjes/ khyi phrug de tsho kha phyir 'khor nas kho mur ba red/ de bzhin lin khon yang gcig mtshungs red/ kho gsod dgos zer nas skad 'bod rgyag mkhan de tsho yang rigs gcig red/ de ni/ gnam nas char pa 'bab pa ltar/ chos nyid lta bur grub yod/[’] ces zer gyi 'dug[”] ces bshad/

Casy said sadly, “I wisht they could see it. I wisht they could see the on'y way they can depen' on their meat- Oh, the hell! Get tar'd sometimes. God-awful tar'd. I knowed a fella. Brang 'im in while I was in the jail house. Been tryin' to start a union. Got one started. An' then them vigilantes bust it up. An' know what? Them very folks he been tryin' to help tossed him out. Wouldn' have nothin' to do with 'im. Scared they'd get saw in his comp'ny. Say, 'Git out. You're a danger on us.' Well, sir, it hurt his feelin's purty bad. But then he says, 'It ain't so bad if you know.' He says, 'French Revolution- all them fellas that figgered her out got their heads chopped off. Always that way,' he says. 'Jus' as natural as rain. You didn' do it for fun no way. Doin' it 'cause you have to. 'Cause it's you. Look a Washington,' he says. 'Fit the Revolution, an' after, them sons-a-bitches turned on him. An' Lincoln the same. Same folks yellin' to kill 'em. Natural as rain.'”

Thom gyis [“]dngos gnas sems pa sdug byed 'dra zhig red a/[”] zhes bshad/ [“]red/ dngos gnas de 'dra zhig red/ de nas btson khang nang gi mi des/ [‘]gang ltar/ khyod kyis gang thub thub cig byed dgos pa red/ de nas/ khyod kyis ches gsal por mthong thub dgos pa ni/ nga tshos mdun skyod kyi gom pa chung chung re spo thengs rer/ phyi nur chung chung re byed srid mod/ 'on kyang / gom pa cha tshang zhig phyi nur byed bzhin med/ de khyod kyis ra sprod byed thub/[’]ces bshad cing / khos mu mthud du/ [‘]des ni nga tshos ci bsgrubs tshang mar grub 'bras yod pa mtshon la/ nga tshos ci byas tshang ma 'phro brlag yin pa lta bur snang mod/ don du de 'dra min pa ra sprod byas yod/[’] ces zer/[”]

“Don't soun' like no fun,” said Tom. “No, it don't. This fella in jail, he says, 'Anyways, you do what you can. An',' he says, 'the on'y thing you got to look at is that ever' time they's a little step fo'ward, she may slip back a little, but she never slips clear back. You can prove that,' he says, 'an' that makes the whole thing right. An' that means they wasn't no waste even if it seemed like they was.'”

Thom gyis [“]skad cha tsam red/ nam rgyun skad cha tsam red/ dper na/ nga'i gcung po al la mtshon na/ kho nam rgyun phyi logs su song nas bu mo 'tshol gyi yod la/ de min gzhan pa gang gi don du'ang kha ya byed kyi med/ khos nyi ma gnyis gsum nang la bu mor gsar pa re 'tshol gyi yod cing / nyin dkar la nam rgyun de'i don du bsam blo 'khor yod la/ mtshan mor nam rgyun de'i don la rgyug gi yod/ khos gom pa mdun rgyab dang g.yas g.yon gang la nur bzhin par kha ya spu tsam yang byed kyi ma red/[”] ces bshad/

“Talkin',” said Tom. “Always talkin'. Take my brother Al. He's out lookin' for a girl. He don't care 'bout nothin' else. Couple days he'll get him a girl. Think about it all day an' do it all night. He don't give a damn 'bout steps up or down or sideways.”

kha se yis [“]de red/ de bden pa red/ khos rang nyid kyis ci zhig byed 'dod pa de byed kyi yod pa red/ nga tsho tshang ma gcig mtshungs red/[”] ces bshad/ gur sgo ru yod pa'i mi des sgo phyar yangs por phyes nas [“]ltas ngan/ gnas tshul yag po yod sa ma red/[”] ces bshad/
“Sure,” said Casy. “Sure. He's jus' doin' what he's got to do. All of us like that.” The man seated outside pulled the tent flap wide. “Goddamn it, I don' like it,” he said.

kha se yis yar bltas [“]gnas tshul ci zhig red/[”] [“]ngas kyang mi shes/ nga la za 'phrug lta bu zhig lang gi 'dug sems pa 'tshab nas byi la lta bu zhig red/[”] [“]shod dang / gnas tshul ci red/[”] [“]ngas kyang mi shes/ ngas sgra zhig go song ba 'dra mod/ 'on kyang / zhib tu nyan pa na grag 'gul ci yang mi 'dug[”] skyes pa gzugs chung skam rid des [“]khyod rang 'tshab drags pa red/[”] ces bshad rjes/ kho yar langs nas phyi logs su song / cung tsam rjes nas khos gur nang du mgo bo bsrings/ [“]sprin nag chen po zhig 'khrigs yong gi 'dug 'brug grag pa yin rgyu red la/ des khor skrag bslangs pa yin rgyu red/ kho la glog 'khyug pa yin rgyu red/[”] de nas khos mgo bo phyir 'then/ thang la bsdad yod pa'i skyes pa gzhan pa de gnyis kyang yar langs nas phyi logs su bud song /

Casy looked out at him. “What's the matter?” “I don' know. I jus' itch all over. Nervous as a cat.” “Well, what's the matter?” “I don' know. Seems like I hear somepin, an' then I listen an' they ain't nothin' to hear.” “You're jus' jumpy,” the wizened man said. He got up and went outside. And in a second he looked into the tent. “They's a great big ol' black cloud a-sailin' over. Bet she's got thunder. That's what's itchin' him- 'lectricity.” He ducked out again. The other two men stood up from the ground and went outside.

kha se yis skad mgo dma' mos [“]kho tsho tshang mar za 'phrug lang gi yod pa red/ nyen rtog pa tshos las 'gul 'dir zhugs mkhan tshang ma sha nyog rus nyog tu brdungs nas/ rdzong 'di nas mtha' skrod gtong gi yin lab kyi yod / ngas skad cha bshad rgyu mang bas/ kho tshos nga las 'gul 'di'i 'go khrid red bsam gyi yod sa red/[”] ces bshad/ skyes pa skam rid des mgo bo yang bskyar nang du bsrings [“]kha se/ sgron me bsad nas phyi logs su shog dang / 'di gar gcig yod sa red/[”]

Casy said softly, “All of 'em's itchy. Them cops been sayin' how they're gonna beat the hell outa us an' run us outa the county. They figger I'm a leader 'cause I talk so much.” The wizened face looked in again. “Casy, turn out that lantern an' come outside. They's somepin.”

kha se yis sgron me'i gcus yu de gcus pas/ me lce de sdong ras ngos su mar nur nas phob sgra zhig dang bcas nag thom mer song / kha se mun pa'i khrod nas lag nyul gyis sgor bud cing / Thom gyis kho'i rjes ded/ kha se yis [“]ci zhig red/[”] ces dris/ [“]ngas kyang mi shes/ 'on kyang / nyon dang /[”]
Casy turned the screw. The flame drew down into the slots and popped and went out. Casy groped outside and Tom followed him. “What is it?” Casy asked softly. “I dunno. Listen!”

lhing 'jags dang 'dres pa'i sbal ba'i 'tsher skad kyis kho tsho'i mtha' nas bskor yod cing / de dang chabs cig tu/ mtho zhing 'tsher ba'i 'bu cha ga pa 'ga' res kyang skad cor sgrog 'on kyang / 'ur zing 'di dag gi rgyab ljongs 'og tu sgra gzhan pa re yang yong gi 'dug la/ de ni lam thog nas grag yong ba'i gsal la mi gsal ba'i rdog sgra dang / yur bu'i rags ngos su dbyug pa 'drud pa'i hrob sgra/ da dung rgyug chu'i smad rgyud nas yar grag yong ba'i rtsi shing gi shag sgra sogs red/

There was a wall of frog sounds that merged with silence. A high, shrill whistle of crickets. But through this background came other sounds- faint footsteps from the road, a crunch of clods up on the bank, a little swish of brush down the stream.

kha se yis [“]gcig grag gi yod med dngos gnas bshad dka' mo 'dra red/ mtshams la lar go nor thebs rgyu'ang yod/ sems pa 'tshab 'tshub yin dus sgra ci zhig yin rung go yong ba de 'dra yin/[”] zhes kho tsho'i sems pa lhod la 'bebs thabs byas nas [“]nga tsho tshang ma sngangs 'tshab skyes yod/ grag 'gul ci zhig yod pa tshor gyi mi 'dug Thom/ khyod kyis ci zhig go yi 'dug gam/[”] zhes bshad/ Thom gyis [“]ngas kyang go yi 'dug red/ ngas go yi 'dug ngas bltas na kho tshos mtha' bskor nas yong bzhin pa 'dra/ nga tsho da lta song na dga' rgyu red/[”] ces bshad/ skyes pa skam rid des [“]zam 'og tu 'gro/ 'di phyogs su 'gro dgos/ rang nyid kyi gur dang dngos gnas 'bral 'dod mi 'dug[”] ces bshad/

“Can't really tell if you hear it. Fools you. Get nervous,” Casy reassured them. “We're all nervous. Can't really tell. You hear it, Tom?” “I hear it,” said Tom. “Yeah, I hear it. I think they's guys comin' from ever' which way. We better get outa here.” The wizened man whispered, “Under the bridge span- out that way. Hate to leave my tent.”

kha se yis [“]des na 'gro/[”] zhes bshad/ kho tsho rgyug chu de'i 'gram ngogs brgyud nas khu sim pos song / zam 'og ni brag phug cig dang 'dra bar kho tsho'i mdun du nag thom mer 'dug kha se yis mgo bo sgur nas zam 'og tu 'dzul nas song zhing / Thom gyis kho'i rjes ded nas yong / kho tshos rkang pa chu nang du spos nas song / kho tshos chu brgal nas mdun phyogs su dbyin khre sum cu tsam song ba na/ kho tsho'i hal sgra de gzhu dbyibs lta bu'i zam pa'i gnam mthil ngos nas brag ca ltar phyir mched yong / de nas kho tsho zam pa'i sne gcig nas phyi la bud nas/ lus po drang mor phyir dgye/ de nas skad gdangs drag po zhig gis [“]kho tsho de na 'dug[”] ces skad brgyab byung la/ lag khyer glog bzhu gnyis kho tsho'i steng du 'phros nas/ kho tsho'i mig gis ci yang mi mthong bar byas/ [“]de gar ma 'gul bar sdod cig[”] mun nag nang nas mi skad grag yong [“]kho red/ ltas ngan skam rid 'di red/ de kho red/[”]

“Le's go,” said Casy. They moved quietly along the edge of the stream. The black span was a cave before them. Casy bent over and moved through. Tom behind. Their feet slipped into the water. Thirty feet they moved, and their breathing echoed from the curved ceiling. Then they came out on the other side and straightened up. A sharp call, “There they are!” Two flashlight beams fell on the men, caught them, blinded them. “Stand where you are.” The voices came out of the darkness. “That's him. That shiny bastard. That's him.”

kha se yis mig zim zim gyis glog bzhu'i phyogs su bltas nas/ dbugs hal hal du len bzhin [“]nyon dang / khyod tshos rang nyid kyis ci zhig sgrub bzhin pa shes kyi med/ khyod tshos nyes med phru gu mang po mu ges gsod rogs byed bzhin yod/[”] ces bshad/ [“]khyi phrug khyod/ khyi kha tshums shig[”] sha rgyags la gzugs po thung ba'i skyes pa zhig glog bzhu'i 'od kyi nang du tshur yong / kho'i lag tu 'jor yu dkar po gsar pa zhig bzung 'dug

Casy stared blindly at the light. He breathed heavily. “Listen,” he said. “You fellas don' know what you're doin'. You're helpin' to starve kids.” “Shut up, you red son-of-a-bitch.” A short heavy man stepped into the light. He carried a new white pick handle.

kha se yis mu mthud du [“]khyod tshos rang nyid kyis ci zhig sgrub kyin pa shes kyi mi 'dug[”] ces bshad/ mi rgyags pa des lag gi dbyug pa de gcig g.yugs pa na/ kha se yis mgo sgur nas g.yol thabs byas/ 'on kyang / dbyug pa ljid mo de kho'i mgo'i 'gram ngos su 'khel nas/ rus rdib kyi phob sgra zhig grag byung la/ de dang mthud nas kha se glog bzhu'i 'od snang khrod nas 'gram du 'gyel/ [“]dkon mchog ye shu/ jor je/ khyod kyis kho bsad song a/[”] jor je yis [“]glog bzhu kho'i steng du khor dang / ltas ngan 'dis sdug gyong rang gis nyos pa red/[”] ces bshad nas/ glog bzhu'i 'od thig sa ngos su phab nas 'tshol bsher byas/ de nas 'od thig de kha se yi 'gas gtor byung ba'i mgo thog tu 'khel/

Casy went on, “You don' know what you're a-doin'.” The heavy man swung with the pick handle. Casy dodged down into the swing. The heavy club crashed into the side of his head with a dull crunch of bone, and Casy fell sideways out of the light. “Jesus, George. I think you killed him.” “Put the light on him,” said George. “Serve the son-of-a-bitch right.” The flashlight beam dropped, searched and found Casy's crushed head.

Thom gyis chos dpon la bltas/ glog bzhu'i 'od thig de mi rgyags pa de'i rkang pa dang 'jor yu dkar po gsar pa de'i thog tu 'khel/ Thom khu sim pos 'jab nas song ste/ glo bur du kho'i lag gi dbyug pa de tshur phrogs nas shugs kyis gzhus pa na/ gzhu thengs dang po de kho'i mgo la ma phog par phrag par 'khel/ drag shugs che ba'i gzhu thengs gnyis pa de kho'i mgo la 'khel byung la/ mi rgyags pa de mar 'gyel bzhin pa'i skabs su Thom gyis kho'i mgo la mu mthud du thengs gsum gzhus/ skabs der glog bzhu'i 'od thig mang pos zhabs bro lta bu 'khrab byung la/ 'bod sgra dang rdog sgra sna tshogs rtsi shing brgyud nas hrag hrag gis slebs/ Thom gyis thang la 'gyel yod pa'i phung po'i steng du mar sgur nas bltas nas yod pa'i skabs su/ kho'i mgo la'ang dbyug pa bang sgra grag pa zhig 'khel byung la/ des kho'i gzugs por glog brgyugs pa lta bu'i tshor ba byin/ de nas kho rgyug chu'i 'gram ngos brgyud nas sgur sgur gyis bros shing / kho'i ra mda' tshos rdog sgra thag thag gis kho'i rjes su bdas/ kho glo bur du 'gram ngos kyi rtsi ldum gyi nang nas yar 'gos shing / tshang tshing du 'khrigs pa'i dug ldan 'gyig lo'i gseng du 'dzul nas/ de gar ma 'gul bar yud tsam la bsdad/

Tom looked down at the preacher. The light crossed the heavy man's legs and the white new pick handle. Tom leaped silently. He wrenched the club free. The first time he knew he had missed and struck a shoulder, but the second time his crushing blow found the head, and as the heavy man sank down, three more blows found his head. The lights danced about. There were shouts, the sound of running feet, crashing through brush. Tom stood over the prostrate man. And then a club reached his head, a glancing blow. He felt the stroke like an electric shock. And then he was running along the stream, bending low. He heard the splash of footsteps following him. Suddenly he turned and squirmed up into the brush, deep into a poison-oak thicket. And he lay still.

de nas gom sgra khag je nyer gyur cing / gsham gyi rgyug chu'i ngos su glog 'od 'phros nas yong bas/ kho rtsi ldum khrod nas yar steng phyogs su nur nas/ shing 'bras ra ba zhig gi nang nas yar bud/ rgyug chu'i 'gram du khos da dung yang kho'i rjes ded nas yong mkhan tsho'i 'bod sgra dang gom sgra thos thub/ kho mar sgur sgur byas nas rmos zin pa'i zhing kha brgyud nas song ba na/ spo tho rnams kho'i rkang 'og nas 'gril zhing shud/ khos phar phyogs kyi zhing tshigs rtsi ldum mthong byung / rtsi ldum de zhing chu'i yur bu'i 'gram brgyud nas skyes yod/

The footsteps came near, the light beams glanced along the stream bottom. Tom wriggled up through the thicket to the top. He emerged in an orchard. And still he could hear the calls, the pursuit in the stream bottom. He bent low and ran over the cultivated earth; the clods slipped and rolled under his feet. Ahead he saw the bushes that bounded the field, bushes along the edges of an irrigation ditch.

kho ra ba'i gseng nas dal mos 'dzul nas/ rgun 'brum 'khri shing dang sil nag sdong po'i gseng nas g.yas gzur g.yon gzur byed bzhin song / de nas kho 'gro mtshams bzhag nas dbugs sob sob tu blangs/ khos rang nyid kyi sbrid nas yod pa'i gdong pa dang sna la reg kho'i sna rus bcag 'dug la/ khrag thigs gar po zhig ma ne'i ngos su mar 'dzags kyi 'dug kho kha sbub tu log nas bsdad de/ sems pa lhod la 'bab tu bcug cing / de nas dal mos yur bu'i sne zur nas yar 'gos/ khos rgyug chu'i nang du gdong pa bshal zhing / nang stod sngon po de'i sne mo gshags nas chu nang du sbangs rjes/ rang nyid kyi mkhur mgo dang sna steng du glan/ chu des kho'i gdong la sbrang mdung gis gtsags pa lta bu'i na zug bskyed/

He slipped through the fence, edged in among vines and blackberry bushes. And then he lay still, panting hoarsely. He felt his numb face and nose. The nose was crushed, and a trickle of blood dripped from his chin. He lay still on his stomach until his mind came back. And then he crawled slowly over the edge of the ditch. He bathed his face in the cool water, tore off the tail of his blue shirt and dipped it and held it against his torn cheek and nose. The water stung and burned.
sprin pa nag po de nam mkha'i mthongs su slebs pas/ skar tshogs bkra ba'i mkha' dbyings su yol ba nag po zhig 'then/ da lta mtshan mo 'di yang bskyar khu sim mer gyur/
The black cloud had crossed the sky, a blob of dark against the stars. The night was quiet again.

Tom stepped into the water and felt the bottom drop from under his feet. He threshed the two strokes across the ditch and pulled himself heavily up the other bank. His clothes clung to him. He moved and made a slopping noise; his shoes squished. Then he sat down, took off his shoes and emptied them. He wrung the bottoms of his trousers, took off his coat and squeezed the water from it. Along the highway he saw the dancing beams of the flashlights, searching the ditches. Tom put on his shoes and moved cautiously across the stubble field. The squishing noise no longer came from his shoes. He went by instinct toward the other side of the stubble field, and at last he came to the road. Very cautiously he approached the square of houses. Once a guard, thinking he heard a noise, called, “Who's there?”

Tom dropped and froze to the ground, and the flashlight beam passed over him. He crept silently to the door of the Joad house. The door squalled on its hinges. And Ma's voice, calm and steady and wide awake: “What's that?” “Me, Tom.” “Well, you better get some sleep. Al ain't in yet.” “He must a foun' a girl.” “Go on to sleep,” she said softly. “Over under the window.”

Tom did not sleep. The nerves of his wounded face came back to life and throbbed, and his cheek bone ached, and his broken nose bulged and pulsed with pain that seemed to toss him about, to shake him. He watched the little square window, saw the stars slide down over it and drop from sight. At intervals he heard the footsteps of the watchmen.

The dawn came finally. In the houses, packed together, there was a sound of movement, a crash of breaking sticks, a little clatter of pans. In the graying gloom Ma sat up suddenly. Tom could see her face, swollen with sleep. She looked at the window, for a long moment. And then she threw the blanket off and found her dress. Still sitting down, she put it over her head and held her arms up and let the dress slide down to her waist. She stood up and pulled the dress down around her ankles. Then in bare feet, she stepped carefully to the window and looked out, and while she stared at the growing light, her quick fingers unbraided her hair and smoothed the strands and braided them up again. Then she clasped her hands in front of her and stood motionless for a moment. Her face was lighted sharply by the window. She turned, stepped carefully among the mattresses, and found the lantern. The shade screeched up, and she lighted the wick.

Pa struggled into his overalls and put on his rusty coat. He went sluggishly out the door, yawning and stretching. The children awakened and watched from under their blanket, like mice. Pale light filled the room now, but colorless light, before the sun. Ma glanced at the mattresses. Uncle John was awake. Al slept heavily. Her eyes moved to Tom. For a moment she peered at him, and then she moved quickly to him. His face was puffed and blue, and the blood was dried black on his lips and chin. The edges of the torn cheek were gathered and tight.

Tom heard the choked, smothered cries. He bit his lower lip and studied the floor. And then he went to Pa's bed. Under the edge of the mattress the rifle lay, a lever-action Winchester .38, long and heavy. Tom picked it up and dropped the lever to see that a cartridge was in the chamber. He tested the hammer on half-cock. And then he went back to his mattress. He laid the rifle on the floor beside him, stock up and barrel pointing down. Rose of Sharon's voice thinned to a whimper. Tom lay down again and covered himself, covered his bruised cheek with the blanket and made a little tunnel to breathe through. He sighed, “Jesus, oh, Jesus!”

Lines of people moving across the fields. Fingerwise. Inquisitive fingers snick in and out and find the bolls. Hardly have to look. Bet I could pick cotton if I was blind. Got a feelin' for a cotton boll. Pick clean, clean as a whistle. Sack's full now. Take her to the scales. Argue. Scale man says you got rocks to make weight. How 'bout him? His scales is fixed. Sometimes he's right, you got rocks in the sack. Sometimes you're right, the scales is crooked. Sometimes both; rocks an' crooked scales. Always argue, always fight. Keeps your head up. An' his head up. What's a few rocks? Jus' one, maybe. Quarter pound? Always argue. Back with the empty sack. Got our own book. Mark in the weight. Got to. If they know you're markin', then they don't cheat. But God he'p ya if ya don' keep your own weight.

The cars move to the cotton fields. The cotton camps set up. The screened high trucks and trailers are piled high with white fluff. Cotton clings to the fence wires, and cotton rolls in little balls along the road when the wind blows. And clean white cotton, going to the gin. And the big, lumpy bales standing, going to the compress. And cotton clinging to your clothes and stuck to your whiskers. Blow your nose, there's cotton in your nose.

Hunch along now, fill up the bag 'fore dark. Wise fingers seeking in the bolls. Hips hunching along, dragging the bag. Kids are tired now, in the evenin'. They trip over their feet in the cultivated earth. And the sun is going down. Wisht it would last. It ain't much money, God knows, but I wisht it would last. On the highway the old cars piling in, drawn by the handbills.

THE BOXCARS, TWELVE of them, stood end to end on a little flat beside the stream. There were two rows of six each, the wheels removed. Up to the big sliding doors slatted planks ran for cat-walks. They made good houses, water-tight and draftless, room for twenty-four families, one family in each end of each car. No windows, but the wide doors stood open. In some of the cars a canvas hung down in the center of the car, while in others only the position of the door made the boundary.

“It's nice,” she said. “It's almost nicer than anything we had 'cept the gov'ment camp.” Each night she unrolled the mattresses on the floor, and each morning rolled them up again. And every day they went into the fields and picked the cotton, and every night they had meat. On a Saturday they drove into Tulare, and they bought a tin stove and new overalls for Al and Pa and Winfield and Uncle John, and they bought a dress for Ma and gave Ma's best dress to Rose of Sharon.

“She's so big,” Ma said. “Jus' a waste of good money to get her a new dress now.” The Joads had been lucky. They got in early enough to have a place in the boxcars. Now the tents of the late-comers filled the little flat, and those who had the boxcars were old-timers, and in a way aristocrats. The narrow stream slipped by, out of the willows, and back into the willows again. From each car a hard-beaten path went down to the stream. Between the cars the clothes lines hung, and every day the lines were covered with drying clothes. In the evening they walked back from the fields, carrying their folded cotton bags under their arms. They went into the store which stood at the crossroads, and there were many pickers in the store, buying their supplies.

Ruthie came near, in her hands two large boxes of Cracker Jack, in her eyes a brooding question, which on a nod or a shake of Ma's head might become tragedy or joyous excitement. “Ma?” She held up the boxes, jerked them up and down to make them attractive. “Now you put them back-” The tragedy began to form in Ruthie's eyes. Pa said, “They're on'y a nickel apiece. Them little fellas worked good today.”

Ma called, “Come on. We got ever'thing.” She carried a bag. Uncle John and Pa each took a package. Outside Ruthie and Winfield were waiting, their eyes strained, their cheeks puffed and full of Cracker Jack. “Won't eat no supper, I bet,” Ma said. People streamed toward the boxcar camp. She waited five minutes and then she stood up and crept on up the trail beside the stream. She moved quietly, so quietly that she could hear the murmur of the water above her soft steps on the willow leaves. Trail and stream swung to the left and then to the right again until they neared the highway. In the gray starlight she could see the embankment and the black round hole of the culvert where she always left Tom's food. She moved forward cautiously, thrust her package into the hole, and took back the empty tin plate which was left there. She crept back among the willows, forced her way into a thicket, and sat down to wait.

rtsi ldum phung po'i khrod nas kho mos phar phyogs kyi sbug yur de gsal por mthong thub/ kho mo'i spar mo pus mo'i steng du bzhag nas khu sim por bsdad/ cung tsam rjes nas rtsi ldum phung po'i khrod du yang bskyar grag 'gul slebs/ zhing tsig cig lo ma'i steng nas gzab gzab kyis 'gro zhing / sre mong zhig gis dri ngan zhig 'khyer nas lam phran gyi steng du snang dogs ci yang med pa'i sgo nas dal 'gros kyis mar yong / de nas rlung bu zhig gis lcang sdong rnams kyi sra snyi tshod lta byed pa ltar ldem ldem du sgul byung bas/ gser mdog gi lo ma ser po rnams thang la lhung nas sa ngos su kha gdan bzhin du btings/ glo bur du drag rlung zhig g.yugs pas/ sdong po rnams shag shag tu sgul byung la/ lo ma rnams sag sag gis thang la zags/ a mas lo ma rnams kho mo'i mgo bo dang phrag pa ru lhung gi yod pa tshor/ skabs der/ nam mkha' ru sprin nag gor mo zhig yong nas/ dgung gi skar tshogs rnams mi mngon par byas/ de nas char thigs rdog po chen po re mar zags nas/ sa la lhung yod pa'i lo ma tsho'i steng du thag thag gis babs/ de rjes sprin pa de phar phyin song bas/ dgung gi skar tshogs rnams yang bskyar mthong snang du phyir mngon/ a ma ci yin 'di yin med par 'dar sig cig brgyab/ da lta rlung bu'i rgyu ba chad zin pas/ rtsi ldum stug po 'di yang bskyar khu sim mer gyur/ 'on kyang / gsham gyi chu phran smad rgyud du sdong po rnams smad nas smad du 'gul gyin 'gul gyin song / rgyab phyogs kyi zhag sgar gyi phyogs nas/ og glan rol cha dkrol ba'i sgra dbyangs gsal la mi gsal ba zhig dus nas dus su grag yong /

Through the tangle she could see the black hole of the culvert. She clasped her knees and sat silently. In a few moments the thicket crept to life again. The field mice moved cautiously over the leaves. A skunk padded heavily and unself-consciously down the trail, carrying a faint effluvium with him. And then a wind stirred the willows delicately, as though it tested them, and a shower of golden leaves coasted down to the ground. Suddenly a gust boiled in and racked the trees, and a cricking downpour of leaves fell. Ma could feel them on her hair and on her shoulders. Over the sky a plump black cloud moved, erasing the stars. The fat drops of rain scattered down, splashing loudly on the fallen leaves, and the cloud moved on and unveiled the stars again. Ma shivered. The wind blew past and left the thicket quiet, but the rushing of the trees went on down the stream. From back at the camp came the thin penetrating tone of a violin feeling about for a tune.

a mas kho mo'i g.yon phyogs kyi lo ma'i khrod nas grag yong ba'i gsang stabs kyi gom sgra zhig thos pas/ kho mo'i sems pa 'tshab 'tshub tu gyur/ kho mos spar mo pus mo'i steng nas blangs nas/ ci yin mi shes pa'i sgra der gsal por nyan ched du mgo bo drang mor dgye/ phar phyogs kyi 'gul skyod de yud tsam la med par gyur song la/ dus yun gang 'tshams song rjes yang bskyar 'gul skyod byed mgo brtsams/ sil sdong gi yal ga zhig lo ma skam po'i steng du thag se lhung / a mas grib gzugs nag po zhig rig sar mngon yong ba mthong zhing / grib gzugs de dal mor sbug yur gyi phyogs su song / sbug yur gyi i khung nag po de yud tsam la mig lam nas bsgribs byung la/ de nas grib gzugs nag po de sbug yur dang bral nas song / a mas skad ngag 'jam pos [“]Thom/[”] zhes bos pa na/ grib gzugs nag po des 'gro mtshams bzhag nas khu sim por mar bsdad byung la/ grib gzugs de ni de 'dra'i khu sim dang de 'dra'i dma' mo yin pas/ phal cher shing rdum zhig e yin nam snyam pa zhig red/ a mas yang bskyar [“]Thom/ a rog Thom/[”] zhes bos pas/ grib gzugs de da gzod 'gul byung /

Ma heard a stealthy step among the leaves far to her left, and she grew tense. She released her knees and straightened her head the better to hear. The movement stopped, and after a long moment began again. A vine rasped harshly on the dry leaves. Ma saw a dark figure creep into the open and draw near to the culvert. The black round hole was obscured for a moment, and then the figure moved back. She called softly, “Tom!” The figure stood still, so still, so low to the ground that it might have been a stump. She called again, “Tom, oh, Tom!” Then the figure moved.

[“]a ma/ khyod yin nam/[”] [“]'di na yod/[”] kho mo yar langs nas kho'i rtsar song / Thom gyis [“]khyod 'di ltar yong mi rung /[”] zhes bshad/ [“]nga khyod dang nges par du thug dgos kyi 'dug Thom/ ngas khyod la bshad rgyu zhig yod/[”] Thom gyis [“]'di lam phran gyi thag nye yin pas/ phar 'gro tshur 'ong byed mkhan yod srid/[”] ces bshad/ [“]khyod la sdod sa 'dra yod dam/ Thom/[”] [“]yod/ 'on kyang / gal srid/ un/ gal srid gcig gis khyod rang nga dang lhan du yod pa mthong na/ de nas khyim tshang gang po dka' las la 'phrad rgyu red/[”] [“]Thom/ nga mi yong thabs med red/ Thom/[”] [“]des na nga'i rjes su shog khu sim po byos/[”]

“That you, Ma?” “Right over here.” She stood up and went to meet him. “You shouldn' of came,” he said. “I got to see you, Tom. I got to talk to you.” “It's near the trail,” he said. “Somebody might come by.” “Ain't you got a place, Tom?” “Yeah- but if- well, s'pose somebody seen you with me- whole fambly'd be in a jam.” “I got to, Tom.” “Then come along. Come quiet.”

khos lham tsam yang ma phud par phar phyogs kyi chu phran de 'dzem med kyis brgal/ a mas kho'i rjes 'brangs/ kho rtsi ldum brgyud nas song ste/ phyogs gzhan pa nas phyir bud nas sa zhing zhig gi steng du slebs shing / de nas sa zhing gi rmos mtshams brgyud nas mu mthud du song / nag por 'gyur bzhin pa'i sring bal sdong po'i gzhung rta rnams sa ngos su sra mor zug nas yod cing / bal sob 'ga' re da dung sring sdong steng du lus 'dug kho gnyis kas zhing 'gram brgyud nas le dbar bzhi cha gcig tsam song zhing / de nas rtsi ldum gyi khrod du phyir 'dzul/ Thom ri skyes sil nag sdong po skyes yod sa'i sa phung po chen po zhig gi nye sar bcar zhing / de nas mar sgur nas sil sdong gi yol ba 'gram du ded rjes [“]nang du gog nas 'gro dgos/[”] zhes bshad/

He crossed the little stream, wading carelessly through the water, and Ma followed him. He moved through the brush, out into a field on the other side of the thicket, and along the plowed ground. The blackening stems of the cotton were harsh against the ground, and a few fluffs of cotton clung to the stems. A quarter of a mile they went along the edge of the field, and then he turned into the brush again. He approached a great mound of wild blackberry bushes, leaned over and pulled a mat of vines aside. “You got to crawl in,” he said.

a ma sgur sgur byas nas lag pa dang pus mo sa la btsugs nas nang du gog nas song / skabs der kho mos rang nyid bye ma'i steng du nur bzhin pa tshor thub/ de nas kho mo'i gzugs po sa khung gi nang ngos su mi thug la/ de dang chabs cig tu/ kho mo'i lag pa thang du btings yod pa'i Thom gyi mal gdan ngos su 'khel/ khos sil sdong gi yol ba de rang sor phyir bkab pas/ sa phug nang yongs su mun nag tu gyur/

Ma went down on her hands and knees. She felt sand under her, and then the black inside of the mound no longer touched her, and she felt Tom's blanket on the ground. He arranged the vines in place again. It was lightless in the cave.

[“]a ma/ khyod gang du yod/[”] [“]nga 'di na yod/ Thom/ skad mgo dma' mo byos/[”] [“]sems khral byed mi dgos/ nga 'di gar ri bong bzhin du bskungs nas yud tsam phyin song /[”] kho mos khos krin sder gyi kha thum phye bzhin pa thos/ kho mos [“]phag sha'i rtsib ma dang zhog khog red/[”] ces bshad/ [“]dkon mchog gzi brjid can po/ da dung yang tsha po red/[”]

“Where are you, Ma?” “Here. Right here. Talk soft, Tom.” “Don't worry. I been livin' like a rabbit some time.” She heard him unwrap his tin plate. “Pork chops,” she said. “And fry potatoes.” “God Awmighty, an' still warm.”
mun nag nang nas a mas kho gsal po mi mthong na'ang / khos phag sha dum bu dum bur btogs nas/ so yis bldad nas mid par mid bzhin pa'i sgra thos nus/
Ma could not see him at all in the blackness, but she could hear him chewing, tearing at the meat and swallowing.

Thom gyis [“]'di sbas skung byed sa cung yag po zhig red/[”] ces bshad/ a mas cung dogs mi bde ba'i sgo nas [“]Thom/ ru the yis gzhan la khyod kyi skor bshad 'dug[”] ces bshad/ skabs der kho mos khos sha rdog kham gang khyur mid btang ba'i sgra thos/ [“]ru the e/ ci'i phyir yin nam/[”] [“]un/ 'di yang kho mor ngan khag 'gel rgyu med/ kho mo phru gu gzhan pa zhig dang 'khrug 'dzing shor nas/ kho mos rang nyid kyi gcen pos bu mo gzhan pa de'i gcen po gsod rgyu yin skor bshad pa yin sa red/ byis pa tsho'i 'khrug 'dzing byed stangs de khyod kyis kyang los shes/ de nas kho mos rang nyid kyi gcen pos mi zhig bsad nas/ da lta sbas skung byas yod ces bshad 'dug[”]

“It's a pretty good hide-out,” he said. Ma said uneasily, “Tom- Ruthie tol' about you.” She heard him gulp. “Ruthie? What for?” “Well, it wasn' her fault. Got in a fight, an' says her brother'll lick that other girl's brother. You know how they do. An' she tol' that her brother killed a man an' was hidin'.”

Thom gad mo bgad/ [“]nga yod dus ngas nam rgyun a khu jon la kho tshor lta rtog byos lab mod/ khos de 'dra la kha ya rtsa ba nas mi byed/ gtam de byis pa'i skad cha red/ a ma/ der skyon yod pa ma red/[”]
Tom was chuckling. “With me I was always gonna get Uncle John after 'em, but he never would do it. That's jus' kid talk, Ma. That's awright.”

a mas [“]de 'dra ma red/ byis pa tshos skad cha de 'dra yar mar la bshad kyi red la/ rim bzhin kho tsho'i bza' mis kyang go yi red/ kho tsho'i bza' mis mtha' 'khor gyi mi rnams la bshad kyi red la/ de ltar mi 'gyangs par skad cha 'di khyod rang 'tshol mkhan gyi rna bar slebs nas/ kho tshos kyang ci yin nam bsam nas blta ru yong gi red/ Thom/ khyod thag ring la song na dga' rgyu red/[”] ces bshad/

“No, it ain't,” Ma said. “Them kids'll tell it aroun' an' then the folks'll hear, an' they'll tell aroun', an' pretty soon, well, they liable to get men out to look, jus' in case. Tom, you got to go away.”

[“]'di ngas thog dang po nas lab pa yin a/ nyin gcig la khyod kyis nga la za ma 'jog bzhin pa mi gzhan gyis mthong gi red bsam nas ngas nam rgyun sems khral byed kyi yod la/ gal srid gzhan gyis dngos su mthong ba yin na/ de nas kho tshos lta rtog byed kyi red/[”]
“That's what I said right along. I was always scared somebody'd see you put stuff in that culvert, an' then they'd watch.”

[“]de ngas shes/ 'on kyang / de ni ngas khyod thag nye ru 'dzin 'dod pas yin la/ khyod la ci zhig 'byung 'ong bsam nas nga rang zhed pas yin/ ngas nyi ma 'di dag la khyod rang ma mthong ba red la/ da lta yang mthong gi mi 'dug khyod kyi gdong pa ga 'dra 'dug[”] [“]mgyogs por drag bzhin 'dug[”]
“I know. But I wanted you near. I was scared for you. I ain't seen you. Can't see you now. How's your face?” “Gettin' well quick.”

[“]tshur nye sar shog dang / Thom/ ngas gcig reg dgos/ nye sar shog[”] kho thag nye ru gog nas song / mun nag gi khrod du/ kho mos lag snyob byas nas kho'i mgo bo rnyed byung la/ de nas kho mo'i mdzub mo mar song nas kho'i sna gdong dang mkhur mgo la reg [“]Thom/ khyod kyi gdong par rma shul ngan pa bsdad 'dug a/ khyod kyi sna yang 'khyog 'dug[”]

“Come clost, Tom. Let me feel it. Come clost.” He crawled near. Her reaching hand found his head in the blackness and her fingers moved down to his nose, and then over his left cheek. “You got a bad scar, Tom. An' your nose is all crooked.”

[“]gcig byas na de mi bzang rgyu yod rgyu ma red/ de nas gcig byas na su gcig gis kyang nga ngos mi zin shas che/ gal srid nga'i mdzub ris kho tshor med rgyu na/ da nga la kha las brgyugs song ba red/[”] khos mu mthud du dgong zas zos/
“Maybe that's a good thing. Nobody wouldn't know me, maybe. If my prints wasn't on record, I'd be glad.” He went back to his eating.
kho mos [“]kha rog rna nyan byos dang /[”] zhes bshad/
“Hush,” she said. “Listen!”
[“]de rlung bu red ya/ a ma/ rlung bu red/[”] drag rlung de chu phran gyi smad rgyud du g.yug nas 'gro bzhin yod cing / drag rlung slebs pa dang chabs cig tu/ sdong po khag sig sig tu g.yo/
“It's the wind, Ma. Jus' the wind.” The gust poured down the stream, and the trees rustled under its passing.

a ma kho'i skad sgra'i thag nye ru bcar [“]Thom/ ngas khyod la yang bskyar gcig reg dang / 'dir mun pa ha cang nag pas/ nga rang long bar gyur pa lta bu zhig red/ ngas khyod kyi gdong dbyibs yid la 'dzin 'dod la/ lag pas myong rgyu ma gtogs mig gis mthong rgyu med rung / nges par du yid la 'dzin dgos/ Thom/ khyod 'di dang bral nas thag ring zhig la song /[”] [“]ya/ ngas thog dang po nas bzung de 'dra bsam yod/[”]

She crawled close to his voice. “I wanta touch ya again, Tom. It's like I'm blin', it's so dark. I wanta remember, even if it's on'y my fingers that remember. You got to go away, Tom.” “Yeah! I knowed it from the start.”

kho mos [“]nga tshos yong 'bab yag po len thub kyi 'dug ngas sgor mo cung tsam zur gsog byas yod/ khyod kyi lag pa tshur srings dang / Thom/ 'dir sgor mo bdun yod/[”] ces bshad/ Thom gyis [“]ngas khyod kyi lag nas sgor ma rtsa ba nas len rgyu min/ nga la gnad don ci yang yod pa ma red/[”] ces bshad/ [“]lag pa tshur srings shig Thom/ gal srid khyod kyi lag tu sgor mo cung tsam med na/ nga dgong mo nyal yang gnyid khug rgyu ma red/ khyod phal cher spyi spyod rlangs 'khor dang / yang na de 'dra'i steng du bsdad nas 'gro dgos rgyu red/ khyod rang thag ga tshod ring na de tshod la song / le dbar sum brgya bzhi brgya'i sa la song /[”] [“]'di ngas 'khyer rgyu min/[”]

“We made purty good,” she said. “I been squirrelin' money away. Hol' out your han', Tom. I got seven dollars here.” “I ain't gonna take ya money,” he said. “I'll get 'long all right.” “Hol' out ya han', Tom. I ain't gonna sleep none if you got no money. Maybe you got to take a bus, or somepin. I want you should go a long ways off, three-four hunderd miles.” “I ain't gonna take it.”

kho mos ngam nag pos [“]Thom/ sgor mo 'di khyer/ khyod kyis go song ngam/ khyod la nga rang sdug la sbyor rgyu'i thob thang yod pa ma red/[”] ces bshad/ Thom gyis [“]'di ltar byas na drang mo ma red a/[”] zhes bshad/ [“]ngas bltas na khyod rang grong khyer chen po zhig la song na bzang rgyu red 'dod/ dper na/ lo si an je le zi grong khyer lta bu/ gnas de 'dra ru khyod rang 'tshol mkhan yod rgyu ma red/[”]

“Tom,” she said sternly. “You take this money. You hear me? You got no right to cause me pain.” “You ain't playin' fair,” he said. “I thought maybe you could go to a big city. Los Angeles, maybe. They wouldn' never look for you there.”

Thom gyis [“]hum/ a ma/ nyon a/ kha sang de ring nga nyin mtshan gnyis kar kher rkyang gis bskungs nas bsdad pa red/ nyin 'di dag ring la ngas ci zhig gi thad la bsam blo gtong gi yod pa shes sam/ kha se'i skor la bsam blo gtong gi yod/ kho skad cha bshad rgyur dga'/ nga mtshams la lar skad cha de 'drar sun snang skyes myong mod/ 'on kyang / deng sang ngas khos bshad pa'i skad cha khag la bsam blo btang yong dus/ khos ci zhig bshad pa tshang ma phyir dran byed thub kyi 'dug thengs ma gcig la/ kho rang gcig pu mi med lung stong du rang nyid kyi rnam shes 'tshol du song ba yin zer la/ khos rang nyid gcig pu la dbang ba'i rnam shes shig ma rnyed par/ rnam shes chen po zhig gi cha shas shig rnyed song zer/ mi med lung stong du/ kho'i rnam shes dum bu de rnam shes kyi cha shas gzhan pa tsho dang lhan du med pas/ kho'i rnam shes de hril por gyur med cing / de'i rkyen gyis gcig pur lung stong 'khyams pa ni don med red zer/ dgod bro ba zhig la/ skabs der ngas kho'i skad char nyan 'jog tsam yang byas med 'dod yod mod/ 'on kyang / da lta ngas kho'i skad cha tshang ma gsal por dran la/ da lta ngas kyang mi ni kher rkyang du bsdad na snying po med pa shes kyi 'dug[”] ces bshad/

“Hm-m,” he said. “Lookie, Ma. I been all day an' all night hidin' alone. Guess who I been thinkin' about? Casy! He talked a lot. Used ta bother me. But now I been thinkin' what he said, an' I can remember-all of it. Says one time he went out in the wilderness to find his own soul, an' he foun' he didn' have no soul that was his'n. Says he foun' he jus' got a little piece of a great big soul. Says a wilderness ain't no good, 'cause his little piece of a soul wasn't no good 'less it was with the rest, an' was whole. Funny how I remember. Didn' think I was even listenin'. But I know now a fella ain't no good alone.”

a mas [“]kho ni dngos gnas mi bzang po zhig yin/[”] zhes bshad/ Thom gyis mu mthud du [“]khos nam rgyun gsung rab nang nas lung 'dren byas nas skad cha bshad kyi yod mod/ 'on kyang / de'i nang don thad nas bltas na/ de 'dra'i gsung rab rtsa chen zhig e yin snyam pa zhig yin/ khos lung de thengs gnyis la drangs song la/ de ni [“]chos dpon/[”] zhes bya ba'i gsung rab las lung drangs pa yin zer/[”] zhes bshad/
“He was a good man,” Ma said. Tom went on, “He spouted out some Scripture once, an' it didn' soun' like no hellfire Scripture. He tol' it twicet, an' I remember it. Says it's from the Preacher.”

[“]de las ci 'dra gsungs 'dug Thom/[”] [“]de las 'di 'dra gsungs 'dug [‘]mi gnyis ni mi gcig las mchog ste/ kho gnyis mnyam du yod tshe dge mtshan che bas so// de yang / mi gnyis mnyam du yod tshe/ gcig 'gyel dus gcig gis skyor na chog mod/ 'on kyang / mi zhig kher rkyang yin tshe/ kho 'gyel dus skyor mkhan med pas/ khos sdug bsdul myong rgyu las ma 'das so//[’] 'di lung de'i cha shas shig red/[”]

“How's it go, Tom?” “Goes, 'Two are better than one, because they have a good reward for their labor. For if they fall, the one will lif' up his fellow, but woe to him that is alone when he falleth, for he hath not another to help him up.' That's part of her.”

a mas [“]mu mthud nas 'don dang / mu mthud nas 'don dang / Thom/[”] zhes bshad/ [“]da dung cung dran gyi 'dug [‘]de bzhin/ mi gnyis lhan du nyal tshe/ kho gnyis kyis phan tshun la drod skyed thub mod/ 'on kyang / mi zhig kher rkyang yin tshe/ su zhig gis kho la drod skyed dam/ de nas/ mi gnyis lhan du yod tshe/ gal srid gcig gis kho gnyis las gcig la snyad brkos na/ kho gnyis ka mnyam du gdong la langs chog la/ thag pa sum rkya chad par dka' zhes pa'i dpe red/[’][”] [“]de yang gsung rab las gsungs pa red dam/[”]

“Go on,” Ma said. “Go on, Tom.” “Jus' a little bit more. 'Again, if two lie together, then they have heat: but how can one be warm alone? And if one prevail against him, two shall withstand him, and a three-fold cord is not quickly broken.'” “An' that's Scripture?”

[“]kha se yis red zer/ [“]chos dpon/[”] zhes bya ba'i gsung rab las gsungs yod zer/[”] [“]kha rog rna nyan byos dang /[”] [“]rlung bu red/ a ma/ nga 'di'i mtha' 'khor gyi rlung bu la cha rgyus yod/ a ma/ ngas bsam blo zhib mor btang na/ nam rgyun gyi chos dpon mang che bas nga tsho lta bu'i dbul phongs tsho'i skor 'chad pa'i skabs su/ khyod tshos thal mo sbyar nas sdod zer ba las gzhan pa ci la yang kha ya mi byed cing / de nas tshe phyi mar slebs tshe/ gser gyi gzhong ba'i nang nas dar zho longs su spyod chog rabs zer/ 'on kyang / [“]chos dpon/[”] zhes bya ba'i gsung rab 'di las/ ngan pa gnyis sdeb byas na/ bzang po gcig la do rabs zer/[”]

“Casy said it was. Called it the Preacher.” “Hush- listen.” “On'y the wind, Ma. I know the wind. An' I got to thinkin', Ma- most of the preachin' is about the poor we shall have always with us, an' if you got nothin', why, jus' fol' your hands an' to hell with it, you gonna git ice cream on gol' plates when you're dead. An' then this here Preacher says two get a better reward for their work.”

kho mos [“]Thom/ khyod kyis 'char gzhi ci zhig 'then bzhin pa yin/[”] zhes dris/ kho yun ring zhig la khu sim por bsdad/ [“]ngas nga tsho gzhung btsugs gzhis sgar de'i nang du yod skabs kyi 'tsho ba la bsam blo btang ba yin la/ nga tshos rang nyid ji ltar bdag skyong byas skor dang / gal srid 'khrug 'dzing byung rung / nang khul nas thag gcod ci 'dra byas skor bcas la bsam blo btang ba yin zhing / dpyi mgo ru dkrum mda' dpyangs nas 'gro mkhan gyi nyen rtog pa med rung / nga tsho'i nang gi sgrig khrims brtsi srung gi ngang tshul de ni rnam pa nyen rtog pa yod pa las kyang lhag pa'i skor la bsam blo btang ba yin/ de nas/ 'o na de dag tshang ma nga tsho rang nyid kyis ci'i phyir mi byed pa yin/ nga tsho rang nyid kyi yul mi ma yin pa'i nyen rtog pa tshang ma phyir phud btang nas/ nga tsho tshang ma mnyam rub kyis nga tsho rang nyid la dbang ba'i sa zhing nang du las ka byas na ci'i phyir mi chog gam bsam gyi yod/[”] a mas yang bskyar [“]Thom/ khyod kyis ci zhig byed 'dod pa yin/[”] zhes dris/

“Tom,” she said. “What you aimin' to do?” He was quiet for a long time. “I been thinkin' how it was in that gov'ment camp, how our folks took care a theirselves, an' if they was a fight they fixed it theirself; an' they wasn't no cops wagglin' their guns, but they was better order than them cops ever give. I been a-wonderin' why we can't do that all over. Throw out the cops that ain't our people. All work together for our own thing-all farm our own lan'.”

Thom gyis [“]kha se yis ci zhig byas pa de byed rgyu yin/[”] zhes bshad/ [“]'on kyang / kho tshos kho dmar gsod btang song a/[”] Thom gyis [“]de red/ kho dbyug pa las g.yol ba dal drags pa red/ khos khrims 'gal gyi bya ba gcig kyang sgrub kyi med ya/ a ma/ ngas bsam gzhig 'dra min sna tshogs byas pa yin/ nga tsho ngal rtsol mi dmangs kyis khyi phag lta bu'i 'tsho ba rol bzhin du/ sa bcud 'dzoms pa'i sa zhing de 'dra yag po mang po sa rgod du bskyur yod pa red/ phyug bdag 'ga' res sa zhing dbyin mu'u sa ya lhag re bdag bzung byas nas/ las la brtson pa'i ngal rtsol mi dmangs khri khri stong stong bkres ltogs la gtad yod pa red/ gal srid nga tsho tshang ma mnyam rub kyis ho pher zhing ra'i steng gi mi brgya phrag gnyis gsum tsam po'i byed stangs dang 'dra bar/ mnyam du skad 'bod byas na ga 'dra yin nam bsam gyi yod/[”]

“Tom,” Ma repeated, “what you gonna do?” “What Casy done,” he said. “But they killed him.” “Yeah,” said Tom. “He didn' duck quick enough. He wasn' doing nothin' against the law, Ma. I been thinkin' a hell of a lot, thinkin' about our people livin' like pigs, an' the good rich lan' layin' fallow, or maybe one fella with a million acres, while a hunderd thousan' good farmers is starvin'. An' I been wonderin' if all our folks got together an' yelled, like them fellas yelled, only a few of 'em at the Hooper ranch-”

a mas [“]kho tshos khyod rang mtha' skrod gtong gi red la/ 'dzin bzung byed rgyu yin zhing / mjug mthar/ kho tshos h+phi lo'e Di la ci zhig byas pa ltar/ khyod rang rim pa rim par shi min ro min zhig tu gtong gi red/[”] ces bshad/ [“]ngas de 'dra ma byas rung kho tshos nga mtha' skrod gtong gi red/ kho tshos nga tsho'i yul mi tshang ma mtha' skrod gtong gi yod pa ma red dam/[”] [“]khyod kyis mi gsod rgyu'i 'char gzhi 'dra 'then gyi yod rgyu ma red/ e yod/[”] [“]gsod 'char med/ 'on kyang / nga rang gang ltar khrims 'gal nyes can zhig yin pa'i cha nas/ gang ltar bsad rung [...] / ltas ngan/ gang ltar ngas de'i thad la bsam blo zhib mo btang med/ a ma/ nga'i don du sems khral ma byed/ khyod kyis nga'i don du sems khral ma byed a/[”]

Ma said, “Tom, they'll drive you, an' cut you down like they done to young Floyd.” “They gonna drive me anyways. They drivin' all our people.” “You don't aim to kill nobody, Tom?” “No. I been thinkin', long as I'm a outlaw anyways, maybe I could-Hell, I ain't thought it out clear, Ma. Don' worry me now. Don' worry me.”

kho tsho nag po sol mdog lta bu'i mun nag khrod du yud tsam la khu sim mer bsdad/ de nas a mas [“]'o na/ ngas khyod kyi gnas tshul ji ltar shes thub/ kho tshos khyod bsad yod rung ngas gnas tshul shes rgyu ma red/ kho tshos khyod la gnod 'tshe gtong nges yin zhing / de lta bu'i skabs su ngas gnas tshul ji ltar shes/[”] zhes bshad/ Thom btsan tshugs kyis gad mo zhig bgad [“]un/ kha se yis bshad pa ltar/ mi zhig la mtshon na/ kho la rnam shes rang bdag pa zhig med par/ kho'i rnam shes de ni rnam shes chen po zhig gi cha shas yin zhing / de bas […][”] [“]de bas ci red/ Thom/[”]

They sat silent in the coal-black cave of vines. Ma said, “How'm I gonna know 'bout you? They might kill ya an' I wouldn' know. They might hurt ya. How'm I gonna know?” Tom laughed uneasily, “Well, maybe like Casy says, a fella ain't got a soul of his own, but on'y a piece of a big one- an' then-” “Then what, Tom?”

[“]de bas khyad par chen po yod pa ma red/ de nas/ mun pa nag sa ru nga'i grib ma yod la/ khyod kyis gang du bltas na/ nga rang de gar 'grengs yod/ bkres ltogs myong bzhin pa'i yul mi tsho'i ched du gang zhig tu 'thab rtsod byed bzhin yod na/ nga rang de gar yod la/ gang zhig tu nyen rtog pas nyes med cig gcar rdung byed bzhin yod na/ nga rang de gar yod/ kha se yis kyang gnas tshul 'di shes bzhin yod na ang 'dod/ mi rnams khong khro langs nas ngar skad 'don dus/ nga rang kho tsho dang mnyam du yod la/ grod khog ltogs pa'i phru gu tshos dgong zas gra sgrig yin pa shes nas gdong la 'dzum chung len dus/ nga rang kho tsho dang mnyam du yod cing / nga tsho'i yul mi tsho rang nyid kyis phug pa'i khang pa'i nang du bsdad nas/ rang nyid kyis bskyangs pa'i zas rigs bza' dus/ nga yang de gar yod/ da shes song ngam/ a dkon mchog ngas kyang kha se'i skad cha lta bu bshad kyi 'dug a/ 'di ni rgyun par kho rang dran drags pa'i rkyen gyis yin rgyu red/ mtshams la lar ngas kho rang dngos su mthong ba lta bu'i snang ba shar/[”] a mas [“]ngas ha go yi mi 'dug ngas dngos gnas mi shes/[”] zhes bshad/

“Then it don' matter. Then I'll be all aroun' in the dark. I'll be ever'where- wherever you look. Wherever they's a fight so hungry people can eat, I'll be there. Wherever they's a cop beatin' up a guy, I'll be there. If Casy knowed, why, I'll be in the way guys yell when they're mad an'- I'll be in the way kids laugh when they're hungry an' they know supper's ready. An' when our folks eat the stuff they raise an' live in the houses they build- why, I'll be there. See? God, I'm talkin' like Casy. Comes of thinkin' about him so much. Seems like I can see him sometimes.” “I don' un'erstan',” Ma said. “I don' really know.”

Thom gyis [“]gsal po zhig ngas kyang mi shes/ 'di dag ni ngas rgyun du bsam blo gtong bzhin pa'i don dag yin/ 'dug sa gcig nas bsdad yod dus/ sems la bsam rgyu 'char rgyu lhag tu mang / da khyod phyir 'gro dgos rgyu red/ a ma/[”] zhes bshad/ [“]des na sgor mo 'di khyod kyis longs/[”] kho yud tsam la 'jam cag ger bsdad cing / de nas [“]des na ya/[”] zhes bshad/ [“]un/ Thom/ gnad don tshang ma 'das song dus/ khyod phyir 'khor nas nga tsho 'tshol du yong rgyu red/ e red/[”]

“Me neither,” said Tom. “It's jus' stuff I been thinkin' about. Get thinkin' a lot when you ain't movin' aroun'. You got to get back, Ma.” “You take the money then.” He was silent for a moment. “Awright,” he said. “An', Tom, later- when it's blowed over, you'll come back. You'll find us?”

Thom gyis [“]los yong / da khyod song na bzang rgyu red/ lag pa tshur srings/[”] zhes bshad rjes/ khos kho mo 'dzul sgo'i phyogs su khrid/ kho mo'i mdzub mos kho'i mkhrig mar dam por 'thams/ khos sil sdong gi phung po phar ded nas/ kho mo phyi logs su khrid [“]zhing kha ded nas yar song na/ de nas g.ya' shing sdong po zhig yod sa der slebs/ de nas chu'i pha rol du rgol/ ya/ da bde mo/[”]

“Sure,” he said. “Now you better go. Here, gimme your han'.” He guided her toward the entrance. Her fingers clutched his wrist. He swept the vines aside and followed her out. “Go up to the field till you come to a sycamore on the edge, an' then cut acrost the stream. Good-by.”

kho mos [“]bde mo/[”] zhes bshad rjes phar mgyogs por song / kho mo'i mig kong rlon par gyur cing / mig zung la tsha gzer rgyag mod/ 'on kyang / kho mo ma ngus/ kho mos lo ma skam po'i steng du gom pa bag med kyis spo bzhin/ hrag sgra dang bcas rtsi ldum khrod nas song / kho mo 'gro bzhin pa'i skabs su/ snang ba rab rib kyi nam mkha' las char pa 'bab mgo brtsams shing / nyung zhing che ba'i char rdog khag lo ma skam po tsho'i steng du thag sgra dang bcas babs/ a ma char chus brlan pa'i rtsi shing stug po'i khrod nas 'gro mtshams bzhag nas yud tsam la langs nas bsdad cing / de nas kho mo kha phyir 'khor nas sa phung phyogs su gom pa gsum tsam spos/ de nas glo bur du phyir 'khor nas/ 'khor sgam khang pa'i sgar gyi phyogs su song / kho mo thad kar sbug yur yod sa der song zhing / de nas gzhung lam steng du yar 'gos/ da lta char pa chad zin la/ gnam ngo 'thibs nas 'dug gzhung lam steng nas/ kho mos rgyab phyogs nas grag yong ba'i gom sgra zhig thos byung la/ kho mos sems 'tshab dang bcas kha phyir 'khor/ lag khyer glog bzhu zhig gi 'od snang mog mog cig gzhung lam ngos su khra lem lem gyis 'phro bzhin yong / a ma kha mdun du phyir 'khor nas khang pa'i phyogs su song / yud tsam rjes su/ skyes pa zhig gis kho mo'i rjes zin zhing / khos gus zhabs dang bcas glog bzhu'i 'od snang thang la phab nas/ kho mo'i gdong par ma bkar/

“Good-by,” she said, and she walked quickly away. Her eyes were wet and burning, but she did not cry. Her footsteps were loud and careless on the leaves as she went through the brush. And as she went, out of the dim sky the rain began to fall, big drops and few, splashing on the dry leaves heavily. Ma stopped and stood still in the dripping thicket. She turned about- took three steps back toward the mound of vines; and then she turned quickly and went back toward the boxcar camp. She went straight out to the culvert and climbed up on the road. The rain had passed now, but the sky was overcast. Behind her on the road she heard footsteps, and she turned nervously. The blinking of a dim flashlight played on the road. Ma turned back and started for home. In a moment a man caught up with her. Politely, he kept his light on the ground and did not play it in her face.
